text:
I have had far too many hung over mornings in this very establishment.  I remember, quite vividly, a painful morning the day of my 21st Birthday.  Though I could not even think about Uncle Bills for years after that painful morning, mostly spent in the bathroom, I have ventured back, because it's an institution, and the pancakes are quite simply delicious.

This place is odd, for sure.  The morning crowd tends to be a lot of families, on Sundays, a ton of people head here after church (so expect a pretty painful wait) but at night time, the place is filled with a rag tag bunch of characters, guaranteed to keep you interested while you pack down hash browns and cup after cup of not that great coffee.  

I know it's not necessarily that different than a Denny's, but Uncle Bills has more character to it.  It is the same place I have been eating since I was a baby and my parents let me gum pancakes to keep me from crying.  The décor really hasn't changed much, and I love that.  It's got charm...even if it's not so charming.

Uncle Bill's Pancake and Dinner House use to be a great place to go for breakfast or brunch.   Be prepared to stand in line for a short time, it moves quickly.  Sunday we decided it was brunch time and since it was my birthday I decided to go here.  Why did I want to go here?  I love their corned beef hash (I think it comes out of a can, but I love it).  

Uncle Bill, Uncle Bill, Uncle Bill. Why was it me that got the burnt corned beef hash?  Shame on Annie, our waitress, for serving that to me and shame on me for not sending it back.  If I sent it back, the rest of my food would have gotten cold plus an additional wait for it.  His omelet was good and there was no problem with it.  I have never been so disappointed in the food at Uncle Bill's. 

Would I come back here?  No, this place is off the breakfast list. There are too many places that serve brunch and breakfast.

Tried this for breakfast early on a Tuesday morning. Place was really quiet and staff was attentive and friendly. Fast service and good food!
Pancakes were good, coffee was good and biscuits and gravy were solid. Exactly what a 24 hour breakfast place should be like - nothing fancy but covered all the basics!
Sabrina did a wonderful job taking care of us.

A great place for great food, any time of day or night.  I'm usually here for brunch, and there's occasionally a ~10 minute wait.  There's several large dining rooms, with nice German-style decor inside.  Good service, good portions, and good prices, you can't go wrong.

This is a place you go after the bar, not so much a place for lunch. I have been to the one on Manchester, but never the original. When you walk in you can tell it's been there awhile, with the old style wood paneling and the smell of grease in the air. They took the order fairly quickly but we sat there from a good 40 min before we got our food. Eggs and pancakes are pretty easy to make, so I have no idea what took so long. The food was as good as what is expected when you go to a place like that. It met my expectations, just the wait was a bit long. 

I filled the craving of breakfast that I was having, so it served it's purpose.

Uncle Bill's is your standard greasy plate 24-hour breakfast place. They have your standard American breakfast plates with eggs, sausage, bacon, pancakes, etc. they also have some sweeter options for breakfast like the crepes and French toast.

I ordered the Uncle Bill skillet (for me) and the Pee-Chee crepes (to split with the table for breakfast dessert). The skillet is pretty good and very filling with a variety of veggies, ham, and cheese scrambled into the eggs. The crepes are decent but nothing to rave about.

I have to give Uncle Bill's 4 stars, based on nostalgia alone. 

I can't tell you how many nights me and my friends hit up Uncle Bill's after a night of late night partying at SLU. Oh, college...I miss you so. Now that I'm older (and wiser?), my partying days are far behind me, so there will be no Uncle Bill's trips in my future. However, I can still reminisce, right? 

I can tell you a few tips to make your Uncle Bill's trip a pleasant one:

1. NEVER come here sober. Just don't do it. Things that would normally bother sober!Stephanie (dirty carpets, smoky interior, sticky chairs) don't bother drunk!Stephanie. 

2. Order the pancakes, bacon, and hash browns. When you're hammered, nothing tastes better than buttermilk pancakes drowning in butter and syrup. NOTHING. 

I wish I could speak on the service and/or prices, but every time I've visited here, details like that seem like a blur. Really, the only proof that I ever visited Uncle Bills lies in the inevitable stomachache I have the next morning from all of the grease. 

And I kinda like it that way.

How can you stay away from Uncle Bill's Pancake House.  I can't and I'm glad to say I had a much better experience than the last time. We got there early on a Sunday but still had to wait in line. Luckily the line moves at a fairly good pace. 

Annie took care of us again this time. I ordered my usual. Eggs with corned beef hash. It comes with a side of hash brown potatoes and toast or biscuit. I was thrilled when my order came out and everything looked delicious. It also tasted delicious. 

Would I come back here?  Yes, I'll see you on the flip side.

The food isn't the best and Uncle Bill's looks like it hasn't changed in the last thirty years.  But I guess that's what gives it the charm. What I really like about this place is that it's open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week - generally a great go to if you're a college student and need some food or coffee at an awkward hour.  If you are unlucky enough to find yourself here during reading week or finals (and you're not a student), you'll probably not get the best experience.  If you're a student, you'll definitely see a handful of classmates, probably also studying for the same exam as you are.

 A group of us decided to stop by on a late evening.  We were seated quickly and the place looked fairly empty.  Our server was really sweet and took great care of us!  She recommended the veggie omelet.  When it came out, I was shocked by how huge it was. Plus, it was served with three buttermilk pancakes.  Geez! The omelet was okay.  Note to self for future: order it easy on the cheese. And the pancakes were delicious.  I definitely had enough food to take home for breakfast and lunch the next day.

Like Aimee mentioned, I would reserve my trips here for late night (or early early morning - depends on how you look at it) runs.

WOW!! Great pancakes and great service. This was our first visit but won't be our last! The bacon was thick and chewy and the link sausage was zippy and perfectly cooked. I can't wait to sample some other menu items--and since I keep odd hours, the 24/7 hours works for me!!

As Bette Davis said in Beyond The Forest, "What a dump." However, in the case of Uncle Bill's, it gives character. I can honestly tell you that UB has not been remodeled or redecorated since I moved to STL in 1979 and that is part of its charm and ambiance. To be honest, it had been at least 8 years since my last visit to UB's and when I walked in for my recent breakfast it was as if things had never changed. That was because they hadn't.

We were quickly seated, which surprised me since it was a Sunday and around 9:00AM. I guess everyone was either at church or sleeping in. The restaurant was still very full and the tables are cramped very close together. Keeping the closeness in mind, you may want to keep that in mind when picking your subject of conversation. The lady next to us was telling her friend about her son in prison. I had to bite my tongue, I so bad wanted to ask her if her son had a bitch or if he was one of the other inmates bitch. 

Our waitress was very attentive, made sure we quickly had our morning coffee. She also had a good sense of humor, she chuckled when I asked if there were any off the menu specials. Since they had no specials we went with the Country Fried Steak and the 2 Pork Chop Breakfast. Both came with two eggs and hash browns on the side. In addition to these hearty breakfasts, we shared an order of biscuits and gravy. 

The Country Fried Steak was very good, a nice big piece of tender beef breaded and covered in flavorful milk gravy. The pork chops were not as good, they were a thin cut and overly cooked making them dry and tough. I was hoping for a thick, juicy chop. Our eggs were  cooked over easy and done well, as were the hash browns. They're not your traditional hash browns, but are more an American Fries.

The star of the breakfast was the hearty serving of biscuits and gravy. We got two huge flaky biscuits covered in milk gravy filled with pieces of sausage. Next time I need a comfort breakfast, I may just come here and order Biscuits & Gravy with a side of hash browns.

I have never been here during the day and I wouldn't even think about doing that!  This is the best place to go after the bars close and you realize just how good pancakes would taste at 3 in the morning...and they do...

The service isn't great but at that time of day, and with as annoying as all the drunk people are, I'm not sure that I would be either.  But that's almost better for me in that state anyway.  Take my order, give me my food, and leave me alone to try to keep the room from spinning, please.  Always get the coffee.  It doesn't sober you up any quicker but does make you feel more awake.

And for future reference, Uncle Bill's is just as good at 5am as it is at 3am when you wake up from passing out on your friend's couch and realize that you're too hungry to wait for a proper hour for breakfast.

Uncle Bill, whoever you are, a heartfelt thank you from all of us who have capped off a wonderful evening with you!

How can you miss the mark on coffee and eggs? I ordered scramble eggs but, got fried. The coffee was...blah. No flavor at all. Of course, I had high expectations for the pancakes and UB certainly delivered! 

Their hours are very convenient 24/7.

Three of us ventured here on Saturday September 19, 2015 before the Angel Arm's Bar Bounce.  I ordered three pancakes, no butter, added powdered sugar and sugar free syrup- delicious!  I needed a kick of protein so I went w/ two poached eggs- I enjoyed my meal.  

The service was friendly but it took some time for the food to be delivered and one in our party never received his hashbrowns...  he wasn't upset and they took it off the bill at checkout.   

The gal running around refilling water was on it!  

The people watching is quite good, the line moved quickly, I would eat here again and most definitely order the pancakes.

How can you complain about a big ol' plate of breakfast grub and endless pots of coffee?  You can't!!!

Had a traditional breakfast platter consisting of eggs, meats, potatoes and (of course!) pancakes.  It was enough to feed a small army, and all tasted as you'd expect from a place known for their diner-style breakfasts.  I especially liked their thick-cut bacon and the pancakes were hearty and filling.

Two thumbs up, Uncle Bill!
I don't think its as gross as some of the reviewers make it out to be, it's your basic south side 24/7 diner that looks more like a resturaunt. For your basic breakfast, you can't go wrong.

Eeeew?  Once upon a time, Uncle Bill's was the only clean option for late night drunks who didn't want to go home.  Now, we have something called 3AM bars, a strew of late night eateries and well, Uncle Bill's sucks.

It's dated (not in a good way), scuzzy, and 1/2 of the food is on the walls & floor.  Last time I was tipsy enough to get talked into Uncle Bill's, we were seated at a filthy table.  When they came to wipe off our dirty table,  the waitress sprayed the table with cleanser while we were sitting there and it ended up tasting better than the food.

It was after midnight. I was playing chauffer and I wasn't very hungry. 

Uncle Bill's epitomizes pancake dive. The walls are dark. The floor is carpeted. It feels but doesn't smell smoky. It feels so - 60s? It attracted every age and manner of person on a Saturday evening. 

Breakfast food isn't really my thing, so I ordered ice cream to go with my hash browns. Prices are decent. Wish they offered baked potatoes all times of day. 

I have finally been to Uncle Bill's!

One of the Best Carne Asada Burritos I ever had. It was exploding with flavor. Love that they put a lot of Mexican cheese that melts in there with a lot of Guacamole and Sour Cream. Super Burrito is like a 2lbs. Burrito. Great customer service and great prices. Parking can get kind of tight during busy hours. Parking lot is for 10 cars. But there is also parking in the street. I would definitely come back. Love that they are open all day everyday.
Get the Asada quesadilla and you will have 3 lbs of cheese and meat and its heaven on earth! I love this place. Definitely not the best area of SB but worth it!

this super cucas location is pretty delicious but it also get pretty packed due to their lack of a parking lot (it is always packed and very difficult to get out of) as well as it being a little grocery store inside as well. They have delicious carne asada, super fresh and their assortment of salsas and sauces really spice the meat up. Their portions are also HUGE so if you get a large burrito, quesadilla or nachos do share that way you won't go home with a ton of leftovers.

This is an awesome, local burrito spot.  Lots of character and flavor to everything they have.
   If you love burritos, you will LOVE this spot.  I have been going here for 15 years at least.

I love this location; it's kind of the hidden gem in a town already filled with excellent Mexican food.

I'm all about the burritos here. I'd go for the Super Burrito: packed with rice, cheese, beans, sour cream, onions, and cilantro. For less than $10 bucks, it's a steal (not to mention two meals! If you can finish the burrito in one sitting, color me impressed).

Grab the green sauce bottle, sit outside, and enjoy your food and gorgeous weather.

Super Cuca's seems to appeal to the demographic that is 
1. drunk. 
2. poor. 
3. desirous of enormous portions.

I've eaten here once, at the request of a former resident of town during his college days. I guess our college days are past us, because I no longer fit into the above criteria and didn't find satisfaction in the food. My sensory experience does not recall any particular tastes, only the sight of an insanely large amount of food, and the unsettled fear in the parking lot that some kind of brawl was going to break out before we could move our car inconspicuously out of the way.

So if you are looking to invest your prime stomach real estate on layers of good flavor, I'm not recommending this place. But if you want to be full to the point of bursting, go for it!

Thank you yelp! On our way from Santa Cruz to San Diego we wanted something not to far from the freeway, with fast and good food. I searched my trusted yelp app and found Super Cuca's.  I had the "Diet burrito" that contains cheese, avocado, beans, rice, and lettuce.  It was huge and although i am not sure that it was diet, I had no problem eating it. 5 stars are well deserved here.  My determination is always based on the salsa.  It is always what can make or break my mexican food.  And the green salsa does not disappoint (unless you are scared of a little heat!)  I know where we are stopping on the way back home!

5/11/18 Daughter, Kaylah & I stopped by after dinner. We all got 2 Mint Oreo & Strawberry Cheesecake. It was very filling with size small. It was a busy evening as well. The weather was 84 degrees warm. Perfect for me!
Great service. Good food. Fresh & flavorful. I just wish I lived closer to try more of the menu. I'll be back if I'm ever close. I had the chicken parm. Very good. Homemade.

I've been wanting to try The BAO since it opened. They did a nice job on the remodel and the space is dimly lit, sparse, and kind of sexy. There was a single TV behind the bar and I think it was intentionally black & white. During my time there the movies on the screen were Little Shop of Horrors and Ferris Bueller's Day Off. These are two movies I could sit and watch in black & white with no sound forever. I met a friend for an early weekday dinner and neither of us were that hungry so we decided to share the Taiwanese Dumplings and the Soft Shell Crab Bao. The Taiwanese Dumplings are filled with chicken and vegetables and come with a soy scallion dipping sauce. They were very well cooked and had lots of nice crispy edges. My dinner date isn't an Asiaphile, as I am, and doesn't eat quite as many dumplings as I do. She thought they were the best she'd ever had and I thought they were just the best I had this week. The bao was actually a clever concept to make into an expensive designer sandwich. The bun has a slight sweetness and a good chew from being steamed and really holds up as a sandwich bun. The soft shell crab was good albeit slightly heavy on the breading. They do not include any kind of side dish with the bao. I felt they could at least put something a little colorful on the plate even as an afterthought but that was just my opinion. The cocktail menu was quite inventive and intricate but I'm not much of a drinker. All in all The BAO is clever and pretty well executed for a designer sandwich restaurant with an Asian twist in Clayton.

Great food, great service, great atmosphere. Came here for brunch after Sunday morning workout, and there was space. The St. Paul Bao  was heavenly. Light, with a delicious aoili, tender near and fluffy Bao. The coconut soup was spiced with pepper oil , fresh mushrooms thin cut, and an order of fries. The manager said the kitchen had an extra order of wings, and the table next to us, who happened to be really nice, shared them with us. The wings were crispy, the best type of crispy, airy, a medium weight breading, full of flavor and inside was tender chicken, not at all oily.

Came here on a recommendation from a friend and wow- so glad we came! You jump in line to order and then get seated. Our food came out a little later than expected and mine came out wrong.  My boyfriend had the chicken katsu rice bowl and it was fantastic. Mine eventually came out like 10 or 15 minutes after my boyfriends food and it was much bigger than expected. I got the chicken teriyaki bao and it was phenomenal. Definitely don't need a side with it- it's huge. The bao is perfectly fluffy and so so good. We had the dumpling appetizer and it was also really good- about 8 dumplings crusted into a pancake type thing. I really like the atmosphere here, really modern and hip. Will definitely be back!

Food- 9/10
Price- 7/10
Service- 5/10

I didnt eat any food. I didn't get a chance too. I went in 2p they didn't have any chicken said in a hour they would. I just called its now after 3p & they still don't have any chicken/fish also said they're not delivering today. Its mid afternoon when does this plan on getting their menu together?  This is why black businesses never last. It's ghetto. Decor looked a mess, outside looked a mess wth. I will give another shot just to see what the food actually taste like that is if they actually have it smh

I called to place a order via phone 2 nights ago they were out of sides. I only let that slide bc it was late but they need to do better

What can I say, its the same as any other Chipotle in the country (maybe with a longer line)... but we finally have one to call ours here in the New Orleans Area. Thank God, I never have to eat at Izzo's again.

I've been to this location a few times.  A few months ago, it was a total shit show; the traditional Chipotle flavors were slightly off, they'd run out of stuff constantly, and they were sloooooooow.  Fast forward to the present and this Chipotle is operating at par with other Chipotles around the country.  My steak tacos with corn tortillas were phenomenal with juicy steak cooked to a perfect medium rare topped with flavorful salsas.  A supremely filling and satisfying meal for $7 and some change; the same meal is over $12 at Felipes and Felipes gives you less food.  

This location has a nice outdoor seating area which is a definite plus.  Since it's one of only 2 locations in the metro area it does get pretty packed, but it's definitely one of only a couple places worth mentioning in Elmwood.

I ended up liking this place a lot more than I thought. I applaud a "quick service" /casual eatery to care about the quality of their food and they seem to put a lot of effort in making sure they are serving organic meats and veggies. It doesn't have a slew of options, but enough. I ordered the burrito in a bowl and everything tasted very fresh and flavorful. Large portions too, "This burrito is delicious, but it is filling"

The only Chipotle location in the New Orleans area and its just like the rest around the country. Like the others this location features excellent tex-mex that I prefer in the bowl rather than burrito. Unlike the others they don't nickel and dime you to death with ad-ons. Unfortunately its quite a ways from downtown New Orleans so I won't be eating here to often but when in the area there is probably no better option in Elmwood.

If I give 3 smackeroos to a fast food place, I'm impressed. My daughter has been after to me to check this place out. She ate at Chipotle's a lot during her college days in S.C. where fast food is so much "better" than in NOLA. See Five Guys. So we met for lunch on a 90 degree day on that lovely stretch of Clearview Pkwy that was so much more scenic when it was a cow pasture, ie, Elmwood, the Concrete Jungle. She walked me through the Felipeesque process of making my "bowl."  I was impressed by the fresh ingredients which is apparently the Chipotle food mission. You can make fast food that is healthy and tasty. And tasty it was. Not knock your socks off tasty, but tasty nonetheless. My "bowl" (which is a burrito with no tortilla) had something like brown rice (flavored with lime and cilantro), black beans, pulled pork, cheese and some sort of salsa. It was a pretty good and healthy dish and beats a double whopper with cheese on both the disgust and bloat factor. 

As for the decor, I can't say I'm a fan. They are trying not to look fast food so basically have designed an interior with stainless steel bar seating which is somewhat communal, very trendy. See Mariza. It is an improvement over the orange and yellow formica at most FF places, but, frankly, I thought the tables would have been perfect for a morgue, easy to clean etc. 

But regardless of the morbid decor, I will go back....and maybe get it to go.

PS I'm not checking off "Romantic" on the additional tips section.

It's always good to have another lunch option near work. Yeah, it's a chain, but it's still a step up from the McD's and Taco Bell across the street from Chipotle. 

Besides, I'll admit it, I did have quite the Chipotle love affair when I used to live in Indiana. It was a craving that had to be satisfied, since I hadn't eaten Chipotle in about 4 years. And yes, it was very satisfying. At least, the food was satisfying. Chicken burrito w/ fajita veggies, black beans, cheese, lettuce, and a little bit of each salsa. 

So big... so filling. It's a good thing that I built up quite the appetite in the 45 minutes that I waited in line. Oh, right, the wait. That would be the reason for 3 stars.

Yes, I get that they just opened. However, when Panera Bread opened a couple of months ago, they were just as overwhelmed. In fact, I think the lines were longer. The difference is, even with Panera's more diverse menu, the line moved quickly. There are some major kinks that need to be worked on at Chipotle, from the chefs to the order takers, and probably worst of all, the wrappers. That seemed to be the major hold up. I'm no burrito-wrapping expert, but I think they need some additional training.

Excellent fresh food at a great price.  You can look at the restaurant and see the low overhead.  I like the chicken burrito.  Better than izzo's, a lower cost, and less novelty.  Highly impressed by this well managed food/restaurant/takeout....

I like Chipotle... I'll admit it! 

I won't argue whether or not it's Mexican food. For reference it's firmly in the American fast food/hungover food category of my brain. I will, however, give a horay! for what it is, a massive burrito with tons of goodie. I usually round it off with some chips and medium salsa + 1 Izzy drink. Since this is a newer location (I guess it's almost 6 months now?), the burrito wrapping skills are still questionable and if you get a veggie burrito it is sometimes on the cold side, which leaves this location in the A-OK category. Also, it's in Harahan which is a bit of a hike for me. If I'm in the area I will always stop for some sweet burrito lovin. 

Also, if you are in super fat kid mode, there is a Pinkberry next door. Viva la chains of Elmwood.

Sadly, it wasn't as good as the Chipotle's I've had in Boston. 

First, they were out of tortillas.  How can you be out? Thats the main thing you sell! Then, the taste was overwhelmingly lime. Yes, I know the rice is lime, but once topped with pico, thats all you could taste. The chicken had some nasty pieces in it and I had a huge chunk of pork fat on my carnitas plate.  

Besides the fact that their menu is limited and they dont have margaritas, I'm going to vote Felipe's holds King of burrito joints.
Typical casual fast dining place in Nola. If you have a quick lunch order a head, cut the line, and eat while everyone waits in a long line :D

New Poke place that opened last September (2017) in University City. Conveniently located under the 3737 Chestnut apartment building, but I can honestly say I've only been there for their BOGO deal. I appreciate that you can add unlimited toppings to your bowl (which some Poke places don't let you do!) I personally think Poke is OK, but it's definitely a healthy option and they have cool edamame noodles you can opt for instead of rice. Their shrimp tempura wasn't that great, a little toooo crispy and not the crunch I was expecting, but their other ingredients are pretty fresh so no complaints. One thing a lot of people were wondering was whether Poke Man is owned by the same people as the previous Caffe Bene that was here for a year... there's also still Caffe Bene pillows and wall decorations so maybe they should take those down to make things a little more professional. Just a recommendation for the management :)

I love this place but they workers gave attitude. Especially when your telling them how to make your bowls. I go there so often and still have a problem every time i order. They make you feel you inconvenience them....
Very good italian food, large portions and wonderful service! Nice atmosphere, your usual italian restaurant feel.

Went here for lunch. Service staff were very pleasant although a little slow. That was probably because of the time of day and the number of guests eating at the venue. The food was good and the portions were large. We had a nice Caesar salad, fried calamari, and chicken with pasta. It is a good, family style Italian eatery.

The only concern I had was that all of the waiters walk through the restaurant with cheese graters, ready to douse your food with parmesan. That bit's good! What's a little less than good is that some of the waiters have their cheese graters attached to the back of their belts, which allows the industrial sizes graters, complete with blocks of cheese, to dangle behind them. I know what many people think about parmesan cheese, but its pungency shouldn't be embellished by being dangled where it can be farted at by the wait staff.

Move the appended parmesan to a location other than the 'bumnal' zone and four stars will be awarded without hesitation.

Went to Amerigo for the first time in several years last night. There was no wait, which was nice. Our waiter was friendly and efficient and the food was really good. I got the Chicken Margarite with the garlic butter sauce. It was so yummy and probably made with 14sticks of butter. The bread is better than Maggianos but still not as good as Macaroni Grille's.

We ended up at Amerigo due to a recommendation and because they were able to handle a last minute reservation for 20. We were at 2 separate tables and had 2 different experiences with service.  My table had amazing service. She was friendly and efficient.  The 2nd table seemed to have the person who should have taken the night off.  She even mentioned at one point that she was having a bad day.  Guess when a restaurant adds gratuity, you can choose to be horrible. 

Our waitress did a great job splitting the bill (providing us all with separate checks). The other table, the bills needed to be sent back because they were charged for something they didn't order.  She was very grabby as she took back the checks. 

When returning the bills our waitress brought us about 10 pens.  The other table got none. 

Food:  

Bruschetta:  very good.  Instead of chopped cold tomatoes, it was roasted cherry tomatos and olives.

Hot artichoke dip:  bluch

Calamari:  it was okay. Nothing special 

Cheese fritters:  very good

I had the eggplant parmigiana.  Horrible. Our waitress did offer to bring me something else or recook a new order. I told her I was fine, as I had filled up on appetizers. She was very apologetic.  The fettuccine that came with it was a bit gummy and the sauce was....well was like a store brand jarred sauce. 

Someone at the other table ordered veggie lasagna and got the meat lasagna.  One of the others said her food reminded her of lean cuisine.  

We did not have dessert. 

One of the people at the other table talked to the manager regarding the poor service and he did provide him with a rather generous gift card. 

Me, I would not return

I would have given a 2.5 rounded down to a 2 if it wasn't for the great service the table I was sitting at received and had the manager not done something, so I rounded up to a 3.

I just keep finding myself here over and over again... Amerigo is not crazy fancy, its more of a feel at home place. It is always a fun scene, busy bot not too loud. They have all Italian staple menu dishes you like to see there, at the same time they surprise you whit other fun stuff.
My favorite right now is the flatbread pizza with figs and balsamico reduction, feta cheese and ruccola. 
Service is always friendly and fast. Upon seating you are served really fresh, warm bread with fabulous Olive Oil and herbs to dip it in. 
A good Italian restaurant have to know how to serve you a great calamari and yes they do! 
Tip: If you have a bigger celebration coming up, book their room for private dining. You get a lot of great food for your money in a very classy setting.

I really like Amerigo. The service is great and consistent. The food is good.  We always get the cheese ball appetizers which will blow your mind.  I swear there is crack in the bread or wait maybe the oil. I probably could just eat the bread and the cheese balls and be very happy, but the salads and entrees are good. 

This location is always slammed busy everyday of the week from 5:45pm-7:30pm. You will wait. You will probably get annoyed because a table of 14 just walked in. Make a reservation and be patient during those busy times. They have a very affordable lunch menu -- that also comes with bread! (hooray!) 

I've noticed some reviews talk about it being bland or salty, and i can see that. Some of the dishes are somewhat plain. Try something different! They have their menu online! 

Limited parking in a small lot around back, street/metered parking out front. 

We often get carry out at Amerigo and they've never screwed up the meal. 

It can get a bit loud in there at peak times, - and try the tiramisu with coffee. Its just heavenly!

Amerigo gets 4 stars for their lunch specials and service.  It has slowly taken over my lunch rotation and brought it to a halt.  I order the same thing every time, salad and spaghetti/meatball combo.  It really makes my week, I kind of look forward to it.  The spring salad is fluffy and fresh with a touch of roasted red peppers for color and flavor.  The spaghetti portion is just my size and it's topped with an extra large meatball.  Now, if this isn't enough, you also get bread and oil.   This whole bundle of joy is a mere $8.  Boom!  Lunch around Vandy isn't the cheapest so this makes my wallet happy.  I do have to note though this isn't the best pasta in town, I mean it's good, but it's no Mama Mia's or Cafe Nonna, but it's perfect for what it is.  I should also note the staff, because this is a lunching place, brings your meal out in almost record time.  They have it down to a science.  (I always eat in the bar area so I don't know if this is true for the tables.)  Thanks Amerigo, see you later in the week!

Came here before concert that we had planned. Got there early on a weekday and location wasn't busy at all. I thought for sure we would get amazing service this time around. 

We're sat right away.  Host/server (possibly even manager, not sure) tried to sit is at a table near the entrance. We asked to sit further back and almost immediately regretted it. 

We got our drinks immediately. Didn't get straws. I asked to sample soup, before deciding if I want a cup in addition to my meal. She wandered off and wanted to take our order before having me sample soup, which didn't make sense. It finally clicked and she brought me a sample. She took a little while to get our orders in, but we did get bar drinks at a decent pace. 

She didn't come back to check on us for a while. We got silverware and straws from another server. 
Our food came out, person who ran food didn't offer to add cheese to our meals. About halfway through our meal, our server came back to check on us. A little late for that. 
The gentleman in front of us must've been a regular because it seemed a manager and about four servers came by to check on him. 

Food was good. Service was okay. I like the food, so I think I'll give them another try. Maybe it was an off day. I was in the restaurant business for six years, so I know it happens.

I recently attended one of the chef's dinners at Amerigo. They sell tickets to these dinners and have them once a month in Nashville. They also do the dinners at the Cool Springs location, on back to back dates. We were greeted & escorted back to at large room in the back of the restaurant. In that room was a HUGE table with people seated. There were 26 people on each side of the table. 

They had a large team of servers who brought out the different courses & drink pairings. The menu changes each month obviously & chef Steven Robilio told us that he tries to source local things for whenever they are in season. This February dinner was a little hard to get local produce, but the meat we had was local. 

Each course was explained & brought out. The timing was pretty good. We had 5 courses along with 5 drink pairings & it was about a two hour affair. I did notice that a lot of the people who attend the chef dinners were repeat customers. I also noticed that a lot of the clientele were seniors.

My favorites of the dinner were the pork lion & the meat balls in the Italian wedding soup. The pork lion was sous-vided & so tender. The meatballs were seasoned will & delicious. One thing that I did notice about the dinner was it was heavier than other course meals I've had in recent times. Maybe the clientele likes to feel like they're getting their monies worth, & they are. We left stuffed. 

One of the drawbacks about the intimacy of the table was it was almost hard to eat the food as the chairs literally touched each other. I kept finding myself trying to to elbow the gentlemen seated next to me. I think it would be much better if they either sat people at the ends of the tables or maybe used the table located on the elevated section of the room too. 

For the $50 price tag (plus 30% gratuity) I think it was a bargain in the Nashville food scene. I've been to course meals with pairings that end up over the 100 dollar mark easily per person.

Good spot for lunch. They always have lunch specials so depending on the day, you  can try their different dishes at a lower price.

Whenever I come here, the service is always good. Their bread is delicious! I always love coming to Italian restaurants just for that.

I had their spicy chicken on pasta with cream sauce. I liked it but it's not something I would order again. I enjoy the more traditional Italian foods rather than the Americanized dishes.

I yelped the restaurants nearby and found Amerigo on the radar. So my buddy and I decided to give it a shot. For starters they bring you this delicious warm bread and olive oil for dipping, nice start!

We ordered the chicken gumbo for starters and for our entree, the pasta bolognese and Chicken Tuscany. 1st and foremost presentation is key to any dish that comes out of the kitchen, its sort of like going out on a blind date, you have one shot to make a good impression, so don't screw it up! 

Unfortunately, "Plate presentation" needs work. The dishes came out sloppy from the kitchen. The bowl and plates had drippings on the side and edges. Check the photos on yelp, you'll know what I mean. 

The food was not bad, the chicken gumbo was rich and flavorful and had just the right amount of kick, but was a little over salted. The pasta in both dishes were cooked perfectly and the Bolognese sauce and Tuscany chicken were on point

I felt the pasta bolognese was a little too small to be considered a entree, but maybe this is the standard portion size for this particular dish.

Kudos to our sever, I forgot his name but he did a great job in refreshing our drinks and delivering us more bread. He was also very knowledgeable of the specials that night.

I look forward to coming back again in the future to give it another go.

This was a great experience from start to finish.

Our server was so friendly and welcoming that we felt comfortable immediately despite being tired, stiff, and cold from our 10 hour drive from DC. We lucked out and got seated in the back of the restaurant in a space that could double as a private room. No other tables in the room were occupied for the entirety of our meal.

The bread and olive oil they brought out first was amazing - soft, still-warm fresh bread and quality oil for dipping. We started with the Cheese Fritters and Calamari Fritti, both of which were delicious. The Fritters were especially great - crunchy perfection on the outside and melty, stringy cheese on the inside. Dipping them in both the honey mustard and the marinara sauce they come with is a must.

The Calamari Fritti had a great crunch and wasn't over- or undercooked; there was enough chew to be comfortable but not so much that you began to worry about the health of your jaw. Eating at least half of it with the caper pesto sauce ensured I was happy throughout the appetizer course.

For dinner we had the seasonal pork special, the Chicken Margarite, and the Smoked Chicken Ravioli between the four of us. (One of us was so stressed out after our drive that he just wanted wine.) Each dish was rich, filling, and so satisfying on a cold night. The portions were also huge; we all had leftovers at the end despite the three of us sampling a little of each other's dishes.

I wish we had had room for dessert but we were all so full that it wasn't an option. Next time I'm in Nashville I plan to return just to try the Chocolate Bread Pudding with rye whiskey caramel sauce. If it's as good as everything we had that night, I'm sure it'll be worth the trip.

as our last dinner out in Nashville it was a very hard choice on where to go. one look at the website seeing that Tortellini made up my mind on where to go. I know it's a chain so I was a bit worried but we were not disappointed. the tortellini was even better then I thought it'd be. it was so good in fact my mom and my fiance kept stealing my food! seriously I had to fight them off....

so thanks Amerigo for making our last dinner in Nashville so glorious. and the bathroom with mouthwash was awesome. why don't all bathrooms have that? that's perfect for a first date!

Came here for dinner on New Years' Day and it was a pretty quiet night. My friend and his wife were already seated when we got there so we were already playing catch up. Our server came back and ran through the specials of the day or 'features' as he called them and I went with the steak and bacon wrapped scallops-not exactly the most Italian thing on the menu but I was hungry and it was what I wanted. The gf got the wild mushroom ravioli while we all split the calamari appetizer.

The calamari was a pretty good one, not overly done but far too little. I forgot whether we got a large order or a small order but it's too small.

I really liked their feature that I ordered, so much so that I just focused on it and didn't taste of everyone else's plate like I usually do. I tried to balance out the steak with the two scallops that came with-they were pretty big though so no complaints, enough to go around and by around I mean enough for it to go around for me and my steak. I don't think he mentioned the risotto that came with it, but it was a big heaping scoop of it with a rich, cheesy flavor to it. 

Our server was pretty good, he came by pretty frequently before I arrived as my friends said but I think waiting and waiting for a late group kind of took a toll. He did come back with everything we asked of him when he came by though.

After a looong tradeshow day (and a late night the night before) my coworkers and I were looking for a comfortable place to sit and some filling comfort food. Pasta is one of my go-tos for that purpose, so I reserved a spot at Amerigo. 

I've had the super authentic and the not-so-authentic Italian fare and Amerigo comes in somewhere in between. But I like it.

For apps we had the cheese fritters. I didn't find them particularly "Italian" but after eating them,  I think they should be served everywhere.

I had the shrimp bisque as well and even though I shouldn't have, I scarffed it all up.

Since rich and filling was the theme, I continued with the fettuccine imperial (grilled chicken and pancetta with mushrooms in parmesan cream sauce). It was excellent. I feel like I should have branched out, but that wasn't really my goal.

I didn't feel like I was back in Florence or anything, but the service was friendly, prices outstanding and the food was yummy.

Noble farms Mac n Cheese! 

I went in on a whim for lunch in the middle of the lunch rush with my 2 year old. I was greeted warmly (much more so than usual when toting a 2 year old in at lunch time) and sat immediately. The server Nora was so pleasant and the bread and apple juice came out quickly...if you don't have a child you know why this is important.

The seasonal lunch pick was Noble Farms Mac n Cheese and was exactly what you would expect...the best mac n cheese you've ever had. It has panko sprinkled on top, perfectly cooked noodles and of course noble farms cheese. It's served in a cassoulet type dish and is a really good size portion for $14.

I cannot wait to go back as I have wanted to try Amerigo for years and never had the opportunity. They definitely impressed!

Forgot how much I love this place for lunch.  It's excellent.  A little more pricey than other lunch options, but not off the charts by any stretch of the imagination.  

I had the soup special--shrimp bisque--and MAN ALIVE was it good!  So it was not the low-fat option I went in saying I was going to get, but it was completely worth it.  If they have a bisque at all--lobster, shrimp, or otherwise--please try it if you like that sort of thing.  You won't be disappointed!  I also had the portabello mushroom burger.  Didn't really eat the bread (but it was on French bread--different and good) but the mushroom was tasty and was topped with feta and roasted red peppers.  All delish.  

Service here is great.  They are just attentive enough--I always had a fresh Diet Coke (add a star for that!) but the waiters aren't annoying either.  Dinner here is equally good, and they have a great wine list.  It's hard not to leave here totally stuffed though--so make sure you have time for an afternoon nap in your cubicle, or after-dinner lounging on the couch.  You'll need it!  Fat and happy...

St. Louis has the best Americanized Chinese food, hands down, so it was a no-brainer that I try this spot.

China King Express is located on Gravois in the Benton Park West neighborhood. The building originally was a Pizza Hut spot back in the day before being converted. It's literally placed on one of the busiest intersections in the city, so you might see a little bit of EVERYTHING, lol. 

There's parking and dining if you choose to stay, but honestly, I wouldn't. It's best to get take-out or have your food delivered. There's just too much activity around that area (traffic and otherwise lol), and my anxiety is too bad for all that. 

Now, the most important thing is the food! When you enter, you'll walk up to a buffet line and a worker will serve you - just tell them what you want. For the entreé, you have a choice between low mein or fried rice. After that, you have a pick of sides, which includes a choice of chicken (fried, general tso, peppercorn, etc.); egg rolls; crab rangoon and some other items. You get THREE sides or a double portion of a side to whatever entreé you choose.  It's A LOT of food given to you; they basically pile it on. Two people literally can share one order. 
 
The food is really good, hot and super affordable ($6). The people have always been nice, and I've never really had an issue with going back. If you're on a budget and want to feed two or more people, I would suggest China King Express.

If you're deciding whether or not to book a tour......definitely go for it! You're in for a treat!!! 

I got the introductory 20 minute tour for me & my boyfriend for our 2 year anniversary. It's such a great date idea that's worth every penny!!! Our pilot Mike was so so fun! (If you want to go on a tour with him, make sure you book a weekend date). He made the experience much more comfortable for us - and he made a lot of jokes while we were in the sky, which made it that much better. The helicopter was also super clean. Such a one of a kind experience :) 

The 20 minutes goes by so fast, so I think if you're trying to choose a perfect package - the most bang for your buck would be the 30 minute one! Definitely gonna get the 50 minute tour next time when I get the chance :) 

Also, if you get motion sick easily, remember to take some motion sickness pills for a better experience!

We love SB Helicopter Tours :)

I'll be the first to admit that I usually don't go for donuts. If I'm going to go for something sweet, I just go for cake, but Joe's might change all that. For some reason, I've become kind of obsessed with their donuts. More specifically, their chocolate sprinkle donuts and their glazed chocolate donuts that actually have a really rich chocolate flavor. Either one will make for a perfect dessert when a craving hits. They also have a variety of other sweet and pastries that I have to resist when my sweet tooth kicks in. Did someone say McKenzie's turtles?! Oh yeah.

I've been here for lunch once and the experience was great. Even though the restaurant was packed, service was attentive and friendly. I got a club sandwich with a side of grits and some donut holes, because when you're eating in a diner, and all of that is available, you go for it. The sandwich was really good, but curiously only had ham and bacon on it as the meats. I guess that's their version of a club and that's fine with me, I enjoyed it. The grits were yummy and, of course, the sweets always hit the spot because they're known for their donuts.

I have yet to try breakfast here, but I'll be doing so soon. I'm glad there's a Joe's in Terrytown.

Every time I come to visit family in New Orleans we wind up going to breakfast at a lot of little places like this that tend to be geared to take-out or serving small groups (1-2 people). Places that are mostly counter space or small tables. We roll in with at least 5 and service is often spotty at best. That was the case here, but the waitresses/staff were friendly and from what I understand this place (at least this location) is pretty new. 

It took a little while to get coffee & place orders, but once everything was straightened out the food was very good! I got a delicious three egg omelette with sausage & I can't remember what veggie. I also got pepper jack cheese. I like when places put the cheese over the omelette & that's what they do a Joe's. It came w/a biscuit that was good as well. Everyone else I was with seemed to enjoy what they ordered as well. My nephew has one of those HUGE Texas donuts which is a fun & unique thing this place has (the pastry case looked AMAZING).

Coffee was good as well, and like I said, after some initial hiccups service was good. Prices are very reasonable for the amount of food you get.

Wonderful service. Definitely sit in the courtyard - enjoy the lights and water fountain. It's very peaceful back there, an oasis considering where you are. I only went for wine, but they have food too. Big wine list and they also have bottled beer and liquors.

This place was recommended to us from a local bar. It is hidden and out of the way and if you were to walk by it you wouldn't give it a second glance.  All that I can say is don't make that mistake. Stop and make this a dinner destination.

Prior to ordering we had a glass of wine and they serve bacon as a free appetizer. We both ordered filet mignon. Mine was rare in hers was medium. Both steaks came out perfectly. You couldn't have asked for a more tender meat that could've been cut with a butter knife. The vegetables that accompanied the meal were properly cooked and were very tender.

If you are ever in New Orleans and walking by this place you need to stop in for an amazing steak at a little out-of-the-way location. Their wine list is also extensive. There wasn't a crowd and it was a perfect opportunity for a peaceful amazing dinner
Mellow bar on a Sat night.  Good escape from the heat and the rain to enjoy a nice glass of wine

Best crab cakes ever!!! Ahhmazing! I would go back over and over just for these! I also had the cheese board and a beautiful glass of pinot that the server recommended. Only complaint was about the cheeseboard. There was one of the four that did not belong and the fruit wasn't sweet. Water crackers were just right though for seperating the flavors. I am a fan of this little place and I will go back the next time I am in NOLA and it is warm so that I can enjoy the courtyard which was beautiful. I should take off a star for the cheese board error but I won't because it was super late and they did their best to make us comfortable and give us a nice relaxing experience.

Came here last Thursday.  Started off with some Rose.  Perfect!  We decided to get the BBQ shrimp.  They were huge and the sauce was amazing.  We then had the crab cakes.  They were very crabby and on point.  We also got the fried avocado with blackened crawfish tails.  I thought the fried avocado was weak.  Definitely needed more flavor salt another component of some kind.  The service was great and I am looking forward to going back!

Did you say bacon ? Well sign me up! Sit at the bar and munch of some deliciousness as you await your cocktail as you overlook the beauty of Jackson Square. Located on a quieter corner of the raunchy strip is this classy establishment which I'm glad I walked into. I noticed the horse posts outside and as soon as I heard a gentleman say there's bacon at the bar, I sped inside and grabbed a strip and ordered a cocktail. The outside terrace reminds me of a quaint vintage courtyard that great friends, drinks, and food come together in perfect harmony. The service was great and we even made some friends at the bar. They have a midday and a late night happy hour so definitely ask your server/bartender what the specials are. I love the piano inside and the beautiful decor on the walls. The whole place is instagram worthy ! So head on down to the Grapevine and get your bacon and drink on.

A French Quarter treasure with a great outdoor courtyard and wine menu. They offer wine flights and inventive food options, occasionally a fish dish or special can be downright inspiring. This is also a good place to get a cheese plate or dessert in mid evening FQ wanderings. A great place to meet a friend or group that isn't too loud and a break from the quarter nuttiness. Prices here are reasonable, modest even for the quality. Great romantic date place too.

SO cute and absolutely a wonderful respite from all the trashy dives in nola!

If you're from out of town and had enough with dirty venues filled with drunkards covered in beads - this is a nice, classy alternative.  I'd been here years ago for a couple glasses of wine with my boyfriend and father, sat outside and it was lovely, right by the cathedral. 

This trip it was disgusting tropical storm weather (same week as our NYC hurricane, so we got to do both in one week, super!), so we sat inside at the bar.  Probably a bit more expensive than other options, but worth it.  The dinner menu looked pretty good as well, and our bartender was awesome.  I got the prosecco, and my boyfriend got a rum and coke, so can't really speak that much of the quality, since both are typically pretty predictable.

Will definitely be back, and bring friends!  I only wish they didn't have the AC pumping so high near the bar area..

Stumbled into this place looking for soup to bring back to sick friend.  Ended up coming back for dinner after delivering the soup.  (Seafood soup that almost didn't make it back because it was so amazing.)
Ended up having steak, potatoes and veggies.  Sounds fairly boring but it was anything but.  The steak was cooked to perfection and topped with a sauce that didn't take away any flavor from the meat but enhanced it and went well with the potatoes.  The bartender paired everything with a great wine.

The wines tend to be more East Coast or imported.  The NW Wines are ones that aren't good representations of the area (to be avoided).  Ask the bartender for recommendations on what will pair with your meal and taste before committing. 

I would classify this restaurant as traditional with a New Orleans flare.  When you are needing a meal that is more traditional this is the place to go.

We were happy to have found this place accidentally - a glass of wine is exactly what we wanted!   We were greeted by a very friendly older gentleman.  Before we even asked, he said he'll check to see if there's a table in the courtyard for us and came back shortly after to lead us out.  The courtyard is lovely with the water fountain, dim lighting along with the balmy weather...so NOLA.

We only wish this was our experience for the rest of the evening.  It appears instead of having a waiter or waitress assigned to the table, they assign a "team" - that's where it all falls apart, especially when you don't know their service is a "team" effort.   That would also explain why our waiter was half ass and disappeared and we had random people bringing us food and checking in on us.

What we had:
Plungerhead zin $10

White Haven sauvignon blanc $11

mixed green salad $8 w/ port poached pears, roquefort cheese and port vinaigrette - this is probably the smallest portion of a salad I've ever seen

crabcakes $13 w/ chipotle pepper set over wilted spinach and caramelized oranges topped with house remoulade - not bad

bacon mussels $13 black mussels steamed in saffron tomato broth with jumbo lump crabmeat, applewood smoked bacon and basil aioli - pretty good

coffee in french press $5 each

chocolate brownie $8 triple chocolate fudge brownie w/ vanilla bean ice cream, topped with strawberry coulis - ok, it's like a brownie ice-cream sandwich but the brownie was dry.

Team 2A = D.

BF and I wanted a nice, quiet and but not too fancy dinner near the Quarter - we found Orleans Grapevine and immediately knew it was just what we were looking for before heading out on Bourbon Street to par-tay.

The place was relatively quiet; we expected at least a short wait, but were sat as soon as we walked in to a back table. The place only holds about 6-8 tables inside, and a big round bar area. Considering it was a Friday night during the 4th of July weekend and during Essence Festival, I considered us very lucky to find an empty table.

They give you a warm loaf of bread and a ramekin of some herbed butter mixture that was out of this world when you sit down - I almost asked to buy a tub of it. We ordered the barbeque shrimp as an appetizer. It must have been an off night or they had a new cook, because the shrimp were tough and really overcooked. If it hadn't of been for the awesome juice they were soaking in, I would have sent it back.

For entrees, BF had the pork loin and I chose the special of the day - Red Snapper. I had a bite of his pork loin, and although it appeared to be cooked medium, it was a little overcooked and tough to cut. I, however, couldn't stop eating my snapper. It was perfectly seared with lumps of deeeeeelish crab meat lumps on top, and sat on a bed of mashed sweet potatoes with a side of corn relish. The Snapper made me forget all about the shrimp and pork loin - I felt like I scored big with my choice.

Service was outstanding. Our server was really attentive and cleared our plates immediately after we had finished, which was nice because the table space was relatively small.

We decided against dessert, but BF had a cup of coffee and it came out French-press style - super cool. He was a happy boy after that.

Our meal, including tip, one Miller Lite and a glass of Sauvignon Blanc, totaled $115. I don't know if I'll eat a full meal there again, but I'll probably go back to try other appetizers and sit at the bar.

We visited this place a few years ago and I fell in love with the location and atmosphere but this time we got there too late and couldn't enjoy the food or the drinks. All they offered was bacon and drinks. The staff was not that attentive or friendly. I guess it had a lot to do with them closing soon.

No complaints but pricier than expected and probably not worth the overall value.  Friendly service at the bar and an interesting group of patrons (as with most places in the Quarter) including a magician who was doing tricks at the bar.

I visited TC CHoys this weekend and wasn't even sure they were still around for dim sum! I'm not sure of any other place in the local Tampa Bay area that does Dim Sum, so it was a welcome surprise.

It's located right off of Platt and Howard in the SOHO district of South Tampa. 

Atmosphere: The inside of the restaurant has plenty of seating for big parties and tables for smaller ones. There is Asian decor adorning the walls and even a large Buddha in the entrance!

Food: My girlfriend and I ordered dim sum, around 230 in the afternoon when they were almost done serving it. Each dish we ordered was only around $4 so we were able to eat a little at a time and split the check down the middle. They even accommodated a request for Chinese broccoli that I'd asked for. The Dim Sum ranged from Shrimp and vegetables in rice paper to Pork Shu Mai dumplings. While the food didn't 'knock my socks off' it was a treat that I'm not used to eating regularly - I would enjoy more flavoring and even more of a seared taste for some of the dumplings.

Service: The server was very pleasant and friendly and smiled each time he came back to check on us. 

For a Sunday Dim Sum fix, I'd definitely come back. The main menu is okay, but not super elaborate. The prices are between $15-20 for an average meal so more than I'd typically pay as well.

Unlike the other yelpers so far, I went to T.C. Choy's for dinner, rather than dim sum.  Boy, was that a mistake!  The food here is overpriced for typical Asian dishes (e.g. ~$20 for phad thai).  It literally took over an hour before we got our food... over an hour!! 

We ordered the chicken lettuce wraps, Malay noodles, lobster tail, and beef medallions.  The lettuce wraps and noodles were too salty, and the lobster tail was utterly and obviously NOT fresh (advertised to be fresh seafood from their tanks)!!  The waitress was very apologetic for our food taking over an hour, and she was able to get us a refund on our lobster.  She is the only person deserving of the one star.  I do not recommend coming here for dinner... stick to the dim sum, although I cannot vouch for it myself.

OMFG... Sunday dim sum was delicious. And the % of asian faces in the dining room was an indication to me that they're doing it right. 

The sweet steamed pork buns were perfect, the asian broccoli (I think thats what it was) was superbly wilted and had a nice garlic sauce on it. Lots of shrimp dishes at my table (but I don't eat shrimp) and everyone loved them. Even the mochi-like balls rolled in coconut kicked ass.

The servers were swift and efficient. 3 of the 5 in our party were Viet or Philippine and had special order requests - which the kitchen whipped up quickly.

Been a very long time since my last visit here, based on this superb Sunday lunch I shall be back a lot sooner.

Oh: As we were leaving, there was an epic line out the door - go at 11 or so to avoid what looked like a hideous wait after 1 pm.

I have to say - There aren't very man Asian options in Tampa let alone good Asian options.  So relative to the area, this might be good alternative for dim sum.  Man, we have it good in California.

The service here is really good. Friendly, helpful and very catering to your needs. That was really refreshing.

Now to the food. The dim sum just wasn't good. Everything was very dry and bland.  I must re-iterate the part about things being dry - the dumplings lacked plumpness and any juice, which you'd expect.  Things were so bland that everything essentially tasted the same.

We were told a few times that TC Choy has turned into a nightclub as well. 

I really think they need to focus on their core business before venturing onto other things.

TC Choy's promotes itself as an Asian Bistro serving Cantonese and Asian Fusion cuisine with over 70 dim sum selections and more than 100 Chinese dishes, some with Japanese, Thai and Malaysian touches.

The restaurant is located in the SoHo district of Tampa along S. Howard Avenue at W. Platt Street. This is a happening area of town with lots of restaurants, bars, and people.....yet TC Choy's was nearly empty when I was there for a business dinner on a weekday night. We walked in at 7:30 and there was only one other couple in the restaurant. By the time we left nearly 90 minutes later no one else had been seated in the dining room. Yikes!

The interior of the restaurant is dark, and as Cari mentioned "gloomy". There's plenty of room for diners - well over 100, but no one was there. I've been to TC Choy's for lunch a few years back and the place was packed, but nowadays it is quiet.

The menu is expansive and the food is quite good, so I'm not sure why the lack of diners. We ordered a mixture of dim sum and sushi for our dinner. For dim sum we had BBQ pork rice noodle rolls, fried shrimp balls, and Chinese sausage sticky rice. Those were all priced at $4 each for an order of three servings of each. For the sushi we had a spicy red & white tuna roll which was red & white tuna with scallions, smelt roe and spicy sauce. We also shared the Tiger Eyes roll which was baked salmon skin with crabmeat, hijiki (crunchy seaweed strips), and avocado. 

There were three sushi chefs working behind the bar and three servers roaming the floor, so it didn't take long for our food to arrive or our water glasses to be filled. Perhaps they were expecting more diners?

Anyway, the food was good, and not outrageously priced. I prefer Ho Ho Choy for my dim sum, and places like SoHo Sushi or Samurai Blue for the sushi -- but I have nothing against the food at TC Choy's. I just question if they'll be able to survive with such a low turnout of diners.

We just dined here for dim sum and I must say this is the only dim sum place I'd return to.  The restaurant is clean!  I've been to some dim sum places in Bradenton and even Chinatown NYC, and it makes a difference when the restaurants and carts are presentable.  We were seated in the cool green room in the back and were greeted immediately by servers and carts full of delectable treats to taste.  The spicy sauce is good on everything, chinese broccoli is fresh and tasty, beef/noodle entree was especially good, all of the dim sum was prepared well; no complaints.

I am an avid fan of CL Deals, so when this certificate became available with an additional promotional code I snatched up two. So I waited to complete this review until after I had used both. Now after having gone two times, once for lunch and once for dinner, I am not impressed.

The reviews rave about the dim sum. Maybe my palate isn't as refined as I think but I wasn't impressed. I selected three items from the dim sum menu before deciding to just order off the menu when I went for lunch. I was disappointed cause I have had great dim sum before.  The walking menu really appealed to me but here there are only a few options which they keep on the cart, which are mostly the baked options. All of the steamed or fried options are prepared once ordered.  Fearing that I would not get full, I also ordered the lettuce wraps to accompany the dim sum.  They were actually well flavored but very oily. 

When I visited the next time, it was for a late dinner with a girl friend. We ordered the chicken teriyaki and seaweed salad. The service was slow just as it was when I visited for lunch. Once delivered the seaweed salad was still frozen. When we brought it to the attention of the server, she seemed shocked. Only after pulling out a piece with ice on it did she believe us and respond. The only thing they did was nuke the salad which we could see since the kitchen is open. This let us know that the salad is not freshly prepared in house.  The chicken teriyaki however was freshly prepared of which I am glad since it took so long for it to be delivered. The flavor was good and the portion was sufficient for one. If not for the cost, I would probably order this more often since it is much better than you will find at the Chinese choose your number restaurants.

We've been coming here since almost 4 years ago and much has changed regarding price and quality of service.

As other reviews have already mentioned, the owner automatically adds a 'Service Charge' of 18% no matter how many is in your party. Needless to say my party of 2 was shocked and irritated. I can now see why the restaurant is so empty. The owner even said the automatic service charge was part of corporate policy. MINUS TWO STARS.

Food was okay, some of it was cold and not well cooked. MINUS one star.

Price: small $3.50, medium $3.75, large $3.95 and kitchen specials are $8.50. The prices have risen ridiculously and even a tab at $35 wasn't filling for two people! MINUS one star.

Parking spaces are cramped and hard to back out when its full. 

Bottomline: I will NOT be returning and I will NOT recommend this to anyone. Save your money and go elsewhere.

TC Choy's has good dim sum and their dinner dishes are tasty as well.  The only drawback is the they are really pricey!  I think for dinner, just my entree was 18 dollars, and it was just sliced beef, not seafood or anything.  I also would say that their dim sum is a little pricey, more than normal anyways.  Their restaurant is nicely decorated and the service is very prompt.  However, I have to disagree with Ryan, I think PF Change is much better value and the food is always consistenly delicious!

Surprisingly fresh sushi, prepared better than that at almost every sushi bar I've been to in America. Oh, and their Chinese food is fantastic too--especially the dim sum. Far better than P.F. Chang's. A must try.

I have only eaten here once and only got to try a few dishes, but the large open dining room and open kitchen were appealing. The service was good, we had the owner's nephew, and the food was very tasty. Great flavors and interesting preparations. Will have to return to try the dim sum lunches they are most known for..

What a great find! We are new to Tampa from NYC and did not think we could find good dim sum here. Excellent service and a very nice and clean dining room. You can watch the cooks in the open air kitchen cooking your food. We were here on a nice and quiet Sunday evening and our food was cooked to perfection. Spacious for families with young children too. We will definitely be back.

I've only come here for dim sum.  the decor is nice, but i'm not as in love w/ the dim sum.  Each time I go- its tasty while it goes down but gives me a nasty headache later.  My msg indicator goes wild and i have trouble driving home after eating here!

I love my little downtown Publix! It doesn't have as big of a selection as the Publix up on 38th Ave, but it has enough. It is great for small shopping trips or picking up a missing ingredient. Before this Publix was built we had to drive about 40 blocks to get to a grocery store. Now we have our own Publix downtown. I do wish that they had a pharmacy, but I know that they didn't have a lot of space. Service is friendly here and they are normally quick and efficient. I am going to miss this Publix when I move. 

Bonus: You can use the Publix parking lot for easy parking for Push or Red Mesa Cantina :)

This store was recommended to me as the best place to shop for groceries during the last trip to St. Pete. It's easy to see why! The selection was good, the staff were super friendly, and check-out was fast. A very classy grocery store. I've never reviewed a grocery store before so it's that good! Wish we had it out here in CA.

Haha ahhh a supermarket review. So here is my deal, I live in friggin Manhattan, there are NO supermarkets (unless you count Wholefoods as a supermarket - which I do not - they are more like fancy highway robbers with pretty clothes). I come to St Pete for work and stay over the road at the Hilton. As soon as I have unpacked, I head to Publix - I love you so much:

1) aisle after aisle of selection (note the Manhattan comment above)
2) super air conditioning
3) my favorite tea to keep me going all week (note the Hilton, work comment above)
4) godamn fried chicken to die for

It's the simple things that make us happy

While I think Publix has a decent reputation for customer service, the selection is underwhelming in my opinion.  I do like this location since it's downtown and better for sustainability, but I wish they would carry much more organic, fair trade, and/or locally produced items. 

Publix's deli and bakery items make me less inclined to come here: it seems they are usually loaded with excessive sugar, white flour (it's rare to find whole wheat), plus dairy (very hard to find anything vegan). 

Finally and most important to me as a consumer, they are still refusing to sign the Fair Food agreement. I think it's important for customers to know how Publix's core business affects migrant farm workers in Florida, and I will not be shopping at Publix until they sign it.

This small shop is just south of Main Street and I actually missed seeing it and had to turn around and come back for it.  As I stepped inside, I realized this is more of a "to go" place with a small display counter of pizza slices and desserts and another counter for checking out.  Since it was late in the lunch hour, there weren't a lot of ready to go options, but I decided the sausage and pepperoni would meet my needs.  The woman behind the counter threw in the sausage slice as well since she didn't think it her best "looking" piece and wouldn't want to sell it.  So, I got two slices of pizza for the price of a single $2.17 (tax included).  Can you believe it?  I spent less time in the shop than I would had I gone to a fast food drive-up! 

And the flavor was good!  The thin crust slices were a little flimsy and flopped if I didn't use two hands or do the fold method, but they were definitely cooked and had really nice flavor.   Okay, not complex and layered, but with minimal toppings, that's hard to achieve.

Tip:  If you are near here, go to Brew Link Brewing across the street and bring a favorite slice from CJ's with you.

Review #605

The only thing I ever order at Vito's is their Buffalo Chicken Pizza. It is a pretty darn good pizza and one slice is very filling. When I do eat 2 slices I don't feel that well for a few hours. Today, I held my ground and stuck with just one slice. I haven't fallen asleep at work yet, so I think one slice was a wise choice.

Vito's has a pretty big menu and several other options. They have hoagies, cheesesteaks, wings, pasta dishes, etc. These all looked pretty good too, maybe next time. 

Vito's was doing a brisk lunch business today. Service was friendly and fast.

3.5 Yelp stars

Kinda decent but didn't blow me away.  Still right off 295, so it makes a great alternative to Fast Food Nation fare when you're on a road trip.  Very nice people working there, although they seemed a little gruff at first.  Decor is bare bones.  There is another pizzeria in the strip mall around the corner.  Will try that one the next time I am passing through NJ.

I really love this Save On.  The product and prices are no better than anywhere else, but the customer service is out of this world.  I know it sounds ridiculous, but I leave this grocery store smiling and I'm just in a good mood.  The employees in the deli specifically are always incredibly smiley and friendly.

Everyone says that the Sunday Brunch is where its at, but I was there for dinner.  Overall Nice Atmosphere, The food was good, but I felt the portions were a bit on the small side for the price. The service was average, the server was "unsure" about a few things on the menu and didn't really seem that interested in resolving the que

Julie and Michael graciously welcome you to their fine dining Donelson restaurant. Dress casually, feel fancy. Music often entertains as you enjoy your dinner. It ranges from piano to easy going vocals, depending on the day. Lunch is good, with a buffet available in addition to menu items. Sunday brunch is even better. Best fare for a picky eatie in Donelson. Red and white wine selections are more than adequate. For special occasions I recommend the Napa Valley cabenet Chateau Montelena. For fun sip the Woop Woop red from down under.

Stopped in for dinner. Very quiet place but it started to pick up as we left. It is way bigger on the inside than it looks. We got the med nachos and bbq shrimp to start
 The nachos were so unique and yummy. That was my favorite dish. The bbq shrimp was yummy but hard to eat. We almost lost a shrimp. We got the lemon rosemary shrimp and steak frites for dinner. They were good! Overall nice restaurant! Our server was super nice.

We wanted a quick lunch that wasn't fast food and was close to our hotel. We saw that Ellendale's had good reviews, so that was our choice. I am guessing we only got the lunch menu, as it was just sandwiches, pasta, and salads. We each got a salad and they were good but nothing special. I am guessing maybe their dinners are more exciting? The service was good and the ambiance was nice enough (though I can see how dinner might be more romantic).

This is a must-visit the next time I am in Nashville!  the service was awesome, the ambiance was classy (including a live pianist!) and the food was amazing.  There were things on the menu that you don't see everywhere!

Ellendales is a little tucked away, so it's a little hard to find, but luckily, I had Yelp reviews and GPS to guide my way to this hidden gem!  After a horrible experience right across the street at Bar-B-Cutie (see scathing review), our tummies were still rumbling and we were on a mission to find something delicious.

We found Ellendales!

Our server was Paul, and he was one of the most attentive waiters I have ever seen in my life.  And one of the nicest!  When we ran low on pita chips for our mediterranean nachos, he brought some more out and we hadn't even asked for them!  When we needed refills, he was right there.  He made good suggestions and was quick to bring out the food with a smile!  he even brought out extra ranch dressing when he saw my friend fipping my discarded cucumbers in there just in case she didn't have enough!

The food:
Mediterranean nachos: Delicious--heavy on the hummus
Rabbit-Flavorful but different
Steak Sandwich-Fantastic, but I did take off the pickled onions--the taste was overpowering the taste of the steak.
Paulimisu: My friend REALLY enjoyed it--and the menu is right, it was heavy on the brandy!

I can't wait to come back again!!

I would truthfully say a 3.5. 4 for atmosphere and 3 for food.  The house is super cute and great for groups but the food was just okay. I've been on 3 separate occasions and nothing was spectacular. The homemade ice cream was pretty good.

#11 Country Club please and thank you.  Of the subs that I like, this one has the most meat making it very filling.  Their meats have great flavor and the bread is always fresh.  I get my sub lettuce, tomato, onion and easy on the mayo.  I love that they are sooo fast, you are in an out in 5 min tops.  So awesome!  This location has a drive through also for convenience.  
Now, I'm not a big fan of the corner they chose to put this building because it's not the easiest to get in and out of, but oh well.

The location just opened about a week ago at the corner of Lindbergh (North 67) and Washington/Charbonier near Dierbergs.  There is a drive-thru and plenty of parking.  Cashier was on top of their game since they tried upselling all over the place: Want to add avocado to your sandwich?  Want to add a cookie or pickle?  Ordered at the drive-thru, paid, and picked up my food at the window in less than 2 minutes.  They really are freaky fast!  Sandwich was perfectly prepared, soda was full, and chips were not smooshed.  5 stars.

Was here yesterday and order lunch special. Shrimp pan roast wit 1/2 Crab sandwich. Shrimp pot was so good it made crab sandwich kind of bland. So today we came back for a shrimp pot by itself. Lunch special was pretty reasonable ($12)   Sign in with Yelp and get a free cocktail. Saving for later don't want to drink at lunch. At least not today. Awesome sourdough bread also have sushi which is pretty good

In Mid-May, we flew up to Reno for several days to visit some close friends in Spanish Springs. One evening, we decided to try Oceano. The service and food was excellent. I especially loved it when they brought out the sourdough bread. It was the whole round loaf. We just ate into it like there was no tomorrow. 
I ordered the sashimi combo, soft shell crab and salmon skin handroll. MMMM MMMM good!! For being so far from the ocean, it was like being there.

Came here for Happy Hour oysters. Between me and three others, we shared two dozen fresh oysters and two side order of fried calamari. The tables for the HH section is puny. we had to squeeze the table together to create a semi larger table to hold up the oyster trays.
