Waterfront gorgeous.
Downtown refuge for the soul.
Walk, play, eat, enjoy.

This is a super cool park in downtown. It's right on the riverwalk. There is the children's museum, the city skyline, food, grass, entertainment, food trucks, Mosque. If you need a break, check it out. Tampa's not so bad. Parking is hell to find...

This is a great water park thats free for anyone. Kids love to come here and play, and its close to all the things downtown. There's a dog area, bicyclers, skateboarders, joggers, dog walkers, etc all in this area, and it over looks the water. We go via boat and dock the boat and walk up to the water park for some relaxing time. Bring the kids and swimsuits for a while to have a nice day.

Great location on Ashley street in downtown tampa. Parking garage right next door, view of the water. Tampa university looks pretty all lot up at night. Yes it can get crowded during events but that is what brings the masses to downtown. Ice skating was a bit pricey at $10 pp but that included skate rentals and 90 min session. Lots of happy skaters of all ages made for a good time.

Situated on the banks of the Hillsborough River (buffered by the Riverwalk), Curtis Hixon is an awesome and beautiful venue in downtown Tampa. It is a great place to take a stroll and take in the sights, watch a performance, attend a festival, or go to a special event. 

This waterfront event destination is outstanding. Freelancing as a park during any given day, events that are held here are largely festival-like and has a large capacity for vendors and patrons alike. With a view of the Hillsborough River as well as Plant Hall of the University of Tampa and the new and attractive RiverWalk, I cannot say enough good things about this place. There are public restrooms and a children's play area as well as a splash park area closer to Ashley. There is a large stage which is a perfect place for local acts or entertainment of larger proportions. On a most recent time I saw performers from the Straz Center in a free show. 

This park is very versatile: I have been here for a gamut of different reasons, to walk/talk with a friend, take my dog to the dog park, attend festivals, etc. Tampa hosts a Rock the Park thing which is year round, the 1st Thursday of every month. http://www.rocktheparktampa.com/2015-schedule.html  I think this is an excellent live concert venue and I love when there is live music here. With the new RiverWalk up and running, there is more vivacious activity going on and you access the walkway and can walk the length or the river as long as the walk is if you so choose to. Curtis Hixon also now offers free wifi, how great! In addition, there is a fabulous pop up ice rink in the wintertime. Check this Tampa gem out if you haven't been!

I've been to quite a few events that have been hosted at this park and they have all been a hit primarily due to this venue.  It is a great area to showcase the downtown area and the views from all areas of the park are amazing.  Whatever direction you look you have the image of Tampa's skyscrapers, the University of Tampa, Hillsborough River, or the museums it is adjacent too.  

It's so great to see that there is such a great greenspace and park area located within the heart of downtown to draw visitors and locals alike to.  Tampa Riverwalk also runs adjacent to the park so its a great spot to take a break or just sit and enjoy a little bit of peace in an urban setting.

Based on the beauty of this park, and the fact that it's right on the water, I want so badly to give it 5 stars. However, this park has been completely taken over by vagrants, and it's sad. What used to be a beautiful place to excercise, study, or just get some fresh air, has become a place for vagrants to urinate, bathe in the fountains, and even have sex (something I witnessed while attempting to take a walk).  Since 2012, protesters also seem to love to crowd the sidewalks and common areas of the park and disturb the peace during family events. It's very disheartening.

Neat little park on the Riverwalk with a small fenced in dog playing area, kids playing areas and lots of grassy spots to sit or smooth concrete places to walk and jog and exercise. There are even reasonable bathrooms! Lots of open space and the big flat area looked like it's ready to set up for a market or festival.

The small amphitheater set up looked very neat, though nothing was going on there when I stopped by.

And yep, there are still some signs that refer to it as "Nations Bank Park Plaza." Nations Bank has since morphed into Bank of America.

Another perfect example of what ever day sights Tampa holds for us. A beautiful, shaded  active riverfront park in the heart of downtown  Tampa. 
You never know what to expect: ice skating, bands, Bordeaux & BBQ, the Florida Symphony.... the list goes on & on.
Thankfully  the City of Tampa, Starz Center & an entire host of event hosts utilize  this park for a wide variety of events, that are usually well executed & carri out. Sorry, but once again I have to put down the City of Tampa, for not having recycling  bins at their events.
 Get it together, man up & promote recycling! 
Even with no events, a quiet, restful, picturesque  & peas full sitting for man & his best friend. There is an amphitheater,  kids playground and kina sorta a water splash park.
Whatever your reason for visiting, make it count! Relax, enjoy yourself with or without  friend, check out the view of University  of  Tampa  & how the lights play on the water, enjoy what reverse is going on, even if it is just nature at it's  best. You are home, enjoy.
What's  a  girl  to  do? it doesn't matter where I am, I always kick back & enjoy.

Unanimously, a drop dead gorgeous park.

Located in what seems to be the heart of in Downtown Tampa (I'm not too familiar with the area) you'll find a park for all seasons here. By the looks of other reviews, everything from festivals and concerts take place at Curtis Hixon throughout the year. 

There are vast patches of fresh-cut green grass, playgrounds for the young ones, and a brick-lined waterfront walkway by the river. The views are remarkable. You can tell a lot of time and effort went into the construction (and a hefty chunk of change). 

Without a doubt, as good as it gets!

Love this open view waterfront park. This park is beautiful. Only wish.... More shade.. Being in sunny Florida, direct sunshine gets hot! I do love to come here with a picnic basket, blanket and hang out while the kids play at the playground or run through the large splash pads. This park hosts some great festivals,
Concerts and even free yoga on Sunday's. The riverwalk is a work in progress. But it's so wonderful to take a walk on the river. Tampa has stepped up its game while continuing to grow its waterfront Realestate.

I really like this park. It has a sweet view and hosts lots of great events like food truck rallies and Rock the Park. I always try to stop by for a stroll if I'm hanging out downtown. The only thing is that it seems so empty at night I constantly wonder if I've missed the zombie apocalypse or something. I wonder why more folks don't use it. I've never found it to be unsafe at night. I'm looking forward to going to the mayor's mac and cheese event!

This is an okay dunkin donuts. I end up stopping here occasionally for coffee when in the area. It is in a very tight spot and parking is a pain. In the mornings, the drive thru will be backed up almost onto Bethlehem Pike. I once decided to park and go inside because the drive thru line was so long, big mistake! It was seriously impossible to get out without going through the drive thru. The inside of this location is nicer than your average dunkin,with a cozy area for sitting with a fake fireplace. Employees are hit or miss, usually they're nice enough. However, the one time the guy messed up our order by completely leaving the one drink out( it was only two drinks), and instead of being apologetic, acted like it was our fault. No, you just didn't understand us.

I'm not in love with Market Pub House, but I don't despise it either. I want to say "meh," but I feel a bit better about it than two stars, so three it is.

I'm pleased that they have a veggie burger. It's not bad, and it's nice to have a burger option on that long list of burgers for meatatarians. I usually order the sweet potato fries, which are decent but could use a bit of salt. They're awfully nice about bringing me barbeque sauce for dipping, though. :)

During my last visit, I tried the Asian slaw. I'd get this again, as it had a little bit of sweetness poking out from the sour vinegar taste. It was a nice balance.

Friends enjoyed what were apparently extremely cheap drinks during (if I'm remembering correctly) special happy hours or a special day. Their eyes popped when they got their bills - in the good way.

And I have to give major props to the bartender and chef who bent over backwards to pack up some gooey buttercake for me as a to-go order. I need the dessert as a prop for a video I was shooting elsewhere in the Loop, but gooey buttercake normally isn't available as take-out because it melts so quickly. However, once I explained the situation, the bartender and chef worked together to get me a lovely looking (and tasting!) piece of cake that survived the transport to our shooting location.

Alas, the general service I've received at the Pub House has been kind of lackluster. Everyone is friendly, but as others have mentioned, servers are very slow and tend to forget about you.

For me, Market Pub House really only serves as a dinner option when I'm with friends who don't want to indulge me in the great ethnic food that's in the Loop or when I just feel like boring, basic food. It's definitely middle-of-the-road and inoffensive.

The office had a working lunch, so ordered in using 569.DINE. I don't know what they pack the food in, but it's always delivered with the hot stuff hot and the cold stuff cold. Man, does that work.

There were five of us, and I couldn't keep track of everybody's food, but it was gobbled up heartily.

Here's what I saw around the table: two large house salads that were huge (and they were ordered as sides), fried fish sandwich, Dagwood, cheese quesadilla.

I got a small house salad that was still massive. It was fresh and crunchy with beautiful, crisp cucumber slices and diced tomato. The bleu cheese dressing was tasty. I also got the original hamburger with Cheddar. I ditched the bun, but it looked rather fresh. The burger came with lettuce, tomato and onion; I used all of that. Even though the burger was flavorful, it was a bit dry. They didn't ask how I wanted it prepared, a shortcoming in my book.

But the pickle was delicious and tangy!

Ordering from Market Pub House worked for our group, because of the variety of offerings. There was something on the menu for everyone.

I have had several dining experiences at the Market Pub House, each time I have been hoping for the service to improve but have been disappointed each time. The food is your typical bar food, and is hit or miss. It look almost 35 minutes from the time we ordered to get a deli sandwich and a burger on a slow day, and when the burger arrived it was cold. Food is cheap with each dish costing 5, 6, or 7 each. If you are looking for a quick meal while in the Loop I would go over to Fitz's or even Blueberry Hill, you are not missing much by skipping the Market Pub House.

This is definitely one of those places you want to go if you're a college student and want to get out on a weekend, but don't want to drive. I'm not sure how it would run with people outside of college though.

When I came here, we stopped by for trivia night.  Definitely a fun thing to do over the summer when you can round up six or seven friends to get a team going together. One of the things I really enjoyed about the trivia is that they asked a little bit of everything. I really suck at pop culture, so it was refreshing to have some questions about science and languages and other subjects to get the whole table engaged.

As for food, they have a decent selection, but it's all pretty much bar food. I highly recommend getting the everything nachos.  They are just the perfect app to split between your table for a trivia night. Definitely large enough to share :)

I enjoy this place.  I like coming here for wings on wednesday nights and drinking diet pepsi with grenadine. It's nothing overly special but the people who work here are nice and I have good memories here. 

If you do get wings, try getting the jamaican jerk and the japanese black wings... i think they're called... they're both very tasty. 

the sweet potato fries here are decent, but not amazing. the pesto sauce is a-ok as well. not spectacular, tasty enough.

Bought the groupon for 1 app and 2 entrees. Showed up on Monday Burger night. It's $2 for a 5 oz burger, and you pay extra for additions. Just like Bar Louie, except BL's burger is bigger. Also similar to BL, they have $3 drafts during Happy Hour.

I read the reviews before going and was a little wary. But our server was great, made sure to explain how the groupon worked and checked up with the manager to make sure the wings qualified as an appetizer. He was great, attentive, refilled soda and checked up on us frequently.

We ordered the Japanese Black sauce wings. They were great, flavorful, but not really spicy. 

Just one note, the entire place smelled like old dish rags. I'm guessing the water/towel they used to wipe down the tables was old, but it was a really unappetizing smell.

We also ordered french fries and the fish sandwich. The bf ordered the smokehouse burger. It looked nice, I forgot to ask for a bite in the midst of enjoying the fries and fish sandwich. The fries are just like Steak n shake, thin cut, and served with a great chipotle mayo. But, their fries are spiced better than SnS.

The fish sandwich was a little small for my taste, served on buttered white bread  (maybe french?) with not quite enough tartar sauce. I also didn't like that the onions and tomatoes were diced and not thin slices. Oh well, I didn't say anything to the server, so it wasn't that big of a deal for me. My biggest problem with the fish was that it didn't seem to be seasoned. They batter was flavorless, and with the diced veggies, I don't feel like I got the fish sandwich I'm accustomed to. 

But, like I said, I didn't dislike it enough to say something to the server, so I  would still say it was good. I also have to take into to account that I'm addicted to sambal- although I do know the distinction between spice and flavor.

Great experience, great service, good food.

I've been here a few times ... decent food at decent prices but nothing special and the place can get loud ... as in one loud table takes over the airwaves.  Pretty good service otherwise and if you just want a different place to try, it may be good for that.

Honestly, I don't even have much at all to say about Market Pub. My taco meal was bland and the beer list was just alright. Nothing about it really impressed me at all. It reminds me of being the "Applebee's" of the Delmar loop. Nobody would choose this boring place over all the other amazing eclectic places in the loop. 

One word...lame.

Went today for a short happy hour. Sat at the bar . . . bartenders extremely friendly and helpful. $2 bottles, $3 16-ounce drafts. And we were gladly provided water that was refilled generously.

My friend didn't know which beer she wanted, so samples were gladly provided until she found one she liked (took three tries). I had my regular.

Split an order of Market Nachos -- steak (choice of chicken, steak, pork or vegetarian) for $7. Quite tasty. Very filling! Two of us couldn't finish the order.

Ambiance is fine. Some pretty loud heavy metal music for a while, then morphed into "Tie a Yellow Ribbon." Didn't quite get the statement.

Lots of TVs, nearly every one tuned to a different station. Take your pick!

The menu aggravates me, though: Wings don't even come with Ranch or Bleu cheese dressing . . . costs $.50 extra. Cheeseburger comes with cheese, natch . . . unless you want feta or Bleu, which costs $.50 extra. Taco doesn't come with sour cream . . . costs $.50 extra.

This is what I call the "Bleu cheese is extra" syndrome. It's boring and chintzy!

I decided to take my friend, Donna, and mother, Pat, here for lunch. We were met promptly by the bartender and was seated inside. She took our drink order and brought the drinks. it took a bit for her to come back to take our order. when i looked up she was sitting talking to a managerial type person. A young man who i think was supposed to be our server came over to take our order. 

i got the Greek burger w/ a turkey burger patty instead of beef. I like that they offer a variety of proteins. Beef, Turkey, Chicken, and Mushroom Cap is what stands out in my mind. the Greek burger has feta cheese and the sauce i can't spell but starts with a T. I can honestly say that was the best turkey burger i have had in a while. It tasted and looked like real turkey. Not a frozen soybean/turkey mix. 

i then ordered the fry duo for the table. the fry duo is a half order of reg french fries, and a half order of sweet potato fries. I really like sweet potato fries. the side are ordered separate from the sandwich, but they give you $1 off the side item price. 

My mom and friend both ordered wings. The honey BBQ wings are good but very sticky. The mild hot wings were also good, but i did not really taste the sauce that much. 

I will be back to try my new love of sandwiches in my life, the Cuban. 
.

So my rule is that if I want to give .5 stars, I round down.  I do not give the benefit of the doubt when it comes to restaurants.

The waitstaff was aloof and inattentive, and neither my nor my date's meal were particularly memorable.  I ordered some Chili Mac and it wasn't wonderful, though they do have a great beer selection and this "Ghost Wing" level of spice that is above "Stupid Hot" (yes, that's what it's called) on the menu.  Eating all of the wings means you don't have to pay for the order, you get a t-shirt, and you get a photo on the Wall of Flame, also known as the "Wall of Chodes."

Don't bother...there are other places on Delmar that will be a better spend of your time and money.

For those who don't like spicy, oily, and robust foods, Shanghai food is the lightest in terms of those categories. Think lots of noodles, dumplings, and soups. This is a good representative of Taiwan and shang hai (I'm Taiwanese) in terms of their lighter cuisines. 

This place does thier soup dumplings right. Makes sense b/c thats where the soup dumpling comes from! I recommend a sharing of this if you're gonna come here. The staff here are very attentive and definitely refill your tea often and the service is good. Its a middle aged lady and some younger women who work on the side. It's a cleaner, modern, and less dingy restaurant in Chinatown if you're into that kind of aesthetics. 

Good for family, kids, friends, couples and very casual. 

I recommend this, a good stir fry rice cake dish, and finish it off with their glutinous rice dumpling soup cooked in wine. Very traditional Shang hai meal. Everything here is a cleaner taste so it's good for the health conscious, hypertensive, and those who don't want their sinuses drained out.

What a terrific new addition to Chinatown.  This new restaurant is nice on the eyes and great on the tongue.  The food is Shanghai and Taiwanese cuisines .... and a good idea is probably to order something from both of these Chinese culinary traditions.  The one appetizer you must try without a doubt are the incredible beef scallion pancakes from Taiwan.  With beef, scallions, and an oyster sauce inside - you will not want to share them with anyone else at your table.  You want to eat them all yourself! 
And to add to the great dining experience at this restaurant, the service was extremely attentive and friendly.

With the current Korean chicken craze in full flame, I'm planning on coming back to Shanghai 1 to try their Taiwanese lightly salted chicken.  Everyone tells me it is really tasty.  Judging by what I've already eaten at this restaurant, I believe it!

It was cold, wet, and a windy night in Chinatown Philadelphia. We were all hungry after visiting the Christmas Village for the holidays and with several restaurants across from us, we decided to choose this place for their decent reviews.

I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup and beef scallion pancake for appetizer. I am fortunate enough to be living in Las Vegas for nine years where Asian soup from different parts of the world is not hard to find. I would have to say that the beef soup here was less than satisfaction. I prefer my meat cut smaller rather than large chunks, but the meat was very tender. The broth overall was good, but I prefer the Taiwanese  beef noodle soup at Noodle Pot in Vegas.

As for the beef scallion pancakes that seems to be very popular here, is not so popular with me. The sauce was too sweet for me and the pancake was a little bit chewy. The temperature was almost at room temperature that may had contributed for being a little bit chewy. Liang's Kitchen in Vegas has awesome beef scallion pancakes served warm and is seasoned well.

The ladies were great and service was super quick. However, when in Chinatown, I would try other places before coming back here again.

The shanghai crabmeat pork soup dumpling is very good. The shanghai steamed pork dumpling is good too. The crabmeat dumpling is one of their popular dishes. I had stir fried noodles (ho fun), it is ok, not recommended.

The Wu Xi Dumplings were very good (the shrimp & pork soup dumplings just okay.)
I would be willing to try them again - but need to be more adventurous in what I try because some of their sauces seemed very bland to me, and there are too many ridiculously good places around to stick with bland...
Their white rice was probably perfect however- the best for eating with chopsticks and that perfect slightly sticky texture I haven't had in ages!
Staff was friendly and food came out pretty quickly, which along with decent prices made it a good spot for lunch hour during the week.

Stopped by here last night for dinner. I had a bowl of hot and sour soup, and an order of vegetarian dumplings. It was very good plus they give you a lot! I couldn't finish them, so I had to take the rest of it home. Service was also very good, and fast. I was impressed.
Best thing on the menu were the scallion pancakes with beef. The sauce that was used tasted like Peking duck wrap, except in a crunchy scallion pancake. Everything else was good but not memorable.

Not bad; decently authentic Taiwanese dishes with friendly service. The cold cucumbers didn't taste very well marinated (it didn't have the sweet rice-vinegar-tasting and spicy flavor that I'm used to getting in Taiwan). The pan fried noodles were good. The 3 cup chicken was fine as well. The oyster pancake had a pretty good sauce, but the oysters had a strange sour taste, and the pancake itself lacked the usual generous amounts of stuffing with the chewy gelatinous component that you'd usually get in Taiwan. The scallion pancakes were nice and flaky.

We tried Shang Hai 1 on a caprice as we were looking for somewhere new. We were vacillating back and forth between Shang Hai 1 and the Hidden Gem Cafe. With good reviews from Yelp friends AJ, Sari, Hannah and Gerald, we chose Shang Hai 1.

The experience overall was solid. The staff was very friendly and attentive. They kept refilling our tea and water even though they were quite busy. The soup dumplings were excellent, as good as DSG, maybe better. The crispy chicken that AJ recommended was also really tasty with some interesting spices. We had a fried fish that was very good also.

Shang Hai 1 is a newer, hipper, younger type of restaurants that seem to be popping up lately in Chinatown. They take credit cards too which is a big plus. We are absolutely adding this place to our C-Town rotation.

4 Yelp stars

Went here for dinner on a Thursday night with two other friends. There is a wide selection of shanghainese food on the menu and the restaurant wasn't too crowded. However, I was a bit disappointed by the food.

We ordered rice cakes with cabbage and shredded pork, stir fry udon, pork and crab soup dumplings, and pan fried soup dumplings. I wasn't a huge fan of the soup dumplings, mostly because they kept breaking and partly because I didn't really enjoy their flavour. The pan fried dumpling skins were too thick and the meat inside tasted too sweet. As for the rice cakes, it was clear that the restaurant hadn't soaked them long enough in water prior to cooking because they were still hard. However, the udon was not bad. Overall, this place is a nice for a quick bite and I do like their large selection. Would not be opposed to trying some other things on their menu, but definitely not worth it if you are looking for great soup dumplings.

I went to Shanghai 1 with a group of 8 yesterday. We were craving soup dumplings and one of the guys in the group wanted to try out a new place (as opposed to the usual 'dim sum garden'). 

My sister and I ordered steamed soup dumplings, cold cucumber, and a beef with chili pepper soup. Some of our friends got the Dan Dan noodles, the Taiwanese beef noodle soup, and the sweet and sour soup. 

The soup dumplings were good (not much different from Sakura or dim sum garden), but unfortunately nothing else was. 

The beef w/chili pepper tasted not like a soup, but like sautéed beef thrown into a bowl of noodles and hot water. The broth tasted more like oil residue than anything else. 

The Dan Dan noodles were bland. More reminiscent of spaghetti you'd get from your school cafeteria than Dan Dan. 

I tried the other soups as well and wasn't a fan of either. 

The worst part was that once we left, one of our friends let us know that they'd once found a cooked cockroach in one of their soup dumplings -_-. This was apparently a few years back, but it still made me feel super uneasy. Given everything, I definitely don't think it's worthwhile coming.

This review reflects only on the Xiao Long Bao, Beef Scallion Pancakes, Crispy Salted Chicken and Dam Dam (sic?) Noodles, all of which are on the Dim Sum Appetizers menu.  

We chose Shanghai 1 specifically for their reputation for good XLB as described by many Yelpers.  The shop is another of those long narrow houses with tables running along the north wall all the way to the restroom.  It is attractive enough with artificial flowers on each table and modern wall hangings.  The service is fast and friendly, especially if Mandarin is spoken in the exchange.  

We found the Soup Dumplings (XLB) to be very good.  The skin was thin, the soup hot and savory, and the ground pork filling, soft and tasty.  The table rocket with the dumpling vinegar was a great tool for squirting into the open pouch once the top knot was bitten off to suck out the broth.  We liked them so much, we ordered another bamboo steamer of 6 after finishing everything else.  

The Beef Scallion Pancake was likewise very enjoyable.  I did not find it overly oily given it was fried in that scalding fluid, and the beef within was tender and brought to sweet life with the Hoisin Sauce in which it had been prepared.  The Crispy Salted Chicken was their take on the fried chicken craze.  The chicken was tender, but the breading a might over-fried to a too-dark brown.  The pieces were very small and included many droplets of plain dough without any meat within.  While the taste was okay, the overall impression was underwhelming.   

Both the XLB and Pancakes were winners, while the Crispy Fried Chicken left something to be desired. I leave it to others to discuss the relative merits of the XLB created by the other shops known for this Shanghai delicacy, Dim Sum Garden and Sakura Mandarin.  If we had stopped with the first three dishes all would have been quite content.  Our son was still hungry and wanted some noodles.  He ordered the Dam Dam Noodles with Chili Sauce hoping to top off his meal with some spicy carbs.  At 19, he can afford to do that.  Unfortunately, he was disappointed with this dish.  He complained that it was tasteless and bland.  He left half of it in the bowl and declined to take the rest home. Perhaps, we should have known given the exotic spelling of the dish.  

We will stick with the Xiao Long Bao and Scallion Pancakes on future visits.

Since I come from NY with lots of Chinese food, I thought that the food quality in Philly was not that great. But I got impressed my the quality of this place. I ordered: 

- String beans. Well done. Great spice to salt concentration
- Beef dish. Not too salty and not bland. Well done
- Shanghai Xiao Long Bao. Well done. Great soup taste. 

Definitely a great place to come for Asian food!

I was checking out Alphateria, and it's kinda hard to avoid Alpha Brewing Company when the place you are eating is located inside the brewing company, but hey no complaints.

With already being there for Alphateria, I knew I just had to check out their beers. I've been trying to get into more sours lately, so I was happy to see they had 3 on tap. Unfortunately, I was feeling any of them, instead I ended up in my IPA comfort zone.

The space is really awesome, vaulted ceilings with exposed wooden beams. They even have a few pretty big booths to sit in. The bar space and beer selection is more than adequate. I think they had 16 beers on tap.

They even have this cool Sipster drinking club. Lifetime membership for $25 with different perks like half-off on all draft beers on Mondays, cool prices, etc. The bartender also told me once you hit 50 beers, you can get howlers filled for $5 (I believe that's right, doesn't say on their website though).

Cool brewery to check out some beers and with a great option for food in the back.

Alpha is a bit of a hidden gem, located just one block north of Washington between 14th & 15th Street. While it might not be visible from Washington Ave, it's well worth tracking down.

The beer selection here is pretty much what you would expect, a wide variety of Ales and IPAs, however there seems to be a heavier focus on sour beers here than anywhere else in Saint Louis. And let me just say that Alpha does sour beers right,  quite possibly my favorite beer here has to have been their Papaya Brett, which is a Sour American Wild Ale, however all their beers are damn near just as good. My recommendation would be to start off with a flight or two, so you can get an idea of what best suits your tastes, however both full and half pours are available along with Growlers to go!

The staff here is very friendly and knowledgeable too, they know their beer and will gladly talk about it and share their opinions. Check back often as they often rotate out a number of their beers and try new variations. Inside seating is limited, however there are also some spots outside which are better suited to warmer weather.

Overall if you are looking for a quality beer in a casual atmosphere Alpha is the place to be. I can't wait to go back and see what they have available on tap next!

Keep going back and forth with whether my rating should be a 3 or 4 stars, but I think I'm pleased with my 4 star rating.

Had a late afternoon meeting this Friday and usually these meetings end up taking us to Schafley or UCBC, but today I suggested we try something new... And of course Yelp lead me to this place. 

We were the first ones there and the only ones for the first hour or so.  Since there weren't many people there I couldn't pick up on the "regulars" or typical atmosphere, however I enjoyed the atmosphere, lighting and vibe that I got while I was there. Staff was super friendly.  They have an "alpha" and a "beta" list of beer. Seemed like the alpha list was more regular beers that they reproduce. The beta list sounded like it was more of a sample to see if they wanted to continue brewing them and the majority seemed to be more on the "sour" side... Not really my cup of tea. I tried the typical Alpha 5 beer flight. It was $13 for 5 small tasters. It's always cool to try a variety when you're going to a place for the first time. Unfortunately I wasn't personally a fan of the beers, however they were all very unique and had some interesting flavors, so A for effort. Seemed a bit pricy looking  over the menu, but if you're a young brewery I guess you gotta stay afloat some way!

A few disappointments or "meh" feelings I got were... Location was a bit difficult to find, as its on the backside of the building. They were out of several "regular" beers. No food available.  Small outdoor patio.

All in all tho, I think it's a pretty cool hidden spot in St. Louis.  Not the best beer in my opinion but cool place. I had a pleasant experience!

I was very interested to try a couple breweries here in St. Louis and this one intrigued me so I figured we'd give it a shot. The location was in the back of the building, a decent space with a duo singing and playing instruments as the staff eagerly push the beer menus towards us. 

They told us we can taste a few before we went with anything so we took them up on it. The blonde and IPA just fell short for me. My fiancée chose a couple others and none worked for her either. Then I rolled the dice on a taster of the Oatmeal Stout. It was a decent beer and much better than any of the four others we tasted. 

Unfortunately, beer is subjective and we just struggled to find anything that worked with our palettes.

I don't know if it's just me, or if others share this sentiment, but it seems the exponentially growing brewery scene in just about every city is starting to feel a little crowded and redundant. Sure, everyone has an exceptional seasonal beer every now and then, but for the most part it's the same stuff with a different witty name over and over again on everybody's tap lists. I still love going to as many new breweries as I can, but it's just starting to feel like it's getting a little difficult to find places that actually set themselves apart with something unique and memorable. Alpha Brewing has done just that, and they have done it very well. 

Located in a little downtown neighborhood with some other options to eat and drink in the nearby vicinity (I recommend trying some of the crazy pizzas at The Sliced Pint), this brewery certainly doesn't leave any doubt about what it is when you walk up to the place. Behind their nice outdoor patio area is a storefront that is almost all windows, and behind those windows are stacks of barrels, 3 high and 2 deep, aging a whole bunch of beers that are probably nothing you will see at any other brewery in the entire city. 

I love barrel aged beers, and I love sour beers (done properly, none of that kettle souring), and alpha had more options than I could try in one sitting. Our fairly large group found a few tables to push together in the taproom that had a bar with a dozen or so seats, and maybe 6 or 7 smaller tables. There were a few people set up with some board games, and some regulars at the bar, but it wasn't too crowded for a Saturday night. It's a bright taproom that is on the quieter side of things. You can see their brewing operation through a window, which if I am remembering correctly consists of 2.5 barrel brew kettles and 5 gallon fermenters, so they are definitely a small batch place.

The tap list consisted of maybe 5 or 6 of their "Beta Brews" on tap, and a few more in bottles. These were the things out of their barrel aging program, and were all really unique beers. If those weren't up your alley, they also had about 6 or 7 "Alpha Brews", which is more normal stuff that wasn't barrel aged, but still included quite a few really cool beers. If you ended up getting dragged along to a brewery as a non-beer drinker, I believe I at least saw some wine being served. It's not often I find beers that I haven't had at least one similar iteration of at some point in the past, but Alpha had plenty of them, especially their barrel soured beers.

Their prices, although higher than normal beers, were actually pretty decent for their barrel aged and sour beers. They had flights available as well, but those were from preset lists that you couldn't mix and match. I was surprised to see howler and growler fill pricing for their Beta stuff as well. I ended up taking home quite a few bottles from here, and a lot of them were available already chilled if you were taking it somewhere to drink immediately. The bartender working when we were here was great. She was outgoing and talkative, and knew plenty about the beers and the brewery. 

I will definitely be back here the next time I am in St. Louis.

Had an event at this brewery while I was in town for a conference and I can't say enough great things about the place and the owner/brewer.  First, and perhaps most importantly, the beers are excellent. They specialize in barrel aged beers, especially sours, and they know what they are doing and they do it extremely well.  Their IPAs were fantastic too.  Planning for the event was a breeze, the owner was very responsive and helpful and when we arrived he was friendly and accommodating.  My overall experience was excellent and I highly recommend this brewery to anyone who likes beer or who would like to plan a successful event.

Wash Ave's hidden gem is definitely Alpha Brewing Company. 

Hidden behind the strip is 12 beers on tap, bar, table, and patio seating, and a bring or order your own food policy. These things make me happy. 

Their full beer sampler was perfect for sharing and was well priced (I think $15) and my favorites were the Scotch Ale, Imperial Red, and Imperial Storter to name a few. They seem to rotate their selections quite often which makes me excited to come back and try something new.

The service was great, atmosphere was laid back, and no large crowds. The perfect place to just sit and drink good beer either alone or with a few buds. No judging or usual Wash Ave drama here. I will be back for another round real soon.

I would have given this place a higher rating solely based on what I ordered, but seeing the rest of my table be disappointed in their food/drinks made me knock a star off. 

First of all we came in on a Monday. Yay for 2for1 beers and Margaritas and extra yay for kids being able to eat for free. 

I had the garlic butter shrimp plate. Best believe I devoured it all! Aside from the fact the shrimp was a little over cooked because it had a harder rubbery consistency to it, I looked past it because I loved the flavor of the sauce it was sitting in. I sopped up the garlic butter sauce and ate it with my rice and beans once I ran out of shrimp. Nommms! 

Now seeing that it was HH when we came in, our table ordered margaritas but everyone had a slight look of disappointment because they all said it tasted watered down or they couldn't even tell there was alcohol in their drink. But I guess you can't really complain since it was pretty cheap. 

Would I come back?.. probably.

Had some mad garlicky shrimp here. Pretty good but the price was high and the wait was long.

I'd like to try one of their crazy seafood party platters.

Mixed luck here. The mixed seafood over rice and $4 margaritas were quite nice. Other problems were enough to drag my initial rating down to three stars.
I've been meaning to eat here for some time. I can't even remember what restaurants used to be in this building on Plumb Lane a few blocks east of Shopper's Square.
I was in the mood for trying a variety of seafood. The appetizers were mostly in the low to mid teens in costs. Too expensive for me by myself. So I got a shrimp cocktail and the mixed seafood over rice. They also have $4 margaritas.
My first problems came with ordering. My waitress had a limited command of English. For instance, she wasn't able to explain the difference to me between the mixed seafood appetizer and the mixed seafood over rice, which are next to each other under the enrees section of the menu. I asked her which was better and she said the one over rice, so that's the one I went with.
I also ordered the shrimp cocktail. She asked if I wanted it hot or cold. I asked if she was referring to the level of the spice and when she nodded yes I said medium.
When it arrived I realized she meant temperature. My shrimp cocktail had octopus in it, too. Which turned out to be fortunate, because the shrimp was flavorless. Plus it was it was a warm, thin, soupy sauce. I didn't like it at all. And I ordered a medium for $10.
The mixed seafood was pretty good, though. Nice blend of seafood and except for the mussels they all tasted fresh. Nothing was overcooked. A nice sauce. I'd order this again. Although it was quite large. Better for two people to split.
The margaritas were good. I like the strawberry margarita enough I ordered a second, a mango which was even better. Definitely a deal at $4 each.
They offer a red salsa, a pico de gallo and a bean dip with the chips, which was nice.
Another negative, and probably the main reason I'm docking them a star, was the noise. They have these recorded parrot sounds that were annoying and their sound system for music is pretty harsh, too.

As a fro-yo fan, I wanted to try this place for a long time. Finally, I stopped in here for dessert. The selection of yogurt flavours was decent, and I combined plain with chocolate and raspberry. The chocolate was not all that rich, but the other two flavours were good. I think the selection of toppings is the biggest of all of the different fro-yo places I have tried. They even line the wall. Most of the cereals are in hanging containers that you have to release with a lever, and the stuff comes out FAST! I would prefer everything just be in bins to scoop out, because I ended up with far more Lucky Charms than I intended. The fruit looked fresh, and there was lots of candies and nuts. I only wish everything was labelled. Price-wise Twisted Yogurt is comparable with other fro-yo chains, and I wish it was not so out of my way to visit more often.

Finally, USA-style froyo right in my own backyard! I love frozen yogurt more than ice cream. More than gelato, more than anything. And while the mix-y style is cool, it's awesome to have the Pinkberry style now in yeg.

I scored a cup of low-fat chocolate froyo and added chocolate chips and strawberries on top. There were about a half dozen great and different flavours on the wall (but what on earth is Purple Cow?) and lots of yummy toppings, from fruit to cookies to candy.

It's a pretty simply set-up in TY with a few tables inside and a few more out on the patio. (Yeah! Patio season is upon us!) The cashier was nice and friendly and that was that. (The cost is based up on weight of your finished dish.) Easy, yummy, great!

They have 60+ flavors of ice cream, all made by Hershey's. The employee was really nice and let us taste anything we wanted. She was helpful and the ice cream was great! One star off for being cash only, but it's a great place to grab dessert after dinner at one of the many restaurants nearby.

This is right off the corner of a busy street, a spot you can't miss, but may find difficult to park at. They offer several gluten-free ice cream which is feature. 

The only problem I had was with the young girl behind the counter. Doesn't have the greatest service on how to speak to customers.

Well, I must first say that this is much more a hostel than a hotel. Having said that, it is a 4-star hostel! You get your own room and bathroom, but the feel is much more hostel-like. The reasons why it is hostel like: office staff not always there, DVDs you can use in your room, real keys instead of card ones, building a little dated, the towels are small, etc. The bathrooms aren't extremely clean. They look like they have been wiped down, but they need a deep scrub. Thus, if those are your expectations, you will love this place. The location is excellent to restaurants and bars in Hyde Park. It is also a great place to get to Bayshore. I went for a 7-mile run. I started here, went along Bayshore, Davis Island, UT, and then came back here through Hyde Park.

Here's the deal - you need a place to stay in the area, right? You don't necessarily expect 5-stars but you definitely cannot endure anything below 2-stars. Sound familiar?

I booked this hotel through Booking.com and had a different idea in mind of what I thought the boutique hotel should be like.
The parking was free - lots of spaces to be had.
Entering the building (small area) you need to ring up to the office or know the entrance code ahead of time; I called a month before my arrival in order to make sure I could access my room after-hours and was given the door code then. Luckily I had it, or I would have been standing outside looking silly.

This place is NOT for anyone with walking disabilities - the office to check-in is up stairs and to even get to your room, you need to step up a few steps to the main hallway.
After I checked in, I was led to the room. Two double-beds with a tiny kitchenette, very small bathroom, TV and DVD player.

We had four adults staying in the room (including myself) and I'm glad we're good friends, because the room is indeed small. They included two bottles of water in the room, which was a nice touch.

Here's the pros (beyond what I mentioned above):
- Literally within walking distance of a Winn-Dixie. It's directly behind the hotel.
- Plenty of restaurants and unique shops within walking distance of the hotel, too.
- If you're using Uber, the drivers can find you instantly.
- Check out is as simple as dropping your key into a box near the front door.

Here's the (mild) cons:
- The door to the hotel room does NOT lock automatically when you exit. Make sure to lock the door with your given key.
- The shower temperature barely got above a smidge of warm - if you like hot showers, this hotel will disappoint.
- The A/C unit, while it worked, wasn't keeping the room cool enough throughout the night. We weren't too pleased about that.

Overall, considering we stayed here for one night for Gasparilla Music Fest, I would give this hotel 4-stars. Location alone (near a grocery store; 8 minute drive to the festival area) was worth trying out this place.
If I had to stay here beyond the one night, I probably wouldn't rate it as high.

Not a bad choice or an inexpensive one. We tried the fried want one, which were overcooked & really minimalistic on the cream cheese.
The special blend of fried rice was full of pork, chicken, some veggies & a few shrimp. Rice cooked well, not clumpy & taste was pleasant, but not great.
The Mongolian beef was the star. Meat was not soft & mushy. Plenty of green onions & no green peppers
 The sauce mixed with the beef & onions had a great flavor & overall the beast & most expensive dish.
What's a girl to do? When you find good food you return. The Mongolian beef was tasty & memorable enough to return, the stars don't match, because overall it was lacking.

I'm absolutely addicted to Chipotle. I make a trip there at least once a week. My staple order: burrito bol (burrito without the tortilla), with rice, half steak half chicken, lettuce, and doused in hot sauce.

I've tried other burrito places such as QDoba and Moe's, but chipotle is fat superior to the others. Their rice is ridiculous yummy, with lime juice and cilantro, I swear they add crack to it! All the meat is hormone-free and delicious. When I want to switch it up, I will order crunchy tacos with barbacoa (spicy shredded beef). 

The staff at this location is very friendly and warm. Could be because they see me so freaking much. We just got our meal comped today because we are loyal patrons. Yes, very addicted. I could rave on and on about this, but you should just go in and give it a try. You'll love it.

You know, I've been eating Chipotle for a long time, since I moved to San Francisco, so over 5 years.  

That being said, I've also enjoyed burritos better at any other place other than Chipotle.  Their burritos lack a punchy taste, and are always bizarrely salty.

I would typically give them a 2.5 on their food, but I enjoyed the staff at this location.  It was a lot slower than what I'm used to in SF, probably because it isn't as busy.  The staff is nice, and listen to you!  They were out of fajitas which I wanted, but I told them no worries, because I didn't feel like waiting...  Someone brought be a bowl of them as soon as they were finished cooking, which was really nice!

*HOWEVER*, despite their sweetness, they make their burritos with the smallest amount of rice and beans I've ever seen which, as far as I always knew, is the heart and soul of a burrito.  They slopped on guacamole and sour cream like it was expiring at the end of the night.  Kinda gross.

I'd come here if I'm craving a burrito, like, CRAVING a burrito.  Otherwise, it really ain't worth it.

I recommend beefing up the amount of rice and beans you use, ESPECIALLY when I order a vegetarian burrito.....

I went to this Sonic yesterday at the drive-up window. They have a wide selection of two items and drinks it's hard to choose from. So I decided to get a strawberry banana milkshake and tater tots. The person that took my order didn't understand what I was saying I wanted the milkshake extra thick so it wouldn't melt so fast and I wanted hot tater tots. So he kept asking me the same thing over and over I said forget it waited patiently for my items to come out to me. When my items came out my milkshake was watering the tater tots was high but I asked him again I wanted my milkshake thick. He told me because it was so hot out here that the machines was melting the ice cream fast which didn't make sense but I said okay but I don't want this milkshake. He said okay I will take it back and when he came back my milkshake was thick but my tater tots was cold. I love Sonic but I wish they had one near me it would be great for the kids and adults to drive up or just to hang out for some great snacks. And the happy hour is awesome and also the late half price after 8 p.m.

LOVE SONIC......we were road trippin so of course we had to add Sonic to our trip planner, turns out there was one near our hotel.

Are we all familiar with Sonic's awsum set up??? Okay let me give you a quick refresher. Sonic is a "drive in" fast food spot. Each parking spot has its own drive up ordering screen, they "roll up" and bring your order to your car....literally. Servers here are all on roller blades. They also have some tables outside, but no indoor seating. 

Menu is AWSUM, burgers, phillys, hot dogs, chicken and breakfast. They have these new pretzel dogs, bun is a soft pretzel and dog is topped with cheese and bacon....DELISH! I had the philly cheesesteak for the first time, it was huge!! Soft bun, meat was tasty, onions were correctly grilled, and it was just cheesy enough (hate it when they go crazy with the cheese). I was only able to eat half!

After 8.......half price shakes!!! Kind of like a long happy hour.....LOL. They have like 25 different flavors, we got peanut butter and bacon......yes you heard rite. Our server told us its really popular, and we know why.....its like adding salt to peanut butter, so maybe like a peanut butter pretzel type taste, or like reese's peanut butter cup. It was out of control good! 

We also had there Turtle Molten Cake (listen we were just tasting and packing things up for our hotel, we weren't having an eating competition), they have a few different types of molten cake choices, all looked delish. The turtle had vanilla ice cream, caramel and pecans on top of a warm chocolate fudgy cake.........YUMMM!

Service was great, our server was super friendly and gave us some good tips about the area!


Did I say I LOVE SONIC???????

Ugh, I am leaving for Mexico tomorrow and my diet went out the door as soon as I entered this place. I ended up getting my favorite, the chicken tacos and let me tell you, it is heaven to my mouth. Always perfect and delicious!

Chipotle is one of my healthy go to places. You always know what you're getting and the calories, protein, and macros are always in line. Also it's a filling portion. That said I ordered my standard salad with lettuce, carnitas, black beans, roasted chili corn, tomatillo green-chili salsa, and guacamole. It was delicious. The place good have used a good wipe down. It was challenging to find a seat inside that didn't have a mess even though there was only like 1 other person sitting inside. I'll be back but I'll hope they clean up!

Is it the best diner in New Jersey, Land of Diner Enchantment?
Maybe not, but it certainly has history and local color going for it.
Oh, and a great breakfast if you fancy overflowing plates, unlimited coffee, and a Greek Omelet that is a wonder of the world.  
What is it about feta cheese and eggs that moves me so?  Don't know, but when mixed with sausage, potato, onion, peppers, all wrapped up in an fresh egg case, they become an amazing sensory explosion.  
Trenton may have seen better days (we have been waiting for its resurgence since it was "Americas Town" in the 60's), but Pat's carries on.
Diners are only partially about the food, and the rest about the concept, design, and lustful loyalty they inspire. 
Pat's is a worthy contender for the Urban Diner List on Yelp* (If there is one). 
Give it a try. 
Sit at the counter and watch professionals do their thing. Sit at a window and see a worldview that captures the past-its-prime city, the capital of the Garden State, remind you that... We Are Still Here.

This is the Rite kind of place!

Buy one get one free days are in full swing here!

Arriba!

Need to stock up on hydrogen peroxide or batteries or jelly beans?

This is the Rite Time!

What is not to love at Chipotle. I have never had a bad experience at this location - food is fresh, perfectly made, and I always return to this location.

They are open everyday until 10pm.

Highly recommend: Burrito with brown rice, pinto beans, chicken, mild salsa, corn salsa, guacamole, lettuce, cheese and sourcream = my usual.

Enjoy!

Way to go chipotle, my husband got food poisoning from you. I lived to tell the tale since I don't put so much stuff on mine. So either it was the onions, salsa or black beans... I didn't have those. For once it pays to be picky!

Chipotle is my favorite place (to date) for franchise burritos. 

Even their guacamole is pretty darn good. 

The only cons - salty & goo gobs of calories in one sitting! 

This spot is located in a gorgeous, sprawling, ritzy, shopping center. 

Sometimes I come here just to walk around. 

I didn't realize until today that it's only 6 minutes from where I work :)

This Chipotle like many other is incredibly awesome from the minute you walk in the door you are enjoying the sweet smell of chiptoles food.  Always a friendly staff, and always some really awesome food.  Come here get anything you want because no matter what it is it will be awesome and it will be an awesome experience.

After living abroad for months, all I wanted was a delicious burrito. Last week I went to Chipotle at the King of Prussia mall, and it was terrible. I was SO grumpy that my triumphant return to burritos was lackluster.

After a long day of running errands, my husband (who also was abroad for even longer, and had yet to have his first burrito) and I decided to stop at the Marlton Chipotle. Boy, we are glad we did.

We WENT for it. I'm usually a burrito bowl kinda girl, but not this day. Burrito. Sofritos. Sour Cream. Guac. All of it, in my belly. Staff was friendly and attentive, and they made me one heck of a burrito. We grabbed a bag of chips, and sat in silence for ten minutes as we devoured our burritos. 

They were delicious and it was a very satisfying experience! All I could keep saying was... I'm so happy we came here.
They didn't have a sale today. It was some kind of  bug flying around so me and my sister had to leave.

Best chipotle I've been to so far. 
Clean. Friendly staff. Super fast service. Great portions. 
I love chipotle and I'm so glad I finally found a location that's worth going to!

It's a busy spot no matter what time of day but service is quick and I must say they give a more generous portion than some other chipotle restaurants.  

Food is good as always!  My family and I can't get enough of chipotle:)

I had not been to a benihana on over 20 years - and back then ist was teppanyaki only (no real sushi). Ah, the '80's - and we all owe a debt to Rocky Ayoki.

The sushi selections have improved a bit - although fish selections are limited and the Hamachi Hand Roll I had was sub-par.  (Tamago was froze - for $2.75 a piece).  Prices were too high for that sort of mediocrity.

Service was harried - we were seated on a rainy Sunday at 7 PM in the bar area, albeit with our picky 7 year old who did not care for her $3.90 Strawberry Lemonade.  (She had water instead.)

Edamame was boiled within an inch of its life.

My MIL had a tasty steak teriyaki - surprisingly yhe best of the lot.
Oh and for $4.00 a single round blob of chocolate Hagen Daaz was unceremoniously plopped in a dished and thrown at my child.

Not in a hurry to return.

3-4 stars for Dawa our chef who was amazing!  I noticed that he performed many more table-side theatrics than the other chefs and was very meticulous about even the slicing of the meats.  I would recommend asking for him.  

The food itself was pretty standard and be forewarned that A LOT of butter is used so it's not a meal for the light of diet, although you can definitely ask for a lighter version.  I was happy with my Seafood Diablo udon, which came with plenty of shrimp, scallops and squid.  The squid was surprisingly very tender, which is very hard to achieve; most places overcook it.  The yakisoba was decent as well and the chicken teriyaki was very juicy and tender.  The portions are also pretty generous and definitely get the fried rice instead of the steamed.  

We came in a party of 2 and had our own table, which was really nice, as a lot of places will make you share with other diners.  Our hostess was pretty stand-offish with an entitled air of ennui, which was rather annoying, although our actual waitress was great.

My only previous hibachi experience was at an all-inclusive restaurant in Mexico.  While they tried hard, it wasn't the hibachi experience I had always wanted to try.  So the hubster promised me a trip to Benihana - most of the hibachi places in the Lehigh Valley get lackluster reviews, so we figured we'd go to the trademark!

We chose to go for lunch, mostly to save cash.  Lunch hibachi meals range between 10-15 and include fried rice - dinner meals have more "extras" but only steamed rice for 18-30.  Bill for two was just shy of $30.

Lunch time on a Saturday at this location was dead - when we arrived, they were cleaning up a hibachi table that had left a few minutes earlier, and there were two people eating on the sushi side.  They might have sat one more table on the sushi side, and two tables on the hibachi side the hour fifteen we were there.  So very quiet.  But the experience was not lacking for it!  Our waitress took our order very quickly and a hibachi chef was at our table within a few minutes.  I'm sure he's not the best guy they have on staff, but he was nice enough and only made one or two fobbles during his cooking "show."  It cured my need for the hibachi experience I missed in Mexico.

Food was very good...especially the fried rice (we sprung for chicken fried rice - a $1 upgrade) and the hibachi steak.  I had the hibachi lemon chicken, which wasn't bad, but I enjoyed the steak more.  The waitress kept our water topped off and stopped by to make sure we were doing okay a few times.

Finally stopped in for lunch and ordered the hibachi chicken lunch.  I was in a rush so I opted to sit in the lounge, where the hostess doubled as the waitress.  No complaints there as she was efficient and friendly.  it was pretty quiet during lunch so the food came out very quickly.  The salad was okay, and the chicken was flavorful but slightly tough.  The hibachi rice was cooked with butter, which gave it an odd taste when paired with the soy-based sauce.  It didn't taste bad, just different.  Portions were decent for the $10 price.  Overall, a good, relatively inexpensive place to grab lunch.  Dinner did look a bit pricey, though.  They also have sushi but I'd be a bit hesitant to get it here when blue fin is a hop away.

Benihana didn't rock my socks off but it was certainly enjoyable.  A very solid three.  

When we first walked in, they had no record of my reservation (that I had called in on Wednesday for Saturday night), but they were able to accommodate my party of four without a wait.  From beginning to end, I enjoyed the food.  I had the "Land and Sea" hibachi and it came with soup, salad, some appetizer shrimp, and ice cream for dessert.  I felt that the price was reasonable given the amount of food and "the show."  

Our hibachi guy was excellent -- he worked quickly and kept two little kids at a party next to us very entertained and engaged (to the point where we hardly noticed we had kids at our table).  I would have liked if our waitress came back to the table more frequently to check on the drinks -- she forgot water that I asked for and I sat with an empty beer for a good long while before she showed up again to offer another.  They had a decent selection of Japanese beers, which was a definite plus as you don't see that around very often.

As weird as this sounds, I would recommend dressing in layers.  It's cold in there, but it heats up when they start cooking at your table.  Once they shut the stove top off, you're back to fairly chilly while you eat your cold ice cream.  Be prepared if you're sensitive to temperature.

I had a great time here; their food quality is unmatched by any other hibachi style places I've been to before. It is a bit pricey, but you can get away spending around $25.00/person without drinks and before tip. If you order from the hibachi menu, you get miso soup, a salad with ginger dressing, appetizer shrimp, steamed or fried rice, your meat or meat combo of choice, extra onions, and a cup of green tea at the end. I left feeling full and reeking of food. They have a brief sushi menu as well.

The interior is very nicely lit and spacious, and overall aesthetically pleasing. They have a good selection of sake, as well as wine and other beverages. The service was very good, though we were left for a long time in between salads and the chef's arrival. Strangely, this location (and perhaps all Benihana's?) do not make you catch shrimp in your mouth, and are no longer allowed to create a flaming volcano of onions, just a steaming one. Overall, a 4-star experience.

Update review:

Came in when they opened at 11:30 first customers in because my husband really wanted to try the soft shell crab. He was happy when he was able to order it this time.

Much better experience the food was made perfectly the portions was great, my scallops was delicious and not over cooked. 

I had to change my star rating because over all everything was great.

Will be back again.

I've never had Benihana, this was quite the experience. I loved the show which I though it was worth 4 stars but I felt like the food quality to price ratio made this place worth 2 stars.

I had the Benihana salmons with avocado tartar sauce with udon noodles. Which sounds lovely but the dish was not extraordinary. The avocado tartar was disappointing. I ordered salmons because I have borderline high cholesterol and shellfish/steaks might push me over the edge to heart disease land. :( i feel like the show may be worth the experience if you have never done so.

Went here about 1:00pm and was told that to get a hibachi seat would take about and hour to get seated, mean while there were a few open tables, not seats but hibachi tables that was available and unseated.

So we decided to get a table, first of all that in the area they have about 6 high tables and I must say the tables are closely bunched together you can hear the other's tables fulfill conversations with out trying. 

We decided on the drink and I got the blue ocean it was good, I ordered hibachi from the table and my scallops was over cooked very rubbery. The shrimp was also over cooked.

This would be a place to only get sushi from even them they took so long just to make one roll. 

I won't be visiting this location again.

AND DON'T GO FOR THE SOFT-SHELL CRAB (I was told they are almost always out)

Omg where do I start???? We was so excited to get an invitation to Our Neice 26 Birthday Party Dinner. At first we didn't know where it was but my niece text me and said at Benihana's and we said great. I was thinking we was going to the one in New Jersey. But unfortunately that location wasn't close to my neice. So we went to the one in Plymouth Meeting. We had a while to wait because because they were short. They was trying to seat everyone but some people didn't have reservations. So that made our wait longer then suppose to. The kids was getting restless and it was getting late. So finally we got our tables and were seated. Some of the staff was acting like bobbleheads all over the place. It took a good 20 minutes before the chef came to the table. They had one waiter waiting on six tables by his self. The waiter finally came to the table to ask us about drinks we didn't really look at the menu because we had to download it on iPhone it took a minute to get the information on some of the family members phones. So everyone finally Place their order it was plates on the table with napkins no silverware it took them a good 20 minutes for silverware so I made a comment. Do they have to wash and roll them we had our food but no silverware I know I'm jumping before but then the manager came out and was trying to help the waiter. The drinks came out late no one had water then finally the chef came out his uniform was dirty with food stains all over it he was cooking our food and the food was flying everywhere he didn't know how to do the volcano he didn't know how to do the pumping heart with the rice he really needed to go back to training and start over again I think they just hired people take a little class and you're on the grill but he was not entertaining at all and the money that we pay for show and dinner was unacceptable. I don't recommend this Benihana's to no one. And then when I was eating my food I had a shrimp shell in my food that was disgusting. So it was shells all over the grill then he  placed the bowl between me and my husband and eggshells shrimp shells and everything that he cooked on the grill was all on the side of our plate. I had to tell him that all the money that were paying the food was everywhere. The money that you pay at Benihana's they should give you a lot of food the portions that you received at this location is like a children's portion I don't recommend this $40 a plate we could have went some where else and got more for money. Especially when you have a chef that absolutely don't know what he's doing but it was upsetting so we start talking amongst our self and he was doing his own thing then he told us that he had to go to another table to cook. I believe that was the last table for the night but he should have went home after he left our table. That wasn't the kicker for the night the kicker for the night was the manager put a gratuity on everyone's bill without anyone knowing it was up to us to pay what we wanted not what was on the paper this was dishonest to the customer. I think they're trying to make up the lost from the pandemic is not fair is unlegal and I want my money back!!!!!! One thing that was great about this event that my niece had a nice time just to share her birthday with some of her family members. And this was her first time here. they hurried up and wrote our bill out and did want to sing Happy Birthday are you kidding me after all we have been through all they had to do is shake the tamarine and sing Happy Birthday. So the waiter and some other waitress came over to sing Happy Birthday. I just talked to some of my family members and they had diarrhea from the food last night this is unacceptable the whole table had diarrhea what is going on the health department needs to come there and shut it down. How can a whole table be sick. And each of us stayed in the bed all day we didn't know that until we called each other to find out what happened. And another thing while me and my sister was talkin we was saying that it was not sanitized because of the pandemic. Between the customers the chairs and table tops was not wash down so we might have not been the only one sick you never know until other people read your message. And you know the craziest thing to is I usually take pictures but unfortunately I did not take not a one picture last night and I'm so mad because if you would have seen how the chef had our table top you would have known what I was talking about. But only thing I can do is voice my opinion and speak out of what my experience at this Benihana's location. In my party it was my mother, husband, sister, nephew, and my self. But we come to this location for dinner and everyone has diarrhea  unbelievable. I'm so pissed at this time. I might all have food poisoning. I never been to a restaurant when the whole party gets sick.

For a chain restaurant, this is not a bad meal! 

The hibachi chef we had was talented and the food tasted great. The prices are a bit steep, but you're also paying for the experience. 

The support staff who helped wait on us were all great - refilled our drinks, brought our salad and soup promptly and made sure we had everything we needed.

Something to keep in mind - if you do hibachi and your party is fewer than 8, you may be sat with another party or two. It's not bad (depending on who you're sat with), just something to know!

We came here right before seeing a show at the AMC in Plymouth Meeting, and it was perfect! We would be back.

If you want a little bit of entertainment with your dinner, hibachi is always a fun choice, but Benihana let me down a bit.

I've eaten at various hibachi places before and this place doesn't quite measure up. The stuff seems overpriced for what is offered (except for the drinks which were super strong!) and the tricks didn't really impress me. I've had better shows at the place I frequented for lunch in reading.

We ordered the chicken and shrimp for two with onion soup, salad with ginger dressing, shrimp appetizer w/ vegetables, and fried rice for $36. Add on the drinks, dessert, and price to upgrade from the steamed to fried rice and our bill was in the low $80s.

Also, it was rather loud; I could barely understand our server/chef(Eloy) and it doesn't include the drunk woman with 2 kids and her husband at the other end who kept berating him for small mistakes(dropping a utensil or failing to catch something in his pocket).

Overall, I just wasn't impressed.

A surprisingly GOOD experience with Dorjee (our Teppan chef) and our server.
Excellent Sunday-lunchtime service for our table of 10, celebrating a birthday.

The lunch menu is a good value - the "Lunch Boat" - I chose salmon - a teeny piece of salmon - comes with sashimi, edamame, tempura (all in small portions - perfect) and soup/salad.

My daughter (age 12) devoured the tuna tataki app. and a plate of nigiri.

We enjoyed the food and service, while watching the onion volcano.
Nostalgic.

Probably not coming back to this overpriced not worthy place. I will pay good money for food that's worth it but we came here for sushi. Service sucked and the sushi tasted like it's coming from a cafeteria.

I think Pastor Baby Back Ribs got it right:  "Wow, I remember when I was a kid, going to Benihana was a super special, amazing, one of a kind experience. Now, it's everywhere."   Yep.

The Young 'Un had his Official Teenager Birthday (OTB) recently.  For his OTB, he requested dinner at Benihana.  We had been to other Japanese Steakhouses and were curious to see how the 'master' chain compared.   We made Open Table reservations through  Yelp - an easy and pleasant experience - and off we went.  

The restaurant is a stand-alone building on the grounds of Plymouth Meeting Mall, near the AMC Movies and Whole Foods. Parking is plentiful.  Inside, it's very well appointed, lots of reds and river stone and Japanese characters, very upscale-feeling in a comfortable way.  

Our server, Brianna, she really did a great job with orders and keeping a steady supply of drinks coming, it always seemed that just as my drink was getting empty, another one just appeared.  She was friendly and attentive and did a very nice job.

Our chef came out and did a very nice cooking show, even as it felt a bit rote and routine.  They do not use anything with fire, apparently due to a lawsuit or something.  We couldn't help comparing to every other "performance" we've been to, and honestly, it was somewhere in the middle in terms of entertainment.  It really does matter the personality of the chef, as they are all quite skillful.  

The food was meh, and that's to be expected. We've never had a delectable meal from this style of cooking.  Speed and heat are the enemy of delicious protein, however even with this expectation in place, the food all fell short.  The steak was tasteless, the yakisoba was strangely peppery, the salmon chewy.  Only things that got true thumbs up:  Lobster Roll sushi, shrimp, and the chicken dishes.  Warning: "Spicy Hibachi Chicken" is indeed spicy.  Also, the Onion Soup is much better tasting than it sounds, more like a french onion flavor as a clear broth without cheese.

The pricing we thought was quite high for what we got.  Nine of us, only two glasses of alcohol, almost $400 with tip (they do not automatically include gratuity, we tipped 18%).   I've had the same experience with the same number of people for $275.  Not worth it, and we likely won't be back because of this.

So we asked my daughter where she wanted to go for her birthday dinner and Hibachi was her first choice. First off, she likes her birthday on the down low, no mariachi bands and sombreros for this kid! We respect that so we weren't there with the intent on it being some over the top evening filled with embarrassing surprises. So I have no idea how Benihana is for birthdays. 
We love Hibachi but the service and the food were disappointing. We made a reservation and were seated at that time. The restaurant seemed to be laid out well and didn't feel overly crowded. 
The waitress came and took our order and that was pretty uneventful. Usually, at least when I've been, hibachi is a show, it's exciting and fun and sometimes u even get a little rice thrown at u. Not here. Some tables seemed to be having a better time than ours...I began to wonder I our chef had a terribly tragedy and still came into work. He was lackluster and not really into it I guess u could say. I was glad when it was over because it almost felt awkward to be watching someone just cook our food but at the same time it felt disrespectful to have a conversation during the "show". 
Anyway, on to the food!. One word...BLAND! No seasoning at all. The rice...fried rice...was bland. The veggies, bland. The steak, bland! And they don't put salt and pepper on the table so unless u wanna use the aggressive palate destroying sauces your just stuck with bland food. 
Also, if you have an allergy...be careful here, cross contamination is bad and due to it I wasn't feeling too great afterwards despite letting them know I had an allergy and explaining what I could and could not do.  I understand that this is an easy place to cross contaminate but I've been to plenty of hibachi places before with ZERO issues. 
Overall, not a good experience at all. I'll stick to the little hole in the wall hibachi places from now on.

My friend and I went here for happy hour a few weeks ago. Though I work next door, it never even occurred to me to try this place out for happy hour or a meal. Something about its location in the back corner of the mall just made it seem a little sad. 

I had an odd start, because when you first walk in the bar is nowhere in sight. The host greeted me kindly, but did not offer to help me find where I was going. After wandering near the bathroom, and then near the sushi bar, I found the real bar! The bartender was very professional and prompt. He made no time for chit chat, but that was fine by me since he made sure my drinks were delicious and strong. Between my friend and I, we tried about a half dozen cocktails and all were surprisingly great. I really enjoyed both varieties of sangria, especially. We also tried a few sushi rolls and appetizers. Everything was good. Nothing to die for, but good. Great for happy hour prices. 

I would definitely come back here for happy hour, to have a couple drinks and apps for dinner before a movie.

I'm a girl who doesn't like shoe shopping. I actually don't like any type of shopping, except maybe shopping for veggies. I love that. But everything else to me seems like a waste of time and money.  My husband bought me a cute pair of sandals after we met in 2010, which broke while we were at Lake Comanche a couple weekends ago. I realized they were my only pair, so I showed up in super hot Reno with no sandals, but every intention of going to the pool! Thank goodness for CVS!

It was morning time and the store had just opened.  I bought two pairs of sandals (about $15 each - buy one get one half off). I also picked up some mascara, since I either lost or misplaced all of my makeup (not horrible since I don't wear much). The mascara came with eyeliner - bonus! ($12.99) I grabbed a couple of sodas and snacks. 

Most importantly, I bought a bottle of Aleve gels for my husband.  Too many Crown Royale on the rocks the night before... and I needed him to be ready for a day of fun!! My entire purchase was about $50.

8 hours later....

Our group of three returned to CVS several hours later. We bought a box of Angry Orchard ciders and took them back to our hotel to enjoy.

Both visits I received friendly service and I was happy with the prices. I do dislike having to use a club card for discounts.  Just another reason I don't like shopping. But glad that this CVS was large and well-organized and I was in and out very quickly.

Been in this store many times over the years.

It always has what I am looking for and a million things I don't.

This place is not on the modern side, but easy to navigate. 

No matter how many folks in line it has never taken long to check out.

Always a smile too.

This place is soooo ghetto. They have minimal products, horrible checkout service ( usually only one person working, one very sloooow person too), and I usually have to go to a second store to get everything I need. Go to Walgreens down Virginia or even savemart up the street is better. Sorry, but I will never go here again.

For what it is, CVS serves it's purpose. I pick up prescriptions from here all the time. The techs have always been friendly to me. They now have a convenient program where they text you when your prescription is ready to be picked up. 
The store may SEEM "ghetto," but in my opinion it's only because of the building. It's old, what do you expect?
