Check out service was fine too, nobody was rude or slow. I was in and out with what I came for within minutes. 
I don't know if all CVS has this but I noticed that you can get your passport photo taken here too.

This is the best concrete joint in the world, nay, universe! From standard concrete flavors (chocolate chip, strawberry, chocolate, vanilla, etc.) to The Christy (a giant brownie sundae) you really can't go wrong with anything you order. My personal favorite is ordering a vanilla concrete in a Cardinals Cap with Reese's Peanut Butter Cups on top, but the toppings list is endless so, don't feel pressured to copy my order. In the summer the lines will be around the block, but that's part of the experience so bring your dogs, your kids, your friends and make an experience out of it! During the Christmas season they sell Christmas Trees and Concretes, but will close shortly after until about April. An absolute MUST-DO in Saint Louis, so don't miss out!

I have to go here every time I am in St. Louis.  My favorite is the Dutchmen's Delight.  It's custard with hot fudge, caramel sauce, whipped cream, almonds and butterscotch.  Yummy!

This used to be a tiny shack in the middle of a parking lot.  Now it's a medium size shack in a parking lot.  No restroom, but there is water on the side of the building if you need a drink.

There's plenty to choose from on the menu - many kinds of custard, sundaes, banana splits, etc.  The line gets long after a ball game or on a hot summer night, but they move VERY quickly to get your order.  If you want to get it to go and have to drive awhile, they wil give you dry ice.

Insanely good! This is the first time I've ever been in St. Louis and Yelp helped me find this gem! I'm so happy that I found Ted Drewes because BOY IT WAS GOOD! My dad who normally eats insanely healthy had to have one of their concretes! I had "The Christy" and it was absolutely delicious! It had hot fudge, caramel and brownie mixed together as a concrete. It was so good! The brownie was soft and fudgy and the custard was very creamy and flavorful. 

If you're in St. Louis, you need to stop here asap!

Frozen custard was another must have while visiting Saint Louis, and Ted Drewes was the obvious choice. It seems like the kind of place where there will be a perpetual line at any time of day, but luckily there are lots of windows and the lines move quick!

I ordered a "concrete" with cookie dough and peanut butter cups and it was delicious!  A quick google search told me that the difference between frozen custard and ice cream is the addition of egg yolks to custard. It definitely didn't taste eggy, but it did taste different than regular ice cream. A good different!

Some of the servers were flipping the ice cream cups upside down before handing it to the customers, hence the name concrete...what a trick! :)

I had big plans to get homemade ice cream at Crown Candy Kitchen, but never found the time. But through research, I heard that Ted Drewes was another must try in St. Louis and at the recommendation from my Forest Park friends, I headed there.

It was packed! And the people didn't stop coming. I had to park like two streets over, on some curb illegally, walk through and alley to get here.  I worked my way through one of the lines, only to see twice as many people filling in behind me. It goes fast, don't worry!

I asked around to figure out what to get and it was determined a concrete (much like a blizzard or blast) would be the best experience. I got the Fox Treat (fudge, raspberry and macadamia nuts). There is no pictured evidence of this treat because I got stuck in a traffic on my way to my hotel and it didn't last long. However, it was delicious. Ted Drewe's serves frozen custard and to me it was extra sweet.  Too sweet. Next time I'll probably stick with something more simple so I can get the true taste of the custard.  

Oh, one other note.  The portions are HUGE. I think I ordered a small or medium or something. Whatever size I got I was shocked and asked if they got my order wrong. Nope! So, personally, I feel there is no need to splurge if you're feeling extra hungry. Pretty sure a small would have suit me just fine.

In town for a few days a friend who lives in the area wanted to show us all things St. Louis. Of course he drove us by the arch and Forest Park, told us what pork steak is and intrigued us with toasted ravioli. Then he introduced us to Frozen Custard. Boy am I glad he did because it was deeeeeelicious. 

I'm a fan of frozen yogurt, ice cream and gelato so I didn't know where frozen custard would fall on the spectrum. I'd have to say it's a lot lighter in taste than ice cream and maybe even lighter that FroYo. 

With sundaes, malts, shakes, floats and concretes to choose from I had to go with the concrete. My friend compared it to a DQ blizzard and I'd say that's an accurate analogy. 

There were many different flavor choices and combinations to choose from. Thank goodness they had a few combination suggestions. I had the turtle (hot fudge, caramel and pecans) and it was so good. I went with the smallest size (a micro) but wished I had gone bigger b/c I was so sad when it was done. I tasted my friend's lemon crumb and it was sooooo good too. 

I don't come to St. Louis often but the next time I do I'll definitely be back to Ted Drewes.

On my first visit to St. Louis, my bf took me to Ted Drewes. He grew up eating their custards and he insisted that I give them a try. I've always been a fan of frozen yogurt and have never truly indulged in custard. 

As popular as this place is, I expected sort of like an ice cream parlor where you could sit down and enjoy your treat. Well we pull up to Ted Drewes and it is a tiny shop in the middle of a "parking lot." The shop has a window where you place your order. 

We got the oreo concrete. It was silky smooth and ohhh sooo indulgent. I kind of felt guilty eating this but still enjoyed it. 

Bottom line- this business is a St. Louis legacy and you must try their custards if you happen to be in town.

Famous for its frozen custard.  An icon in St. Louis.  Invented the concrete.  Never had a concrete in my life till today 9/28/2014.  I ordered a hot fudge concrete and it was huge and delicious down to the last bite.  I really don't have too much to add to the hundreds of reviews other than it deserves its reputation as an icon.

Hot ol' afternoon, kids in shorts, pretty girl on my arm. This is summer. 

We don't have frozen custard where I come from. Straight up do not even know what it is. God it's good. It tastes like America, and freedom, and 1956. Sitting on a bench with butterscotch custard melting way too fast down my arm made me all kinds of nostalgic and I have no idea why. Like a kid without a care in the world and my whole life ahead of me. I'd go again just for that.

Frozen custard = the fountain of youth.

Tried both the turtle and All Shook Up... The former is packed with nuts and the latter is wonderfully packed with ripe banana... Get some, but due to the extreme richness, order a size smaller if you want your pants to still fit...

I'm from Milwaukee, and we pride ourselves on serving up the best frozen custard in all the land. (WI readers should probably stop here to avoid massive outrage)

Ted Drewes is amazing - it's as good as anything I've had anywhere else and if I'm going to be honest it may be a wee (just a wee) bit better than what I get at home. That was hard for me to admit but Yelp is about honesty, right? 

I had a small s'mores sundae and everything about it was perfect: the custard was perfectly creamy and not overly sweet. The chocolate was luscious, melty milk chocolate and applied in just the right amount. Add in some marshmallow goo & graham cracker bits.....wow. Everything was in perfect proportion - not too much of any one thing. High quality ingredients and friendly staff complete the picture. 

I'm told that Ted's has lines even in the dead of winter & I can see why. I had half a mind to get right back in line myself and order a second helping.

A solid star at least for ambience and refusing to re-tool, redecorate, update or generally cave in to trends over the years.  This is the quintessential "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" food service establishment in St. Louis and an essential Route 66 stop. 

As long as I can remember, you could drive by Ted Drewes on any hot St. Louis summer night and see 60 or so people lined up at their 6 or 8 windows.  Sometimes the lines go almost into the street (and it's pretty busy).  For some locals being hit by a car while in line at Ted Drewes the perfect way to go.

Yes, it's all about nostalgia, but the frozen custard is also pretty good.  Okay, maybe Culver's is as good and a bit cheaper, but it's not a St. Lous thing like a visit to Ted's.  You also have to give kudo's for making this great dish before it was cool (no pun intended).

We went last week again after checking out the great St. Louis Hills Christmas lights.  In wintertime they sell trees (don't know anythying about this - we use fakes), but the ice cream is still for sale.  Seeing those ultra charming St. Louis Hills homes, Christmas lights and Ted Drewes all in one evening?  Well, it doesn't get more St. Louis than that.  

I hope you're not still wondering whether to go.  We're talking maybe ten bucks here - just do it.  I was going to give it just four stars, but I could never show my face before the Arch again if I did.
This is a hometown staple and I have to visit every time I come back.  Always good - it's never, ever changed.

For my recent trip to St. Louis, Ted Drewes was on my list of places to stop by even though it was freezing outside without a bit of sunshine. My friends and I originally went to the other location because it was closer to where we were. But to our disappointment, the other location was closed and it told us to go to this location, which was about a 10-15 minute drive, depending on traffic. We got there and saw that Ted Drewes is a historic tourist spot to visit on Route 66 so we knew we were in for a real treat!

The menu can be overwhelming especially since I wanted to try everything. With the help of the lady taking my order, I narrowed down my choices and ordered the fox treat. And it was amazing. I really enjoyed the fresh fruits in my sundae but I think I wouldn't get the fudge next time because it became a bit too sweet towards the end.

My friends and I ran into a local as we were leaving and she said that this place is amazing and she has been going here once a month for as long as she can remember! This place is definitely a must see if you are visiting STL!

WOOOOOOOOO

When I drove cross country from California to Illinois to go to college, I drove an extra 250 miles to go through St.Louis (my hometown) so that I could stop at Ted Drewes.
It's that good.

This place is great!!! Lots of variety and so hard to choose what to get. I ended up getting the Strawberry Shortcake w/ caramel and nuts on top! Oooh, it was so delicious. My husband got the Christy which is a brownie w/ custard and chocolate and caramel....I think, he said it was pretty good too, but mine was better :). The kids also loved it.

Coming straight from Cecil Whittaker's I was worried about having enough room. Luckily the large s'more concrete just filled in the gaps nicely! Still jonesing for more of that wonder-substance! Pulling in, the place looked like a zoo, but the line was extremely fast. So don't be scared if that's what you see.

Another great place to try if you're looking for some frozen yogurt. I think it speaks volumes that even though it's the middle of winter people were still flowing into get their fix of frozen treats. I ordered the Cindy, which I think was perfect for the weather because of the hot fudge and caramel. The custard is really thick and creamy, something this place is famous for. There are plenty of options to choose from for anyone to find something to enjoy. Definitely worth trying if you're in the area!

To visit St. Louis and not have frozen custard from Ted Drewes would be a traveling faux pas.  For over 70 years, they have been putting smiles on faces on both kids and adults.  Their custard base is not overly sweetened, resulting in a smooth and fresh frozen custard.  They only serve Vanilla, so if you want other flavors, you'll have to get them mixed in via a Concrete, Milkshake or through a Sundae.  There are over 12 Frozen Custard Shops in the St. Louis area, but before you try the rest, you have to try the acclaimed best!

Yum yum yum! I've only been twice, but it's enough to stick in my memory and cause me to argue for a visit every time I'm in town. Culpepper's for dinner, then Ted Drewes for dessert - I'm a happy man. I've never seen them without lines 6 deep, and that's with 6 or 8 windows operating! Still, they move quickly and prices are amazingly good, so it's definitely worth it. Ted Drewes has been a local fixture for so long that you'll see 3 generations of people hanging around eating and chatting - there's no seating, so it's either standing or sitting on the hood/trunk of your car. (With that many people milling around parking can be challenging.)

The frozen custard itself is amazing. Delicious and as smooth and rich as the highest-quality ice cream you've ever had. A large range of excellent toppings and mix-ins are available. I thought my tart cherry and hot fudge ("Cardinal Sin") was good until I tried my dad's raspberry; if he hadn't turned his back on me and walked away (!) after my one bite, he might not have gotten any more. ("We could share it, we could!") I guess ol' Dad's not so dumb after all...

Very efficient and very popular. Several windows and a lot of people working. I a very residential neighborhood and kind of out of the way. Custard is just vanilla soft serve, and they mix other stuff in but they have a ton of stuff to mix in. Doesn't compare to local small batch ice cream, but worth a visit and I can see myself doing it if I lived here.

Thank god our road trip took us through St. Louis just for the Ted Drewes alone!

Located in kind of a suburban area, this location is easy to get to and has ample parking. Staff is nice and prices are fair.

My oreo concrete was delicious. The perfect combination of creamy, cool, refreshing, and tasty on a hot day.

I wish I had the time and the ware-withall to have eaten this immediately instead of hitting the road to make time.  That one is my fault entirely. However, we did not.

We got to Ted Drewes on a Tuesday morning, 10 minutes before it opened, and we were the 8 and 9th people in line.  In June.  Yes, it's that popular.  By the time it openned, there were about 20 people in line, and about half of the people seemed to be first timers, because half went to the back of the line, and the other half asked "Why we weren't just getting our ice cream already," or "Why do you say I'm not in line? I just decided to stand next to the window and ignore the other 20 people who look like they're patiently waiting..."

By the time I was trying to plow through my blueberry concrete, it was about 10-15 minutes after it was put into the cup. The top was melted like crazy, and was a complete mess. The blueberries were a great addition though, and the flavor was solid.  I just really wanted to try the texture of the concrete as it was intended.  I thought it was a little on the sweet side, but I also know that was in part due to me waiting on eating it.  If I didn't wait 5 minutes, I am 80% sure that the sweetness would have been spot on.

My husband got the new pomegranate concrete, and well, he pretty much drank his.  It did taste good, but I wish I wish I wish we ate them faster.

What's to say about Ted Drewes? It's delicious. I like the Cindermint concrete and the Johnny Rabbit concrete. On Friday  night I had the Johnny Rabbit (cherries and chocolate chips). Yum! I took my grandmother and she had the Terramizzou. She was thrilled and hadn't been there in years. Go there. It's delicious!

This place is an institution, and worth visiting, and very yummy.  What is a concrete?  It's frozen custard, and they mix the toppings within like a blizzard.  Go for one of the multiple signature creations or make your own.  This place gets crowded on certain nights as it is quite famous.

I've now visited a half-dozen different frozen custard places, and while I recognize this is pretty much "the original" and the mecca of frozen custard fans...I still think all of it tastes basically the same!  However, Ted Drewes wins in the toppings department.  I've never found such great combos or extensive topping selection (pistachios!) at a custard shop.  I also really liked their graphics on the cups, building and signs.  Prices right in line with other similar chains, and much faster service even though they were packed!

Am I the only St. Louisian who thinks Ted Drewes is just a little overrated? Just me? Okay. 

The custard is good -- not exceptional -- good. 

I'll give them credit for having exceptionally speedy service.

Oh, Ted Drewes--want to touch the heiney!

I am not from St. Louis.  My husband is.  Ted Drewes on the ol' Route 66 is perhaps the first place we stopped on my first trip to The Lou, which just happened to be in the dead of winter.  Why, in the dead of winter with a parking lot full of Christmas trees, were there loads of people in line for more coldness?  Why?  Because it is damn amazing, that's why.  And really freakin' fast.  

Don't let the line frighten or deter you, 'cause it's just one short wait before creamy dairyland bliss.  My first concrete (basically a blizzard, but with better chunks and handed to you upside down to demonstrate its concrete-ity) had real peach slices swirled through the vanilla custard and is tied for my favorite concrete with the TeDad's--local St. Louis oatmeal cookies are mixed into that tasty treat.

I love that the place runs like a well-oiled machine by teenagers working towards a Ted Drewes-sponsored college scholarship and that you can buy cartons of the stuff for your own enjoyment--we even had some at our rehearsal dinner!  Even better, they'll pack a pile of frozen custard with dry ice so it survives the trip from STL to Chicago.

Yeah, I know STLians are sort of fanatical about Ted Drewes (but that's sort of normal from what I can tell, because they're basically fanatical about anything STL in general), but this is not unfounded loyalty and love.  I used to say that a trip to STL was wasted unless we visited my frozen custard heaven... now my love/hate relationship with lactose limits the visits I can handle.  Even with the belly aches, though, every trip to Ted Drewes is so worth it.

*Edit* 2/5/08

How dare you, Ted Drewes.  I move to St. Louis in the dour month of January and you're CLOSED?  WHAT???  And now it's February and you're STILL CLOSED?  Geez, if I'd known better, I woulda stayed in Chicago til Spring!  Bah.

Our fantastic tour guide Jan brought us here last night.  After roaming the virtually deserted streets of downtown St Lou for a few hours, it was rather shocking to turn the corner and see such a massive amount of people crammed around this place.  So THIS is the place to be!

After trying to decide what in the world to order, and thinking I had oodles of time considering the lines, I was quickly jolted back into reality when I suddenly found myself face to face with a girl behind the counter demanding to know what I wanted.  Scrambling to decide I finally blurted out "Uncle Sam", not knowing really what that was.

Oh but what a choice it had been!  A giant (I am talking bigger than a Ben and Jerry's container) cup full of vanilla custard, topped with shortcake, strawberries, blueberries and whipped cream.  Everything was ridiculously fresh, and insanely sweet and delicious.  I made it through a bit over half when I had to wave the white flag.  If you are a sweets fan you will definitely be in heaven coming here.

I can see why this place is so popular.  There are so many different flavours, and combinations that it easily could take you a lifetime to try them all. As Andy said "oh, so they are printing money back there huh?"  They might as well be seeing as what an awesome business model they have going on.  We will definitely be back, someone here mentioned a pumpkin pie flavour which I must try!!

One night in St. Louis, and my traveling companion suggested we stop here.  Given the temperature, I was up for something cold and expecting long lines.  Apparently, Monday around noon is not prime Ted Drewes time - which was lucky for us as we were nearly melting ourselves.  Plenty of parking and no line - just walked up to the window and ordered a concrete and a chocolate dipped cone which were rapidly produced.

Now, apparently, one is supposed to be able to prove the thickness of said concrete by turning the thing upside down and watching it not fall to the ground.  Given the temperature, the beating sun sucking our will to live, and the rapidly melting nature of the product, we were too chicken to try this.

It was good frozen custard.  Not great, not legendary, but excellent on a hot day.  People were friendly, I didn't get too much melted stuff on my shirt.  They have a cool sign about them and Route 66 and history in the parking lot.

While in St. Louis, I had to make the pilgrimage to Ted's. There's just something about a long-time business on Route 66 that makes it much more special.

There was a massive queue when I arrived, but it moved surprisingly quick. I had no idea what to order. The menu is extensive and I hadn't read any tips on the "must try" other than the Concrete. Other customers in the queue discussed their order, and the popular flavor appeared to be vanilla or coffee. I went with the latter.

My Concrete was delicious! Custard is much creamier and thicker than normal ice cream. I do wish I had added some toppings, particularly the free banana they offer during summertime. The concept reminded me of the Dairy Queen Blizzard, however, Ted's has been around much longer making it the original treat. Plus it was tastier, in my opinion.

If you're a tourist making a pilgrimage to Ted's:
 - Get a medium Concrete, vanilla or coffee. Pick ONE add in.
 - Cost: $3.50

Simply the best!  I had been to St. Louis twice before but never made it out here.  This time Im glad I did!  I got a Hawaiin which is custard, pineapple, coconut, banana and macadamia nuts!  Good lord!!  This thing was packed to the brim with all those things and it was simply AMAZING!

I really couldn't believe that a day in November at 9pm at night there were about 25-30 people outside this obvious locally beloved establishment.

Then, I had "The Great Pumpkin" concrete. Now I know the reason why.

In short, it was a loving spoonful in every bite. It was a delicious pumpkin custard with chunks of pie in it topped with lots of whipped cream. My sister got "The Big Apple" and was just as amazing except it was apple pie flavored. 

I would probably freeze my ass off and stand in line like I'm sure the locals do for a taste for more of this in the dead of winter. To the people of St. Louis, you all are so lucky... but I'm pretty sure you all knew that already!

Anyone that lives in St. Louis is well aware of Ted Drew's. Just as a local is familiar with fried ravioli, this is a staple to the St. Louis history. When you drive up, anytime of they day when they are open you fill find a crowd of people standing around, in line and eating ice cream. 

Don't let the crown make you nervous. Just go get in one of 15 lines and you will have your frozen custard in no time. They staff heavy and they move quickly. 

This is up there with an almost "Must Do" when in St. Louis so don't pass it up.

You would think no one would want to try frozen custard during the chilly November time. To my surprise, there was definitely enough crowd to keep the business going even though the temperature was approximately 45 - 50 F.

I have tried a lot of ice cream and frozen yogurt places in the Los Angeles area, but never have I tried a frozen custard before. My 1st order was a big apple concrete (apple pie mixed with vanilla custard topped with whipped cream) for $3.7. The word "concrete" (or blended custard) definitely lived up to its name - vanilla custard was really, REALLY thick. I personally didn't like big apple concrete because I felt like I was eating frozen apple pie more than enjoying the flavor of vanilla custard. The flavor of apple pie simply overshadowed the flavor of vanilla custard. I guess if anyone likes apple pie, then definitely order big apple concrete! 

So I decided to order again and this time I ordered a peach concrete. In addition to mini ($2.3), regular ($3.7), and large ($5) sizes, there is another size called "micro" (it's not shown on the menu) for less than $2 with tax - basically micro is smaller version of mini. I really like my peach concrete. You can taste the peach and overall sweetness is just right. Now that's what I called yummy! 

Screw the cold weather, I am more than happy to come back here and try even more concretes. However, I do think you're going to find some hits and misses here.

This is the best custard I have ever tasted! I was expecting it to be really heavy and too sweet, but it was lighter and the perfect consistency- I could actually eat the entire thing. Also, you can hold it upside down for a couple seconds, and it won't all out. There are so many flavors and special combinations that they offer. I got the Hawaiin one (macadamia nuts, pineapple, and coconut), but I would recommend the "Blues" custard- it's lemon blueberry and is sooo amazing. It was pretty crowded at 9PM at night, but the service was quick. Definitely coming back here the next time I'm in St. Louis.

Date night date night!!! I am truly a romantic, when I arrived at Ted Drewes I was immediately brought down to earth by the semi cult following of friendly custard lovers, a sparkling night sky, pretty neon lights and their old fashion push lettered menus. The lines at first glance appear long and crazy, but once you get closer you realize they are just people crowding around enjoying their custards, we literally only waited 5 minutes in line and I thought for sure it was going to be a half an hour wait at least. I was overwhelmed, constantly checking the yelp page to get ideas of what to order, asking others what they were savoring, and my friend Sam made a simple suggestion of getting the mint and oreo combo. I was skeptical, after all how can one pass up the decadent Christie or Uncle Sam... I was very pleased with the Mint Oreo and my only regret is that I didn't get a medium but rather went with a small because I was trying to be good. It was very velvety and delicious. We tailgated in Sam's '85 Toyota Land Cruiser and indulged in Saint Louis's finest. 

The Rasberry flavor is also very delicious, simply classy and clean. I liked the Christie, but it was a bit too rich for me, it was almost too chocolaty and thick. The Uncle Sam was great, but very sweet. Some other patrons were enjoying the oreo and vanilla and when I told them I was getting mint and oreo they were just mind blown and said they wish they had ordered that... so apparently it's a secret delicious combo! 

The reason why I said 'date night date night' at the beginning of this review is because Ted Drewes, this location in particular, is romantic... the location, the lights, friendly visitors, and honestly what more could one want other than to enjoy a delicious treat with your loved one(s) under a bed of stars... I rest my case. Enjoy!
You have to try a legendary place like this.  Don't be scared of the lines.  They go fast!!  The concrete treats are MUCH better than DQ!!  My strawberry shake was excellent as well!

Will drive from West County anytime someone wants a Ted Drew's concrete.  Oreo is boss but every once and awhile a Dutchman's Delight is in order.  They will pack to go orders we dry ice if you ask.  Long lines only make it taste better ;).  The workers are amazing and friendly.   A STL institution.

I absolutely love Ted Drews! It's one of the best frozen custard in STL! I've tried almost everything there! To name a few must have is orange slush, Carmel apple sundae, strawberry shortcake, all shook up, and their pumpkin  yumm . I would highly recommend everyone trying out Ted Drews at least once in their life time! In the summer it can get extremely busy so now is a good time to go!

Super quick lines even though there are swarms of people all over.  Very friendly people in line willing to pet your dog while you wait, too.  We ordered a kiddie hot fudge sundae and a oatmeal cookie ice cream sandwich and spent less than $5.

There is extra parking in the lot across the street.  Or, there is street parking in front of the left lot (no one ever seems to park here until I show them its ok).

This is a STL landmark. You will never find better custard concretes anywhere. The only hard part is picking which flavor to get. I went with the tiramasu. Absolute heaven. My last day here, couldn't leave without one.  Next onto lunch, yes doing it backwards it's that good

For all y'all fro-yo lovers, once you have St. Louis custard, you'll never go back!!

Ted Drewes is a classic part of St. Louis - especially in the summer! My husband and I tend to get the concretes, not the sundaes, because we like have everything pre-mixed. They have tons of great mix-ins!! My husbands favorite is mint, brownie, cookie dough and hot fudge. I'm usually not a fan of mint when it comes to ice cream, but theirs in light and sweet and is one of my favorites! I try something different just about every time, but just about anything with the butterscotch is delicious! One I haven't tried is raspberry...I'm thinking I need to get that soon. Also, if you get more than a few mix-ins, they usually have to put it in a bigger cup, which is awesome because you feel like you're getting more than you paid for. On the other hand, I don't think I can get a medium/large any more - it's super filling!

This place can get pretty darn crowded. Parking can sometimes be a challenge, but the line always moves fast!

The only down side for me is the fact that they don't offer peanut butter as a mix-in!!! Ted Drewes, please add peanut butter to the list!!! Reese's just aren't enough! I need both!

If there's anything you need to know and worthy of visiting in the entire state of Missouri it's the Gateway Arch and Ted Drewes. Everything else is garbage (truth).

Endless amounts of flavors, toppings, and novelty mixtures this place was poppin' even at the last hour before closing. And if you're a tourist like me, you'll get a kick at how they flip your cup upside down and nothing falls out!  To my surprise, if there's anything non american about this place, it was the fact that it wasn't too sugary. Custard should not sugary anyways but hell this is America. But the cup sizes?! Get this: A small cup is equivalent to the size of a large or 'love it' bowl from Cold Stone Creamery. Their large is a whoppin' 32oz!

While in Nashville, a few locals from St. Louis told us they miss Ted Drewes the most.  We had to get there and we added it to our list.  It was pretty packed, but the lines moved fast.  A lot of options, but I had to go with a sundae.  Everything was good, but I didn't find anything that really made it stand out.  Perhaps because I'm spoiled in Philadelphia by so many other places.  Still, a decent place to stop by.

If you like ice cream, you'll love frozen custard. It reminds me of extremely dense soft serve, but with a rich flavor.  This place is so popular that it hired an armed security guard to keep the patrons in line during the chaos in the parking lot.  If you're visiting St. Louis, it's a must. If you can't make it, they have a vending machine at the airport.

Omg!!!  I've never had frozen custard before and this was amazing!!!!!!!!!  I had the strawberry shortcake one and WOW is all I have to say.  A definite must for anyone who's never tried it.  Plus it was quite a sight to see people tailgating in the parking lot at 9pm at night.  And no, there was no sporting event going on...

I love custard! Being a native Wisconsinite, I was afraid I wouldn't be able to find good custard in St Louis. Ted Drewes is almost as good as Wisconsin custard (we have 2 local custard shops in Metro Milwaukee, Oscar's and Kopp's...fabulous must tries if your in the Milwaukee area).

I've had a Pistachio and Reese's PBcup in a concrete. Concrete just means they blend it like a blizzard. It's hard to choose what to have...a sundae, shake, concrete, malt, etc...every flavor combination they have looks very good and the basic ingredient  (i.e. CUSTARD) is the BOMB so you can't go wrong. 

I would have to say though that I was slightly disappointed when I ordered a cookie sandwich. The cookie was an oatmeal cookie, I was expecting chocolate chip. It looked and tasted store bought, it was small, crispy and flat with a small amount of custard in the middle. However, it was only $1.25...so you get what you paid for. Don't waste your order on a cookie sandwich. Size wise, a regular is plenty big and depending on your appetite it could be shared by two. A regular seems to be about 2-3 cups of custard.

I know peopole really love this place and it's a cardinal sin to NOT like Ted Drewes...however, I've had custard before and this is not custard.  Real custard is smooth, silky, rich, delicious....fake custard is milky and not anything special. I mean, don't get me wrong,  I had the oreo/heath mixture and I still ate it, but it just wasn't custard.  Wisconsin has real custard, Missouri does not.

I've been here five brazillion times. It doesn't matter how long the lines are, there's never a long wait to give your order.

Sometimes I think they've got as many servers inside making your concoction as there are customers.

I usually get a small concrete: chocolate-banana or chocolate-strawberry -- gotta get your fruit, doncha know!

But one time I had a banana split for dinner. Man, was that good!!

We got there before 3 bus load of people arrived, whew. it was VERY VERY sweet but what isn't in St. Louis right? No seating. boo but it was fun to visit. there was a shop next to it called, Chocolate chocolate chocolate. didn't taste

Ted drewes is my favorite guilty pleasure treat. I have yet to be disappointed by any of their delicious concretes. Today I had a s'more concrete (marshmallow and chocolate with graham cracker pieces). A couple weeks ago i ordered the bunny concrete which was just like a carrot cake in frozen custard form :) My husband swears by their hot fudge sundae.

This place is AWESOME!!! I love the frozen custard at Ted Drewe's which is the best I've ever had in my life! When I'm traveling through the STL, I always make a sidetrip to Ted Drewe's for the rich creamy custard. My favorite custard flavors are the pistachio and chocolate. Ted Drewe's puts other custards I've had to shame. Since Ted Drewe's will never franchise and expand their operation, I'm looking very forward to another trip to St. Louis!

Most popular and delicious ice cream in St. Louis. The quality and consistency is always there. Sometime there can be a rather long line just drive down to the other location if you don't feel like waiting. St. Louis classic right here!

A classic place to visit while in St. Louis! I ordered The Christy while is a frosted brownie and the Ted Drewes classic vanilla custard. The brownie was hot so it started to melt quickly which forced me to eat it rather quickly. It was pretty crowded but we still got our order really fast!

Ted Drewes seems to be a St. Louis institution and man, I'm glad I was able to be schooled by their amazing custard and other delicious desserts.

Before visiting St. Louis, I Yelped which places (food naturally) I wanted to try. Ted's was number one on my list. As soon as I got my rental car we made a bee-line over to this location. Based on everything I read, we were probably in for a wait so better to go sooner rather than later.

Parking is a little tricky because the lot is small, but we were able to park in the neighborhood nearby and walk. Imagine being Ted Drewes' neighbor? The good and bad that comes with being so close to this widely popular spot.

Anyway, this place is such a throwback. It's super reminiscent of those 60's walk up eateries well, because you walk up, order and wait for them to stick their hand out of the screen with your item in it. Oh and yes, there were plenty of people huddled around, waiting for their custard or ice cream. I will say, the line moved really quickly and before you knew it, we were ordering.

So this place is more than just custard. They've got malts, shakes, concretes (those super thick things that you can hang upside down and it doesn't fall out of your cup), sundaes, floats, ice cream soda. What do you get? Can I get one of each? Technically, I shouldn't be eating any of this but I have to try it.

 I ended up with their apple pie sundae which was apple pie topped with custard and caramel and almonds. Wow. The custard was amazing. I see why the line was ridiculously long because the wait is worth it. The portion was huge but it was just the right size to curb any sweet tooth craving I had and I think I paid $4-$5 for it so my wallet wasn't stabbed either.

The weather was perfect so we walked around the area, eating our "Drewes" and enjoying our first moment in St. Louis.

You must go to this location (don't buy this stuff from the airport which they do sell there). Get it fresh. Get the full experience. You'll love it for sure.

Ted Drewes was recommended by several people, and I'm so happy we had a chance to stop by! The line moved quickly, and the frozen custard was delicious. It seemed to be a popular stop for many people that night - families, Little League teams, people coming from the Cardinals game. 

Glad we got to experience a piece of classic St. Louis!

Stop #18 on my "Eating my way through Chicago/St. Louis and possibly doing other things on this trip Summer Tour 2011" found me looking for something cold to eat in the St. Louis heat.  My travel food book pointed in this general direction.  I really didn't need it as frozen custard is one of my favorite things ever.  For reals.

Apparently it is the favorite thing for many people as this place was packed in the middle of the day on a Tuesday.  Do people work anymore?  Maybe everyone was on vacation like me.  Or not.  Who knows?

Ted Drewes needs to have a swimming pool filled with custard to jump in.  I would totally have done that if given the option to do such a thing.  Since they don't, you'll just have to eat it.  The Concrete was the way I was going on this trip.  Basically they start out with Vanilla frozen custard and combine it with a list of flavors.  You name it, they probably have it.  Anything from Abaco Mocha (whatever that is) to Tart Cherry.  I went simple.  Chocolate.  I'm a purist that way.  I did get the large one because baby it was hot outside and I needed something cold to beat the heat.  The perfect cure to those summertime blues.

Ted Drewes is an institution.  Don't leave St. Louis without trying some of their custard.

When I was in Madison a few weeks ago, I got off the highway and drove about 11 miles to eat soft serve at a chain I'd previously eaten at in Beloit or Kenosha.  I'm not going to identify that chain, because it will undermine the legitimacy of this review.  

Anyway, the coolest thing about Ted's, to me, was seeing some hat that Jack Clark (Cards slugger for a few years in the 1980s; booed out of New York in 1987 for clubbing 27 HR before Barry juice) had scribbled on.  This was probably random, but I like to imagine that Jack Clark's signed hat was the most visible in the pile by design.  

That is to say that the frozen custard didn't really make it for me.  Maybe it's because the Grand St location wasn't yet open for the season, so I really built it up in my head on the drive over to Chippewa.  More likely it was because I got an unmanageably large "regular" concrete (on the scale of obesity promotion offensiveness, it ranks just below Burger King's offering "ribs").  And the "concrete" turned to creamy foam within a few bites.

I mean, no, it wasn't spectacular.  I wasn't bummed out that I got it, because I had about four hours to kill before my flight.  And I did eat about two-thirds of it.  Just that I could talk about ice cream, frozen treats, and custard for hours, and I'd mention a lot of names and memories (the old Sedutto's of Staten Island, the days when Yankee Stadium still sold Steve's bars, Bassetts) before I'd mention Ted.

Unless Jack Clark is showing up any time soon.  I might fly back to shake his hand.  And I'd surely eat a concrete again if I did.

This is a "Don't-Miss" if you are in St. Louis.  My first experience with frozen custard and "concrete" met every expectation and I'd gladly go back for more!  It's called "concrete" because it's so thick that you can turn it upside-down and nothing falls out.

There can be a long line and large crowds, but that's only because it's so great!  

Along with the Gateway Arch and seeing a Cards game at New Busch, this was one of the memorable points of my trip to St. Louis!

I've tried to come back to you this year Ted, but it just isn't working for me anymore. 
Your custard isn't as thick and creamy as it once was and your staff is developing attitude. 

You are no longer the only custard in town, you now have competition and they are all serving up a better product. Even Andy the new boy in town is providing a superior cup or cone of custard. 

I know I am giving a big thumbs down to a St. Louis institution, but it really isn't that good, guys and gals.

People in St. Louis are crazy.  When we visited Ted's, it was right around lunch time.  And there were about a billion people here.  Apparently, St. Louis people enjoy custard for lunch.  

We shared a pistachio custard.  In the heat, it quickly became a little melty.  Good thing is was in a cup, otherwise, we would have a serious issues on our hands.  The flavor was really good and I liked the grittiness of all the nuts!  One visit and I'm a fan.  Great place.

This is one of the city's most famous places.  It's known for its frozen custard and it's concretes.  With concretes, you mix their custard with ingredients and it's so thick that it maintains its shape even when you flip it upside down.  

I ordered their southern delight.   With this, they mixed their custard with caramel and pecan praline.  If you order their fruity concretes, then you'll get pieces of fruit mixed into the custard.  Nice touch.

 It was delicious and it was refreshing on a humid day.  I was just surprised by how quickly it melted.  But, overall, it tasted really good and it was perfect after a long day of road tripping.

The Gold standard in my opinion!  Every other frozen custard I taste I compare to good old Ted Drewes and very few come close.  There is just something about the smoothness of the custard and all the available toppings that make this the best.  Yes I understand there is a lot of hype associated with Route 66 and of course the Food Network and Travel Channel visits, but if you are visiting St. Louis you MUST try Ted Drewes at least once.
My first Ted Drewes experience was under the arch during the VP Fair when I was a teenager.  Since then I've brought family, classmates, coworkers, girlfriends, and out of town relatives to the custard stand on Chippewa, all without one "meh".  
I do remember one summer visiting Ted Drewes so often with a friend that she ran out of different flavors to try so she ordered the "magnet" flavor!  Ok maybe that was a little much.
My favorites still end up being the "Crater Copernicus" and the "All Shook up."

Needless to say you can find me here many a summer nights and after most Cardinal games!

This place is really good and always packed with customers because they're so good! It's actually pretty close to my house so I go often. Not the best frozen custard I've ever had but it's still really good

Best. Ice cream. Ever. You haven't had the true St. Louis experience without seeing the Arch, Busch Stadium, eating some toasted ravs, and getting some Ted Drews frozen custard. Order from the menu or create your own. I personally love the Fox Treat sundae (light on the hot fudge) or a mint oreo concrete or even a tried and true vanilla cone. Don't be intimidated by the lines, they move very quickly and are a part of the experience. And after you've ordered find a spot to sit and enjoy--preferably the tailgate or trunk of your car. If you get it to-go don't forget the dry ice--even as an adult I still get a kick out of making a witches brew in the kitchen sink.

It's been 2 1/2 years since I was last in St. Louis, MO and my wife and I still reminisce about Ted Drewe's frozen custard.  The stars must have been aligned that day because the chances of us just randomly searching out this place was next to nil.  We just happened to be in St. Louis for the U2 concert (360 tour), just happened to have a Route 66 guide book featuring this roadside attraction and just happened to check the Yelp reviews on my I-phone.

That being said, we purposely took a side excusion on Route 66 to visit this landmark of frozen bliss.  It was a warm June day in 2010 and a frozen custard sounded like the perfect summer treat.  What an understatement.  Neither my wife nor I had ever experienced frozen custard, but we both love ice cream so we decided to try it.  Besides, it's been located on Route 66 (the Mother Road) since 1941 and has been a St. Louis landmark since 1929; so it had to be good.  

Part of the appeal was the old world charm of a small wooden building with no seating to speak of and a parking lot full of people chatting while they waited to be served.  We were not disappointed, as the custard, was rich and velvety; and left you wanting more. The only downside was that we were only going to be in town for 2 days and this ended up being our one and only visit.

If you find yourself within 50 miles of this place, do yourself a favor and exit the freeway to enjoy one of the finest frozen desserts you'll ever taste.

Hands down the best custard I have ever had dance on my tongue...It was oh so creamy and good....I got the heath bar and i am ready to go back and eat my way across the menu...One thing that would be fabulous if they offered a flight of flavors and had like 5-6 dixie cup sizes so you can try many flavors at once.....

I will make sure I take all my out of town guest here ----custard does not get any better than this!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I'd heard about this place when starting to tell people that I was visiting St. Louis, so I decided to try it out. We pulled up to the shop, and although there were a good amount of people there, there were still a few parking spots available in the lot. That was nice, as parking is often difficult in cities.

They have a lot of different flavors, plus the option to choose your own. My wife and I each got a micro, and it was a good amount. Tasty and smooth, although mine wouldn't have been "concrete" because the hot fudge started melting it. Still, a nice treat at a reasonable price!

I still think Ted Drewes is ridiculously overrated. 

However, I am a pumpkin addict, and when I heard endless praise about Ted Drewes' pumpkin concrete (The Great Pumpkin), I thought I'd give them another try. 

Oh, and I still have about $30 left on the Ted Drewes gift card my mom gave me TWO YEARS AGO. Heh. 

Taste-wise, the pumpkin concrete is spot on. I loved it. 

However, even on the cool day I purchased it (seriously, it wasn't even 70 degrees), it started melting pretty much immediately. I savored the one bite I took, and promptly stuck it in the freezer at home. 

After a few hours in the freezer, it was acceptable. But seriously...should I really have to do this every time? 

It's a good thing my gift card doesn't expire. I have a feeling it's going to take me a long long time to burn through the rest of it. 

Color me unimpressed.

Plethora of awesome frozen custard choices and some creative ones!  (See menu) 

We loved the twisted salted caramel, Root 66 (subtle malt and root beer) and S'mores (vanilla custard with marshmallow cream and fudge and graham cracker) 

Watch where you walk while you are in custard coma- it's a very busy parking lot!

Yesterday in St. Louis the winter sky was heavy with rain and thick, dark clouds.  Temperatures were just above freezing, and the wind blew dirty water from every direction onto the windshield and blocked my view of the highway.  

Despite the obstacles that Mother Nature placed in my way to thwart my quest for Ted Drewes frozen custard, I succeeded in navigating the potholes and dangerous streets of St. Louis to accomplish my mission.  It was during summer, 17 years ago that I last indulged in Ted Drewes.  It was time for another rendez-vous with Mr. Drewes' thick and creamy goodness.  

My California-raised boyfriend had never seen a frozen lake or ever tasted frozen custard until yesterday.  Despite the admitted tastiness of the concrete, it still was less impressive than a flock of Canadien geese walking across an icy lake.

My large concrete (frozen vanilla custard with fudge and pistachios mixed in) was served in a waxed paper cup that was approximately 8 inches tall.  As always, the concrete was thick enough to stay put in the cup after the teenager mixed it all together and turned the cup upside down.   The taste?  Smooth.  Sweet.  Nutty.  Fudgy.  Disappointing.  I only ate about 2 or 3 inches of concrete before putting it back in the cup holder and contemplating attacking the leftover White Castle hamburgers in the back seat.

For 17 years, Ted Drewes grew into a greater legend in my mind than it turned out to be in reality.  It was great to continue the St. Louis tradition of feeding one's sweet tooth (which I do not actually have, but my boyfriend has a mouthful of) at Ted Drewes, but I can say that I won't be particularly distressed to wait another 17 years until my next visit.

If you live in St. Louis, Ted Drewes on the old Route 66 is a destination that you really shouldn't miss.  If you're going to St. Louis for a short visit, don't try to hard to squeeze it into your itinerary.  You might be disappointed by the return after considering the monumental effort it takes to get down there.
It's been quite a few years now, Ted.  But, tonight, I was craving you big time.

This place is a St. Louis institution and one of the few things I miss about the town where I went to college.  It is always crowded in the summer and with good reason -- their "concretes" kick ass.  They are kinda like a DQ Blizzard on steroids.  Mix in whatever you want and enjoy.

Well.. The ever famous Ted Drewes. Lines do eventually form for these frosty treats, and I will say the popularity of this place is super noticeable when you arrive. The Hubbster and I were only looking at the wall menu for about 2 mins, when plenty of customers strolled on by.. I was wondering though.. what is so great about this place??

Since the Hubbster and I were new to STL and its comfort foods, we were absolutely willing to try all the good eats around town. Word of mouth from my in-laws, was that Ted Drewes was awesome. We were super excited to try it. Once we got there, I felt completely overwhelmed with that menu.. It seemed self explainable, but some flavors were just WAY out there with no details on exactly what it is.. The hubbster was considering just a plain mint, but had to definitely research all of the other wondrous flavors and specials like Cindermint, Tedads, the Christy, or a Terramizzou (which is not an incorrect spelling of Tiramisu) Believe me, it really was total research of standing aside and being one of those annoying customers of asking what each flavor consists of, but the staff was very friendly and energetic.. Yes I felt so touristy..but I guess it keeps the fun in trying out any of the frozen custards.

Nonetheless, we went with something tame and it had to be a "concrete" which basically means the custard consistency is thick, and it wont spill out,  so the S'mores flavor was something we knew and could handle. To our dismay, it was not anything amazing. It was very creamy, and you could see the bits of graham and chocolate. Being a frozen custard.. I just don't know what I am missing exactly. I have had custard before in pies, with ice cream and Italian Ice.. not sure what makes this stand out in presentation, creativity or just taste. 

Perks: Great portion for the $. Nice location on the street for a sidewalk stop. Also an official Route 66 Roadside attraction. 

Downsides: Long lines, but does move fairly quick. Menu can be overwhelming especially if its your very first time. 

Awesome TIP: The "concrete" way is the best way. Locals vouch for it.

OverALL: A-OK. Awesome for locals, but its a hit or miss. It wasn't EPIC for me, but it wasn't horrible. It was definitely a nice cool down from driving around town and sight seeing.

Walking here and back home, helps me justify the calories.
(Round trip is about 5 miles)
My favorite concrete is M & M's, for some reason - I just keep ordering it time again and again. I also like raspberry.
However, every year my first order is always just a dish of the custard plain - to experience the best frozen custard in the Midwest.
Whatever your favorite is, it will make a great concrete or sundae. You'll also enjoy checking out all the celebrity autographs in the window

Lately I've been seeing a ton of Ted Drewes commercials about how thick their concretes are.  The commercials paid off, because the hubby and I went for concretes because we had Ted Drewes on the mind.  Man was it busy!  Parking could be an issue, but the turnover is pretty quick.

The lines looked long, but it took no more than 10 minutes to get to the register, order and get our concretes.  I don't know how anyone eats a large concrete from TD, but lots of people had them...that would be a belt stretcher dessert for sure.    

I went with a mini, their small, concrete mixed with raspberry.  The hubby went with a medium Reese PB-cup.  I have to say, that commercial is a joke because unless it's below 60 degrees or colder out or your inside with air-conditioning, that frosty treat is gonna melt before you can turn it upside-down.  By the time I had it in my hand it was already melting around the edges and I wasn't going to risk loosing my dish of custard just to test my point.  

Good custard, but maybe a little overrated if your not from St Louis...which I am not, because I still think no custard beats Wisconsin's.

I've watched Ted Drewes on Travel Channel over and over, so I just HAD to go there to see/taste it for myself (despite of lukewarm reaction from my boyfriend's family members).

We got there around 11 am. There was no line, so we proceeded to order promptly. My boyfriend got Cardinal Sin, and I got Pumpkin Pie. They were both yummy; however, they weren't as solid or shall I say "concrete" as I thought they would be. Is it because they had mix-ins? Or is it because it was 11:00 in the morning? Well, they were good but not the best custard I've ever tasted.

Notwithstanding, I'll go back there and try different flavours if an opportunity arises.

When you know a place is great, explore. I've had gallons of Ted Drewes over the years, but the best thing I have ever done is to try new things. And I've never been disappointed. Often, I ignore the menu and just look for the decorated notecards in the windows. These are the new or different selections.

Tonight I ordered "the Christy," an iced brownie sundae with caramel and hot fudge. I added some marshmallow cream for good measure. It was rich and creamy, with a little salty kick from the caramel.

Whenever I'm in St. Louis, I always pay a visit to Ted Drewes. Sometimes two visits.

Next up, the iconic Ted Drewes, a spot I'm actually surprised I did not visit even in my youth given its fame but a location that was perfectly situated in our eating agenda following a nearly 100 degree afternoon at the Missouri Botanical Garden.  Featuring frozen custard in a single flavor - vanilla - with hundreds of possible combinations of mix-ins to formulate your own customized concrete we were fortunate to arrive at an off-hour and after opting for four "Micromini" cups at $1.80 each the selections were packed in a bag with blocks of ice and spoons putting us back in the air conditioned car to enjoy less than 10 minutes after pulling off Route 66.

Soft, smooth, rich, and not overly sweet on its own I will admit that I did not flip the cup over to see just how "concrete" the concoction was, but certainly thicker than standard softserve despite the heat and humidity I've little doubt all but the melted portion would have stayed put.  Skipping the sundaes or options with too many variable and instead going with two fruit options but two choices suggested by the young woman at the counter I personally found the Tedad and Blueberry to both be excellent while the butterscotch was a bit thin and the sour cherry too artificial.  A fun spot and one of those "must visit" landmarks I cannot say I'd go out of my way for Ted Drewes, but I definitely wouldn't drive past it on a cross country trip - particularly in the middle of summer.

This place offers superb custard for great value. This place can get crowded but they have so many windows so it actually moves pretty smoothly. I tried the strawberry shortcake. It comes in a cup and it has a cake that is topped with vanilla custard, strawberry sauce, strawberries, and whipped cream. This was heaven galore. I devoured this sugary goodness with the quickness even though it was much larger than i expected. The custard is smooth creamy, not too hard and it is very flavorful. A big 2 thumbs up here.

Somehow we ended up going for custard while it was 29°F outside, which is probably not the optimal time to visit an outdoor frozen dessert stand.  But it was worth it to introduce a newbie to Ted Drewes and the world of midwestern custard.

I always try to find out what foods/restaurants are special to locals in an area, and my MO friends swear by Ted Drewes.  So when a new colleague came with us on a business trip and said she didn't know the difference between ice cream and custard... we knew what needed to be done.

There's something about their custard that is the right combination of rich and creamy and flavorful.  I'm a sucker for a concrete (let's face it, plain custard is pretty boring), and they've got so many flavors to choose from!  It's all vanilla custard, but you barely notice once it's been mixed up with all sorts of toppings.  This time I got the Dutchman, because I love pecans and butterscotch.  It was soooo good, I almost forgot I was freezing (almost).

A few things keep me from giving them the last star.  One: I really wish they also had chocolate.  I'm a chocoholic and some concretes would just be better with chocolate as the base.  Two:  I know the walk-up model is popular and classic, but I'd love more places to keep warm if they're going to serve custard in sub-freezing temps.  Three:  the smallest size concrete is still a lot of custard.  I'm not a cheapskate, I just don't want to eat an entire meal of custard.  Calling a size "micro" that's still like 12oz is laughable.  I threw out half of it and would rather have just not wasted that food.  

The lines move fast, and they've got lots of menus and signs posted so you can think about what you're going to order in advance.  They make everything pretty fast, too.

I love ice cream and I adore frozen custard for its richness.  If you want really good frozen custard, come to Ted Drewes.  

I had never heard of Ted Drewes before I moved to St Louis, but I was quickly introduced into the world of the concrete - custard so thick its like concrete.  There are some interesting combination but I'm a purist.  I really just like the vanilla.  Plain and simple but so rich and creamy.  

Its still a must visit place when I go and visit.  Ok.  Its still a must visit every day place =)

My GAWD I miss Ted Drewes, I know this review is a couple of months late, but forgive me....

This Ted Drewes is still my preferred location over South Grand. South Grand is nice and was convenient to where I lived, but you just can't beat the one on Chippewa. You can't.

What do I love about Ted Drewes you ask? 

- I love their flavors. Granted you can only get vanilla custard, but who cares! It is so orgasmic good! 

- Though slightly pricey, you definitely get bang for your buck. Quality and enjoyment out of a cup of happiness. You couldn't ask for better.

- They offer amazing seasonal flavors. Just to name a few I am in love with -- apple pie, strawberry shortcake (mmmmmmmmm, or is that year round?), pumpkin pie, apple caramel, and the list is endless.

Hands down the best frozen custard in St. Louis... not to be confused or categorized as ice cream. 

I love you, Teddy! If only you had a location in Washington DC would my sugary goodness heart be fulfilled.

There is nothing in the world as good as this place for genuine frozen custard. Make no mistake...this is not ice cream, it's frozen custard. 

I've been coming here for years! My recommendations:

HAWAIIAN DELIGHT-Concrete or sundae with pineapple, bananas, coconut and macadamia nuts.

SOUTHERN DELIGHT - A concrete or sundae with praline pecans and butterscotch yumminess 

CARDINAL SIN - A concrete or sundae with tart cherries and thick hot fudge

ALL SHOOK UP - A concrete or sundae with Reese's® peanut butter cups and bananas Elvis style

TERRAMIZZOU - A concrete or sundae with pistachios and Ted's secret blend of chocolate

Mmmmmmm! Drooling.

Ted Drewes is pretty awesome. Yes, it is definitely overhyped But still awesome nonetheless. I first came here when I was a freshman at SLU and I didn't think it was very special. But flashforward to a week ago when Sean took me here after dinner at Aya's. Omg, so tasty. I had the Great Pumpkin (which I have since had twice more) and it was sooo good. Pumpkin frozen custard with chunks of pumpkin PIE in it? Holy crap. Unfffff! The only downside is that it can get insanely crowded and you have to be careful when you're driving in and out of here lest you be bowling for children. Also every time I have gone, my custard was practically melted by the time I got it. It needs to be much colder and more "solid" in my opinion but since I live in St. Charles I can't really get it to a freezer in time, unless I buy the generic vanilla in the yellow tub from Walgreens down the road... lol.

Also I am glad they take credit cards for $3.00 purchases lol.

Not growing up in Missouri, this was may first experience with Ted Drewes.  BTW, when locals talk about this place, they say it so fast that they do not enunciate the name well. 

I got the concrete with brownie and hot fudge.  It was truly brilliant.  I grew up with Dairy Queen and eventually getting the blizzard from there.  I now believe that they stole this idea from TD.  It was so much better than a blizzard.  

The flavor is much sweeter than standard ice cream or soft serve.  The texture similar with a slightly smoother finish.  The brownie is tastes homemade and the lack of similarity in size of chucks again lend it to being homemade.  

What did I learn today?  Even when it is 53 degrees with rain, Ted's is a great decision.

Ted Drewes is a St. Louis thing. Until last summer when I first moved here, I didn't know what a "Ted Drewes' was. But now that I have experienced it a handful of times, I am glad to be acquainted with this delightful little place.

I took a recent spantaneous trip over here last Tuesday night just because I was in a kick for something sweet. It was a perfect night, a short line of other costumers waiting to get their fix, and as I was scanning through all the different varieties, I noticed they had added a holiday flavor for Easter. It was a carrot cake concrete. I zoned in, got it, and consumed it over the course of 2 days. It was to die for!! I typically am not a huge chocolate eater, so I go for the more fruit flavors, or things that are different. I certainly loved it though!

After reading a couple of the other reviews on Ted Drewes, I guess I never really paid that much attention to the fact that they do indeed only use vanilla custard. I do not mind it though. For those of you who do, I would still recommend this place. KEEP an open mind. They do have something for everyone, and are very accommodating to get what you want. 

Now for the 4 star rating... I do not believe in paying $4 for a cup of ice cream when I can get two container sized ones at the store or buy a gallon of gas for that now-a-days. Just saying. Other than that, I love this place.

When I lived in St. Louis, I took a family friend to Ted Drewes. She was from Chicago originally, recently finished her residency in L.A., and was doing a post-doc year in STL. She was skinny; like model skinny.

We joined the back of the long fast-moving line on an early summer evening. She looked around at the crowd and said, much too loudly, "Oh, now I see why everyone in St.Louis is so FAT". 

I grabbed her arm and hustled her off to the side. "Look, the fine fat people you just ridiculed are old-style. That means they are a little bit chivalrous. That means they do not hit women. So if you piss them off, they are going to hit ME. Can we just order some custard without starting an incident?"

We rejoined the line and acquired our creamy provender. It was enough to keep her eating and not talking.
Safe and satisfied. The power of Ted Drewes.

I don't remember exactly what we all got here. I know I got the strawberry shortcake (which was good) and my cousin got the pumpkin pie concrete (which was my favorite out of the four... good consistency and excellent taste), but I don't remember what my brother and friend got. I just remember my brother got something w/ caramel in it which was extremely sweet; there was no way I would have been able to finish the whole thing. My recommendation would be to just stick w/ the concretes.
 
All in all, this place was good. It might bother some people that I'm not ecstatic about this, but it's just not in me to rave about ice creams/frozen yogurts/frozen custards. I've never had one that made me giddy and think, "WOW!"

BTW, I believe this is the location (out of the two) that's open year-round; the other is closed during non-summer months.

If you're used to custard joints, this is about average I guess.

I like that they offer micro and mini size servings. I also like that they have sugar free chocolate custard, but it's less awesome than possible given that they won't blend it with mix-ins for you. Weird.

I thought my chocolate - marshmallow-almond concrete was runny. I had a micro, but it was 1/3 melted within 5 minutes (in October, not a hot night).

The ordering situation is a bit ridiculous. If it's your first visit, good luck figuring out the menu. Also, the lines aren't always obvious.

You weren't kidding about the lines. Yet, as promised, they move quickly! 

So here's the deal- I am not from St. Louis, so I am comparing Ted Drewes to Shakes back home. The pricing at Ted Drewes is pretty good for the portions you get. The hubby and I shared a large Fox Treat (raspberries, chocolate, macadamia nuts) concrete. The custard was EXTREMELY soft- more like a milkshake. And the toppings were well blended.  

Good, not quite great. I tend to like a slightly harder cream and chunks of fruit, chocolate, etc. But I can appreciate Ted Drewes. I get the appeal :)

I'd seen Ted Drewes on Alton Brown's Feasting on Asphalt ages ago, but this was my first chance to actually check them out.  And they really do deliver.  Loads of flavor variations.  I had the Lemon Crunch concrete which was absolutely fabulous.  It's very rich, but doesn't have that stick to the inside of your mouth that some rich food has.  Very refreshing.  Yum yum yum.

Between a wedding and a reception, how does one kill the time? With a famous bite of custard, that's how. No really, my group saw a wedding party having their photos taken while ordering. It really is worth it to blow time between the two parts. ;)

I liked that the custard was cool and creamy; it definitely tasted better than whatever you pull from a grocery store freezer! I was also impressed with the brownie underneath of mine. I couldn't even finish my entire sundae, but man whatever I made it through was delicious.

One should note that even the smallest size is huuuuuuuuuuuuuuge. My ice cream/custard loving guy couldn't finish it... Worth a share if you're not too hungry, but regardless it's worth a drive over.

Had my first Ted Drewes visit of the summer season tonight and it felt good to be back! As Andy D mentioned, don't be phased by a long line. There were probably 30 or so people in line when we pulled up, but we really only waited about five minutes. I have no idea how they work so quickly, but there's gotta be a very specific process inside that glorious yellow building.

So why the knocking of a star? I'm probably against some secret St. Louis code or something but I don't think the custard is THAT good. It's just okay to me, but I have found out what I prefer more... it tastes better to me with yummy fruit inside like blueberries or strawberries, and they can spare me the Reeses and cookie dough. Fruit is the way to go, for sure. 

I love when it's fall and you can go by for a pumpkin pie concrete - now that I can give five stars to. Also, it's so cool to wander around and pick out a Christmas tree. I'm glad this place is in St. Louis, and I'm glad they have such amazing commercials!

That's just the way I feel, guys. And gals.

***Ted Drewes features reasonably priced frozen custard, but I thought it was just okay and too soft***

Ted Drewes is a very well known frozen custard spot in St. Louis.  Its building has a very charming look to it and I imagine it is quite iconic in St. Louis.

I actually first heard about Ted Drewes through Food Network's Best Thing I Ever Ate where Bobby Flay highlighted Ted Drewes' concrete concoctions, which are Blizzard-esque though they feature much more customization of fillings.  Bobby Flay created his own concrete, which was vanilla frozen custard mixed with Oreo, Heath bar and caramel.

It was just okay.  Given the candy bar fillings, the quality of the add-ins were pretty standard stuff.  I thought the frozen custard was too soft.  While I thought the overall flavor combination was nothing special, the frozen custard had a pretty good flavor.  Still, its lack of thickness kind of kept it from being really good frozen custard for me.

The other problem was that they did not really fill the frozen custard all the way to the top so it kind of felt like a less than generous portion.

I also had their vanilla frozen custard in a cone.  While the frozen custard was too soft here as well, I think this option is a simpler and maybe even more enjoyable way to have their frozen custard.

Service was pleasant and quick and prices were reasonable for a frozen treat.

I left Ted Drewes Frozen Custard disappointed.  For a very acclaimed frozen dessert spot, I was expecting a better experience than a Foster's Freeze in California, but I actually have enjoyed my visits to some Foster's Freeze locations more than my one trip to Ted Drewes.  Ted Drewes is still very prominent though and if you like ice cream, frozen yogurt, soft serve, gelato, or frozen custard, you should probably give Ted Drewes a try if you are in St. Louis.

Ted Drewes Frozen Custard has its own parking lot, which is free.

What's not to love about this classic? Not only is it delicious, and quite a busy social scene at all hours, but the prices seem to be stuck in the 1970's! 

There are a million (okay, dozens) of special flavors and combinations to choose from - and you could certainly fill up on Ted Drewes for a meal if you wanted to - not that I ever have... :)

Just go! You won't be disappointed. And you may return sooner than you'd expect.

At first I was intimidated by the crowd of people, lingering around the front of this small building, adorned with adorable Christmas decorations, smelling of pine trees from the lot next store, but it wasn't as bad as I feared. 
I ordered in a matter of minutes upon arrival, at the counter, where I was presented with an old-school, hand written menu, with what I imagine are hundreds of yummy frozen possibilities. 
I settled on the Smore's custard treat, and asked them to mix it with vanilla custard instead of chocolate. 
I got the "mini", which... even by my standards, was not so mini. I speculate it would be about six ounces of rich, smooth goodness. 
The amount of graham cracker mixed into this treat along with marshmallow topping was balanced, resulting in a not-too-sweet, but still sweet and enjoyable breakfast for me, all for about three bucks. 
Tip: Know what you want before you plant your feet in the actual line, because it moves faster than extra clerks being assigned to help ring up customers at a Costco during Christmas.

Rainy, cold, and there's still a line??

To be honest, I was really happy to see that line, which means that people really love Ted Drewes.  I like ice cream so I could not pass up the opportunity to try their popular concretes.

Ted Drewes only has frozen vanilla custard.  You get that as a base, then choose the mix-ins & toppings, or go with one of the specials and favorites.  It's exactly like how a DQ Blizzard or McFlurry is, except much better.  It's so thick and creamy that even after they put it the mix-ins, they flip it upside down to show you that it won't fall!

I went for the Mint Oreo, which is the custard, mixed with mint flavoring and Oreo.  That custard really is one of the best I've had and perfect with the crunchy Oreo.  Mint was very light, which was fine cause that custard was damn tasty.

We made a mistake of ordering another of the special that was too similar, with Oreo and marshmallow.  You actually get little bites of marshmallow that's all integrated with the custard so it's silky and sweet, but at times, it does get lost.  Should've read the menu much more carefully..

Comes in variety of sizes, and while we went for the mini, it was definitely enough for us.  Maybe on a super hot day I could go for the regular, but it is very sweet and I can see myself get sick of it quickly.  For people with a sweet tooth, Ted Drewes is perfect!

Figured the almost 100 people I saw outside had to mean something in regards to how good this place was. Clearly we had to check it out!

I had the strawberry shortcake. It was so yummmm! Soft yogurt, strawberries, crumb bottom later and I think it was cake of some sort... Who knows but it was bomb! 

They have tons of flavors! Tons of add-in options and even more ways to create your own goodness!!

disclaimer: I was at a conference and they got Ted Drewes to "cater" our dessert, so they had vanilla, choco, and strawberry frozen custard in dixie cups pre-made for us. I didn't let mine thaw as much as I could have. so mine was a little less custard consistency. Really tasty, really enjoyed the strawberry! I'm sure it would be PHENOMENAL in real-time.

I of course have to review Ted Drewes, I feel like it's a right of passage when you live in this city. There are usually long, long lines in the summer but they go incredibly fast. There are so many people working at this place it's unreal. I love their pre-made ice cream combos, not gonna lie. The "All Shook Up" is insanely delicious with peanut butter cookies and banana...heaven. I'm also a pumpkin addict so the Great Pumpkin is delicious but so is the Big Apple. In other words you really can't go wrong when it comes to their concoctions. I'm also a huge fan of the mini concrete option, so that I don't feel as awful when I stuff my face, the smaller portion soothes my inner health-nut screaming "put down the spoon!!"
   The custard melts pretty quickly unfortunately even though they claim you can turn it upside down and it won't come unglued from the cup....mine did. So 4 stars it is, but it's still a place I can't resist when I'm craving something cool and sweet!

Believe what you read. Yes, it is that good. 

While I love the Southern Delight and Strawberry Shortcake, it's the Christy that I simply can't resist when I get back to Chippewa. 

Butterscotch, Pralines, and Chocolate Chip are also universally loved in this house.

They ship nationwide and thankfully so.
It's busy all year round for a reason!

I'm so disappointed in Ted Drews! We came here on a Tuesday evening...we had ordered 4 sundaes and non of them tasted good at all! Yes, I tried a bite from all 4! First off, the frozen custard was all runny and melted. We had ordered a Route 66 that had no flavor what so ever. you can barely taste hints of root beer and this is coming from an 11 year old. We also had the lemon graham cracker, had very faint lemon flavor and little chunks of graham crackers. My 10 year old nephew loved his cookie dough so now complaints to that besides it being more runny like a milkshake. I had ordered the terramizzou...wow HUGE disappointment. I was charge 50 cents for chocolate sauce that had no flavor, I didn't even know there was chocolate sauce in it...my ice cream was pure runny like slime white with pistachios...I was lucky enough to taste the pistachios. yes it was high 80's out but that should not have been the reason to have runny and flavorless ice cream served to us. I've had way better experience in the past, I think it will be a very long time until I come back. I would understand if 1 sundae had a boo boo but all 4? or I should say 3.5? common! get it together Ted Drewes!

I got to know Ted Drewes as a signature St Louis treat. Had it twice this summer, and I went with the classic concrete both times. One was catered at an event, and the other I got from original store on Route 66. To my surprise, the latter came with a cookie and frozen cherry pieces. The cherry added a different texture, and I'm all about it. The custard itself was rich, creamy, and delicious. It was just a tad too sweet for my liking, especially when it starts to melt. 

The actual store gets busy with long lines out of the window, but they move at a reasonable pace. Don't expect to wait long. I do wish that there was a designated space to enjoy it. Maybe some seating areas, even if it's just a few benches. There were heaps of people just standing in the parking lot, taking spoonful of the custard at a time. The set up definitely has its charm, but I found it bit awkward and not the most enjoyable under the blazing sun.

This was my first time trying frozen custard so I have nothing else to compare it to but Ted's was a plus!  The solid frozen custard was so thick you can turn the cup upside down and it won't fall out!  I  had a chocolate and cookie dough concrete and it was yummy!  In fact, it was better than my boyfriend's oreo cookie one!!

This place was packed even with 40 degree weather!!!

For my 700th review I figured that I should bring it back to a local icon that I have ignored over the years, Ted Drewes!
