Yes, Ted Drewes is a Saint Louis icon known for creating the "concrete" which is a custard blended with any number of combinations that is so thick that if a spoon was inserted and the cup was turned upside down it wouldn't fall out, and that is just the way they are served to you here. 

Opened in 1941, this location is a landmark and gets very busy during the summer season that parking can often be difficult, the one major plus is that the lines move fast so you are never really waiting long. Credit cards are accepted here, so no need to worry about having enough cash. Prices are reasonable too so you don't have to worry about breaking the bank. If you do not want to brave the crowds, the famous custard can be found in Ballpark Village, Lambert Airport, and many St. Louis grocers. However its bet enjoyed here, where the cool creamy custard can be blended with a wide variety of flavors and toppings. Seasonal ingredients like cherry, apple, and yes even pumpkin pie have their turn depending on the time of year.

Overall Ted Drewes is a well-known and highly recommended spot, however it's not my favorite custard stop in the area, that honor goes to Bobby's Frozen Custard located just across the river in Maryville, IL. Don't get me wrong the custard here is good, however I feel that there are just better options. Yet, another reason why I wish Yelp would allow  1/2 star ratings, I think a solid 3.5 star rating is due here since the custard is good, just not great.

Sure you can get this stuff now all over town at restaurants, but nothing beats coming here in person, even in December, for a concrete frozen custard. Tonight I had the Strawberry. Divine.
'nough said.

Okay, Ted Drewes, you were a little too much hype for me. Yes, you're probably considered iconic in St. Louis and you're definitely worth the visit because you do have this vintage feeling about you, but I wasn't overly impressed. The place is easy to find as it looks like someone's house with big red letters that spell out Ted Drewes. I'm still not too sure why it's called frozen custard where in Chicago we just call it custard even if it's cold, but no worries, I'll get with the St. Louis vibe.

We came on a Sunday afternoon around 2pm and it was pretty busy, we only had to wait about 5 minutes in line so that wasn't so bad but I can imagine it getting way too busy during the hot summer months. I saw many people were having the vanilla custard in a cone so I decided to order my personal favorite flavor, Chocolate in a cone as well. The girl says to me "sorry, we only put Vanilla in the cones." Okay, that's a star off right there. I mean, how hard is it to put the same custard you put in a cup, but in a cone? So that rule seemed a little off to me. So I told her I would like a small in a cup. I think the price is decent and you get enough even for a small. I shared some with my hubby and he liked it, but for me, the chocolate looked like vanilla. Where was the cocoa? It was too much on the sweet sugary side and less on the chocolatey side. I should have just ordered their vanilla flavor in a cone but oh well. Maybe if you get some of their fancier flavors and sundaes, you will have more of an exciting experience but my regular chocolate was just so so. Honestly, I wouldn't be dying to go back but I'm happy that we shared the experience. 

Ted Drewes, keep doing what you're doing, but you're just not for me.

I finally tried Ted Drewes! We decided to stop by after dinner one evening and I got the Hawaiian concrete.  The great thing about my concrete was that they use macadamia nuts instead of other roasted nuts such as pecan.  I do appreciate that a lot and they weren't shy with the toppings either.  The part that disappointed me though was that the frozen custard was more on the melted side. I definitely prefer my frozen custard elsewhere and this place didn't really convince me to want to come back any time soon.  The woman handing me my concrete did a halfway turn instead of a complete upside down thing since she saw it was quite melted already before I got it. I don't like melted ice cream or frozen custard, I think it's gross so I ended up eating half of it and threw it in the freezer at home to hopefully salvage the slurpie with toppings. The next day, it was better as a fully frozen custard yet still not my favorite in STL.

I would say of all the places I've tried, this place comes second. It's pretty close to home and to one of my favorite barbeque places so I'm sure I'll stop by another time.  Plus adding the macadamia nuts was an excellent choice!

Aside from my melted custard, the experience was quite fun. I can see why people come here. They have benches to sit in and enjoy your ice cream at and socialize during the summer.

This location is definitely in a better area and is open all year! The other location is not, as we found out. We've been here before and when in the area, definitely deserves a visit while in St. Louis. I had the butter pecan, or something to that nature. Butterscotch pecan, I think, very, very tasty. The parking lot is large which is very much appreciated for travelers, you don't have to drive around looking for parking here. We've never had to wait long, but I can't stress enough how you need to go, if in St. Louis!
Tasty and great prices. Always packed. Friendly people.. prices are great and it's a safe environment I'd advise or want to go there once in awhile

Ted Drewes is a must have if you're downtown St. Louis. It's just tradition. Also everyone else in Stl is here so you might as well join the party. Don't worry, the line may be intimidating, but I assure you it moves quickly! 

I love their concretes and every now and then I splurge to get "The Christy." It's a sundae with an entire brownie at the bottom of your pile of vanilla frozen custard, hot fudge, and caramel. I usually shoot a text to my pancreas to say, "PREPARE THE INSULIN." It's so delicious and sugary sweet and my teeth hurt thinking about it but I love it so. 

The staff is friendly and works very quickly to get you your sweet treat. I pretty much recommend all the things here so make sure you stop by!!!

Ok so Ted Drewes is possibly one of the most iconic food establishments in St. Louis. It's one of those places you have to try and stand outside in line waiting for. They have a wall of celebrity pictures of people who have fréquentes their custard shop and in the summer it's not uncommon to see a wedding party roll through for treats and pictures. I enjoy grabbing a Big Apple and sitting in our truck bed with my family and dog enjoying a summer night. For me it's more of the experience that draws me more than the custard. I don't think it's the end all be all of ice cream joints in St. Louis there are plenty others worth mentioning. But as far as places in St. Louis that just scream summertime this is one of the places to be.

Always a line but it moves quickly

What a great way to end a Sunday Funday at the zoo with a stop at Ted Drewes on the way home. Today we found a good parking spot near the building. This place is so popular sometimes you need to park across the street and prance through the traffic. The selection and sizes are perfect. We had the S'more concrete and the Special, a little piece of heaven in the form of chocolate and ice cream and my grand just some white ice cream aka as vanilla. The staff is quick to take your order and in no time you are sitting on the benches sharing your ice cream treat. As Mr Ted Drewes himself says "Guys it really is good."

My cousin asked me what the big difference is between the custard here and the stuff from DQ, I was so offended by that noob question as a pseudo-foodie that I just scoffed and made him order. His brownie custard spoke for itself later. 

My dad also thought the custard was good, which is a big deal because he doesn't typically like non-essential-for-survival-foods he has to pay for.

I got the seasonal pumpkin pie custard, with actual pumpkin pie pieces mixed in and interesting silky dense custard texture.  It was one of the best frozen treats I've had.

I'm not really sure why my boyfriend urged us to go here before we left St. Louis like it's the end of the world if we did not. When I got my mint custard and added chocolate chips inside, I'm thinking, "why is this thing so soupy/watery?" I had my fair share of ice cream and ice cream should not look like it's already melted before you take your first bite.

I loved reading from one of the other reviewers that she wanted her "St. Louis Merit Badge" now that she had been to Ted Drewes.  Of course it's a landmark.  Of course it's listed in every guidebook about St. Louis.  And of course she deserves her merit badge.  I mean, so do I. :-)

The way it's set up, with the multiple windows, handwritten menus, tschotchke for sale, I'm so reminded of stopping at ice cream shops in Cape Cod.  High school kids spending all summer serving ice cream to the rest of us.

She held my M&M concrete upside down to show me it wasn't going to spill.  I then had to take a picture of it myself:

http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?pid=2642977&l=718e6a3819&id=1142340120

Pretty cool.  And Delicious.  Head down there and earn your own merit badge :-)

Wow.  I've never had ice cream this good.  Or flavors this creative.  I had something with blackberries and macadamia nuts.  Not sure what it was called but it was great. 
The lines move along pretty quickly but it was a little chaotic when I went. It's a good idea to check out the flavors listed on the side of the building  before you even think about getting in line.

When I die, I would like someone to super freeze  300 lbs of the  Ted Drewes chocolate chip custard and then sculpt it into my likeness. At the funeral everyone could gather round with spoons and eat me.

Ted, it has been two years since my original review and figured I needed to give you an update. I am glad I waited till now and did not do it last fall. At that point, you were starting to lose me as a fan, but this season you are on a strong A-Game. 

Your custard is rich, creamy and can be turned upside down without any consequences. I have even been able to turn mine upside down after a 2 mile drive home.  I've tried other flavors, but I will always be true to my M & M's  being my favorite. 

I also want to commend you on your staff. Your front window employees are always friendly and know how to move the line quickly. Then  I wonder how those who make the sweet treats, how they can turn them so fast. Your custard truly is a treat of Saint Louis and Route 66.

Last week I ordered some Oreo & Hawaiian frozen custard. All the way from Vegas! It arrived moments ago to my home via UPS. I did take pictures so enjoy. Thank you TD! I can't wait to eat the yummy goodness! I have 15 cups of heaven go get yours today and as ted always says it really is good guys & girls!

This is my favorite custard place besides Andy's in Springfield, MO/ Cape Girardeau. I love the Scotch-Oatmeal Cookie Concrete and I have mixed many of the toppings with it. Usually Chocolate Chip. It is one of the top local spots in St. Louis.

How can you not love Ted Drewes?  It's one of my favorite places to get a tasty treat. This last time I went I got a heath bar. Vanilla custard with crushed Heath bar mixed in.  Wonderful. My favorite is the brownie custard. It has large chunks of brownie in it. There is a place to get a cup of water by the windows to go with your treat.  Don't look at the crowd. They always have enough people working and it moves quickly.  And to top it all off, Ted Drewes is a Route 66 Roadside attraction.  The only negative is that there is no place to sit and enjoy your treat.  

Would I come back here?  ABSOLUTELY!!!

I mean, it's Ted Drewes. TED DREWES. The crazy long lines, delicious custard, fake icicles, yellow and green cups, crap-where-am-I-going-to-park Ted Drewes. 

You don't like it? Seriously?

I appreciate a place that has specialties called "Terramizzou" and "Cardinal Sin." Even more than that, I appreciate the Fox Trot: a hot fudge, macadamia nut, and raspberry sundae of epic greatness. And that's fresh raspberries, not some kind of fake sauce with crushed berries and raspberry flavored syrup. You get all that and a smile for $3.60. 

This is a St. Louis institution and a summer staple. Thanks, Ted. You're the man.

The Lemon Crumb is my favorite at Ted Drewe's; a combination of vanilla concrete (frozen custard), lemon cream, and crunchy graham crackers. It is a refreshing summer treat! 
Sometimes the lines are long and can be confusing, since there are multiple windows and no one seems to know where to line up. 
In my experience, service is fast and courteous at Ted Drewe's! There is an adjacent parking lot, but I imagine it can become full at busier times. 
If you are visiting St. Louis for the first time, I highly recommend giving this place a try; it's an institution!

RICHER THAN ICE CREAM!  frozen custard by itself, topped or blended with my favorite extras into a thick (able to hold upside-down) concrete is the StL treat no matter what time of the year.

I admit this is not health food.  Custard is richer and softer with eggs and higher fat content than normal ice cream.  (Since I was raised on it I can taste the difference)  Then I order raspberries, nuts and chocolate "fox treat"  sundae or blend with whatever sounds good.  (I like deciding, with the concrete, what exactly I want in my own personal dessert- fruit, candy bar, nuts, pies, and/or chocolate fudge (I like the fudge to be added on top of the mix).  The list of stuff I can add is insane in length and variety, plus the ability to combine...)  I only live once so I will treat myself to my own personally created indulgence, even in the winter.

In the summer this place looks insane.  The lines does move FAST so just get ready to order (do not procrastinate on making a decision on what anyone in your group wants- I get everyones order and tell them to wait at the car).  This place is a hangout during summer nights for kids of all ages.

I worked across the street for 4 years and they always have a line.  In the middle of winter with snow on the ground, THERE IS A LINE.  The frozen custard is that good (something richer than standard ice cream).

If you want standard hard scoop ice cream that you can pick the extras like a concrete- GO to Cold Stone so we have less of a line.

=)

Family owned and operated they spoil you with the best stuff ever this place is a gift  from the GOD's. I was blessed to live around the corner from this Chippewa location  and I loved every moment of it. I loved the Hawailan Delight its packed with all the good stuff that makes me need Ted Drewes Custard Anonymous ...Hi my name is Samantha and I've been addicted to Ted Drewes for 5 years Its a sad sight really. But I love the Pineapple, Banana, Coconut, & Macadamia Nuts this is nothing but a guilty pleasure for me. I eat this stuff and it feels like I'm in heaven. This is so good it will make you slap your grand ma! It don't matter what you order its gonna be lip licking brain freeze pack on the custard good. Thank you Ted Drewes! Like Ted always says it really is good guys and girls!

We saw Ted Drewes on Man vs. Food's Route 66 Special and it looked good -- a local Dairy Queen with concretes/blizzard concoctions.  When we drove past it at 10PM, we saw the entire lot full of people and the lines looked like it would take forever.  (See photo!)  

However, the lines went super fast.  From waiting, ordering, and getting the ice cream, probably less than 5 minutes.   

I got the Hawaiian Concrete -- pineapple, macadamia nuts, and coconut.  Delish! 

The only drawback would be... there's not much standing room with the amount of people, so we ate our ice cream in the car.  Which is not bad because at least we had AC!
Maybe I am not a custard person. It was just that, custard...Simple and tasty but I didn't see what all the raves were about.....Am I missing something?

This place easily gets top rating from me.  It's a slice of americana.  It's cheap, unique, and oh so good.  

Whenever I have guests in town, I take them here after dinner.  I've never heard anyone compare Drewe's to an establishment they have in their city.  And they're always blown away by how good it is. 

I guarantee that the $15 I spent here impressed as much as the $150 I spent at dinner.

Delicious custard. Very fast service. Only have one flavor, but you have the option to mix in a lot of different toppings. Take out counter only. I mixed in caramel, Oreo, and hazelnut. It was delicious

A visit to St. Louis is not complete without a concrete from the famous Ted Drewes. Today the temp was 98 and it was definitely a day to get something cool. We drove in and as expected the lines were long but, were moving. We checked the menu on the side of the building and I decided on the "Cardinal Sin" concrete. Chocolate and cherries. My wife loves a "Hot Fudge Sundae". So we walked over to the walk up window and ordered. Within a minute we had a delicious treats and we were on our way. We are only visitors and it is too bad we don't have one of these locations where we live. I would visit a couple of times a week. If you are visiting the city make sure you try one of their 3 locations.

I was happy to be able to enjoy a Ted Drewes cup of custard earlier today. While I did not visit Ted Drewes directly, a friend was able to find a few at a local shop and purchased a few of their cups to go to bring to our picnic today. Such a nice treat during a hot day! 

Pro-tip: If you are unable to visit the custard stand; you can certainly purchase these treats at some local retailers as they offer their 3 basic flavors; strawberry, vanilla and chocolate. All are portioned out and packed separately so they are easy to pass out during a pandemic. There is even a vending machine at the airport! 

The chocolate custard was so creamy and delicious; now I can't stop thinking about visiting Ted Drewes to pick up a concrete.

I tried the strawberry custard with hot fudge and it was very good. I would definitely recommend getting a solid topping instead of a hot liquid, because it melts the custard very fast, turning it soupy.
The second time around, I got the vanilla custard with peanut butter and waffle cone bits. I definitely prefer the vanilla custard as a base.
The lines moves fast so don't be intimidated if the place is crowded. I felt like a true local, coming here and enjoying custard on a hot summer day.

I was finally able to get my hands on Ted Drewes, I had it many times in the past but never fresh.  I totally understand why Ted Drewes is so popular now, the custard is so so so freaking creamy, beyond creamy.  The creaminess doesn't transfer as well when you get it from the grocery store. 

We came around 9 pm at night and there was a decent chunk of people in line.  There are plenty of people working so you will be able to order pretty quickly.  I wanted to try the st. louis style ooey gooey butter cake so I ordered the classic.  The classic is vanilla custard on top of an ooey gooey butter cake and some tart sour cherries.  

The custard also pleased my family whom usually don't like american style desserts because they think they are way too sweet, but my dad was a huge fan!!! So 5 stars from me !

A nostalgia-laced icon,  this branch of Ted Drewes is my favorite. It's located on Route 66 in a very pretty neighborhood and part of the experience is enjoying the ambiance as you stand outside waiting to order.

This is the first place I ever had frozen custard, that luscious concoction that is richer than ice cream and usually prepared soft serve style to lend itself to all sorts of invention.   The richness is due to high butterfat and egg content and minimal air.

Important term:  "concrete" - the frozen custard equivalent of a Dairy Queen Blizzard, you pick your mix-ins and they blend it up into decadent goodness.

One of my favorite items at Ted Drewes is the Christie, which is actually a sundae:  a brownie, frozen custard, hot fudge, and caramel ($5).  Great diet food!

Highly recommended to any frozen confection lover visiting St. Louis!!

I can't believe that I've never written a review for this place!!!
I would eat here EVERY SINGLE NIGHT if I wouldn't suffer the weight gain from it.   I am SERIOUS!  I am a huge ice cream, gelato, custard whatever nut and this is one of my favorites.
I used to come here as a kid, and now my kids grew up coming here.  We get our tree here every year as well and we also love their hotdog food truck.
I will NOT say anything against this landmark, and I'm so glad we have it here in St. Louis so I don't have to drive outta state.

I tried again and this time all 5 cups of concrete were dripping and melted. This is just not how concrete is supposed to be so it is just very disappointing, especially for a place that prides itself on serving "concrete" custard. We got the TeDad's, peppermint, brownie, and pistachio. The peppermint was actual crushed peppermint candy so it's very minty. I didn't try the pistachio but it was green and not just nuts folded into vanilla custard. The flavors were fun to try but we'd get something else next time to explore.

When someone told me this was the birthplace of frozen custard, I knew I HAD to try it out.  

I ordered the smores flavor...wouldn't go that route the next time.  The graham crackers got this weird, soggy, sticky-ish consistency.  The frozen custard itself, though, was delish!

-1 star for the price.  I thought it was pretty expensive for essentially ice cream.
Daplaz2B on Friday night, crowded with convivial custard consumers. If you need gluten-free, ask for basic custard, clean spindle. Friendly staff, fair prices, and no tips accepted.

Love this STL institution. I know there are some diverging opinions out there who refuse to be part of the mainstream, but you have to at least try Ted Drewes if you're in the city. They offer different types of ice cream. The "concrete" is similar to what you think of as traditional ice cream--though once they're blended, it's much softer.

They have a lot of ready-made combos on the parking lot side of the store, based on popularity. My personal favorite is the twisted pretzel--super sweet and caramel.

A few notes:
(1) incredibly fast service--don't be discouraged by long lines. Half of those people are waiting to get their ice cream, not waiting to order, so just ask if they're waiting to order, and most of them will say they're just waiting for the ice cream.
(2) the size--the mini is usually enough for one person. Do not get any bigger sizes; their portions are HUGE.

A perfect combination of gluttony at its finest. My sister took me here while I was visiting for a bit before heading off to Chicago.

The creamiest of all icecream is here. She told me the line is usually wrapped around,but we stopped by at about 1pm on a Friday.

I ordered the "Christy". Brownie, frozen custard and hot fudge. Oh Christy, you were oh so creamy and amazing. I wish you were here in California as well..

I lived in Saint Louis many years ago. I've had other versions of frozen custard in other areas of the country since, but nothing ever compares to Ted Drewes. After a relatively recent visit back to STL, I can confirm that this still the case.

Legend has it that a Ted Drewes concrete will hold up if you turn it upside down. I've tried this myself - but only for a split second. When I lived in STL, my constant go-to was the Terramizzou, which comes mixed with chocolate and pistachio nuts. On my more recent visit, I enjoyed the Dutchman Delight. Because who doesn't love those tall, strapping Dutchmen? Big feet, among other things. But I digress. It's a concrete that comes with chocolate, butterscotch, and pecans. So much oozy, delightful creaminess worth slurping down lovingly.

Because of all the live mix-ins upon request, your concretes or sundaes here won't be as thick as the packaged cups of Ted Drewes that you can find at supermarkets and convenience stores throughout the area. But these are certainly worth trying so you can see for yourself how dense the frozen custard is when compared to ice cream.

All in all, Ted Drewes remains one of my favorite things about STL!

We came here after our dinner at Van Goghz.  It was a hair above 30 degrees, so not the ideal weather for frozen anything. After some debate, I got the regular Cardinal Sin. I liked the texture a lot better than ice cream and it's a little more solid than frozen yogurt. Chocolate and cherries is a combination that never disappoints. It definitely warrants a return trip the next time I'm in town.

I couldn't believe the amount of people milling around Ted Drewes on a weeknight evening, but fret not - the lines move super fast and I got my concrete custard within 5 minutes. It truly is incredible and beats any frozen custard I have tried on the East Coast. Not only is there a multitude of options, but the custard itself is creamy, rich, and extremely smooth. I tried the Lemon Crumb and it was exactly as I pictured - did not taste artificial at all and full of yummy mix-in of graham crackers. My co-workers were equally enraptured with their choices. A small was actually too large for me as a post-dinner snack - will be getting a mini next time if I ever am in St. Louis again. Highly recommend.

Neil Sedaka use to sing a song about, "Breaking Up Is Hard To Do" and he was  so right. Ted, we've been together so long that it breaks my heart that I have to tell you that there is now another custard in my life. I've tried to see both of you, but after our last outing I just can not do it anymore. I am leaving you for Mr. Wizard. 

While I was seeing you both, I admit I was doing comparisons ordering the exact same thing to see which one would satisfy me the most. Mr. Wizard was slowly taking the lead and when I compared the Cherry Chocolate Chip Concretes,  he knocked it out of the custard ballpark. However, what really pushed me to the Wizard was the melting, or the not melting. 

My drive from Mr. Wizard to home is 2.5 miles and his custard is still firm, thick and ready to be enjoyed in the comforts of my own home. My home from you Ted is 1.2 miles and with  the air conditioning blasting, your custard is soup when I get home. We can drink our concretes. Also, Mr. Wizard is blending my ingredients better and the finished product has a better presentation. 

We were together 35 years Ted, so I'm still going to give you 3 Stars. Plus, you are an institution on Route 66 and all the tourist coming to STL need to experience you. However, Mr. Wizard is now my Custard Man.

If you're from St. Louis this is one of the most legendary destinations in the city - aside from Busch Stadium and Steak & Shake!
They make the most amazing concrete's I have ever had - yummmmy homemade custard mixed with your choice of decadent (a.k.a. fattening) candies, fruits, etc.  This was always a popular place to have the limo take you after prom.  
Good times, good times.

Frozen custard is delicious! When I first moved to St. Louis Ted Drewes was on my list of places recommended by many locals. I can understand why. This is a touristy spot and even the locals come here and wait in line for their sweet treat! 

I remember my first visit very well. I had no idea how to order or what to order. I was so overwhelmed with the choices. While waiting in line I was reading the menu and asking for tips on what to order;  however, instead of trying to try something different I simply asked for a M&M Concrete; it was that simple. Thank goodness! I was nervous I was going to order incorrectly. 

Now that I have gone back a few times I have tried their Great Pumpkin and I also tried some kind of cherry concrete with dark chocolate. Both were really good, but I'll stick with my traditional M&M concrete since it is simple and sweet. 

If I ever have friends come to town I know I can take them here-I explain that the lines will be long and we just have to be patient. What's really funny is that even in the cold winter months people still wait in line-no way! Not me. I prefer to eat my concretes during the warmer months. 

Ted Drewes, I will come in the spring. Keep up the good work!

Ted Drewes is indeed the best. There are an indefinite number of combinations one can have here, and all the hype in my opinion is definitely worth it. I've had the custard w/fudge sundae, and a concrete mixed w/fudge, and both were delicious. I also appreciate that they're open even in the colder days--you can always stop by and pick up one of these amazing treats!

This place got a place on my list after reading about  their popular "Concrete" which is malt or shake so thick that is served upside down.Ted's Custard basically became a st.Louis tradition.

Ordered 2 Mini Concretes one with Lime Pie flavor and other with Chocolate flavor called Dutch Man which costed us $9 and both were awesome.

I did try to hold the concrete upside down and it din't fell off .

Pros:
-----
Awesome Custard
Decent prices
Quick service
Free parking
They are also sell Christmas trees

Stopped here on our Route 66 road trip adventure. Going on a Route 66 trip, this is one of the iconic historical places to stop at. My dog and I sure tried to stop at as many places as possible!

I love that this place is dog friendly and that you can order straight from an outside window! Most people seem to ask their frozen custard from the back of their cars. There really isn't any seating here. They have some different types of custard you can order, but they are known for their concretes. You can add in different toppings and order them in different flavors. I ordered a coffee one with almonds and coconut. The ones I ordered seemed more melted than what I had expected. It may have been because it was a super hot day. There workers were friendly and everyone loved seeing my dog! He was super well behaved and patiently waited for his own cup of custard! I bought him a plain vanilla kids small cup... but you can save a few bucks because they have FREE doggie sized ones! I had no idea and had already ordered and paid, then another worker stuck his head out and asked me if I wanted to give my dog his own cup. I said I already bought one and he said next time, just ask for a doggie one, it's free. My dog being 96lbs could probably have easily finished his small cup along with a doggie cup lol. It was pretty packed when we went, but it moved fast still. They have so many windows open and you get your sweet treat pretty quickly. Like I said, there really isn't any seating, but most people enjoy their treats on the spot at their cars. It's like a ice cream tailgating party!

If I am ever in the area again, I would come by here for a dessert stop! If you are traveling with your dog, take them here!! They welcome you and your pup! Not the cheapest, but prices are also pretty decent.

I have a confession:  I went almost fifteen years without Ted Drewe's Frozen Custard.

I'm not proud, but I spend a great deal of time living outside of St. Louis.  My first experience at TD happened when I was sixteen.  I went with a friend's family and have a limited memory of the occasion.  Why sixteen?  I don't know.  Ask my parents.  I blame them!

Years went by, and I had tried several different custard places, primarily Fritz's in Florissant and Andy's in Springfield, MO.  I always enjoyed my visits to these frozen custard stands, but I never knew what I was missing.

Fast forward to 2010.  On a whim, I decided to take my wife, then girlfriend, to Ted Drewe's for the first time.  I couldn't recall what she ordered, but I had the strawberry shortcake, a staple for me anywhere I go for custard.

I dug my spoon into the thick vanilla custard, smothered with strawberries and whipped cream, and as I tasted TD for the first time in years, I suddenly wanted all those years back.  For nearly fifteen years, I had deprived myself the benefit of St. Louis's staple, the true basilica where treat and religion undeniably meet.

Recently, my wife mentioned craving ice cream, and I took it one step beyond that, making another routine trip to the Chippewa store.  Frozen custard trumps ice cream, and Ted Drewe's trumps all other frozen custards.

Take heed, all you imitators.
Still good.  Not as good as it once was was, but still worth the trip.

St Louis tradition! Custard is my favorite form of ice cream. It's so smooth and creamy! This custard is delicious with tons of toppings to choose from. I can't give it a 5 star because they only have vanilla! What? No chocolate? Every custard stand should have chocolate custard. I must admit, for someone who never orders vanilla anything....this was still very good!

Its a good thing I don't live around here, otherwise I would be here everyday after a meal.  The frozen custard here is just simply delicious.  The service is quick and the prices are reasonable.  They have lots of combination that you can choose from.  To me, any cold dessert is usefully my weakness - whether it be frozen custard, ice cream, soft serve, frozen yogurt, etc...

The frozen custard here has a nice not too heavy taste and not too sweet. I'm just disappointed that I can't taste all the flavors.

You can't put together a list of St. Louis icons without Ted Drewes. Rain or shine, sun or snow, locals flock here around the year for the most famous frozen custard in the Midwest. You can get your custard as a sundae (frozen custard with toppings on top) or as a concrete (frozen custard with toppings blended in). They offer a variety of pre-made flavor combinations, such as "the Brennan" (mocha, hazelnuts, and caramel) - or you can make your own combo with whatever toppings and flavors you want. The lines can be a bit long, but they always move quickly. So come satisfy your sweet tooth with a dish full of indulgent St. Louis tradition at Ted Drewes!

During my visit to STL, this place was recommended by my bf's entire family. Like, they swore on their lives this place has the best ice cream in the world.

Well, let me tell you. They were not wrong.

TD's has the largest flavor variety of any ice cream place I've been to. I ordered the Tiramisu and OMG words can't even describe. It was so creamy and delicious. I finished my whole serving and I'm the type of person who can't handle too much of one dessert. I usually take a few bites and I can't finish it. This wasn't the case with this amazing cup of magic in my hands.

The wait in the below freezing weather was well worth it. Lines moved fast, but it was busy that night and I'm a Texan who's not acclimated to cold weather so it seemed like 10 years. 

Once that delicious goodness was in my belly, nothing else mattered. Not my red nose or numb fingers.

Try it if you're in STL!

Today was a perfect summer day in Saint Louis, so we went to the Missouri Botanical Garden and after headed to Ted Drewes for delicious ice cream concretes.  Ted Drewes feels like a time warp back to vintage America from a Mad Men episode.  My favorite flavor this summer is the Twisted Caramel Pretzel Concrete.  

The sizes are generous, so you're safe ordering a size smaller than you'd expect.  They offer micro, mini, regular, and large.

This is a sweet thing to do in STL.  There's also another location on Grand.  

=  Ambiance - busy and chaotic with people hovering at the order / pick up windows and standing /walkers at the parking lot

+  Custard and Concrete - a wide range of choices from classic sundaes to creative concrete mixes and whip cream if desired.  Generous portions but they melt incredibly fast!  I ate all my hot fudge but only about 1/2 of my custard.  

+  Service is friendly and fast.  Even with so many people, we didn't have any wait to order.  Custards and concretes are served very fast too.

+  Price is very fair.

+  Parking is sufficient for parkers who hang to consume and also constant turns.

Its a good place to go unique to STL.

Nom Nom Nom..Frozen Custard!!!! That was all we could think about after walking in the hot sun. In addition, the frozen custard was one of the best lunches during our road trip :)

The service at this place is awesome! We were frozen custard newbies and didn't know what anything was on the menu. Our cashier cheerfully explained the flavors and the difference between the sundae and the concrete. A+ service.

I had the regular pistachio concrete. Wheee.. the custard was sweet and creamy. I love the pistachio mixed into the vanilla custard. My fiance had the regular Tedad's concrete as it came with oatmeal cookie. Oh goodness. It was amazing! The cherry sundae was pretty good too.

Forget all of the froyo places back at home. Bring in the frozen custard!

Why are there so many famous ice cream or the "fancier, smoother" sister custard joints across the Midwest??  After all, it's only warm for 7 months of the 12...at most!

Well even though it's edging onto the end of winter, I was finally able to visit the Route 66 St. Louis landmark Ted Drewes on Chippewa.  Once you make up your mind on which ice cream concoction you want, you'll get asked whether you want it as a sundae or "concrete."  The latter is basically a blizzard that goes by another name.  I had the Terramizzou concrete (pronounced like the Italian delicacy tiramisu)  that is a secret blend of chocolate and pistachio nuts.  Too many nuts for me, but it was definitely delicious and didn't give me an upset stomach after chowing down.  Also the portions are definitely larger than they look, so you have been forewarned!

All in all, Ted Drewes is definitely a St. Louisian cultural landmark that you can't admit you have never been to when in St. Louis.  Picture it as a "When in St. Louis" kinda thing.  Now for the truth...I personally prefer my basic Culvers or Kopps custard.  It must be because I'm originally from the Illinois-Wisconsin border.

For those who don't know the area well, take my word on this: While you chow down on your custard, take a graceful drive down the hilly tree-lined neighborhood streets of St. Louis Hills (best blocks are on Nottingham and Murdoch Aves).  Truly adorable gingerbread-looking houses with a central park called Francis Park.

Ted drewes is so St. Louis (just ask Nelly's tattooist). I bring out of town guests here who want that local experience (but skip Imo's, never again). The lines are always long, but move quickly. There's a nostalgic feeling when you come here at night & see the bright neon sign & your waited on by pimply teenagers. It just feels right to end the night here. 

Ive dabbled in the menu & love the strawberry shortcake, Christie, & smores, but my hat goes off to the twisted caramel (salted caramel w/ chunks of pretzels) in a mini size. It's a perfect combo of salty & sweet & has been my go to all summer long. 

Ted Drewes = one of my top ten things I love about stl.

Very tasty frozen custard. My office in Boston actually got this delivered by the company as a sister office lost a world series bet. The ice cream was delicious and the win made it taste even better. My favorite flavor was the Tedad flavor, at least that is what was wrote on the cap. I think it was some sort of oatmeal cookie. I wouldn't hesitate to return for a visit or order some on my own.

Absolute heaven in a cup! When I told my friends I was going to St Louis, more than one highly encouraged me to check out Ted Drewes. Solid recommendation!

Ted Drewes has been crafting delicious frozen custard since the early 1900s and is an attraction on Route 66. The staff are super friendly and keep the line moving. I went in the early afternoon and the line wasn't terrible at all. There was also plenty of room to park. While there are not a whole lot of seating options, it's no big deal. I found a bench but most people were in their cars. I went with a sundae--vanilla custard, topped with hot fudge and raspberries. It was divine!

The other thing I noticed was that people really want to share the love of Ted Drewes frozen custard. There were lots of parents there with kids, people on dates, etc. I shared my bench with a grandfather and his granddaughter and they were so sweet and enthusiastic about their Ted Drewes! This stop is well-loved by locals and people passing through on Rte 66.

Not gonna lie, I looked at the BF like he was insane when we pulled up to this place and there was a monster mob of people outside. 

The wait ended up being 15 mins from the back to receiving our ice cream.  He got his favorite and I ended up getting a strawberry, banana and raspberry shake.  They forgot the banana but truthfully, this place has such good stuff that it doesn't matter if you're missing a mix-in.

Highly recommend.
Concretes here are quite fun, but not one of the great ice cream places I have been to.

Their custard here is about as good as it gets.  I've been waiting to come here for nearly 10+yrs now but havent been able to make it to the STL area until now.  I ordered the regular sized terramizzou: chocolate and pistachios....and this was more than enough for a late night dessert.

A lot of people waiting around in the parking lot and near the building, but luckily most had already ordered and were already eating their desserts.

My order came out quickly and I also added a yellow t-shirt (the only color) for another $14.

A must visit at this original location along Route 66.

Ted Drewes is a landmark in the St Louis area, and rightfully so. 
It is a small custard shop without all sorts of frills or fancy extras. They do what they do, and they do it well. I was visiting in the Fall, so it was not as busy as a hot summer day would be, but it was still hoppin'. Ted's has all of the standard custard options between cones, bowls, sundaes, etc. They do all of the fun mix in toppings, and do them well. There is no inside seating, but there are benches and seats outside. You can also sit in your car and enjoy your frozen treat from the comfort of your own automobile.

Ted's has a real old timey, throwback sort of feel to it, which gives it an extra bit of charm and nostalgia that just cannot be replicated by a newcomer to the block. Everything tastes great, the prices are perfect, and the service is as would be expected.

If you are in the area, I highly suggest giving Ted Drewes a shot. As a bit of a custard connoisseur, I think you will be more than happy with your decision.

We got the lime, tart cherry, TeDad's, and mocha with Heath mini concretes. My mocha was not that "concrete" and was melting and dripping when I attempted to turn it over. The flavor was ok but I would get something else next time. The TeDad's was good and I would get that next time. The tart cherry was also very good. It tasted like actual maraschino cherries with small bits. The lime didn't really taste like lime. 

We came here because it is said to be a must try in St Louis. We enjoyed the concrete and would come back for the TeDad (a bigger one!) or cherry or try some other flavors.

Best frozen custard evah!!!!! (Yes that is my Oprah imitation) I am saying this as someone who has frequented Wisconsin's famed custard stands and as a non native of St Louis so there.

My sister intro-ed me shortly after moving to St Lou. For those of you not in the know, Ted Drewes is the famous home of the concrete aka crete, a custard mixture so thick they serve it to you upside down.

She is a fan of the cretes where they stick in a whole piece of pie (her fave is pumpkin) into your creation and mix it into bliss. I am a devotee of the fox treat crete with hot fudge, raspberries and macadamia nuts. I also like the Hawaiian crete with pineapple, banana, coconut and macadamia nuts. A plain chocolate chip crete or a chocolate shake will do in a pinch. 

I know her kids are all born and bred Ted Drewes addicts and frankly it makes me proud. 

Whenever I am in town this is a must stop. You are crazy if you live nearby and never stop in.

Well worth the drive from the county! What can I say that hasn't been said? I love the custard. The consistency is perfect. It looked like there were a million people there this Friday night, but we got helped immediately and barely had stepped to the side before our orders came out. Lots of interesting combinations but I stuck to my tried and true - vanilla custard with Reese's. YUM.

Photos: http://www.flickr.com/photos/karmanlee/sets/72157601624685403/
I love frozen custard! Love this place...tons of flavor to pick from...

Lines are still long when we get there after dinner....

Wish it wasn't so damn hot last night, my frozen custard melted so fast!!!!

Very good custard!  Flavorful, cold and refreshing!  Prices are reasonable which is a sight for sore eyes (and wallets).  I got a few wonderful flavors in a large and I was not disappointed.  My wife who isn't a big sweets person really enjoyed hers as well!  Hope to come back again soon!
This is an iconic St. Louis thing to do and fun if you have family or friends visiting from out of town.  Tons of flavors and always a crowd enjoying their frozen custard.

Ate what the locals ate. Kept it classic with Vanilla. It was pretty good. Came out hard as a rock, but became more malleable as the time approached to board my flight. It's a great, sober way to pass the time (unless you splash some rum on top - recommended!).

St. Louis is known for three things: the Arch, Imo's Pizza, and Ted Drewes! This summer stand out has been serving up thick, creamy frozen custard to millions of residents and visitors since 1929. To me, nothing says summer like leaving a hot and sticky Cardinals game to get a dish of Ted Drewes. It's the perfect way to cool down. 

My favorite aspect of the Ted Drewes menu is how customizable it is. While they offer a ton of pre-concocted treats, it's so fun to mix and match toppings to create your perfect dish of custard. Choosing from over 50 unique toppings, my personal favorite combo is pretzel, caramel and hot fudge. It tastes like a frozen chocolate covered pretzel! 

The lines at Ted Drewes can appear incredibly intimidating if it's your first rodeo. Fear not! The custard slingers who keep the Ted Drewes machinery humming have customer service down to a science. I'm always so impressed with how quickly they get through lines. To help customers in the COVID-era, they have installed barricades between each service window. They aren't large enough to keep the crowds out though. 

Pro tip for first time Ted Drewes adventurers: They post the menu on both sides of the building. Definitely take a look at it before you get in line. The only menu by the service stations are tiny and you can't read them from the end of the line. It can be super stressful when you get to the front of the line and you don't know what you want yet. Don't be that person who holds up the line!

The other thing to note here is size. The interesting thing is the inconsistency and confusing sizing structure. More often than not they serve you a size larger than you order. They claim it's the same size, just in a bigger cup... but it's clearly more custard!

Anyone who gives Ted Drewes less than 5 stars is just nit-picking! A St.Louisan most of my life have been here several times, and its always heaven! I normally always get the Fox Treat...man oh man!!!! If you're visiting from outta town, be prepared to wait, and please have patience, its worth it!!!!! It is seriously--- no words can describe the deliciounsess and history of Ted Drewes/...

A dessert place with a long line can mean two things. One, it is an Instagram photo-worthy hype. Two, the dessert tastes really amazing. Of course, it can also be a combination of both factors, but for Ted Drewes, it is simply the latter option. The dessert served here is solely vanilla custard, and you can play around and customize it by adding some sauces or toppings or by making it a concrete, shake, malt, or a few other variations. Choose from one of the menu options, or get creative and make your own flavor combination. Either way, whatever you do, the custard remains the star of the show, and what makes it so good is that it is high quality while staying simple and unpretentious. It is super creamy and looks, feels, and tastes homemade. 

There really is not anything fancy in appearances about the storefront or the custard at all, but the lack of disguise is what makes it so charming. You order at a window and either eat your custard outside or take it to-go with you somewhere. The line may be long, but it moves fast. I placed my order and then received my dessert almost instantaneously. If you want to avoid the line completely, go on a day when the weather is terrible and people do not want to be outside.

There are plenty of ice cream places in any town so I will give you a fact that might convince you to make a visit like it convinced me to. According to SoolNua's 2016 annual World ICECREAM Index, Ted Drewes was rated as the world's best ice cream. I am no connoisseur and have no idea how prestigious SoolNua's World ICECREAM Index is, but it sounds pretty cool. I do not know if Ted Drewes is the best custard in the world, but I can say that the custard is pretty darn good and worth a visit.

I am a SF girl with a strong affinity to the Midwest, particularly St. Louis. I have many friends who live or are from the Lou, and it's really insane as one of  my best friend's, college roomie and her hubby, an ex-BF, an old and even a current co-worker, etc., A close friend from SF actually moved to the Lou for law school. Some days I feel like I'm a native since I know much about the city from visiting it at least once a year. 
*As an aside, even in SF, I often meet and run into folks originally from the Lou -- I must send out that "attracted to people from Lou" vibe or something. 

Anywho, I don't ask for much whenever I visit, and the main request is going to Ted Drewes. Words alone cannot describe how much I love this purely St. Louis tradition. This is way better and richer than ice cream or gelato. Regardless of the outside temperature (a hot and humid summer day OR freezing cold winter day), OR how long I have to wait in line, I will always have TD. There are many fIavors and specialities (concretes, sundaes, etc.,) to choose from, and I've ordered everything from a simple vanilla cone to an oreo concrete to a strawberry shortcake sundae. One of my favs is a Teddad, which is their version of an ice cream sandwich, but custard style -  with the frozen custard blended with Dad's Perfect Scotch Oatmeal Cookies. Yum, yum, yum!

Regardless of what is ordered, TD never lets me down. Service is always friendly (midwest charm) and speedy!
Knowing how much I love TD, my friend bought me that infamous yellow tshirt, and I wear it with pride! 

I'm sorry to say that TD will never franchise and expand to the West Coast. Sigh... What a huge bummer!!!  :(  
According to their website, they do "ship orders via DHL,  and shipping one package costs $90 plus the price of the custard for the continental US."  
Holy crap, are you kidding me? That's friggin' expensive and just asinine (that's for you, Kate!!). I'd rather just cope with knowing TD will never make it to SF, and keep coming back to the Lou. Til next time TD!

Despite just raising our blood sugar with gooey butter cake, we had to swing by Ted Drewes on our way out of St. Louis to see what all the fuss is about. 

This was 4th of July BTW so you can imagine, there were quite the lines outside. 

As a n00b to this kind of thing, I was a little bit confused by how the whole thing works but it turns out that it's pretty simple, you get in one of many lines in front of windows with people on the other side and when it's finally your turn, you order, and then subsequently stand slightly to the side where you then wait for your order to be ready. 

They have about a hundred different custard flavors and various ways to enjoy them: malts, shakes, sundaes, floats, ice cream soda, ice cream sandwiches, etc. I deviated from my standard mint chocolate chip and ordered their version of cookies n cream. Idk what possessed my GF to order  an orange SLUSHY at a CUSTARD place but it's a free country. 

One of the great things about this place is that instead of offering standard cup sizes the cup sizes are literally cups that are usually meant for beverages. In other words, they're fucking massive and dangerous imo. 

I wasn't particularly hungry at this time so I ordered the smaller size. 

Both things we ordered were good but standard as far as ice cream goes. I just think the entire experience and variety is maybe what the fuss is all about.

Stopped by this vending machine at Terminal 1, next to Gate A15.  I didn't have time to visit their locations in the city, so I was happy when I found out the airport had a location as well.   They only have a limited selection of concretes, but they are: chocolate chip, strawberry, vanilla, heath and oreo.  I was also able to convince my colleague who was traveling with me to try a custard as well.  Not bad at all when you're in a pinch.
I tried the Crater Copernicus sundae (devil's food cake, vanilla frozen custard, hot fudge and whipped cream).  It was delicious.

I want to write 100 pages on how Ted Drews is the best thing to happen to frozen treats ever. If we ever leave STL this will be the place we talk about for years to come. 

Best most velvety custard I have ever had. 

It brings a little tear to my eye it's so good. 

You're currently closed for the season and I hate you for it. You're a bad drug dealer.

Went with fam on Father's Day.  It was crowded, but the line wasn't too long and went fast.  We ordered mini concretes, which were just the right size for us.  I ordered the terramizzou, with chocolate and pistachios.  I was delicious!  One of us ordered the chocolate dipped cone.  It was a hot day and the custard was melting quickly!  I'm not one to like melted/soupy ice cream, but this was so good that I ate it quickly and didn't waste a drop (even the melty stuff!).  Most of the benches, and especially the ones in the shade, were taken.  So, we hopped back in the car, cranked up the AC and enjoyed our custard.

Why 5 stars? Because THIS St Louis staple lives up to the hype!

   ---   ---   ---

Night and day from my experience at Imo's as a "must-try" while in STL. The marshmallow was thick, creamy, and flavorful. Giggity.

Anytime you can combine the two phenomenons of marshmallow and ice cream, you have to do it. I loved my life while I was indulging this cup of heaven and now I want more. I just might have to find myself in middle America again.

Sooooo... I don't get all the hype about Ted Drewes. It's not amazing (am I allowed to say that?), but it's decent. Well, actually, let me back up a little and say that I'm not from St. Louis. Maybe that clears things up for some of you about why I'm not on the Ted Drewes bandwagon, but I know that for me, it's because their frozen custard is just so so (again, decent, but not amazing). That said, they do have a ton of flavors and it's pretty cheap for how much custard you get. 

Even though the crowd (and the parking lot) might look packed, you actually get your custard (or concrete or sundae or whatever) pretty quickly seeing as they have a lot of lines and cash registers open. Just consider that as part of the experience! 

I'm not as attached as some others are to Ted Drewes, but I would definitely consider going if I had a craving for something cold and sweet!

Located in St. Louis on historic Route 66 Ted Drewes has been selling frozen custard (and occasionally Christmas Trees) since 1929. Frozen custard is mixture of butterfat and egg yolks.  It's very smooth and creamy.  I love Ted Drewes andI have never been disappointed by anything I have ordered there.  I visit the Chippewa location every time I visit St. Louis no matter the time of year (as long as they're open) or what the temperature is outside.  The staff is always friendly and helpful.  Once I wanted to bring some frozen custard home with me to California and they packed my order in dry ice so it would fit on a small cooler I could pack in my suite case.  They did such a good job of it that it made it home completely in tact. On my most recent visit on 12/11/2013 it was 21º outside and there was still of a line of people waiting to purchase there frozen custard.  You a place that serves ice cold desert is popular when people line up sub freezing temperatures to enjoy it.  If you never tried frozen custard you should where ever you can get it.  If you're in St. Louis you should expend any effort necessary to get yourself to Ted Drewes.

Just remarkable.  I can't believe I haven't written a review yet for one of my favorite locations in all of St. Louis: Ted Drewes Frozen Custard!

All I can do is echo some of the other reviewers:

1. The "All Shook Up" concrete is the best (it's banana and Reese's cup).  Heath or Hawaiian-flavored concretes are also great.

2. This place sells CHRISTMAS TREES in December.  Great service and great value (except for the whoppingly-expensive 'Dottie Trees').

3. Ted's is closed from about January 15 - February 15.

4. Avoid it here after Cardinals games!  Alternatively, come after Cards games for the real experience!

5. They sell gift cards!

6. They close when they're out of customers, more or less.  We showed up at 12:15a the other night and barely made it in, to give you an idea.

7. Don't be fazed by long lines.  Those many counters make for a well-oiled MACHINE.

Bottom line is, though, if you haven't been to Ted's, it's high time.
Turtle concrete was excellent.   Service was friendly and extremely fast.   The place was packed and we got our order in just minutes.

Oh, Ted Drewes. This is one of those rare local food obsessions that I feel is actually worth the hype. Having lived in St. Louis for 10+ years, I actually haven't been as frequently as you might think, but every time I go, I love it. The custard is absolute silk, probably the best I've ever had, and their sundaes are hard to resist. I usually go with a Fox Treat or a Cardinal Sin - the tart berries in each are awfully good with the vanilla custard. Plus great butterscotch malts, and they actually know to ask if you want it thin enough to drink (handy for yours truly, driving and thus not able to work a spoon).

I've actually been back more frequently as I drive through the city on vacations than I probably did when I was living here...If you're on your way through, especially if you're on I-44, you owe it to yourself to stop. Just be aware that this place can have some pretty amazing lines. Although, on my last visit, I did discover that going during the middle of Easter dinner was a good option to avoid the rush.

You gotta love a dessert called "Concrete"!  While visiting St.Louis I was disappointed to find out that the Fountain on Locust were closed on Mondays, so it was time for plan B.  Ted Drewe's Frozen Custard to the rescue!  Drewe's flavorful frozen custard was so thick they turn every last one over just to prove it as they hand it to you.  This frozen custard is so rich & creamy you could eat it by it's self, but what would be the fun in that.  I added chucks of chocolate chip cookie dough.  I was so glad that I didn't get the large one, the frosty treat is rich & very filling.  I understand why this is local favorite and how they get away with charging the prices they do.  The kids loved their mini St. Louis Cardinals baseball cap full of "Concrete"!  I would also like to say nice touch on the water dispenser with cups located on the wall for us customers, I gotta say, that is the first time I have ever seen that.

I had no idea what frozen custard is before coming here. I just remember being confused and not knowing what to get. 

The first time I came here was a week into arriving in St. Louis. I remember thinking there were way too many people gathered around the funny looking building. I remember worrying if I can find parking. I remember not knowing if I even LIKED custard. My roommate and I stood in line and stretched our necks to read the menu. I don't remember what I got; I just remember how good it was -- smooth and cold -- as it ran down my throat. It was a fairly warm day. The frozen custard made me very happy.

Since then I've come here a few times. I now know their Reese's concrete is really good and so is anything with raspberry, chocolate, or pistachio... or maybe I'm just extremely fond of those things. I know my favorite flavors are their pies and cakes. Their apple pie concrete is divine as is the pumpkin pie one. (Do yourself a favor and don't try to drink pumpkin beer after eating their pumpkin concrete. Your taste buds will be confused.)  I also love how they serve carrot cake flavored concrete around easter time.

The St. Louis staple.  Apparently my parents were here when my mom's water broke (TMI maybe?).  Later, when I was still a baby my parents returned and supposedly I managed to eat a small cup by myself.  21 years after that, it turns out I have a dairy allergy.

But whatever, there is no stopping me from eating dairy and Ted Drewes is an excellent reason to throw any allergy concerns to the wind.  It's that good.  Even though it was in the 50s when I was there, people were still lining up to get their fix.

The custard here is extremely thick and satisfying.  If you need a comparison for richness and thickness, Freckles would be at the bottom of the sliding scale, Andy's in the middle and Ted Drewes at the top.  I had a sundae with raspberries and macadamia nuts.  It was great.  

Sure custard melts faster than ice cream, but I finished my cup before any meltage occurred.

This place is one of several reasons why I need to return to St. Louis more often.

Finally tried Ted Drewes! This place is one of the things St. Louis is known for so I was so pumped to finally try this place out. Came at around 2 on a weekday and was surprised that there was actually a line?

I will not lie, I have no idea what is the difference between frozen custard and ice cream, but whatever I ate, it was good!
- Cardinal Sin - So so YUMMY! I never had hot fudge on ice cream before and this was the perfect combination. The berry syrup with the rich chocolate contrasted perfectly with the ice cream and I really appreciate the whole chunks of cherry they had in there.
- Peach - I didn't like this one as much, I thought it would be peach flavored rather than mixed in peaches, but once again, I appreciate the whole fruit they put into the custard.

To be honest, I think I like ice cream a little bit more (it wasn't mindblowing), but not mad about this place at all! Will definitely come back because of its prices... it's so cheap!

What can I say about Ted Drewes that hasn't been said before? More importantly, what can a girl who doesn't really like cold things (ice cream included) say about Ted Drewes?

First, this place is a must-stop when you're in St. Louis if you LOVE ice cream/custard (and probably still a must-stop if you're like me and only kind of like ice cream). Every time I take an out-of-town guest here, they just rave about it. I think this is due to the fact that their custard is pretty darn good and very affordable. 

Second, Ted Drewes has a HUGE selection of choices, which is fantastic. You know those Coke machines at some fast food places where they rave that there are over 200 different types of drinks you can choose from? Think of Ted Drewes as the custard version of that Coke machine. There are sooooooo many different delicious things you can mix into their custard (nuts, cookie dough, pistachios, cookies, strawberries, pecans, M&Ms, etc.). The list of different toppings and flavors just goes on and on and on. In addition to a plethora of toppings, you can order a sundae, a shortcake, a banana split, a concrete mixer, etc. Again, the possibilities are endless. In addition to all of these regular choices, they also rotate out several items. For example, the last time I was there they had a salted caramel pretzel custard dish. I truly regret not trying it. 

In terms of service, I've generally been pretty impressed with the speed and friendliness of the staff. There could be over 100 people in line and I've still gotten my custard easily within 10 minutes. With that said, choosing which line to stand in is a lot like Russian Roulette. Sometimes the line takes 2 minutes, but pick the wrong line, and it might take closer to 15. 

In terms of downsides, I can think of only 3. First, there isn't a designated area for picking up your custard after you order it. This creates a cluster-fudge as you end up bumping up against both people who are also waiting for their order, as well as those who haven't ordered yet. Another downside to this place is there is limited to no seating. This means you either eat your custard standing up or eat it in your car and pray that you don't spill the custardy goodness all over your seat. Finally, the parking can be kind of a nightmare given how popular this place is.

Two other important notes. First, there are two Ted Drewes locations. The other one is on South Grand Blvd. Second, it is worth asking the staff what constitutes a small, medium, and large. We ordered a large and were completely overwhelmed by the amount of custard (which is my fault). I just found out that they have a micro mini size, and will definitely be ordering that size next time :).

Wow. SO much hype for this place, including some articles about it being one of the best ice cream shops in the world. REALLY? Y'all need to get out more.

Stopped here on my tour of St. Louis favorites. I LOVE custard, so I was very excited to try the famous concrete. But the ice cream was very melty and not at all thick or cold enough. A lot of pontificating about something that doesn't exist here. Maybe it used to be better and they've gotten sloppy? I also ordered the s'mores flavored concrete, which, had little to no toppings visible.

This is really nothing more than a glorified ice cream stand. There's no seating inside or out, and you know who has better ice cream? DQ. Also, there's this whole myth about Ted's that they turn your concrete upside-down to prove its worthiness. They didn't. You know who does that every time I order a Blizzard? DQ.

Just go to DQ.

I attended a conference in St Louis a few weeks ago, and the only thing I cared about was getting my Ted Drewes fix.  I ordered a Mississippi Mud Concrete, which has waffle cone pieces, chocolate, and something else.  It was delicious and totally worth the stop.  The custard is very soft here, which I like.  Visiting at 11:00 am in the morning also means no lines!

This is a St Louis favorite so you have to stop!

I simply love Ted Drewes, there is nothing like it that I have had so far.  There have been plenty that come close, but this by far is the best in the USA.

They don't have anything that I don't love and enjoy.  Delicious banana splits, mouthwatering sundaes and more.

My problem it is so good and rich, that I gain weight when I treat myself to this lovely indulgence.   They have two locations and they are seasonal, but you can always find this sweet treat in the store,, but nothing like getting it at the source freshly made.

i cant see myself loving anyone elses frozen custard like I enjoy this one.  They have so many flavors and you can make it anyway you want to.

If you are visiting or live here in St. Louis, do yourself a favor and treat yourself to some delicious indulgence and be happy.  You owe this to yourself to try.  Especially if you love frozen custard!

I'm not sure if it's the frozen custard I love so much or the nostalgia of this being associated with my good old college days. They have a huge array of the most amazing custard options. 

I do love the Terramizzou - incredible combo of pistachio and chocolate. The inside are is limited and hard to eat.

Also bonus for Thanksgiving through Christmas: they do have Christmas trees for you. Get two birds with one stone :)

Ahh Ted Drewes.  My friend and I used to skip school and end up here instead.  I have a million favorites.  Great Pumpkin and Big Apple each with a whole slice of pie ground in, Polynesian, and more recently blueberry.  However, nothing can hold a candle to the Bunny Crete.  My friend and I called every single day for weeks to ask if it was in yet.  They grew to know and loathe us by the time the beautiful treasure finally came in.  The Bunny Crete is vanilla custard, cream cheese, raisins, carrot, and nuts.  It's only around for Easter.  I'd try to make it at home, but what would be the point?

Tried Ted Drewes a few weeks ago but didn't really understand the hype.  We arrived about an hour until closing and the custard we got was already semi-melted. The people working the cashier looked about ready to bounce and take a nap also! 

Since I was driving I didn't get a taste of my strawberry and macadamia nut custard right as I got it. It was all right. I do admire all the flavors available though! It definitely had me second guessing what I wanted to taste. I guess it's worth a try if you're in the area. Even an hour til closing there was a little line, but parking was not an issue with the lot they had.

I tried again and this time all 5 cups of concrete were dripping and melted. This is just not how concrete is supposed to be so it is just very disappointing, especially for a place that prides itself on serving "concrete" custard. We got the TeDad's, peppermint, brownie, and pistachio. The peppermint was actual crushed peppermint candy so it's very minty. I didn't try the pistachio but it was green and not just nuts folded into vanilla custard. We've also tried the mint and root beer, which are syrups mixed in. The mint was ok but the root beer was not very good. The flavors were fun to try but we'd get something else next time to explore.

When on vacation, it's rare to find a place you'll wish you could visit EVERY day of your vacation, then wish you'd stayed longer to visit even MORE.  Ted Drewes is just that sort of place.

My wife went with the Twisted Caramel Pretzel Concrete while I decided on the Fox Treat.  Don't worry about making the wrong selection here, I seriously can't imagine ANYTHING not tasting as great as the choices we made.

The Twisted Caramel Pretzel Concrete is exactly what it sounds like (caramel flavored ice cream with pretzel chunks in it), but that doesn't mean it isn't addictively good.  The Fox Treat is ice cream with raspberry and macadamia nuts....oh....my.  I couldn't stop eating it.

If you're a local, I'm comfortable saying you're crazy if you aren't flocking here anytime the weather gets warm.  If you're a visitor like I was, you're crazy for not trying this at least once on your trip, no matter the weather!

If I was made to choose only one confection I'd ever get to have again, it would be ie cream, hands down. But I may have come across something even better (as close as they are) in frozen custard. I'd never had it before visiting St. Louis. So creamy, and the perfect taste treat for summer. They have plain sundaes and some good specialties, and of course I love a banana split. Don't be fooled by the masses of people outside or the full parking lot - you'll wait maybe five minutes for your order, if that long. I can see why they'd not want to francise and dilute their brand and lose quality control, but man I wish they'd open a chicago store! This place will be my first stop next time I'm in St. Louis!

I was there last night, & Oh My! Can I say? This place was PACKED. They have a great selection of frozen custards. Although it was super busy, I was pretty impressed by how fast and efficient they were. I definitely recommend coming here if u just want some nice cold sweets. There's also bathrooms on the side of their building.

To be honest, I had never heard of Ted Drewes until I saw an episode of the NBC reality show, "The Great American Road Trip."  It's an historic Route 66 attraction.  I'm not really sure what sets it apart from any other frozen custard place.  I certainly enjoyed the "Concrete Terramizzou" that I ordered, but maybe I'm just not a frozen custard afficionado.  Still, it's worth a visit to see what all the fuss is about.

Not too much more I can add about this quaint custard shop! It does what it does and it does it well. 

I ordered up a News 11 concrete which had their Scotch Oatmeal cookie and Reese's peanut butter cups blended in. My brother got the Apple Pie concrete which was delicious and my grandma got an apple cobbler drenched in caramel and custard. My grandpa went with his favorite dessert- a banana split and although it was huge, I'm pretty sure his empty container suggests it was tasty! 

We got here right when it opened and got our dessert right away to enjoy on the benches. It'd be nice if they had some tables set up but the absence kind of adds to the novelty of the place. Like many others, this will definitely be a go-to whenever I am back in St. Louis.

While most of St. Louis rightfully knows Ted Drewes for their amazing frozen custard creations (10/10 good all year round), I also know them as my local dry ice dealer. When I'm in need of dry ice for a photo set or fun effects for Halloween, Ted Drewes always has my back. In the morning you can go to the side door, ring the bell, and place and pick up your dry ice order there. Or during regular hours, you can place your dry ice order right at the front counter. Staffers are always happy to help, and now they give out a small paper that has helpful facts about working with dry ice. Best of all, it's only $1/per pound!

Axiom fitness is a real breath of fresh air as far as the 24 hour-ish gyms go. Now I have been a member of the Anytime fitness and Planet Fitness, as well as Snap but this one just is a few steps above in quality and atmosphere. 

From the moment I walked in and was greeted by the staff I was impressed. They have membership people and trainers who also give new members evaluations/assessments for free and of course those at the front desk who great you with a smile each visit. The locker room has been a little less than clean on occasion and the counters are always covered with water and there are no towels, paper or otherwise available for wiping down. This could use some improvement. The facilities seem to be clean at all times and if a piece of equipment seems to be broken, it's only for a day or so before it's back in service.

We were brought here by my sister the first time we visited her in Philly.  La Baia is definitely yummy, with generous portions of traditional Italian fare. I am a fan of BYOB, but the cash-only policy is a little frustrating (my husband had to walk down a shady side street to grab a wad of cash from an ATM after we were done eating). The restaurant is cramped, so if noisy isn't your thing this might not be the place for you. But if you can get past the screaming kiddies or go later in the evening, I could definitely see this being a cute date spot. A solid 3 stars.

This is a quiet neighborhood BYOB, cozy interior. The fare is basic American-Italian, nothing super authentic nor experimental. It's cheap and pretty good for the spectacular pricing. Our waiter was very friendly on the one visit we've made. I'd go again if I were in the neighborhood.

This place is a decent, classic, Italian BYOB, but nothing extraordinary.

I know it's pretty small inside, but both times I've been I sat outside which was really nice.

The service leaves something to be desired.

Had the grilled calamari, which was good, and very simple. Just remember, it's not going to come out crispy or deep fried, so if you're not into that, don't order it.

I think I've tried the fish and veal, neither left a lasting impression.

I had a groupon here one of the times I came and that was a pretty good deal, so I'd definitely come back with a groupon, but probably not otherwise. Brick is right around the corner (although not BYOB) if you want good food, and La Viola and Fontana della Citta are within blocks and are better Italian BYOBs. 

Cash Only.

As many other reviewers have stated, it is a wonderfully tiny Mom & Pop Italian / cash only / BYOB. 

I went on Valentine's Day with a group of 4 total and had an enjoyable, but cramped meal.  The space is TINY.  And I honestly don't think they could fit another table in the space.  After awkwardly climbing over people to get to our seat, the meal was good.  The bread seemed a little stale, but I wasn't that put off by it.

I ordered the Risotto with Salmon, which was simple and delicious.  It was a pretty sizable portion, and the risotto was perfectly cooked.  

Service was average, but understandably busy considering the occasion.

Prices were a bit higher than they appeared on the online menu, but nothing too shocking.

The food here isn't bad per se, but neither is it particularly good.

The pasta was not al dente enough. When the centerpiece of your dish is pasta, it had better be cooked to perfection. The sauces were fine, nothing out of the ordinary. The mushroom appetizer was sauteed with onions, breadcrumbs and parmesan crumbles. There may also have been a few pieces of shrimp hidden in there. While tasty, it was nothing I couldn't make myself. The grilled calamari was also fine: a little on the rubbery side, but the lemon butter herb dip was good. Portion sizes were pretty decent, but prices were a little expensive for what you were getting (~$17 per home-style pasta dish). 

Service wasn't overtly friendly, but neither was it rude. It was perfunctory and serviceable. Also the lighting is now super bright. It used to be super dark. Find a happy medium, people!

All in all, there are better Italian BYOS that cost the same or less, so I would say skip this place unless you're in the area and don't mind paying a lot of money for blandish homecooked food.

While in Philly last weekend, my friend and I went to dinner at Bistro La Baia. It's one of her favorite restaurants, and she was excited to have me try it.

We arrived around 6:30 on a Friday night. We didn't have reservations, and there were a few larger parties that night, so we had a choice of a cramped table in the corner (with a 1 hour limit, as they'd need the table for someone with a 7:30pm reservation), or a table right in front of the door. The restaurant was tiny, like most good Philly BYOB restaurants. However, the number of tables and arrangement made it feel a bit cramped. 

I think the restaurant is owned by a couple and the waiter is their son (pure conjecture!). Throughout the dinner, I couldn't tell if the staff was friendly or unfriendly- they were just very straight-forward and to the point. However, there were a few regulars there who they talked to for awhile and seemed friendly with.

They promptly opened up our bottle of wine, and then brought us some bread. It was delicious, and served with a bowl of olive oil and balsamic vinegar. We ran out of bread quickly and asked for more- they brought us some, but didn't refill our olive oil (sadface). For appetizers, we both ordered Caesar salads ($7 each). I ordered mine without cheese and with dressing on the side (I'm not supposed to eat dairy), and not only was he nice about me being high maintenance, the salad also came out correctly. For our entrees, I ordered potato gnocchi in pesto sauce ($12) and my friend ordered the lobster ravioli ($14). I didn't try her ravioli, but she said it was her favorite dish there.
