My gnocchi was delicious but the sauce was a tiny bit heavier than I was hoping (but still good). We ate ourselves full and still had plenty of pasta left to take home. 

Overall, Bistro La Baia was cute, small, inexpensive, and had minimal frills. Most importantly, the food was tasty and came in quantity. I would definitely go back next time I was in Philly!

Bistro LaBaia is one of my go-to restaurants for BYOB dinners with a large group. It's a small place, so you will definitely need to get reservations if you're planning to bring a crowd. Pin your friends down to make plans in advance, because it is definitely worth it. 

The menu is solid Italian food. I haven't found it to be particularly innovative, but everything is well-done. The prices are reasonable and the portions generous. The grilled calamari are delicious, and if you go with friends you're going to need more than one order to share with everyone. The pollo involtino is good, but ask about the specials of the day because they're often worth trying. I've had some great fish entrees, although I could not tell you what they were!

I've had some off experiences in terms of service, but again I'm usually here with a lot of people, which can be a challenge in such a small space. It's easy to overlook a bit of inattentiveness when you've got a dozen friends and as many bottles of wine to pass around the table while you wait.

For some reason, people love this little Italian eatery.

It is wicked small, and can get loud. But such makes a great Italian BYOB eatery's atmosphere.

The reason it gets 3 stars from me was the food. It wasn't spectacular Italian at all. Actually there is another reason: service. The wait is usually ridiculous (make reservations) and the servers are kinda cold and unfriendly. And if you are in an aisle seat, prepared to get bumped by the servers going in and out of the kitchen!

Two words...Chicken Parmesan.  It isn't on the menu, but ask for it.

La Baia is interesting...definitely a mom and pop joint (which I love) with good italian food.  Who doesn't like an inexpensive italian meal?  And its a BYO.  I would recommend this as a date or for a group of friends...or a double date.  Just a relaxed place to grab some good food.

I think one of the complaints is the service...but with all mom and pop type places, you need to engage the waiter before they will take the best care of you.  So be nice and you have nothing to worry about.

Solid little BYO.

Fresh bread that's piping hot? Check.
Fabulous outdoor seating? Check.
Good food? Check.
Reasonable prices? Check.
BYOB? Check.

What's not to love?

-1 star b/c the staff isn't the friendliest.

I've been here three times now with friends for a large party - birthday, retirement, and another birthday. In a city of really good Italian, it's good. But far from great! 

The starters are rather large portions, but not that creative. Each time I've been here, I've had a boring salad (honestly, it was the only option I was open to / interested in).  The pasta I had was pretty darn delicious and on point (penne arrabbiata) - but honestly, that is pretty hard to get wrong - and it wasn't blow your mind good, but it was certainly good.  The dessert was good - again not great. 

The thing that I really appreciated about this joint, was the service.  We've had large parties here both times, and both times they were MORE than accommodating and helpful, which I really appreciate.  There are just other Italian options I'd pursue first!

I live two doors down from this place and wanted to try it for the longest time. They are always packed when I walk by at night (only open for dinner). Luckily, one night when la viola and la fontana had ridiculous waits, this was next on my list. We arrived just as a large party was clearing out so we were seated right away which was nice. What wasn't so nice is that we were squeezed into a tiny table right by the door when there were plenty of other open tables. 

Anyway, looking past that the food was pretty good. We ordered the calamari, which to our surprise was grilled and not fried. It was good but kind of bland without the breading. I ordered penne with eggplant and marscapone cheese, and my date had some sort of ravioli. They were both really tasty. Nothing crazy, but good, simple italian food. The portions are large, and I had enough of my pasta to take home and eat for another meal. The prices are reasonable as well, and they have a pretty good selection on their menu, which is usually not the case at tiny BYOBs. They are cash only though, so make sure you bring some.

It was a cold night at the end of a long and arduous year, and COVID19 precautions had made dining out (literally, in little wooden sidewalk pod enclosures) less than completely appealing. But this lady was determined to still have a nice chef-prepared dinner for her wedding anniversary, and she was going to trek out by bus and trudge through icy air to get it.

Italian pasta was the plan, and after much searching on Yelp (whereby I discovered many COVID19-related closures), I finally found Bistro La Baia. With promising reviews, we decided to try this option on the outskirts of Rittenhouse Square. Lobster ravioli for me, and penne arrabiata for the significant other. The food was ready right on time when I arrived, and came with a complimentary bundled of delicious slices of Italian bread that practically crackles when bitten into.

The entrees were quite good as well. The ravioli consisted of six pieces, two sauteed shrimp and a rich, creamy tomato sauce. That and half a piece of the Italian bread made for a perfectly portioned and delicious meal for me. The penne arrabiata was a larger portion, and while not the best ever, it still met with the S.O.'s overall approval.

The sidewalk seating wooden pods were empty when I arrived, but that was before 6PM, so maybe the restaurant was busier later in the evening. It really gave me the impression of the sort of place that would primarily be frequented by residents of the surrounding neighborhoods. The one person I interacted with there was very polite and helpful (even giving me time to put my mittens back on before handing me the food for my journey home). I probably wouldn't have thought to try Bistro La Baia under most circumstances, so it was a nice discovery. I hope that it'll be able to survive the wave of restaurant closures that Philadelphia has seen as a result of the pandemic.

I arrived here a bit ahead of the party that I was joining. The host seated me promptly, and offered to open the bottle of Malbec I'd brought with me. I thanked him and poured myself a glass while I waited.

And then my dates arrived. All 16 of them. Just kidding, though I was in fact the only guy at the table - thank you, ballet class. Wine gets poured, orders are taken - soup of the day and calamari - and all the usual comings and goings of a restaurant occur thereafter.

I know complimentary bread with olive oil is a standard thing, but I still find it to be delicious, so that was pleasant.

The food came out, and I thoroughly I enjoyed their mushroom soup. Their grilled calamari was also good - nice charred flavoring, while at the same time retaining a moist, springy-but-not-chewy texture.

Service was quick and efficient, if not overly familial. Suggestions came out quickly, along with answers to any questions we had. Bottles were opened when they needed to be, water was poured when it was empty, nd empty bottles were taken away.

All in all, this place is nice - cozy and quaint. Nothing I'd write home about, but definitely worth a visit. You may love it.

Also, I like that it's a BYO. Though, I may want to hit it on less busy nights.

Pro-tip: Be prepared to be around a lot of college aged folks. Meaning you may make guest appearances in lots of Facebook pictures. Also, this place is cash only!

For a restaurant week date night, I decided it was time to try Bistro La Baia. I have passed this cute little Italian spot plenty of times walking through my neighborhood and checked out the mixed reviews here on Yelp. My boyfriend and I decided we'd see for ourselves what we thought of Bistro La Baia.

We were easily able to make our reservation by calling about a week in advance. While on the phone they let us know that they are BYOB. I noticed that past reviews note that it is cash only, but we learned that they do accept cards now. Upon our arrival for our Sunday night dinner, we were seated immediately, and brought water and bread with oil and balsamic.

Contrary to other reviews, the service was extremely prompt. We placed our full orders from starters to desserts and within minutes our first dishes were brought out. We were so shocked by the quick service that I checked the time, and learned we had been there 15 minutes when our entrees arrived. The entire experience start to finish took 48 minutes, but we did not feel rushed at all. I was seriously blown away considering what I had read from others regarding slow service being a big issue.

To eat, we started with the Eggplant Rollatini and Arancini. The Arancini was not crisp on the outside, but the flavor was good and the sauce was delicious. The Eggplant Rollatini was delicious and similar to the arancini, the sauce was perfection. I'm super picky when it comes to tomato sauce and I would genuinely eat this with a spoon. For entrees, my boyfriend had the Pappardelle con Salsiccia. The pasta was fresh, sausage was flavorful, and the sauce was delicious. The dish was very hot temperature wise as well, which was great because we made our walk over in the snow. For my entree, I had the Chicken Parmesan which was a gamble on my part. I tend to skip ordering chicken parm out, because I'm really picky. However, the picture of the dish on their website intrigued me so I went for it. I'm so glad that I did! The chicken was not crispy, but it was thinly sliced and portioned well. I ordered a side of veggies with it instead of the pasta. The veggies were so well seasoned! For dessert, we tried the Chocolate Cake and Panna Cotta. Both were great, but we both preferred the chocolate cake.

From start to finish, the service was attentive, the food was delicious, and the portions for the price were perfect. We're super excited to return with friends and enjoy this neighborhood BYOB gem!

I did not know this location in Clearwater was the very first original Hooters until I looked it up on Yelp.  So does it mean the food or the girls they have better than other locations??  The answer is no!  

I have been to Hooters only once besides this time.  That  was in NC...the food was much better (not saying their food was great....it was decent).   The food I had in Clearwater was just disgusting.  

Now the service.  Our waitress was nice to us but I think she just wanted to get good tips.  Other girls who weren't serving out table were just terrible.  They got no smile on their faces, no greeting and they do not even acknowledge your existence.  One of my friends was going to  fill an application for a waitress position here, but she passed. She said the girls were very bitchy and mean to her....so that's their real faces just so you know.  But I am a girl and so is my friend.  If you are a guy, you would probably get treated better.  

I just wished I would have gone to some other place to have a better lunch.

I think this place is an great place to grab some wings and catch up with your friends. It may get busy and crowded at times but it's a great place meet new and old friends. This is the original Hooters so that's something to be proud of and most of the girls will help you no matter what. 

The food has always been good. I love the blue cheese burger, wings, raw oysters and the buckets of oysters!

Went here for lunch and had steamed shrimp and teriyaki baked wings. Great food and quality. The customer service was outstanding by our waitress, always checking in on us, making sure our table was clean, and topping off our drinks.

Just OK. We came tonight on a Saturday night around 830pm. The wait time was told 25/30 mins but ended up being about 10 minutes only. Wings & curly fries are hot & GOOD! Clam chowder was thick & medium brown color. Did not taste good. The sweet tea was NOT good either. 3 star rating because food quality service was just OK. I still enjoy Hooters wings but I would rave too much. This particular location has a huge selection of novelties to bought Hooters gear. Great BIG selection of cups / clothes etc.  If you need Hooters gear come here. Food is OK
3 stars because this is the original and it is an OK place to stop for a beer. The food is pretty mediocre in my opinion. I just never liked anything on the menu.

I am not a Hooters guy by any stretch of the imagination.  The casino in Vegas was pretty deplorable, and I only suffered through that to see a concert.  However, when I saw a sign indicating that this was the ORIGINAL location of Hooters, I felt compelled as a man to see what all of the fuss was about.  After all, it was this very location that spawned a nationwide chain of restaurants, an airline, and plenty of controversy along the way.  There must be something magical about this place.  

Or not.  I liked the layout of this bar and restaurant.  Being Florida, they have additional outdoor seating year-round which gives the place an informal, breeziness.  The ambiance is laid back and is definitely a chill place to grab a beer or see a sports game.  The eye candy was really incidental to the place for me.  

I popped in for lunch and put in a to-go order.  I was able to get a 6-piece wing lunch with fries for either $6 or $7, I can't recall.  Either way, it was especially cheap.  Waiting at the bar, my order was filled in not even 5 minutes.  The service was gracious, and the food was generally bad.  The wings are breaded and really oily, and the fries are curly and bland.  It cries out for a beer, but this was lunch.  Oh well.  I should say though that these wings are better than the ones I had at the Hooters in Fredericksburg, VA during trivia nights years ago, but I am quibbling about gradations of badness.  This is nothing you would likely want to eat on a regular basis.  The location was nice enough though for me to visit on a drinks-only basis.  Recommend for that.  3 stars because they are the original restaurant, and that is about as high as I could rate any Hooters really.

Enjoyed being able to say I went to the Original Hooters. Service was-- eh... the girl wasn't really attentive and brought us our Caesar Salad with no eating utensils and we couldn't find her for a good 5 minutes after she walked away. Then we get our wings and sauce, we get 2 ranch 2 bleu cheese, yet we didn't ask for any bleu cheese. YUCK! She also forgot to bring out our potato salad, and we had to wait for her to show her face for a good 10 minutes. When we finally got it, again, she's MIA. She took our forks with the salad, so guess what? We damn near ate the whole thing with our hands. Wings were really good as any other hooters. I had a drink that came with a tall hooters girl glass, and you got to keep the glass. The drink was pretty delish, can't remember the name of it but it was the only one that you could get the glass with, that wasn't creamy. 

Food was good but the service needs help!

Store Numero Uno! #1. 
As mentioned this "historic property" had seen it's better days until the renovation. I've come here to get away from the hectic life of retirement, ;-P do brews with buffalo boneless wings, and watch sports on the tube! I've also done two run races which American Running Company has done with Hooters. Those events rocked and I will continue to do it yearly! Hooters is Hooters! It's as simple as that. It's just a good place to hang out!

I don't really like Hooters but it is on our way home from Tampa and we tend to stop on our way home from a USF football game. We usually call our order in when we are about 15 minutes out. We often have to wait for it when we get there, which is not that big of a deal but on this occasion, I think our food was ready and the girls just weren't paying attention because my husband noticed boxes sitting up by the grill and he had to tell them about it.

The thing about getting take out wings is that by the time you get home the steam in the box has caused the breading to get soggy or even falling off. We've eaten at this establishment before and the food is better when you have it there (like most wing places, I have had the same experiences at Wing House so this is not just a Hooters thing.)

I get boneless wings, my husband gets regular wings. I really am not a fan of breaded wings, but the boneless ones are ok.  My husband loves Hooters wings so that is a big reason we go to any Hooters. 

There is inside and outside seating and they have a really big parking lot so those are some other good features about the restaurant.

Was in Florida for 2 months training for a job and Hooters was a frequent stop for my friend and me. Unlike a lot of folks I actually dig the food, especially the wings. 

I've gone to Hooters in SF, San Diego, and Dublin, the girls at the Clearwater location were better looking and nicer than the other locations. I've gone to the Hotel in Vegas too but that doesn't count cause well...it's Vegas and everything "looks" better in Vegas right?

The Grouper sandwich at this place was pretty tasty. Battered and fried fish served on a seasame seeded kaiser roll. Can't really go wrong with that right?

Hot busy day and stumbled in absolutely starving. One look at the gorgeous waitress and said a little prayer hoping for fast, and competent service before I just broke down and started spraying condiments down my gullet in a hungry act of desperation. Thought I could get by, by adding some crab legs to a few wings and possibly some shrimp. Wasn't going to happen. Only got to order five wings-thats it. My man got the other five, and a salad with a couple beers. After a bug-carcass filled beer, and a few wings we realized we weren't getting any more food. Not only could we not order any additional food after the first round, but what we did order would never be delivered to us. Server is AWOL although I can see her just inside the window fixing her face in a Covergirl mirror. Deciding we might sustain our lives by eating the salad we eventually got, it arrived all wrong. We cancel the order and crawl to Pete and Shorty's next door for nutrition. Had a far better experience sans young retarded waitress with coochie cutter shorts and tights that didn't match her skin tone. yay!

Had to check out The Original Hooters of Clearwater Florida. I was waited on by Danielle who was absolutely spectacular helping me decide on what to order.  I decided on the lunch special of 6 buffalo shrimp and 6 boneless wings with Hooters special sauce. They have a great bar withtons of tv's for the sports fan. When in Clearwater, a stop at Hooters is a must. Don't forget to ask for Danielle.

I was joking around with my friend "Hooters has to be the biggest business in Florida!"  He informed me that the original location was right here in Clearwater.  With that bit of information, I knew we had to go.  I usually make fun of people who take kids to hooters, but I'm guilty as charged.

It wasn't different than any other Hooters.  It was on the small side, the drafts were lacking, and the talent was lacking.  The Hooters in Texas are better and they're not even good.

Yes, it's the original Hooters location, opened in 1983. They're still serving up wings, shrimp, oysters and beer, but have since added to the menu to include wraps and even little dessert bites.

Our waitress, Momma J., who is expecting a little one, along with Assistant Manager, Pat, were on point in making sure the oysters, shrimp, curley fries and wings were exactly to our liking.

I was craving something other than beer, so I got a Red Sangria. Icy-cold and refreshing, it was just what the doctor ordered. My Daytona-style Sweet-Thai wings were also just right. But, the two of them together--not a marriage made in Heaven. No one's fault, but my own.

The waitresses STILL wear the little white tee-shirt material tops and the teeny shorts, just like they did it in the 80's.  Back then, it was pushing the envelope, but pretty tame by today's standards.

There are plenty of TV's all around with different sports on each, should you run out of conversation topics.  One of my friends mentioned the noise level, as it is a bit on the noisy side.  

If ya haven't visited a Hooters by now---where have you been?

Holy cow! No one's reviewed the ORIGINAL Hooters location?  i have been graced with being the first?? Wow.
So where to begin? THis place has so much history and local gossip that I'm not sure is appropriate to share......  

In any case, its a 2 story looking beach shanty on your right off 60 as you head towards CLW beach.  The food is like any other Hooters - oily breaded wings which I'm not a huge fan of.  Their clam chowder is ok.  Their curly fries are pretty good.  Service is friendly and pretty laid back adding to that super beachy floridian appeal. Typical local joke is that the girls working are the original hooters girls too (its not).  Definitely worth a stop just to say youv'e been there - but i've never been huge fan of their food so I can't really give them high marks.

+ great wings
- slow service, no wifi

This is the original Hooters.  It's nice inside, with updated decor.  Lots of booths, and super friendly waitresses.  I was disappointed they did not offer free wifi.

Bar is very open and loud, so be prepared for a not so quiet meal.  But it is Hooters, so you really can't complain.

How could I not like Sonic?  They have a Peanut Butter Shake.  I've had a hard time finding those, so I always enjoy resisting the urge to actually get one.  My waistline clearly shows how often I am successful at this.

You really can't go wrong with Sonic!

I was sat with in a few minutes of arriving. My waitress, Anita, came by and took my beverage order in a very timely manner. I see a slew of really recent negative reviews. I had absolutely no issues with either service or food quality or the speed and accuracy of my Slam. I don't get to this Denny's often, but I rather enjoyed the causal ambiance.  Not exactly a diner, yet comfortable and fast. As for my breakfast, I made a slam of scrambled eggs, white toast, bacon and sausage. Every tasted very good. I really liked the thin, crispy bacon which was crunchy and not smoky. The thick ceramic mug really held the heat of the coffee which was served piping hot.

Panaderia y Taqueria Lili is a small restaurant on Kirkwood Highway inside a small strip of businesses near the YMCA. The unpresuming exterior belies a modestly decorated inside with tables and seating for thirty. Perhaps the most striking feature upon entering is the counter, behind which the large kitchen is open and visible. 

This restaurant serves Mexican food, with tortas, burritos and tacos in a traditional style. The al pastor is good, and adding piña accentuates the spices nicely. Asada and bistec are both delicious here, and the adovada is cooked well. I recommend trying the salsas, which provide an infusion of flavor and a not unwanted kick of heat.

The refrigerator has plenty of refreshing favorites like Jarritos and Sidral Mundet. The baked goods, from what I've tried, are also delicious. The service can be expedited through use of Spanish. It won't be long before I return. I give this restaurant five stars for offering delicious, affordable Mexican food.

When I saw a new "fancy" restaurant was opening in my hood, I was pretty excited. Super bonus: they have shrimp and grits on the menu! I am giving the place a 3.5 stars just because they have only been open about a month and they are still working out some issues.

We were here for lunch and there was a good crowd, but it wasn't packed. They have a pretty diverse menu with things like fried catfish, shrimp and grits, pasta and even lobster. I decided to be less predictable this time and I get the corn and crab bisque and the fried catfish Lafitte lunch special which came with sausage jambalaya.

The waitress brought out my entree before my corn and crab bisque. I had intended the bisque to be my appetizer, but I guess I should have mentioned that, The catfish was interesting. It was topped with red sauce (which the waitress mentioned ahead of time) and it was fried nicely. The jambalaya was okay, but didn't really dazzle me.

The corn and crab bisque was just okay, as well. It didn't taste the way other bisque I have had in the past tasted. I don't know how to explain it, but I was expecting more. My dad got the shrimp and pasta and wasn't that into it either. He was so not into it that he let me take his leftovers home so I could eat it later. When I tried it, all it was was flavorless pasta and overcooked shrimp- disappointing.

Our waitress was beyond sweet and made sure that we were happy with everything. Like I said, this spot has only been open a month so I expect them to work out the issues and do okay. One suggestion: you offer an entree of shrimp and grits for $19; I would love if you would offer an app size for maybe half that price.

The food isn't bad at all the flavors are good. Chicken wings could be a bit more flavorful though. The yams are great. The macaroni & cheese flavors are great but not consistent. I've been here twice & they look completely different (look at pics) also the noodles are OVER cooked which is a big no no. They were over cooked both times which is a shame. I tried the dollar shrimp but they were soaked in the sauce which made them soo soggy. I will only come back if I'm desperate

Sometimes I like Don's and sometimes I don't.  They have a great selection of guns--no debate.  They are also tremendously overpriced--in both firearms, ammunition, and in their range prices.  I have a lot more reservation about the clientele of the store than the management.  I have purchased three guns from Don (and his associates), and I thought they seemed to go the extra mile to make sure I wasn't a felon or a mental health case.  Besides the government forms you have to fill out in order to purchase a gun, they also have their own form with extra questions.

The staff at Don's is hit-or-miss.  Several of them are ultra-friendly and honest salesmen and several are not.

O
Been here twice. Love the arrabiata and the ambience, but the service is reliably sleepy and the list a bit overpriced. Convenient location from downtown and East Nasty.

We were craving classic Italian cuisine and our search through Yelp's reviews brought us here. 

There is a small parking lot behind the restaurant and a municipal lot directly across the street. No more valet parking 

Our reservations were on the late side, intentionally, after the show crowd cleared out. We were seated promptly in the large open dining area and our waitress was friendly and efficient, respecting our wishes to enjoy a leisurely meal.

We brought an old Italian wine - corkage is a reasonable $20 - and paired this with our meal after a starter glass of prosecco.

We shared the Bruschetta and Mozzarella Caprese with our bubbles and then built our own pastas - you pick the pasta and one of eight sauces and any of the toppers (veggies, fish, meats).

Pasta dishes were fresh and plentiful and we were pleasantly full at the finish. 

Overall a good spot for an Italian meal downtown.

Was at the NAMM show last week and checked out Sole Mio for dinner on Friday night. Wow. That's what I can come up with right now as I think back on the deliciousness that was our meal.

First off, their bread is crazy good. I know they say don't fill up on it, but I love carbs and I sort of did. But I don't regret it. Also, try the caprese - it was perfect.

For dinner I did a pre fixe option with a Cesar salad, stuffed salmon with vegetable risotto and for dessert I got the chocolate amaretto cake. How I wish I could have that entire meal right here, right now!

The salad was fantastic - everything seemed from scratch and the dressing was out of this world. The salmon - a huge portion and stuffed with yummy goodness like shrimp and other things. It came on a bed of vegetable risotto and although that was just slightly overcooked, the salmon more than made up for it. The chocolate amaretto cake was decent - good even - but I was missing the amaretto. Just not quite enough kick there.

They've got a GREAT wine list and even though the service was a little slow, our waiter was pretty on top of it and attentive. He knew the menu well and gave some great suggestions. It's the real deal Italian - worth stopping by if you're in Nashville.
Not a lot of veggie juice options. But the wheatgrass shot is great and super affordable. They also have good protein bar options.

Smoothies are always good. Service is usually good, but every so often they have someone taking smoothie orders who should perhaps be making smoothies instead as they are not as cheerful, helpful or pleasant as the normal staff.

Thanks again to Coty S. for making such a great suggestion/review/point in the right direction. (Seriously, guys, if you're looking at Asian whatever, she's a good one to check.)

So I got my first Florida paychecks today and decided to use a little of that to take myself and the Mr. out on the town. Here is where we ended up and both of us couldn't have been happier.

Honestly, the service was wonderful. We asked our server what he would suggest (I haven't had Vietnamese since I got Stateside from Thailand five years ago, and the Mr. has never had). He was efficient and described what each section had. We did get vegetarian spring rolls (pictured), and they were WONDERFUL. I'm not sure what the sauce was, but it was a winner.

On to dinner. (I know that our server apologized for the "long wait", but it couldn't have been more than a few minutes. I guess that just speaks to their desire to be quick and efficient? =] ) I got the Ph Rau Ci (veggie rice noodle soup, pictured) though I don't think I made it through a quarter. The portions are *generous*, and for $8 I have at least two or three more meals with what I brought home. The Mr. got Bún Gà Nng (grilled chicken on vermicelli, pictured), which he enjoyed thoroughly.

We both know that this is a place we'll go again. Not only was the service great, the food delicious and the restaurant clean, but it was really affordable. I would suggest this to anyone that asked. =]

It's so nice to know that I can get vegetarian pho. True, that doesn't make the broth very flavorful, but now that the weather is cooling down, a hot bowl of pho is delicious no matter what's in it.

What's pho? It's a soup, usually made with beef stock, and it comes with fresh herbs and bean sprouts that you add yourself. You can also add a bit of soy, sriracha, etc. to make it more to your liking, but you'll probably like it just as it is.

Unfortunately, because the designer of the strip mall was thoughtless (and the landlord hasn't fixed the problem), the nearest wheelchair ramp is at the front end of the strip mall, all the way up by Jason's Deli, and there is no ramp near Pho Quyen at the back end. So if you're coming in a chair, park at the Fowler end of the building and head north on the sidewalk.

I tried Pho Quyen again after a disappointing first experience.  It has mostly redeemed itself.

The first time I went to Pho Quyen, I tried the Bun with pork and egg roll.  I found the sauce to be heavy on the fish sauce, and I did not enjoy the experience.

This time, I tried the combination Pho, and I found it very satisfying after doctoring it up with a little sriracha and a heavy amount of basil (and some lime).  The broth was beefy, and I enjoyed the quality of the tendon used.  The different cuts of beef were all quite good and not tough.  

The young coconut juice was very refreshing.

Service is only okay, but I don't expect much.

Prices were on the high side for pho.  I guess these are Temple Terrace prices.  I have a feeling that pho at any of the Vietnamese places on Waters would be much more reasonable.

Met my friends Rachel and Fern here for lunch. Have not had good Pho since San Diego so I was eager to have some warm noodles with the cold weather Tampa was experiencing this past week. Oh how I miss my Vietnamese friends in San Diego. They would order for me every time so I did feel a little lost looking at Pho Quyen's massive menu. 

It took us awhile to order because we were not only catching up but also discussing the menu items. Out of no where we heard what we thought was a duck quacking loudly. We looked around and did not see a duck -- it did not sound distressed. I realized later that the duck we were hearing was no other than a cell phone notification but for some reason struck us as funny. We were laughing so hard at one point I had tears rolling down my face. 

Decided get the vegetarian spring rolls for an appetizer and for my entree opted for the vegetarian Pho. Wow were those spring rolls fresh. When I bit into them you could taste the fresh veggies snap. If you like fresh spring rolls then I highly recommend them. My vegetarian Pho was kind of bland -- just needed more seasoning. The veggies were all fresh and plentiful -- there were a massive amount of noodles. So many I could not eat them all. Next time going to try one of the meat dishes. Perhaps there will be more seasoning. Will be back  -- cannot get my mind off of the those yummy spring rolls.
Delicious broth and tons of yummy veggies and tender chicken. I like to order the chicken pho and add veggies. It's filling and nutritious!

Great place to go by campus. Their food is fresh and they have lots of options. I especially like their curry chicken and spring roll bun. The spring roll bun is sort of self-indulgent, but how can you go wrong with tasty fried food on noodles. I also enjoy their broken rice with pork chop. I recommend spending the extra money on the pork chop, as you get a nice, big, fresh portion. I haven't liked their sautéed dishes as much, but I've only had their lemon grass vegetarian chicken.

We had great service, and the food was very good, but we would have walked out were it not for all the positive reviews here. It smells oddly of stale urine when you walk in the front door. At least, it did the day we visited in pouring rain and flood conditions. Further into the restaurant, it wasn't noticeable, but it negatively color our impression. The wonton soup was good if a little band and the shrimp and pork soup was awesome. The accouterments featured cilantro instead of Thai basil. Worn interior, but clean.

Came here to warm up w some yummy soup and yummy spring rolls. They did not disappoint. My mom and I ordered a beef soup and my dad ordered the sweet and sour soup w fish. They were all good and warmed us up nicely but the sweet and sour soup w fish was a yummy surprise. I need to order that next time along with rice vermicelli noodles w pork and fried spring rolls. I still find Vietnamese restaurants challenging to order from but I am always wanting more.
I liked this location. Service was pretty good. I would come back again.

Subway has tasty lower-fat sandwiches for Brentwood. This one is in the Kroger shopping center. Newest item I tried is the Sweet Onion Chicken Terriyaki sandwich which I enjoyed with their Dannon natural yogurt. I also was good  by having the baked, not fried, potato chips. I was surprised the baked tasted as good as the fried ones I was used to. They have seven other "Fresh Fit" sandwiches like veggie, roast beef and turkey on their new low fat Fresh Fit menu, as well as the classic Subway favorites.
This is a clean and well run Subway.  When the line gets long during the lunch rush, they seem to process folks through pretty quickly.

Mm yea GC is SUCKING these days. How complicated is it to make lo mein properly if you've been cooking it all day every day for... decades? Lo mein here has become consistently greasy & has a lovely burnt flavor. It's so oily that I leave the last few mouthfuls so I don't have a heart attack on the spot. The food here overall is overpriced and crappy. The one thing I order [shrimp w/broccoli] is really hard to F up, but eating with other folks has shown me how hit or miss GC is. For some reason it always takes 10 light years to get the food when I order in store for sit-down service. That gives me homicidal thoughts that I can't shake for days.

This place isn't even trying anymore. They know they don't have to because an entire neighborhood that's flush with cash thinks GC is the only viable option for Chinese. See all the reviews post 2008? They ain't lyin. Forget MY first review & get your Chinese somewhere else!

Delivery is my specialty. lol. I love ordering-out when I'm way too busy at work. Either late lunch or dinner. I have ordered the veggie dumplings fried and steam. It is really good. My fave is the Beef Cho Ho Fun extra spicy. They are just as good as Chinatown food. I've had many other menu items from here and have never been disappointed.

From String Beans in Garlic sauce to Fried Chicken. The only thing is the delivery sur charge. lol. $1.50 is not much to ask but if your a good tipper then that just sucks.

This would be a highly recommend place to order take-out. I get my deliveries to Brewerytown and they are pretty quick.

I had the worst chinese of my life here. That says a lot considering I have had chinese food in places like Utah and upstate New Hampshire. It was so greasy and foul I ended up throwing it out. I probably should have known better given the skeezy neon lights.

The eggrolls tasted like they had been fried, then thrown aside for 6 or so hours, and then refried in really dirty oil. So gross.

The chicken with broccoli was a greasy mess. It tasted like it had been reheated as well. The kung pow chicken was also swimming in old grease. 

I have heard other people say they like it, but I really don't think I am going to give them another chance. I'll stick with Chinatown.

I ordered take out from here last night, which apparently was a mistake. I was at a friend's house in NoLibs, which yes, is about 18ish blocks away, but still not that far.

It took close to 2 hours to get our food delivered. When the delivery guy finally arrived, he wouldn't hand me the bag, but kept showing me the receipt. I told him that I'd already paid because I ordered online. He then made me wait while he called his boss. During this process, he set the bag down on a step, only to have it topple over. Seriously, guy, you made us wait way too long, so just give me our food and beat it.

The food itself was whatever. Outside of Chinatown, all Chinese places taste relatively the same.

I judge a Chinese food restaurant by the wonton soup and Golden Chopstick is A-OK in my book. The food isn't gourmet, but at the same time it's solid. After much local experimentation, I think it might have landed the spot of go-to for basic Chinese take-out and delivery.

For my most recently order, my husband and I ordered a ton of food including multiple pints of wonton soups, Singapore Mei Fun, "diet" chicken & veggies with garlic sauce and a side of rice. They clearly thought there were more than two people dining because we got 4 fortune cookies. I'm always amused by their analysis of the number of diners based on the fortune cookies given. 

In any case, it was all tasty and stretched into two meals. Bottom line was that the food was flavorful and the dishes were prepared how they should be. I'll be ordering from them again.

Ok, I came here on the advice of co-workers who basically said "Don't eat at Long River" - which is across the street from my office.

So I trudged over the 2-3 blocks to Golden Chopstick, stood in a pretty long line and ordered a Chicken & Stringbean lunch special with brown rice to go. "Light on the sauce", I implored.

Service was friendly and the order took about 6-8 minutes to come out (not bad considering there were 7 people ahead of me.)

Walked the take-out grub back to my desk and voila.  Tasteless - abut thankfully not greasy due to the lack of sauce.  Beans were the best part - crisp.  Chicken (thankfully white meat) was bone dry and flavorless.

Not sure If I'd ever come back.

Now I am really in fear of Long River.  This is supposed to be the "good" Chinese place near my office.

Oh well.

My new go-to Chinese delivery service.  I ordered from here last Sunday when I was way too lazy and tired to leave my couch.  The deal was outstanding.  I got the dinner combo of sweet and sour chicken and vegetable fried rice.  It came with an egg roll and won ton soup and was literally $10. 

The delivery was prompt and they bring an iPad with them, so you can pay with your card.  I am happy to have found this spot and am v excited to continue ordering from here! 

Disclaimer: not luxurious or decadent Chinese, basically fast food type, so if you're into that like I am - this place is for you!
Good decent kinda crappy chinese food (and I mean that in a good way).  They have quick delivery, a n expansive menu and it's cheap (around $7for the combo)
Perfectly mediocre takeout Chinese.  I get the mixed veggies with tofu and yes, it does have too much oil in it but this isn't Chinatown.

I agree with Scott F. This is our neighborhood Chinese spot and I have to say, the food is decent, CHEAP, and the service is great. We can order our food and have it delivered in 20 minutes. Plus, it's enough to feed the two of us for more than one meal. It's Chinese food. I have no complaints!

Delivery took 40 minutes and this place is 0.4 miles away...

Hot and sour soup is actually one of the better ones I've had

Broccoli with shrimp and garlic sauce was just OK. 

Also had quite the trip in the bathroom later that day... can't point fingers but I'm assuming...

For what it's worth, Golden Chopstick is a great place to go if you're in the Spring Garden area and are looking for well-priced yet delicious Chinese food.  Came here on a lunch break from a face painting class taught by a master artist from Vegas who was unfamiliar with the area, so everyone in the workshop decided to come here for lunch.  Thank goodness we were able to find a table big enough to seat everyone!  If I'm in the area again I will most definitely come back!

Hands down the best Chinese takeout since I moved to Philly. They deliver quickly and you can do it all online. The food is consistently good and always fresh. They will make it spicy to taste, and lt you ask for xtra veggies

Hooray for GC, which looks nicer than your average grimy Chinese take-out joint, but is your average grimy Chinese take-out joint at heart.  You can sit inside if you like and take in the ambiance of crazy purple neon lights along the windows.  They look radioactive.  I think there's a TV in there, too.

How's the food?  It tastes how the food always tastes at a Chinese place with industrial tile flooring and strange glowing photographs of anonymous plates of food above the counter.  I think they even sell those giant plastic containers of iced tea/lemonade.  That's just nasty, but their food is fine--you know how it is.  If have $5 and you want some, go get it!

I ordered the Sichuan Tofu.  On the menu, it shows two hot peppers next to this item.  This lead me to believe it would be at least moderately spicy.  Unfortunately, there wasn't as much heat as I hoped.  The service was friendly.  But since I ordered with a group, our food took much longer to be served.  The food portions were generous considering the price.  And not surprising, the quality of food was sacrificed.

If you're in the mood for Chinese, not looking to spend much, and aren't ordering in a group, Golden Chopstick should work out.
Closed as of 1/3/13. If you bought a Groupon you can redeem it at Marhaba across the bridge in Lambertville

Surprisingly tasty sushi at an adorable price.

J Sushi boat for $60 covered with a soup, salad, and edamame on top of 2 rolls and 21 pieces of sushi. The pink lady took had a lot of slices. I'm not a sushi fan but would definitely go back. 

 Parking is a bit difficult there but you can find street metered parking around.

Delivery through multiple online platforms.    There was a mixup on my order, and they called me right away to clear everything up.   The hostess was very pleasant on the phones as well.     

The salad actually had decent ginger dressing & the sushi was really fresh.   Although I ordered veggie rolls, all the ingredients were top notch.   I also appreciated the interesting and different makis like eggplant tempura roll...yum!    

All told a good new rotation for my work lunch splurge days.    And the delivery was on time or even a bit early.

They accept credit credit. I really hope that this place stays in business because it is probably the best sushi place that I have been in Philly. All the staff were super friendly and accommodating. Restaurant is very clean and modern looking. Overall quality of the fish was solid: had the spicy roll combo (8 pieces each of spicy tuna, salmon, and yellowtail). What was special was their plates. All of them had some cherry blossoms or butterflies drawn with sauces, which I thought was a really cool touch.

I've gotten delivery and take out from this sushi place and both times I thought it was just okay. Honestly, there are a ton of sushi places in the area and this one just doesn't live up to expectations. 

We tried the 2 roll special combo with the pink lady roll and the christmas roll and the 3 roll special combo with the white tuna avo, salmon avo, and spicy tuna rolls.

Sure, the price is pretty good for sushi.. 14.99 for 3 rolls plus soup is ridiculous and a good option when you don't want to spend a lot. But the sushi just doesn't taste that fresh and they love glopping a ton of sauce all over the rolls. I had to physically scrape the tops of all the rolls I got because of how much spicy mayo and other gloppy sauce was all over them. Not how I like my sushi.

The kids working here may still be "in training" ... We stopped by a few weeks after they finally opened and honestly it was just to try the new queso. 

Strike 1: Guess what ... They were out of queso at the start of the dinner rush! It was like 5:30 p.m. on a Tuesday. Shouldn't everyone be at Taco Tuesday over at TFlats? Come on now!

Strike 2: My husband's burrito was overloaded with black bean juice and fell apart before he took his first bite. 

The layout of this location feels awkward and I couldn't figure out why. Maybe it's a smaller Chipotle? 

I like Chipotle in general, this visit was just a little bit of a let down.

The adults only tag line just means no kids, so no funny business. It's a decent place and the staff is super friendly. Surprisingly the area is pretty quite. The rooms are pretty cheap as well. Not the best quality but lots of space. The rooms are huge!

Wi-Fi is limited. There is one spot near the office door leading to the pool that has it.

Overall, decent for a large group of drunkies.
My experience goes back and forth as of recent I felt the need to let you all know service has improved and errors have decreased!  Also, back in menu is the beloved white cheddar I missed!

I don't think I've ever seen such a well-stocked DD before.  Walking up, my cousin said, "Boston Cream," and I replied back by stating a DD in a gas station is sure to be sold out of Boston Creams at 2 in the afternoon.  Everyone knows they're the first to go, but not at this DD.  Not only were they in stock, but in freaking BULK bro!  And yes, they were fresh.  In fact, everything was fresh.  I've been to a lot of DD in my day, and I've never seen anything like it.  Ordered up a medium iced coffee, a Boston Cream and hit the road.  They should all be like this.

I come here pretty often but never make the time for a review so I figured I'd leave one.  So far I would say been coming here for about 4 years maybe everything is come out as ordered and the ladies at the drive-through are quite helpful and friendly.  I even have ordered ahead of time when I want to bring something into the office and they do a great job!!

Lately now, everything I love we don't quite have ?  a few of my favorites were white cheddar, or turkey bacon, or go bars!  Guess it's a corporate decision . Service has also become spotty, most of time I use drive in but I've come in a few times too and depends who's on.  A few occasions we ordered a hot latte and the cup is 1/2 full, and while it is a pain, they had it remade for me. . We'll see if this update has a lasting effect but think they know they don't have competition in this area so folks suck it up.

A DD inside a gas station.  They have a drive-thru too, which is handy if you've got dogs or no legs (I guess).

Everything is consistently the same as every other Dunkin around.  It's generally good enough and fast enough.  But as I'm writing this, I keep clicking between 2 stars and three stars.  

Two stars - the donut upselling.  I go in for three, and the cashier tells me "It's cheaper if you get 4."  It's cheaper PER DONUT, but you're still always paying more.  There's a serious distinction between those two concepts, and that attempted upsell happens every time I go in.

Three stars - dog treats (or a couple stale donut holes) for the corgi when I bring her through the drive-thru.  They don't have to do anything like that, but it is very kind of them (and Stella loves it).  

Three stars wins out, since my dog is staring at me, probably thinking about squirrels or food or tennis balls - whatever corgis think about.

I'd had this spot bookmarked since it opened and figured I'd better check it out. 
First impression was that the place needed an identity. The interior was very bizarre and the restaurant had an odd layout. It seemed like it wanted to be high end, but they ran out of money and went in a different direction. 
That being said, the server was amazing. Extremely attentive and genuine. 
The menu was also a bit odd, but we asked for suggestions. 
We ordered the hot chicken wings which had a dry rub on them. I'm pretty sure they were the best wings I've ever eaten. I don't know how they make them but I'd highly recommend trying them. I had the meatball ragout and the BF has some sort of sandwich that he enjoyed. 
The food was delicious and service was good. The price and ambiance didn't seem to match. 
But I'll definitely be back.

We opted for what my partner calls the "best kept secret on Tanque Verde" and I'm pleased he let me in on it. Jackson's is an oasis of class soaring quietly in a sea of mediocrity. The ambience is cool and minimalist, and the spicy marinara meatballs lived up to their name. The owner was wearing many hats the night we stopped in, but the service was still impeccable. The big screens were on but not blaring intrusively and the small touches (backlit bar, extensive wine list, paper menus, sparkling clean) make this an intimate East Side spot. I'll try the jalapeno meatloaf, which looks outrageous coming out of the kitchen, next time.

I would give this 6 stars if I could. Where to begin?

The BRUNCH is off the hook, same price as Jeannine's but you're eating in an art museum with French tapestries, elegant flatware, beauty in every corner of the room. 

I don't know how ANYONE could give this less than 5 stars. Now, at dinner it's apparently pricey. Duh. This is a fine dining institution in Santa Barbara and it's French with a star LA chef and the owners spared no expense in the remodeling of the casual, not divey but not nice, State and A which managed to stay in business a couple decades in spite of the subpar food. 

It turns out the owners have grown daughters in NYC and I have so enjoyed my afternoon here. My iPhone 5 makes a hotspot so I'm blogging before I meet a friend at 4 and swim to work off the potato daphinois--don't ask about the fat content--a sinful tower of thinly sliced potatoes with cheese and oil and all manner of terrible things which taste wonderful. 

My scramble--a bargain at 12.95--included perfect carmelized onions, roasted peppers, spinach and a hint of goat cheese--and I will dream of this till my next brunch here after Chicago/Michigan trip. 

After 5 cups of coffee to wake me up from horrible asthmatic night, I had a glass of the Ballard Pinot for dessert Nice but no better than the cheaper--9/glass--Kenwood Cab which I think is quite a respectable Cab for the money. 

The coffee is good but if you're like my father who, due to his time in the military, requires coffee which scalds the tongue, you will need to pull a Dad and ask them to nuke it in the "radar oven." It's not hot but I don't really care as it tasted good and did the trick: that is, it enabled me to have two glasses of wine after a miserable night of wheezing, hacking and blowing my nose. 

I cannot say enough for Maggie's and am so happy it's here in SB. I will come before my next show at the Granada for dinner at the bar. I have a subscription (see Yelp) and come alone.

PS I haven't eaten here at dinner yet but every single person who brought me food or booze was fabulous and I got to chat at length with the spectacular, smart owner with whom it turns out I have quite a bit culturally in common. I have no clue what people are talking about re service. It's not crowded but it's not empty and they have taken magnificent care of me.

This was State and A, where I met my boyfriend in Aug of 2010 (but never went before or after) so it's a sentimental location for me across from the Granada Theater, where we went to Marquee after with another person after the SBYP function. 

I knew it had closed sometime ago and reopened as something but I did NOT know this was going to be as beautiful as an art museum, faintly reminiscent of the Cloisters, the medieval wing of the Met right on the Hudson by Columbia. 

It is BREATHTAKING. I just had wine before and after the symphony last Saturday but saw lots of food at the bar, including a dazzling ox tail and I can't wait to come here for a full meal. 

Apparently, the wealthy owner, who doesn't need to make money at all, much less off a restaurant which is a hobby or vanity project (nothing wrong with either one but generally such restaurants do not serve the best food), so it's going to stick around whether it brings people in during the week or not. 

I also learned that this owner hired a very famous LA chef to run the place and that she spares no expense in making this place perfect. 

The brunch is one of their selling points and while I don't think I can make it before my Midwestern trip (as I will be in LA for Easter, not the holiday of course which I don't celebrate, next week), I am SO looking forward to coming back!

Based on what I saw, this will instantly update to 5 stars after I come for brunch or dinner.

We came for happy hour. I don't think Maggie's knows what "happy hour" means, because one Stella Artois and one small serving of fries cost us $12. In fact, this was the most unpleasant hour we spent in Santa Barbara that day. 

We were seated at the patio, the only area one can participate in happy hour, apparently. All was still good as we perused the limited menu. Heck, all was still good when we got our beer. But when the parmesan truffle fries arrived--with, as requested, parmesan on the side--we were just annoyed. Six dollars for just a handful of fries?! On top of that, the fries weren't even anything special--I'd much rather have McDonalds or In N Out's. Further, the parmesan tasted disgustingly stale. I thought it'd be the snow-flakey parmesan one gently sprinkles on top of pasta, but nope. This was small chunks of pale yellow staleness. Yuck.

The only good thing about my experience was the cleanliness of the restroom...

We were a party of 4 stopping in for dinner during a day in Santa Barbara. The atmosphere was a bit strange, as we first noticed the outdoor patio area, which had a nicely dressed young lady playing classical piano. The inside also looked elegant. But then there were large TV's everywhere with sports on. It was as if a sports bar and a fine dining restaurant had a baby - but a strange one.

The staff, although friendly, seemed very young, unprofessional, and poorly trained. They were good kids, just didn't really fit the establishment. For instance, when someone in our party asked about the fish of the day, the server told us it was an Atlantic Sea Bass - which we ordered. We waited a while for our food, and about the time I was expecting it would be coming out, the server returned only to tell us that the fish of the day was actually a Cod. What? It was strange that A) he didn't know the fish of the day, B) he waited so long to tell us there was a mistake, and C) he didn't apologize for the error. Something else was ordered in its place, but it was then delivered later than the other entrees which came out. It was poor execution. Also, when we initially sat down and were poured waters, the water was warm - no even room temperature, but actually warm. When they refilled them, it was cold water with ice in it, but it seems like the initial pitcher must have been sitting out for a long time.

I had ordered the salmon salad, which was much smaller than what I had imagined an entree salad to be. The salmon was mediocre, and the small salad was missing one of the key ingredients the menu mentioned it included. I'm not sure if they were just out of the ingredient and they didn't want to tell me, or if it was just another mistake. The food was definitely overpriced for what it was.

In conclusion, the restaurant seemed confused on whether they were a classical piano playing fine dining restaurant or a sports bar. The staff was nice, but very young and seemingly very inexperienced. The food is nothing special and portion sizes are small and lacking quality. There are plenty of dining establishments in Santa Barbara, and I would recommend going elsewhere.

I''m a fan.. of BREAKFAST here.  Maybe not so much a fan at any other time of day, but if you are looking for a decently priced and tasty breakfast then Colonial will suffice.  They run specials during the week (Mon-Fri maybe 6-10 am?) that include coffee and juice.

I'm fond of the croissant French Toast and the egg dishes with French Fries swapped for potatoes.  The waitresses are on the whole nice & efficient.  You can pay with cards up front.
Kid friendly and free coffee refills.  Really, what more can you ask for from a diner that serves up breakfast at the crack of dawn?

Sorry to report that our most recent breakfast experiences here have been disappointing.  Still nice service but the food was not so tasty & the prices went up.  New owners I guess.   I'm sure they'll be just fine without my business.  At least they're still 24 hours for post-bar feeds.

They have a cubano and red velvet pancakes with cream cheese frosting.  The cubano was made with sliced bread, which isn't what I would choose, but wasn't bad for a diner.  The fries were good, the cole slaw was okay.  I had never seen red velvet pancakes before.  I was impress that there was something like this on the menu.  The frosting wasn't as amazing as cream cheese frosting normally is, but they get some points for thinking outside the box.  

The staff was arguing among themselves, practically right over the top of our table.  It got sort of heated, and pretty awkward.  

I will be back to try this place again.  It will be nice to have a diner that is so close to my house.

Pregnant girls!  Do not pass go.  Do not collect $200.  Go directly to Grille 39 in Carmel.  My mom's group, Mamas Helping Mamas spend a few Mondays a month having martinis here (none for you PG ladies), and I have to tell you, aside from those, I looooooooooove the apple crisp dessert which comes in a large hot bowl of deliciousness full of crispy delightful flavors that burst in your mouth and then a sweet cool refreshing vanilla bean ice cream to cleanse your pallet.  OMG.  I want one now.  

For starters, the salads are always wonderful and I've had the salmon on multiple occasions and it is sooooo good.  

The service is consistent and the restaurant is quiet, trendy and romantic if you want something a little more intimate.  For medium groups, they have a semi-private room which is great for couples dinners out and they don't charge for the space.

Overall, this is a great meeting place for a nice meal if you want to hear yourselves talk or if you are looking for a fun, hot dessert to make your belly happy.

My friend and I used Yelp to find a place for cocktails in Carmel the other night and decided on this place. I struggled to find the entrance since the GPS brought me straight to the Renaissance hotel. I wasn't expecting a hotel restaurant (should have read the reviews better!), but I was tired and decided to go in anyway. It was very bland. I tried a pear vodka drink that was watered down and uninspired. My truffle "fries" were large chunks of baked potatoes. Mac & cheese tasted pretty formulaic. Overall, not impressed and will not be returning.

I don't know what it is about Grille 39 but I think it is one of Carmel's best kept secrets.  Since discovering it when I was pregnant nearly 6 years ago, the consistency alone in it's above average food at good prices continues to bring me back!  

My girlfriends and I used to partake in martini Mondays here...since, we go back for a glass of wine and a salad or just for dessert (the apple crisp - don't miss it).  It's always very good and the service is also excellent.  It's NEVER busy it seems, even on weekends when the Renaissance is full!

Most recently, however, we ended up here again b/c my sister was turning 30 and 17 of her closest friends came into town to share a meal with her.  Unfortunately Kona and Cooper's Hawk could not accommodate us (at all or if they could, there was a room fee - silly).  Grille 39 not only had no issue accommodating in a semi-private area, they offered us a VERY affordable menu to choose from.  For $25/pp we were able to choose a three course meal off a pre-set menu.  The choices were extremely appetizing and they assured us service would be smooth and stressfree.

They were 100% correct.  Everyone seemed to devour their meals and I especially LOVED my salmon. The portions were perfect, the food was cooked well and the service ran extremely smooth.  We had two wonderful servers who filled drinks, cleaned up one of my messes (spilled water glass) and were always around to clean up plates.  It went very well!  Then dessert came out and other than the brownie, which was hard and ....tasteless, everyone seemed very happy.  I was disappointed in the brownie that I tasted off someone else's plate, but honestly that is the ONLY complaint.

Overall, I highly recommend this place if you have a larger group and need space, want something more private and intimate for a date night and/or a quiet place to grab a drink and have a real conversation.  It never seems crowded and there is always good food/drinks to be had. For a restaurant in a hotel, it really could not be any better!

Not really a surprise as this is one of the nicest hotels in Indy.  Grille 39 was a great place to have a quiet lunch with someone special.  They play a special upbeat (but not loud) techno mix instead of the weird stuff you hear places.  Food was excellent and served fast and hot - just the way I like it.  Everything in this hotel, from the mix of stonework and stainless, carpet and leather, electronics and bamboo, feeds into the atmosphere here.

Absolutely love this place. Unfortunately I only seem to get there for lunch, so I haven't been able to enjoy their wine selection, but I have to tell ya. There isn't much better then this place. 

The Spinach salad is unbelievable and the tortellini is the best I have ever eaten. All tortellini, in my mind, is compared to the taste of this place. 

It also has a very unique atmosphere sitting in an atrium like setting watching the older looking elevator run up and down the wall.

This is one of those odd restaurant locations that can throw you off because it's inside a odd business location, the only other one like it I know is the Barn at Lucerne ... when you walk in with various businesses located there and then there is "patio" with a businesses meet up type thing and you go this way to enter the restaurant, it's just odd, with an older décor feeling.  Not sure what to expect I was then actually surprised the food was as good as it was.   You do have that Italian service that goes with it, not anything high end, more like being served by your family or neighborhood friends but good service regardless.

On our plates this night were the house salad (pretty good) Tilapia (very good), the strip steak (pretty good) and the tiramisu (very good, which is hard to do with tiramisu).    

Overall it's closer to a 3 than it would be a 5 so it was a decent experience and not outstanding but I am glad I had the chance to try.

I can't believe this place hasn't been reviewed yet! It's nestled in a cozy area in Frontenac.

The food is terrific; you can't go wrong with calamari as an appetizer; it's perfectly cooked, and comes with a delicious sauce for dipping.  The escargot is also tasty. 

The food: DELICIOUS! The lobster ravioli is so good. I've tried a few other things there (my memory is failing me now), but I've never been disappointed. The portions are huge; good luck on finishing it all!

I'd definitely recommend this place.

Dining out is entertainment.  So if Niche is our Michael Buble and Tony's is our Frank Sinatra, I'd say Trattoria Branica is probably Jerry Vale or Mike Douglas.  Good singers, yes, all but forgotten.  On a recent evening visit, I don't think there was even one guest who wouldn't remember both Jerry Vale and Mike Douglas.  Gray hair was definitely the order of the day.  For the middle of the holiday season and smack in the center of the St. Louis population, it sure was quiet.  They're in the middle of a pretty exclusive little mall, so maybe they do a good lunch business.   

I asked myself after leaving:  if I was from out of town and stumbled in, would I recognize this as a place that's been around and lost whatever buzz it's had?  The old awning over the entry is telling.  Other than that, though, the ambience isn't particularly old school.  The menus seem kind of old, yes, but service is friendly, if not all that polished, and they're cranking out some pretty good food.

We had Tenderloin Broschettes and a seared scallop special.  Both were pretty good, around $20, with salads about $6 or so (also good).  Louis Martini cabernet was $32 a bottle - not bad for a good bottle of wine. 

No complaints really, but it was just so quiet and kind of sad.  In the world of entertainment, "kind of sad" doesn't draw raves.   If this restaurant ever had buzz, it predates Yelp (3 reviews before me).  Maybe a makeover is in order.  If you're looking for a trendy hot spot, try Sugo's about 100 feet away.  If you want to take grandma to dinner without reservations, and you want some good food at a fair enough price, and you want to hear every whisper of the conversation, this is your place.    

Probably great and a lot more lively for lunch.

The office for lunch today. Opted out of the lovely Branica salad for minestrone soup. Not the best choice.

The soup had lots of nice vegetables -- zucchini, yellow squash, celery, onion (?) and corn (didn't know there was corn in minestrone soup) -- but the broth was rather lacking in flavor and was clear. No tomato base anywhere.

Entrees were much more successful:
#1 got large spinach salad and subbed Mozzarella for the gorgonzola -- $7.95 -- and a side of roasted vegetables (zucchini and yellow squash with fresh tomato).

#2 got the Branica salad (mixed greens, tomato, onion and Mozzarella with house vinaigrette) -- $3.95 -- and Fettucine Genovesi (sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms and pinenuts in cream sauce) -- $7.75. The portion was huge. He said he thought maybe they gave him more 'cause he's a tall man.

#3 got the minestrone soup (we critiqued the soup together, and both agreed) and Grigliata Biblico (breaded tilapia topped with tomato tapenade), served with the roasted vegetables and roasted potatoes -- $9.95.

I got the chicken special (chicken topped with three kinds of mushrooms and pinenuts in a lovely, deep mushroom sauce), served with the roasted vegetables and roasted potatoes. Delightful!

I got a little taste of the tilapia, and the fish was moist and flaky. That tomato tapenade was so flavorful with stuffed green olive slices and lovely, briny capers!!

Not many diners, but our service was painfully slow. We just had to wait far too long to order, then progress through the meal to the check to the running of the check. We were there 90 minutes. Our server was extremely soft-spoken. Waters were replenished diligently, but iced tea and soda were not.

The office ordered in using 569.DINE, and delivery was, as usual, beautiful!

There were six of us, so I lost track of what everybody got.

I opted for a different salad this time: the Fagioli (I thought that was soup!) -- cannellini beans, red onions, cherry tomatoes and egg slices ($4.95).

Holy cow. I ate it first, and couldn't eat another thing! It was filling, delicious and a wonderful forkful of surprises every time. Who would have thought this mixture of "stuff" would have made this wonderful salad.

My entree (which had to wait for the next day) was the Grigliata Biblico -- sicilian lightly breaded tilapia topped with tomato tapenade. It was spectacular, even waiting 24 hours. Heated up well in the microwave . . . perhaps a little breading suffering, but the taste was incredible!

Yum!!

I went back for my birthday! Yummy as usual. 

Tried the mussels for an appetizer; they were DELICIOUS. I wish I didn't have to share with everyone else. 

For dinner, I was going to go with the seafood pasta, but after I heard that night's special (mustard crusted salmon with potatoes and grilled vegetables), I HAD to go with that. It was delicious. YUM. 

I love this place.

Slightly above average food and strange service. 

The place was completely packed and had an older crowd at around 6:30 on a Saturday. Food took a long time to come out of the kitchen, probably for the reason just mentioned. 
The smoked trout appetizer was good; I liked my seafood frettucine even though it looked like it had been sitting as the sauce was a bit congealed when the plate came onto the table. My dining partners didn't care for their lamb (you know when you get a lamb that isn't cooked exactly right, it tastes chew-y?) and lasagna, but I heard the trout entree was decent.  

Service was...odd to say the least. Our waiter almost sounded condescending at times (I suspect it was because there was some sort of coupon involved...I had no idea what kind as I was invited by the person with the coupon). He was stumbling all over the specials; later, when one of the people in my party asked for more bread, he snapped back at him with a "hold on!". I overheard him snap at other tables when they tried to flag him down with a request. Jeeez..what was with the attitude. In the end of the meal when he asked if there was an occasion (probably because there was a little bag that we exchanged sitting on the table), we mentioned it was two people's birthdays. He responded with "Do you want a cake or something?" Eh...we'll pass if you put it that way. I have never heard a waiter ask me that before. You either bring it out or you don't say anything. That was just...strange. 

Overall, meh. For Italian, it was pretty cheap. My fettucine was $17 I believe and the portion was pretty big. I just didn't find it all that special, especially given the strange, borderlying-rude service we received.

First time for dinner . . . all my other visits have been for lunch. And as it turns out, lunch is a bargain compared to dinner!

We had a 5:30 p.m. reservation, and I was the first diner in the place. The hostess offered the dining room or the indoor patio. I selected the patio -- with all the festive Christmas decorations around in the four-story courtyard.

I settled in at the nice, roomy table for two, was served water, rolls and butter, and a beverage, and read my book while waiting for my college chum. I did arrive a tad early.

There wasn't too much happening. There was one couple in the dining room, and that was about it for a while.

We both got the Branica salad ($4.50), which is a lucious combination of greens (no iceberg), mozz, halved cherry tomatoes and onion with house vinaigrette. It was a beautiful presentation of a composed salad. And it tasted fabulous.

For entrees, we both got the Tortilloni de Pollo ($14.95) -- Chicken and prosciutto tortelloni in a thick, rich cream sauce with peas and mushrooms. We both asked for extra mushrooms, and there was a upcharge, of which we were not apprised.

The tortilloni was absolutely grand! Sooo rich, neither one of us could even get through half of it.

We had a Groupon for $30 of food (for which I paid $15), but I thought it was still kinda pricey for a pasta dinner.

We both had huge to-go vessels.

Service from Larry was spot-on!

And the rolls were spectacular!!

I've been here probably five or six times, always for lunch. We make our reservation for 11:30 a.m. And EVERY TIME we've been there, the place packs up about mid-meal.

This little jewel is tucked away in the castle (Le Chateau Village) behind the Frontenac Hilton at Clayton and Lindbergh. You got to know it's there, or it's invisible.

Today we sat on the patio. (It's a patio to me, even if it is indoors.) We had the most delightful server who was so relaxed and friendly. She took drink orders, then told us the specials, so we could consider those while studying the menu. WHAT A GREAT IDEA!! I hate it when a server tells you the specials when you've already decided what you're going to order, and I do believe that's the norm.

The rolls, the rolls, the rolls. Fresh, hot, yeasty. Slather on some butter (or eat them naked -- the rolls, silly, not you!), and you've got a feast. Nuff said!

Today I got the red trout special . . . beautifully baked (?), moist skin-on fish with a savory light lemon-caper sauce, roasted potatoes and broccoli with a touch of tomato. A little wedge of lemon brought a bright burst of citrus that was splendid. I started with the small Branica salad ($3.95), a lucious blend of greens with tomato, onion, mozzarella and house-made dressing. One of my dining partners absolutely loves the spinach salad.

I opted for a third course, because our server raved about it: the corn soup. It's fine. But I'm a soup snob. I didn't finish it, didn't even eat half of it -- maybe three or four spoonsful. It wasn't worth the calories. One of my dining partners tried it and declared it also . . . fine.

I took home enough leftovers to serve as my dinner -- so two meals for the price of one.

My dining partners got:
The chicken special -- light chicken meat prepared with a light tomato sauce (with chunks of tomato) and eggplant, with the potatoes and broccoli.
Fettucine Genovesi at $7.75 for the lunch portion -- with sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms and pine nuts in a rich cream sauce.

Everybody raved about their meals, including our vegetarian dining partner, who had the large spinach salad and an order of broccoli.

On other visits, I've had and thoroughly enjoyed (and always with the small Branica salad):
Veal Al Limone at $9.95 for the lunch portion -- in light lemon sauce, with shitake mushrooms.
Grilled Salmon at $9.95 for the lunch portion --  topped with lemon butter capers.
Chicken Tortellloni at $7.95 for the lunch portion -- in cream sauce with peas and mushrooms.
Pizza Branica at $8.95 -- chicken. gorgonzola, mushrooms and olive.

One time we were seated inside the restaurant, which is (to me) more formal and old-world, but lovely and rich. The patio seems more festive and casual relaxed -- even if it's not really outside. There are awnings, for goodness sake. Get an imagination!! And no having to duck that pesky sun!!

Trattoria Branica is a hidden treasure that's beautifully appointed. We've always had exceptional service, all glasses (whether water or another beverage) heartily attended to, and we've always felt welcomed and appreciated.








,

The Morris Burner Hotel is a little slice of what Burning Man is and has to offer.  It's a place to go and mix/mingle with like minded people.  They have drum circles on Monday nights, Tuesday Talks, with educational and informative topics.  They have pot lucks, DJ's, bands, art cars, art pieces.  I've never stayed the night here, but I have looked at quite a few of the rooms.  They're all decorated differently, and give off an amazing vibe.
The bar has recently been updated with a sort of Steam Punk feel to it.  It's absolutely beautiful.   If you ever want to get an idea of what Burning Man is like, or what/who Burners are, pop on down to the Morris.  You'll be welcomed with open arms by everyone that's there.  You'll probably get a warming hug as you walk in.  )'(

My husband and I were in Reno last fall and some friends told us they were also in town and they'd be at a party later in the evening at this hotel.  We weren't far so we walked a few blocks and found ourselves ringing the door bell, trying to find a way in. The neighborhood is horrible and we probably would have stayed at the party later but we didn't want to walk back to the casinos in the dark. Be aware of your surroundings if youre walking by!

Once inside the hotel, we were offered a tour of some of the rooms. Very unique! Several were occupied and we couldn't look at these, but the ones we saw were really fun with great paintings and decorations.

A narrow stairway leads you to a large yard in the back. Lots of large scale art, a few chairs, and a stage. It started to rain as we left - wonder if people piled inside the small lobby or braved it outdoors. It was a cool place to check out before working our way safely back to our own hotel.

Huge thanks to Chris M for setting this up. 

I had no idea or preconceptions of this place. But we were going to be in the backyard at 1 pm for a food event. 
Chris set up an art tour of the hotel prior  to our food event. 

The Morrison Burner Hotel was started in 2013. It was remodeled by volunteers using as much original material and recycled furnishings. The hotel is also ran by volunteers. Their philosophy is based in the ten principles of burning man. Gemini escorted us thru the first and second floors, the saloon and backyard of the 1928 building.  

Steam Punk Saloon is a great space. And you can't knock the prices. 

The hotel hosts various events for fund raisers in the saloon and in the massive backyard, that is complete with a fabulous large stage. 

In the second floor there are hostel rooms and a few full rooms. Different artists have themed many of the rooms, making it hard to choose a place to stay.  The 3rd & 4th floors are for longer term residents. 

If you ever get a chance check the place out. Or if you have partied too hard downtown- stay for the night.
