We did the St. Louis Cemetery #1 tour. I don't recall what our guide's name was, but she was lovely and had a lot of history to share with us. It was well paced so it's good for young and old alike.
Bob was a great tour guide. We learned a lot of fun facts about local history and how certain phrases were coined.

Excellent tour! We had Sandy and she was very knowledgeable and fun! We learned so much about the area, past and present, and she was definitely a local and very passionate. Definitely a highlight of our trip. We also had a Groupon, so it was a steal!

Allow me to preface this review by stating that I might be slightly biased because I am totally devastated over the loss of my favorite Indian restaurant, Dhaba Indy, which was here in this same spot before it closed and Biryani Hut replaced it. I was going to give it a 3 but I'll give it a 4 for benefit of the doubt.

For those of you who frequented Dhaba before, here's the lowdown on the transition: the menu is smaller. They took out all the awesome little street snacks (REST IN PEACE) and some of the main dishes, but still have dosa, a lot of vegetarian and meat entrees, and of course biryani. Another change is that it looks like the price has increased slightly, which isn't a huge deal, but Dhaba was already pricy, so dinner for 2 here last night was $30. They still have a buffet at lunch, and it seems like a lot of the same stuff probably carries over to that. Didn't recognize any of the employees, but some of the dishes were similar if not the same, so clearly there are connections between the two.

I ordered the chicken biryani. PSA, it's definitely big enough for 2 people to share if not literally 3 people. I mean, it's massive. For some reason I thought it wasn't quite as flavorful as Dhaba's biryani (interesting since it's called Biryani Hut), but was still pretty tasty. Unfortunately I didn't even make it to the chicken, which was all at the bottom of the (very deep) bowl. I took home not one but two to-go boxes full of biryani.

My friend had the chicken 65, which is an item carried over from the Dhaba menu. This was still really good. The waiter asked what spice level she wanted: mild or American mild...LOL. The American mild surprisingly still packs a bit of heat, but that's not surprising because this chicken is literally red from all the spices.

If you're going to order naan, don't bother with the regular, try the butter or garlic or some other kind. The regular naan was not good. It was super thin. (Downgrade from Dhaba' s pillowy naan, sigh.)

I need to try some more things here to really sort out my opinion of it. I'm sure it's a good restaurant, I'm still just so attached to Dhaba that Biryani Hut didn't live up to expectations.

Before coming here for a work outing, I wasn't a Ruby Tuesday's fan by any stretch of the imagination. However, this formerly generic burger chain has upped their game. They've added some healthier options with their Light and Fit menu, and even a health-nut like me was able to order a satisfactory meal that I didn't regret eating later that day.

I ordered the three-veggie meal which allowed me to choose three sides paired with the salad bar. The salad bar isn't anything special, but you can load up on spinach leaves and carrot shavings if that's what you're into. I did go off-diet and snacked on the spinach artichoke dip that was ordered for the table. It came in a three-dip sampler with an okay guacamole, and a neon-orange queso dip that was left largely untouched at our 10-person table.  For my three-veggie meal, I ordered the roasted spaghetti squash, steamed brocolli, and sugar snap peas. The spaghetti squash was surprisingly low in sodium and very yummy; the broccoli was another low-sodium option, but was a little overcooked; the snap peas were drowned in oil and I skipped them.

I'm not going out of my way to hit this chain, but if I end up here again, I'll know what to order.

Been here a few times, lunch and dinner. What's changed in the past 4 years... Their menu, a few times and their staff... What hasn't changed? Their carpets and seats / booths, which could use a fresh look! 

Besides that, always had great service at this place. Friendly, welcoming and warm staff.. Entrees are a bit expensive.. Upwards of $16, but that's RT everywhere I guess!

This gorgeous shop is any glamour girls dream!

What caught my eye and got me into this shop were the lovely tiaras in the window. Honestly, I really want one, but I sometimes wonder if that's a level of "the most" that I'm not ready to approach just yet. Walking in, there are all kinds of high end sparklies that any woman would love. This is really high end costume jewelry, not the cheapo stuff that you might find at the mall (not that I have any issue with the cheapo stuff).

They have an entire table full of different rhinestone tiaras and another table full of rhinestone masks. If you're looking for something for a ball or a costume party, this is definitely the place. They even have a case full of rhinestone crowns, if you are really feeling regal and want to add some fancy head gear to your collection.

The shop owner was very sweet and asked if I needed help and informed me of the items that were for sale. I didn't purchase anything this time, but I do really want a fancy tiara, so I will eventually be back.

This was my third escape room and the first of which I did NOT escape from. That being said, it was pretty challenging so it did feel fulfilling since my team and I were so close at the last step. My friends and I had the honor to trial this room out and we came on Saturday at 11:30am. The theme was escape from Alcatraz which leans towards the mysterious side. Given the theme, I thought it was well thought out. The setup was unique and there were more puzzles to decode compared to other rooms. My issues with this room includes the timer which starts based on what time you enter each proceeding room, thus, makes it confusing on how much actual time we have. Also, it was difficult to understand our moderator on the walkie talkies - fuzzy feedback plus muffled speech - not helpful. Also there was one or two mechanical issues with a lock but I can't go into detail since that would give it away.
Nonetheless, once they tweak these minor misshaps, this room is a fantastic room to play. Give it a try once they open it to the public!

This is our first time here and we were blown away by the experience. Our waiter, Andrew, was extremely professional, knowledgeable, and pleasant. He sat us down and prompted asked us for drink orders, as well as, explaining the menu and listing the popular dishes. 

An extra star that I gave this place is purely because of how clean the establishment and service is. Andrew took our complicated order without writing it down. When I checked into YELP I received a coupon for a free fresh lemonade worth ($3). 

I ordered 1lb of fresh crawfish ($9/lb) and 1lb of frozen crawfish ($14/lb) with mild boiling house sauce. I added two extra corn and potatoes. The sauce was delicious and there was a generous helping. I wanted to try out the difference between the frozen and fresh crawfish, and discovered there was a big difference in size. Next time, I'll get 2lbs of the fresh. 

My partner ordered the snow crab cluster with the same sauce. I do want to comment that we ordered it with sausages and that the kitchen forgot ir. Our waiter ended up removing the sausages from the bill, since we finished eating our entrees by the time they came out.

I came here for dinner with a group. The restaurant really specializes in seafood boils with you being able to make your own combination choosing from first the seafood like crab, lobster, crawfish, shrimp, mussels, 2) the sauce you want it cooked in like Old Bay, Cajun, or garlic butter, and 3) then select the add-ons like sausage, corn, potato. Three of us decided to split a seafood bake with crab legs and mussels. 

The only minor complaint was the service-our waiter didn't refill our waters or give us napkins even after we asked about 5 times. We would definitely go here again but that is annoying.

Boiling House is my new hot spot! I love seafood and this place kicks ass. I also love create your own anything and the CYO seafood boil here was awesome. 
I got snow crabs and shrimp in the Boiling House sauce with medium heat. Oh, and the garlic noodles which are a must by the way. Everything was fresh and fabulous. I might get the sauce spicy next time since the medium wasn't as spicy as I anticipated it, but live and learn that's what I say. 
Boyfriend got the lobster and oysters which were equally delicious. Oh and you must get the ciabatta roll to soak up all the delicious garlicky sauce. To top it all off Boiling House is a BYOB. Check this place out for sure!

We had some trepidation from the other Yelp reviews because of the reports of long waits for food and spotty service but we decided to give this newer, local restaurant a try last Saturday night. 

The Boiling House's location once housed French restaurant Dream Cuisine. The interior is brightly colored and there are several TV's on the wall. It took the staff a little bit of time to greet us. We told them we did not have a reservation and hoped we could get a table. The restaurant was only 1/2 full. After a brief discussion they were able to seat us.

The Boiling House, like other restaurants (Hot & Juicy, Bistro SouthEast, Crabby Cafe, etc) of this style puts a big piece of paper over the table and provides a bucket for the shells. We ordered the shrimp and snow crab boil, garlic noodles, sweet potato fries and spring rolls.

The Good - The food was excellent, we had the Cajun sauce for the boil and it was delicious and the seafood tasted fresh. We asked for medium heat and this was not spicy, if you like heat you should ask for a higher level. The garlic noodles were very good also and the sweet potato fries were outstanding. The one disappointing point about the boil was that potatoes, corn and sausage were all an extra charge. Usually there are a few pieces of these items included in the other boil type restaurants we have tried.

Service was spotty the whole night. Our original waiter disappeared and we had a couple of other ones. I don't know where he went. The food took about 25-30 minutes to come out which isn't terrible. However the spacing was a bit off. The first item to arrive was the garlic noodles. Then after about 10 minutes the spring rolls and the two boil items came out together. It would have been better if the spring rolls came out first and then the noodles with the seafood.

The staff at the Boiling House seemed a bit overwhelmed also and that is probably due to some growing pains. They didn't give us bibs, or plastic gloves that some other tables had. These usually come in the bucket; we had to ask for the bibs. 

We did have a nice meal at the Boiling House and for right now patience is a virtue. Even with spotty service and odd pacing, the food was excellent and I hope this restaurant's service will improve and the Boiling House will flourish.

Food 4.5 stars
Service 3 
Close to being a fan, so close

Had a hankering for really good seafood, and not fried, simply boiled bucket seafood like in Mass, Cape Cod etc.  Sadly I can't find anything remotely like The Boiling House near home (Yardley PA).  I remember my days living in Hoboken NJ and going to Just BeCaws in Jersey City.  Well, we found a suitable comparison to Just BeClaws and within only 40 minutes south in Cherry Hill NJ.

Look for the red fishing boat along Marlton Pike about, just 30 yards north of the Jaguar/Land Rover dealership on Marlton Pike in Cherry Hill.

They are located deep down the center of the shopping center stores back on the right down the steps.

With the pandemic, we called to check on inside seating and their protocols which met with our approval these days. Everyone is masked, many servers with gloves and cleaning between patrons.  Tables were spotless and readied with napkins, plates lobster bid and plastic disposable gloves.  No menus, QR code scan in a placard or you can use the Yelp menu.

Let me start by saying Dave, our server, was fantastic.  Handled all our questions, was courteous friendly and definitely attentive. 

Upon figuring out the menu and our interests we opt to pick our own dishes vs the larger multi-option dishes for the table.  I built my own seafood pot with Dungeness Crab Cluster, two large clusters weighing in at 1.25lbs of fabulous, succulent, perfectly cooked meat that was boiled with old bay and some garlic butter.  Was meal that will be remembered.  

My spouse had the seafood fried rice -- lobster, shrimp, king carb, Dungeness, snow carb meat, mussels and egg and mixed veggies.  She loved it.  As an add on, we ordered one Andouille sausage, it had kick, was a perfect complement to both our meals.

BYOB, parking lot, credit cards, attentive staff, great food.
Can't wait for the hankering to show up again soon.

See our pics.

A real treat for seafood lovers. This low key, hidden from the main road joint was one of the best discoveries I've found recently. My birthday coincided with father's day so I didn't want to deal with the hassle of going out on fathers's day weekend and decided to celebrate my birthday a week early here.

The dining room area was beautiful and modern. While most seafood boil places are set up like a bar, at Boiling House, you feel like you're in a fancy modern restaurant. The service was also amazing. You can choose from the menu or make your own seafood boil. First, you pick your seafood then pick the sauce that you want and finally, the spice level.

I opted for their Sea Festival, which came with king crab, snow crab, Dungeness crabs, lobsters, potatoes and corns, sausages, two pounds of live crawfish, 2 fresh lemonade and garlic noodles. This order was about $150 and fed 4 people. I highly recommend the Boiling House sauce and spicy. The seafood was just amazing, everything tasted fresh and they had some huge crawfish. The sauce was very buttery and flavorful. The main surprise hit was actually the garlic noodles. Their noodles had a chewy textures that held against their super flavorful sauce.

Overall, this place was solid. Although on the higher price of things, you cannot really complaint because of their location. I will be back here many times and bring lots of friends! I wonder why the place haven't had a higher ratings. Although it may not be Louisiana or Texas, Boiling House is representing the East Coast pretty well. Four for the food and one extra star for awesome service.
Fresh seafood boils. Very good house seasoning. The seafood fried rice was wonderful. The garlic noodles are one of their specialties, a must get. Modern atmosphere and large TV's on wall. BYOB!!

My friend and I had a reservation the other night at 7:30. The restaurant looked packed. We checked in and hung out in the little waiting area, it was beyond freezing out. By 8pm, we were going to walk out. Two other sets of people waiting were told to go next door to their other dining room,  which we were told to follow and then finally sat. 

Ordered. They brought out our garlic noodles instantly which would have been better brought out with the main course, but for the fact we were starving it was fine. Noodles were ok. Not hot. Lots of garlic. 

I got a lb of mussels, add sausage, went with their house seasoning and mild. My friend got snow crabs, garlic seasoning. So funny, but it took at least 10 minutes to get someone's attention to get crackers for the crabs. So that was a little annoying. The sausage was over cooked. Seasoning on everything was good. 
This dining room was also packed, noisy and service was a little slow. Also, no hushpuppies on the menu? What gives.

We had a gift certificate here so we decided to take advantage of it and order tons of food to bring back to the hotel.

First of all, in the dark of winter, it was really hard to find. Look for the entrance just after the Jaguar dealership and park in the back, walking through a small courtyard. The restaurant is on the left among all the businesses.

We had a somewhat complicated order but they did everything right. All told, the meal came out to about $140 or so, but we ordered the garlic noodles (we should have ordered more, they were Da BOMB), two orders of Vietnamese fried egg rolls (surprisingly good), seafood rice (pricy and decent amount of seafood, just disappointingly dry), and several pounds of assorted mussels, jumbo shrimp, oysters. Now let me note that we three who were dining on this meal are no lightweights when it comes to an appetite and we certainly had our fill.  We opted for the special house sauce and it was deeeeeeelish - nice kick.  Lemme have some more of that!  Big messy eating and thoroughly enjoyable.

I also noted to the restaurant that we were eating this at a hotel, and they generously provided lots of napkins and extra empty containers for us to dump all our "empties" (ie shells) to keep a mess in the hotel room to a minimum.

It took a little arm-twisting to get my better half to try this place as he is convinced that boiling pots taste like you're "eating the ocean". What a card! A soupy, salty, fishy pot of seafood is not what you'll get here. Nicely seasoned, well cooked, fresh seafood is what you WILL get. 

We created our own pot and split it with each other. Snow crab legs (ample size and oh-so-tender), clams, and shrimp. We selected the Boiling House seasoning, mild spice level, and passed on adding any starches. We ordered a side of their famous garlic noodles as well. We were pleasantly full but not stuffed to oblivion. Perfecto!

This place is easy to miss as it's very off the beaten path of Route 70. When you see the Jaguar dealership, then you know you're almost upon it. 

Bring some wine and ask to sit outside. Let your tastebuds be pampered!

This place has ben on my radar for years! I mean look at the pictures..... all delicious seafood! And not gonna lie, all the youtube videos of people eating seafood has made me want to try this place even more. 

Hubs and I came here on a date night and it was a nice shake up to our normal dinner night out. DO NOT wear anything cute- you will get messy. 
At least I was a hot mess.... anyway, the seafood here is super fresh. 
We got two different pots with their famous sauce. I would get the crab legs, and shrimp again but I would actually try a different sauce. There was nothing special about their special sauce. We also got their garlic noodles- if you come here for only the garlic noodles, I would not judge you... they are that good. 

This spot is also a BYO which is a big plus! 
I'd recommend this place if you are a big seafood fan or want to try something new. Personally I cant see myself being here too often unless its for the noodles.

I went today and spoke with the owner about my terrible experience last time. I have chatted friendly w/ him for years, and thought he would be concerned about my experience. He basically defended the lack of carne asada in the breakfast burritos saying that it is a half scoop of meat. I have no idea what is a scoop, but I do know that I paid an extra $1 x 3 and got about 3-5 small pieces of asada in 3 breakfast burritos. This used to be my favorite breakfast burrito in town when it was done right. I won't ever be back since there was a chance for us to make amends today, and he likes giving people NO VALUE for their $$!

At many Mexican restaurants you anticipate the moment when your food arrives with the warning, "Be careful, it's a very hot plate." Then there's Taqueria La Michoacana, where everything from nachos to enchiladas is served just above room temperature.

A combination of 24 hour access and affordability makes this a perfect choice for hungry party animals on an all-night bender. I'd advise choosing take-out, as the policy on bussing tables appears to be, "wait until 80% of the tables are covered in trash before cleaning."

The menu includes all the usual suspects, with large screens displaying photos of available dishes. Our order arrived from the kitchen really fast. So fast, I wondered if any actual cooking had occurred in that timespan. It isn't uncommon for Mexican food to be prepared in advance, then assembled and placed in a broiler to melt the cheese and heat everything--including the plate--to piping hot perfection. But based on our experience, it's more likely a microwave oven was involved.

Our shared plate of carnitas nachos featured round--clearly store-bought--tortilla chips covered with an ample supply of tasty pork, sour cream, pico de gallo, and room-temperature nacho cheese that must have been poured straight from a can. The flavors were actually quite good--we ate the whole thing--but I can't recall ever being served cold nachos. It was essentially a dressed-up version of 7-11 chips and cheese, sans the heat of a convenience store cheese dispenser ($5.95).

Despite my best instincts, I ordered chiles relleno with sauce on the side to see if the poblanos were fried crispy before being soaked. The result was just as mushy as most I've seen in town, further confirming my suspicion that the chiles are being fried and refrigerated in advance, then microwaved and dunked in sauce to hide the crime. Extra disappointing in this instance, being the sauce was not your average mess of tomato puree. It was smooth, spicy, full of onion and good enough to make me enjoy the dish despite the lack of fresh-fried texture ($6.99).

The chicken in my wife's enchiladas was very dry, and the fact the topping of shredded cheese went from melty on the plate's outside edge, to completely unmelted in the center, only furthered my suspicions on the use of high-frequency radio waves as a heat source ($6.99). On both dinner plates the rice and beans were par for the course.

Keeping the urgent care number on speed dial, I went ahead and tried a room-temp ceviche tostada ($2.49). Despite my concerns, the fish appeared to be reasonably fresh and was combined with a great mix of veg and plenty of cilantro. Actually quite good. Sadly, the cabeza sope I ordered was so gnarly I couldn't finish it ($1.99). Piled high with lettuce, cheese, and meat, it looked promising on the plate. But the thick-fried masa was very difficult to bite through, possessing mostly the flavor of old, burned oil. 

Similarly, an order of tacos al pastor tasted overcooked and a tad burned ($1.25 each), with tiny pebbles of meat that--though still edible--didn't have a hint of spice or pineapple. 

Perhaps the most successful dish was caldo camaron, a soup of shrimp and vegetables ($9.49). The shrimp wasn't overcooked, and the broth was spicy without being overbearing. Oddly, the veggies were cut in very large pieces, with carrots and squash the length of my fingers, and several whole red potatoes. Odd, but not a deal breaker. The soup wasn't served as hot as I'd like, but it was the warmest dish we were served.

Taqueria La Michoacana has been hidden in plain sight from me for more than a decade. By that I mean I knew there was a Mexican place in the same shopping center as a certain popular chain Italian restaurant, but I didn't realize it was open 24 hours until just recently. After my first visit I have to say I'd probably need to be drunk in order to eat in that dining room. Not that it was completely terrible, but it's a tad more ramshackle than I'd expected. The room seems too big for the amount of seating provided, the furniture is shabby, and the decor--such as it is--is garish at best, grubby at worst. If you can look past what it lacks in aesthetics, the place offers reasonably good Mexican street food at cheap prices. They offer all the usual items you'll find at other taquerias including seafood--Michoacán being a coastal state of Mexico--and a large selection of smoothies, speciality drinks, fresh-squeezed juices, desserts, and snacks. Smoothing out my reservations was the speed at which I received my order. I barely had time to jot down a couple notes before they handed me a torta lengua and quesadilla, both of which tasted pretty good in the comfort of my living room while marathoning Netflix.

Ah, the late night food craving... It's so nice to find a place that is open late and is not fast food.
 
The restaurant is pretty bare bones and kind of reminds me of a cafeteria. The pictures of the menu items are discolored from being displayed for way too long, not that that has any reflection on the quality of food, it just really stood out to me for some reason. I guess basically what I am saying is this place majorly lacks in atmosphere, but I guess you're not really there for that.
 
We decided on the wet burrito to share. There are a couple of options for the type of meat; we chose carne asada. Along with the burrito, we got an order of chips and salsa.
 
Our food was ready to pick up pretty quickly. The serving of chips was huge. I wasn't a fan of the salsa, which is completely smooth, but this might just be a personal preference. Sharing the burrito was a good choice; it really is big enough to serve two people, especially with the side of chips. The red sauce that the burrito is topped with has a really tin-like flavor which was really off putting, but the fillings inside were much better.
 
Overall, a passable late night meal. I had no idea this place existed until recently, so I foresee some more trips here in the future, I just might stay away from the wet burritos and salsa...
mediocre mexican 24 hours a day. coming from the bay area this is atrocious, but around here, they are a rarity. added star for the plethora of lime slices available for the taking.

Brand Spanking New Opening.

The pho here looks better than the ones from Saigon Express around the corner, but their dry dishes (vermicelli and rice plates) did not make me happy...not at all!

I ordered the bbq beef vermicelli with fried egg roll, when i received my food there was a bowl full of vermicelli, one egg roll (about 1.5 inches long) cut into two bite sized pieces, and a handfull of lettuce. 

thats not what it's supposed to look like! its supposed to have carrots and bean sprouts and more meat and more egg roll! and whatsup with the fish sauce? isn't it supposed to be orangey red? why did they give me a soysaucy one...is that something that's usually put it in? i'm not used to it. 

this is not a review of their pho, so when and if i do go back, i will update.

The chick that works here is seriously retarded. Spacey as fck, dosent pay attention, and can't take an order. 

Its IV, so can't expect much. 

The pho was a little funky... wanst a huge fan of the broth, but it had a lot of veggies and tofu in it, so i was fairly satisfied. 

Iced coffee was good. 

meh.

Solid not going to complain, I mean they are doing it... bringing pho to mainstream America (well UCSB that is).  I wish they were here when I attended UCSB but better late than never.  

I had the Pho Tai and if you are craving pho then this may satisfy your craving.  However, I prefer my thin slices of meat rare and thin.  My noodles were a bit limp and I like my bean sprouts crisper.  I also would have loved me some more jalapeno, limes and Thai Basil.  Can't get enough of the Thai Basil.

My sister got her usual bowl and WOW that was amazing.  I would definately reccommend that.  Ban Cha Gio Tom Thit Nuong a lovely medley of Rice noodles, egg roll, grilled shrimp choice of pork or chicken served atop of lettuce, cucumbers, bean sprouts, cilantro, crushed peanuts and served with a ddipping sauce (containing fish sauce I'm guessing).  Solid.  It's also called the #32 in case you are wondering.  This bowl is bursting with flavors.  My sister got the pork and it was tender and full of flavor.  Addiciting.

The 2 young men behind the counter were very sweet and lovely.  Although I'm more of a salty girl but when it comes to Vietnamese Coffee, I go all out.  Give me the 2 inches of condensed milk.   They go light here, maybe just looking out for you.

Yeah a bit pricey for a Vietnamese joint but I'd rather spend 10 bucks on a meal here then spend $7 at a drive thru.  Much better for you and go ahead and titilate your senses.  You can alwasy douse your pho with Siracha or Hoisin Sauce.

The servers & managers are honestly the nicest people ever. Mr. Lee and Miss Kelly are the cutest and friendliest workers ever as well! They just speak really loudly, which gives the impression that they're rude...but that's how a lot of Vietnamese people speak! 

Service: A lot of people complain about the service, but do keep in mind that they are very understaffed. It is extremely difficult to both cook and serve at the same time, especially on busy days. They really do try their best! Pho takes HOURS to prepare and the broth takes a lot of work to maintain-- this goes for most Vietnamese food. Cut them some slack. They even offer free samples! And the other workers are extremely sweet as well.

As for the food: my boyfriend and I love their beef fried rice. It's simple and yummy. Their pho is delicious on cold, SB days when you're too lazy to go out (and of course...they're the best cure for your IV hangovers). I also love love love their coffee milk tea!!! Their banh mi isn't how they're traditionally made in most SoCal places (cold cut meat, veggies, etc) but their beef banh mi is still really really good!

Got spring rolls and their shrimp fried rice since we were skeptical of getting pho at a place where the people did not know how to speak vietnamese. Spring rolls were alright, definitely not the best I've ever had but they were decent although a little plain tasting if you didn't douse it with sauce. Whatever, the thing that was really bad was the fried rice! First of all, it was all orange... And tasted like I don't know did they use ketchup or some tomato sauce to make it? The rice itself wasn't even good. The shrimp were orange too and gross. It was super greasy too. Not appetizing at all. It was shared between three girls and we didn't even make a dent in it. Van D lost her appetite and didn't even want to try it... Have we been too spoiled by the Vietnamese food we have available in the San Gabriel Valley and Westminster/Garden Grove area?! I dont know, either way it didn't taste good.

The banh mi at Pho Bistro was huge and stuffed with grilled meat of your choice, cucumber, jalapeno, carrot, mayo, onion, tomato, and cilantro.  At under $4 each,  it makes a great meal for hungry students.  The grilled pork and beef had a sweet robust marinade and were more flavorful than the other Vietnamese places in town.  The downside was that the grilled meat had too much char.  A little char and smoke is great for flavor, but in this instance, there were several pieces of meat that I had to pick out because I didn't want to put that much polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in my body.

The cha gio was generously sized, but the filling had an unappetizing sour note.  I don't know if they purposely seasoned it that way or was it because the filling wasn't fresh.  The nouc mam was nicely concocted, not too watery, with a good balance of salty and sweet.

At least 90% of pho places throughout SoCal are likely better than Pho Bistro. In hindsight, every time I ate here I thought it would have been better eating nearly anywhere else in IV. The pho soup is terrible:

- the broth lacks any dimension
- the sprout and veggie toppings are lacking and not fresh
- the meat is skimpy in portion too
- the meat choices are limited, with mostly a few types of tough meat as your only options. If you like less common cuts of meat like tripe and tendons you are out of luck here. The meatballs are the most flavorful option available.

As a UCSB student, I ate here a couple times out of desperation for pho, and I can now happily say I will never dine here again. 

One recent night I was craving pho and Pho Bistro was the only place still open in town, so I went on in. A waitress asked my party if we would like to dine in or order take out. We chose the latter and were promptly seated.

The same waitress came around again about five minutes later and asked if we knew what we wanted to order. I asked for a few more minutes, and eventually we placed our orders. Well, the girl came back from the kitchen asking if we minded ordering take out.

If you haven't tried it, to-go pho, in particular, is not very palatable, especially in large styrofoam cups. This place closed early and led us into thinking we could dine in. Being led on like this was very upsetting. This misleading service on top of terrible pho is why I'll never go back.

My friends and I got the rice combinations and while the meat was tasty, the rice was an odd cheddar yellow color that (surprisingly due to it's outstanding color) tasted like normal white rice. So odd.

Yes, their vietnamese food is pretty decent - it's enough to satisfy your cravings for Vietnamese food. However, their prices are very high. I can order Pho for $5 in OC but here, it's nearly double that.

Their spring rolls and won ton cheesecake are delicious.

Hey guys LISTEN UP. I worked at this Pho place for about 5 months or so. It's definitely not the cleanest restaurant and the food is alright but I do recommend a few dishes that I think are actually really good. The fried rice is definitely good. Just the shrimp one though cause I think the other meats used in the the fried rice are bland. THE PEPPER CHICKEN WINGS ARE BOMB. Sure its a little pricey but its reallyyyy good. The chowfun is bomb too btw so get that. The eggrolls are decent and so are the spring rolls. The drinks are good when I MAKE THEM FOR SURE. I got that ingredient ratio on point my friends. I actually ate here a lot even though I worked here because I love pho and it was the only decent pho place in the area besides Noodle City. Also 50% off so woohooo. When I first came here I thought it was like really bad pho but then I got used to it and I think it started tasting better and better LOLLL. Obviously its not the best pho around but its decent and id still eat here like 3 times a week cause thats how much I love pho.

i'd rather stay home and starve then go here. Just go a little further into Goleta and anything is better then this ]: Just the thought that i could get two delicious bowls of pho for the price of one pho bistro bowl. WEnt once, never went back.

Pho is my favorite hangover cure, but definitely not when it's from Pho Bistro.

Straight to the point: overpriced and awful. 

The pho was just plain bad. As the only pho place in Isla Vista, my theory is that there's no pressure from competition for them to cook up quality food for a good price. The broth (which has a pretty dominant influence on your meal, and my favorite part) was extremely greasy. Gross.

I've never tried anything else here but I noticed a lot of others were getting the fried rice. I came here to fix my pho craving, but my recommendation is to just wait until you can get your hands on something better.

Pho Bistro is pretty good for pho being available in the IV area. The only thing that I would really have to say here is that the food is slightly overpriced for my liking. Also, I feel like every time I ask for no cilantro in my pho, they don't deliver my requests. Depending on what time you come here, it may be really rowdy due to the crowds outside, but aside from that, the food comes out fairly quickly, which I can always appreciate. I would recommend Pho Bistro to anyone who enjoys Vietnamese food!

Strolled here desperate for pho because Noodle City was closed. We asked if they were still open and yes they were. We were seated and after mulling over the menu settled on some orders of Pho. 

But then...waitress comes back from kitchen and is like "would you mind taking this to go?". Wtf hell nah. I was already settling on your lame pho and now you want me to take it to go? Nah

I hope they made it to the party they were talking about because I went that Friday night without a bowl of pho.

Avoid.

I have to second what other reviewers have already pointed out...employees at this location seem miserable. Not rude or anything, just miserable. There's one woman that usually runs the window in the morning, and I often wonder if she's just not a morning person or if she's possibly depressed. My orders are always correct and they always make my custom ice coffee order perfectly. Just makes you wonder if there is a management issue with the employees seemingly so miserable.

After having my first visit to a Chipotle in L.A. while visiting family, I was anxious to try this local store to see how it compared to the fresh flavors I found in first experience out west and subsequent visits to other stores around the country.  Not too much to say about the interior of this location, as like most fast food places, they stick to the formula, and it's pleasant.  Order taking was very prompt, and the food prep/delivery was lightning fast in spite of the fairly busy crowd.   I've tried several different dishes, but my favorite burrito is the barbacoa, which is braised and shredded beef shoulder flavored with fresh garlic, chipotle chili adobo, toasted cumin, fresh oregano, and S&P.

The food was good, but not as flavorful as what I found in L.A.  Still fresher and better than most any fast food place, though, so a good alternative when you want a quick meal.   

After followup visits to several Chipotle's in different cities around the country, I can't help comparing it to the ~10 Qdoba's I've eaten at from FL to NC and the midwest.   The formula is obviously the same, but I've found I prefer Qdoba's flavors.  I know Chipotle's commitment to organic and local ingredients, and their preference for meats raised without antibiotics or hormones.   So I always anticipate Chipotle should wow me with significantly better flavors, but inevitably, I still end up tilting to Qdoba for my preference.  The only thing I can attribute that preference to would be the seasonings they use, both which kind and freshness.   Add in that Qdoba has queso, and it's always been Qdoba for the win.

I'd still choose a Chipotle in a side-by-side choice with any burger joint, so they definitely succeed in that regard.

The staff changed. I am hoping their food is better. Today's experience was pretty good. In the past I had burnt meat, wilted veggies and scrapes of whatever they clean off the grill. I guess management finally cracked down on the past staff.

Worst chipotle in the area. I give fast food many chances before writing them off...1 out of 3 times I see major health concerns. Save ur self the disgust and drive 10 mins north to the countryside location. The servers are slower than molasses. The lettuce is often so wilted, it's BROWN and slimy. In fact, I pointed that out to a server and I asked her to get me fresh lettuce...once she served me, she mixed the old brown slimy leaves in with the new ones. GROSS. I once ordered the veggies and they had burnt crud from the improperly scrapped grill. I nearly gagged. Another time, the guac was brown, and i get it. Guac oxidizes really quickly...at least scrape it off before serving it! The meat is often chewy and over cooked. Aside from all that, the tables are not always wiped( on slow days, so no excuse) and the servers are deaf.  I love chipotle,  but this convinient location to my home is a major turn off.

I love it! It's cheap, filling and it's delicious. The location could be a little tricky to get to, but there's a front and back parking, a front and back door so don't be afraid to go through the back door. During lunch and dinner hours it may be a little busy, and when I say busy the line may go out the door so try to stay away from those hours.

Must try if you haven't already!

How have i NOT written a review of my Go-TO Chipotle at Gulf-to-Bay Ave. At first i tried ( more than once) to go to the chipotle near Countryside Mall (go see my review on this place if you'd like) but after (a few) bad experiences i rather keep it safe and come to this tried and true Chipotle. This Chipotle tends to be a little busy in the afternoon but they usually get the line moving pretty fast. They are clean and have good and fast service. Would i return here? Of course... I come here once a week.

While in Clearwater, FL on a business trip I dropped by this Chipotle to grab some dinner since I was trying to eat near my hotel and wanted something that was healthy and quick. I glad I was able to find this location on Gulf Bay Blvd on my Yelp app. The location wasn't far from the Marriott I was staying at and had plenty of seating space inside and out which is usually a problem for some location if you traffic then frequently. 

The traffic inside was brief and the staff did a great job getting customers their food to reduce lines and wait time. I ordered a salad with extra chicken, corn, drained pinto beans, onions and peppers with guacamole. All ingredients appeared to be fresh with great color and tasted superb! The chicken was steaming hot as I was lucky to get an off the grill batch just being served. 

My entire experience was pleasant as the restaurant was clean, the food was great and the staff was friendly and helpful.

Let's be clear about this:

Is it authentic? No.
Is it as healthy as they claim? Well, depending on how you build things, yes.
Is it delicious? Yes.
Is it high quality food for a very good price? Yes.

Chipotle be good food.

Nice convenient and quick. This is on the way to clearwater beach. So, guess what, ordered my chipotle real quick, and took it to the beach in a jiff. there were no crazy seagulls so luckily no bird jumped on my head to eat my chipotle. I would have been so angry. I will always be back. It's nice that they have outside seating as any chipotle does so if I do want to sit outside with my dog, I sure can.

I was not impressed. It really was nothing more than a bit more fancy Moe's. All the plain metal and wood. The menu didn't interest me in the slightest. The biggest thing it has going for it is that it's 50' from the husband's work place. So that makes it a plus in my book. It's not bad at all, don't get me wrong, it's just not my idea of a good time.

I saw all the raves on Yelp and had to go out and try this place.  

The staffs are friendly, helpful and fast.  They do not skimp on meat :) I wish they keep the meat, rice and beans hotter tho.  

Nearly $2 for guacamole is kind of a pricey upgrade.The taste was alright, nothing amazing.  But just like other burrito's place, you will get very full.  It was $18 for 2 entrees and 2 drinks.  I thought it was a little expesive for a fast food place.  

I guess I was expecting more since I saw others' reviews on this place.  Do not get me wrong this place is not bad at all for a chain fast food restaurant...I give it a 3 star because there is nothing special about it.

Dang. I've been on an Indian kick recently, and I was really looking forward to Amber once I saw the many many positive Yelp! reviews. I dined with a few people over the lunch buffet, 2 which know a thing or two about Indian food (since they are Indian) and they were very nice to go and explain what everything was. Like Tandoori King, I can't exactly state what I ate other than it was amazing, the garlic bread (naan?) was great, and the service was phenomenal. The guys always came around to refill water, a few times which was definitely needed after trying a few things blindly.

Amber Indian is worth the drive to suburban hell--it's by far the best Indian in the metro area! The weekend buffet was beautiful--spicy chaat, pickles, onion pakoras, nav rattan korma et al. Everything was intricately and uniquely spiced; I usually find saag paneer and channa masala somewhat pedestrian, but both dishes made my tongue dance at Amber Indian. It looked like there were a ton of options for meatitarians as well. This buffet rivals my faves on Devon Avenue in Chicago. It's a must-go for anyone who enjoys Indian. 

The only downside was they had two TeeVees playing some really inane-looking Tim Allen movie. Blech.

I have only been there for their lunch buffet, and it's excellent. There's a pretty wide variety and the food is of fairly high quality. My favorite is the lamb curry, which is chopped up lamb with bones in a savory sauce that's excellent with the rice or the naan (garlic, of course). For about $9, it's a very good deal.  

My only issue is that none of the dishes are really spicy. That's not atypical in the midwest, but it would be nice if there were some spicy dishes. Quite a few of the patrons appear to be ethnic Indians, which says to me the food has not been Americanized too much.

When I couchsurf in Indy, I make it to cajole and beg my hosts to cater to my culturally deprived palate.  The dearth of spice and subtlety in Muncie is characteristically appalling.  That said, my dining buddies and I grew weary of Shalimar and their predictability.

Amber offered us, for my money, a superb lunch buffet.  $7.99 is a tick high, but the vast expanse of their steam table more than made up for the price.  I'm a glutton, hands down, but I frequent buffets not for the sheer volume one can stuff down his craw, but for the breadth of flavor combinations.  Amber has more options than any other buffet I've seen in greater-Indy.

All the standards were up to and above my expectations.  Veggie options seemed substantial (dal, sag paneer, aloo chat, veg korma, et al) and chicken and lamb entrees were aplenty as well.  Samosas were conspicuously absent, but the pakoras and aloo tiki were solid.

While it seems some competitors deep fry their naan and throw it willynilly on the steam table, Amber serves their naan - plain or garlic - fresh to your table.  I've seen piping hot naan come right out the oven from Paki cab stands, and Amber's is just as good.  This little touch goes a long way to please.  

The deserts were all tasty (I never eat that mango pudding), especially the gulab.  I make a better carrot halwa, but I was pleasantly surprised.

Based on plaques by the register, the owner/operators are Punjabi.  If ordering off the menu, consider Punjab specialties.  

All in all, this was a great find.  I hope they don't succumb to pressure to bastardize their recipes for Carmel's dumbass tastes.

Oh man...I keep seeing places on here that I have never reviewed yet come to all the time.  Forgive me Amber Indian!!!

On a side note, I can only rate this place for the Lunch Buffet as I have never come here for dinner.

The buffet is outstanding!  So many choices and variety from vegetarian options to some with meat.  3 different kinds of rice and all the naan you can possibly stomach without exploding....and explode you will...because you will easily over-indulge here on the choices and deliciousness of them all.


Is this the BEST Indian food I've had? no....but it sure is the best Indian Buffet I've had.


if half stars were possible, I'd give this place a 4.5 honestly.  Amazing, but not perfect

We has the lunch buffet and the food was great!  Plenty of different dishes. Want to do there for dinner and would definitely recommend this place.  We did wish the food was a little spicier but it was a buffet.

Indian restaurants are somewhat scarce in the Indy-north 'burbs and Amber is the only one I know of in Carmel proper.

Located in a small strip center at the northwest corner of Carmel Drive and Meridian Street, this unassuming Indian eatery combines efficient service with decent fare.....if a bit pricey. Then again, given the price of gas lately, a short drive to Amber more and more frequently trumps the longer drive to some of our more wallet-friendly Indian haunts in the city.

The food does not disappoint and personal faves include the Nav Ratan Korma - a vegetable curry that is creamy and deeply satisfying - think Indian comfort food! Lamb Vindaloo is usually what my better half chooses here - so spicy he needs a refreshing Mango Lassi (yogurt and Mango puree -based drink) to vanquish the flames!
One thing not to be missed, in my humble opinion, is the Kashmiri Naan bread. It's a bit sweet thanks to its nut, shredded coconut and dried cherry stuffing and boy does it ever pair well with the savory side of the menu!  Also, be sure to try the Gulab Jamun (mini fried dough balls in cardamon-infused honey syrup) or Kheer (Indian rice pudding - I often get extra for breakfast the next day..LOL) for dessert.

Amber is open seven days per week and offers a lunch buffet from 11:00-2:30 pm. Catering is also offered, though I've not tried that yet.

The $10.99 weekend lunch buffet is a good deal. There was a pretty good variety of food and most of it was very tasty. I especially enjoyed the chicken tikka masala, saag paneer and navratan korma. I was a little disappointed by the naan which was dry and kind of burnt. Service could have been a bit more attentive. My husband liked the naan more than I did and wanted a refill, but we weren't able to get one.

Maybe a 4.5.  Note- this review is specifically based on the buffet.

400- BOOM.  Thought I'd mark this milestone with one of my favorite places in Indy.  A friend (yes, he happens to be Indian) recommended this place to me.  He claimed this to be the best Indian in the naptown area.  I had to examine the claim.

AMBIANCE- The place is in a strip mall, but when you walk in, the place is bright and open (unlike many Indian restaurants I've been to).  Seating is probably about 50-60ish, though they may have a backroom (I cant' recall).

SERVICE- for a buffet, I didn't really expect much service.  The servers were friendly though, and were very quick to replenish the naan (more on that later).

MENU- this place has to have one of the more exhaustive selections as far as a buffet goes.  Many of your favorites can be found here- palak paneer, rav korma, pakora, tikka masala, goat curry, tandoori chicken etc....  They have an interesting "Chicken 65" which in my opinion is like boneless buffalo wings Indian style.  Standard desserts such as mango pudding and kheer (rice pudding) can be found, as well as chai to finish up the meal.  Oh yeah, the naan.  They bring out fresh orders of naan (either garlic or regular) with the buffet as well.

FOOD- most everything is delicious.  I must say I was a little disappointed with the palak paneer as it seemed to be a little too pureed in my opinion, and it being a buffet, the food tends to lack a little heat, but you can always add some spice if you need to.  The garlic naan is really strong, but very good as well.  The kheer has raisins, but you can pick them out if that ain't your thang.

OVERALL- come hungry, leave happy.  This place rocks.  $9 for lunch (plus you can get a $1 off coupon at indycoupons.com) is money well spent.  If you've been wanting to try Indian food, or are just looking for some good Indian food, this is your best bet.  Do it up.

Celebrity Rating- DJ Khaled

So, we received a recommendation for Amber from a friend. We had planned to dine in at some point but on the spur of the moment one evening, decided that Indian takeout was in order. The ordering process went smoothly, pick-up was quick and timely, and everything was packaged well to make the trip home to our kitchen a breeze. Even with a 10-minute drive, the food stayed hot.

I had the Chicken Korma and my husband had half a Tandori Chicken and the Mattar Paneer. We split an order of the vegetable samosas for an appetizer. Overall, we were satisfied with the meal, but comparing it to Indian food from back in Philly, it seemed a little bland to us. Though my husband was pleasantly surprised to find out how spicy they made his meal (they asked about heat level when we ordered). He likes things pretty hot, so he found it to be just right. I asked for regular or moderate spiciness and didn't find any heat in my dish. The hubs thought the paneer was a little chewy compared to other paneer dishes he has had in the past. Our overall biggest disappointment was with the samosas. I love samosas and for me, these missed the mark. Low on spice and flavor and really heavy on potato in the filling. I also noted that they didn't seem fried all the way; the dough was kind of chewy on the inside (and for the record, it didn't seem like a lack of crispiness that you might expect as a peril of takeout, because they actually were crispy on the outside).

So, I would probably go back to Amber and give them another chance before I made a final call, but it was just a good experience, not great. I'll also keep exploring other Indian options in the area as limited as they seem to be.

Had a Sat lunch buffet. Excellent quality food. Large variety on the buffet. Nice fresh naan brought to the table. Water glasses filled as needed. Salad section was not skimpy as I've seen at other Indian buffets.

We got there around 12:30pm, and it got a little crowded as we were leaving at 1:30pm.

Cleanliness was impeccable. So was food and service. These guys are pros.

Warning: some buffet items were extremely salty, probably the more spicier items, since nothing stood out as too salty while I was eating.  But I drank a lot of water, and got bloated/retained water.

Definitely happy with this place - very close to my client, and I should have gone more often. Just a really solid Indian buffet, with almost everything very tasty. Good standard stuff like butter chicken and tandoori, but also some more unusual stuff like aloo chat and a devastatingly good mushroom korma that I could eat a gallon of. I also really like their mint chutney - a little extra tart in there makes it just my style. Their naan is also pretty good, in both standard and the not-my-preference garlic varieties. The price is reasonable, and while service isn't outstanding, it's fine. I don't need to be fawned over at lunchtime. It's too bad this is just a carb nap waiting to happen, or I think we would have gone more often.

Such a fantastic Indian restaurant. The food here is consistently delicious. As soon as you are seated they bring out the wafer like bread and wonderful homemade chutney. The mint is my favorite! The menu is pretty typical for an Indian restaurant. My dish of choice- Paneer Tika Masala. The portion sizes are pretty big and I usually end up taking half of it home for left overs that are equally wonderful. The one drawback, and not at the fault of the restaurant, is that there is a ton of construction in the area and getting to the place can be somewhat difficult. I am sure that this is only a temporary problem. But don't let that stop you, the place if definately worth the hunt!

OK, the food is very reasonable in price and fair to middlin' in taste and quality.  The menu includes some nice home-style Italian faves.  It's the type of place you grab a bottle from your wine rack at home, jump in the car, and go enjoy an impromptu night at this Mom and Pop operation.

Pop is in the kitchen throwing together mass quantities of food and Mom is out among the Friday night half-filled restaurant looking like she is hating every minute being there.   Her miserable puss exudes a bad vibe throughout the restaurant.

One time I was there,  Mom was having a shouting match with one of the servers in front of the customers, to which the server exited on the spot.  It was a most uncomfortable evening.  So I waited awhile to go back.  

The Shrimp Fra Diavolo grabbed my attention and the nice spice hit the spot.  Dinner Rolls buried in garlic and oil are just leaving my taste buds 3 days later...overkill there.  The salad which was included might as well not be... iceberg lettuce and a dab of Italian dressing sitting in a tiny puddle in the middle of the salad doesn't do it for me.

Service is OK.  The girls are working their butts off.  I guess they don't want to face the wrath of Mom.
Employees  friendly & greet you on entrance! Full service drugstore. I've had great experience with the pharmacy too. Now in higher position Holly was very good . Easy parking & access.

Updated review 1-5-2021 went into pharmacy in back ne corner to see major renovations to accommodate the surge of shots & vacations flu, shingles, and soon to arrive covid vaccine . Multiple elders asking the pharmacist Ryan who suggests going to cvs.com . Seems cvs has expanded its healthcare services. They now have a more organized waiting area, also a private area closed off where pharmacist delivers vaccines . The pharmacist station also has been moved further away from the public. Sadly I didn't bring my cel phone for pictures of the née renovations . Ryan has a pleasant calm ,manner in his patient communications. Thank you

Employees  friendly & greet you on entrance! Full service drugstore. I've had great experience with the pharmacy too. Now in higher position Holly was very good . Easy parking & access

Waited 10 min on phone no one answered sat am 942

Authentic Mexican food. Came here for lunch and the food came SO fast! The waiter we had was super friendly too. The lunch menu had a lot of combos and options and reasonably priced. The food wasn't anything crazy special, but decent for the price.

I adore this market! As soon as you walk in, the bakery case is right there. It is bright and beautiful, and everything looks delicious. In addition to regular cakes, desserts and breads they have Latin ones which look amazing. There is tons of choice. As you keep walking, there is a hot food bar that looks and smells amazing. It is a bit overwhelming because the menu is set over the middle of the food, but if you just stand back and look for a minute you should be good to go. The produce section is next and it is beautiful. They have everything you find in a regular grocery, plus things I've only seen there. I love it! The isles are fun- again a mix of the usual and the imported/unusual. But my absolute favorite part is the meat counter. The meats are gorgeous and the prices are great. This is definitely a place to at least check out once if you have never been!

Really an excellent Latin market. Many specialty food markets don't have a lot of fresh vegetables, but their selection is impressive, and I would go here if I was in need of obvious Central American specialties like jalapeno peppers or avocados. I also took a deep breath and bought a bit of cactus. We'll see how that goes.

They have plenty of other things, including appealing bakery items, fantastic tortillas, and "authentic" lo mein. Hot sauces aplenty of course, and you can get your beans plenty of ways here. Their prepared foods seem vegetarian unfriendly (and not labeled really, whereas the rest of the store has pretty clear bilingual labels in most areas), and there are certainly areas of the store that are of no use to me, but there's enough that is. This location seemed larger than the Central City one.

The big negative, although I haven't dinged them too heavily for it, was that checkout was a mess. Lines developed, and they opened another register to help, but the guy working it clearly had no idea what was going on, and struggled mightily. I was half inclined to try figuring out how to ring up mushrooms myself or make my own change. I felt rather sorry for him; it's not the individual's fault of course, but staffing and training is someone's responsibility and someone dropped the ball the night I visited. Assuming that most of the time this is not happening, I still recommend the place.
This publix is always clean and the employees are nice. The woman who works the seafood counter is the best!
The Ritzes are the best places to see a movie in Philadelphia.

Not to be confused with Ritz Five, which is right around the corner! 

All of the Ritz are great. Their movie selection, concessions selection, service- everything is top-notch. There are only two movies playing at this particular location. 

If you're looking to grub somewhere, Positano Coast is great for drinks and apps but can get kinda pricey beyond that and the food can be hit or miss (more hit than miss). There's also a Chinese restaurant right next door. 

Special Note: Wednesdays are cheaper than other days!

Our impromptu tour of Old City ended with plans to see a movie here. Street parking for the two-hour spots around here is pretty cutthroat so we ended up using the automated multi-story parking garage attached to the theatre. I was all psyched to use my old uni ID but the impatient lady at the ticket counter was hollering, "No student discounts on Saturdays!" Oh well. Not like I hadn't wanted to see Black Swan anyways.

Interesting that they rotate a lineup of two showings at this location. The concessions staff were an efficient lot, even though the non-fountain beverages didn't call to me. A very long booth facing the bathrooms/concessions makes for comfortable seating for waiting friends. Everyone respected the rules during the movie; no one left their phone off vibrate, no one made loud obnoxious commentary. Not even a crying baby in our crowded lot. I was a little embarrassed when my hyena laughter rang out like a gunshot and sank a little lower in my tippy seat.

To echo what many have said, this is my favorite theater in the Philly area too.  Just a different experience than the AMCs and Regals we get so accustomed to.  Every movie i've seen there I've enjoyed.  They really choose some great ones.  Seats are the nicest, but they are surprisingly comfortable.  The snack bar is amazing.  So many cool and different options.  Staff is really kind and helpful with the customers.  Also, they have some amazing deals on weekdays, like $6.50 Wednesdays.  Hope to be back sooner rather than later!

A bit far form center city but in a cool area and still offers film viewing at a reasonable price.  The seats are fine but the screens are small (compared to the multiplexes that everyone goes to nowadays) but you wouldn't come here to see a major blockbuster action movie.  I've watched Slumdog Millionaire and Conviction here and both times, the place was just perfect.  The student discount and matinee pricing are awesome too!

Yes this is definitely a great theatre in Philadelphia probably because it is located the ritzy Olde City. They show independent films. I'm not much of a movie theatre person until someone drags with me with. The last time I was here was to see to see Slum Dog millionaire, which wasn't available in all theaters so it was good it was shown here. Great movie, great experience. I recommend Ritz East if you are a movie buff.

A really great independent movie theatre located in old city.

The ritz is fairly small (with only two screens), but it has a great feel, decently large theatre spaces, and a fully stocked concession stand. The first time I came was to see a Japanese language film, "Like Father Like Son," during the Philadelphia film festival three years back. The Ritz was the only theatre showing it in Philly I believe. 

I went for the second time yesterday for a free early screening of "Criminal." The movie was definitely not on par with the last I'd seen, but it was still a fun time, and I still stand by the Ritz and its mission!

Ritz East is one of 3 Ritz theaters all in walking distance. Like its counter parts, Ritz East is arts sort of house. It carries smaller indie movies, which includes some of the major Oscar contending movies.

The other two Ritz theaters carry 5 movies a piece. Ritz East, however, has only two movies. That said, it has much more seating and larger screens. Though, the screens considering the size of the theaters could be a little bigger. But hey, it is an arts house.

Ritz East is kept up very well. It's clean and about as modern as you'd expect an arts house to be. Since it's not pulling in the big bucks of a major theater, you should not expect it to be state of the arts.

The service is very good. And, the prices are always better than a major theater. And to be honest, the quality of movies is better too! Good spot to see those less popular, but clearly better, movies.

Came here last night for an early screening of Don't Think Twice and some of the cast came by at the end for a Q&A! Great experience - this theater is super comfy and big and there's a good amount of available parking in the area. It's also right next to Penn's Landing so you can take a nice stroll next to the water and contemplate whatever indie or artsy movie you've just seen afterwards.

I like this Ritz the best. I just like it. When there's a good movie showing here, it's great. The num nums are inexpensive, the popcorn is tasty, the guys working behind the counter move relatively fast (rather than the snail-like pace at every other movie theater I've ever been to in my lifetime). they serve delicious hot chocolate, and if you go at just the right time, the crowd of people always looks like a sea of parents, which is better than high school students. And one time I stood behind Marc Summers in line here. 

I want a hot chocolate.

This was actually the 1st of the ritz theaters we came to . We haven't seen a movie here since then but the highly reviewed devils double opened friday so we planned a matinee after brunch. We snagged a sweet spot on 2nd St . Like all the others comfy chairs, organic popcorn and hoards of seniors wanting their discounts .

I love all my Philly Ritzes. I can always count on at least one of them to be showing a film that I want to see. More often than not Ritz East, Ritz at the Bourse and Ritz 5 are ALL featuring films on my "wanna see" list.

I love independent films the most. I love foreign films and art joints. Here's where you find em in Filmadelphia (I'm the worst). Ritz East is well-maintained, clean and comfortable. I am a fan.

 I love going to see films and then being able to ramble incessantly with friends willing or otherwise about what we've seen. Judging by the thin-lipped smiles and glazed over expressions on their faces, I'm sure that I take it to an insufferable level; as is my way. Maybe it's just that I keep repeating the word, "film," over and over. I really geek over this stuff. 

One of my favorite things in Philly life is to hatch a plan where we go catch what's playing at one of the Ritzes, then go for a drink/meal/bite along our walking way to another nearby Ritz, another movie. 

How bout a movie-meal crawl? For when you're feelin like you deserve some fun and special treatment. It's a nice little movie-meal-movie-meal cycle. Double double feature, get me?

I do love all my Ritzes, and this one is a beaute.

The staff is friendly and consists completely of the epitome of movie dorkdom.  The theatre is clean enough.  I've seen better, I've seen worse.  Prices on eats?  Who knows.  Only a sucker actually buys food and drink at a movie theatre.  

There was an old man sitting in the back row that seemed to be mumbling to himself or perhaps breathing oddly.  I changed my seat as to not be distracted by aforementioned breathing and talking to one's self.  He made a slight outburst near the beginning of the picture when four late comers that were being hoes turned on their flashlight app in order to see where they were going and many patrons sent angry outbursts and he exclaimed "what is wrong with you?!" but to the flashlight hoes or to the disgruntled patrons?  One will never know.  This man is likely deceased by now.

Then again, we were there to see "Nymphomaniac"

Love Love Love the Ritz!  Always interesting independent films are shown here.

I've seen "Waiting For Superman",  "Vicky Cristina Barcelona", and "Convicted" here just to name a few.  

This place is so cool that one day I did the unthinkable in the movie theater....get your mind out the gutter!  I saw a flick ALONE.  This is the type of movie theater you can do this in though because you can be deemed as an intellectual and not a looser with no friends or date lol.

The concession stand has all of your typical snacks plus some eats for the yuppies (ie flavored coffees, muffins, and scones).  

I like that this theater has an old-school vibe to it too.  It's just so nice to get away from mainstream Blockbusters once in a while and see raw and intellectually stimulating movies.

Out of the trinity of Ritzes, this is probably my favorite. That isn't to say I don't love the Bourse & 5, but East is generally quieter, less crowded than the other two, and tucked away under dappled shade next to Pagoda, where you can enjoy an inexpensive bowl of noodles pre or post movie. Yes, the others have a wider (relatively speaking) selection, but if a film that catches my eye plays here, I'm all the happier for it. 
Unlike Valerie T, I have always had good experiences with the staff- most notably the occasion when I went batty over a huge brilliant cardboard stand-up ad for The Fall, and asked the manager what I had to do/fork over to be the proud owner of such a beauty. With a slightly bemused smile he told me that they give them for free to whoever calls dibs first, and they promised to notify me the moment they changed promo materials in the lobby. I gleefully (and awkwardly) carted the monstrosity off after the movie finished its run. 

Oh, and as with the other Ritzes, parking validation is niiiice.

When I saw that Ritz East was a Landmark theater I knew I was in good hands. I've been a huge fan of their Tivoli and Plaza Frontenac locations in St. Louis for years, so I know they are pretty much synonymous with quality independent and foreign films in a nice atmosphere. 

As far as I know they are the only theater showing Moonrise Kingdom anywhere in the city, which is a major plus. The ticket prices, too, are extremely reasonable for the location--$9.50 for Saturday evening shows, $6.50 for shows on Wednesdays, and $7.25 for matinees are pretty stellar prices if you ask me. 

My only advice, which is less of a downside and more of a peak-time reality, is to show up a bit early on weekends. When we went for our 8:45 p.m. show yesterday (Saturday) the theater did get very crowded, and a sign posted said that the 7:45 p.m. show had actually sold out. We ended up buying our tickets about half an hour early and walking around for a bit beforehand, which worked out really well because when we came back the ticket line had gotten really long and the theater was starting to fill up. So, be prepared to come early if you want your pick of seats.

Don't know why I haven't reviewed this theater , yet. Been there couple last couple years. Once to see Pans Labyrinth , another time after. I like this theater, only reason I gave it 4-stars is parking . If you are from across the bridge ,Parking is a Bitch!!! I hate it. Locals you're good, walk or get a cab. But other then that, nice.., go downstairs, different theaters are designated, looks are deceiving but the inside bigger then it looks. Surprisingly clean & the crowd it draws is predominantly more mature, not alot rift raft, independent movies, etc tend to do that-Yippy!!

Now I think I am reviewing the right place - I saw a movie last night at the "Landmark East" theatre on 2nd Street between Chestnut & Walnut.  It was clean and there were no ticket lines.  Hardly anybody there - which made it nice.

Restrooms were clean - but I bet if it were crowded that it would not have been.  Concession area offered hot & cold beferages, popcorn, candy and snacks - plus you could purchase DVDs to take home.  The staff was friendly.

All in all we had an excellent viewing experience

The Ritz East, or as Elizabeth B so memorably put it, the "Ritz Pagoda" is my heavy crush of the three RItz theaters just blocks apart in Old City.  These fraternal triplets show the artsy, indie and otherwise unknown flicks you must see, plus the occasional big-budget studio picture.  

Big reclining seats, icy cold A/C and not much of a crowd means you can get as comfortable here as on your own couch.  But don't take your shoes off, please; that's just weird.

*Insert snobby hipster comment about mainstream movies here*  In all seriousness though, this is a nice space.  I do like that unlike Ritz at the Bourse, I can use my cell phone in here without losing a signal.  (I have an attention span problem ok?)

Small BYO spot close to the park. Delicious, the food compared to other spots in the area is much fresher and has way less holding time. Big fan of their vindaloo recipe. Garlic naan was piping hot and tasty. Prices are high, but understandable given the area.

Desperately looking for open restaurants later on a Sunday night (around 9:20). This spot was open till 10, so confirmed via phone call and headed there as quickly as possible.

We arrived with half an hour to spare but at that point they were only doing takeout orders. Quickly went through the menu and ordered the Chili Chicken ($13) and Garlic Naan ($4). Food was ready after about 10 minutes - tightly packed in a to-go back, and thankfully with utensils after asking. Chili chicken is a large serviced of sliced chicken marinated in chili paste, tomato ketchup, and other spices. The overall taste is sweet because of all the tomato ketchup, with some spicy follow-through. Naan is your basic fare, not too much garlic but went well to scoop up the chicken.

Was hoping for a sit-down meal, but they seemed ready to close out for the night. Plenty of options to choose from here, so could be hit or miss.

Medium level Mexican joint. Honestly, there isn't much to say. It has the typical large Mexican menu, average or even below average quality food and decent at best margaritas. I have been twice for lunch and both times it's been too greasy meat, half a taco filled with just lettuce and just ok salsa. There is better Mexican right up the street by the Starbucks- go there instead

Maybe for Nashville it's good Mexican food, but it's not good Mexican food to a Californian. The fajitas lacked seasoning and were sitting in wayyy too much oil/water in the skillet. The bean dip was weird but good, and the salsa was delicious.

You want reasonably priced, yummy Mexican food and super fast friendly service? Eat at Cinco De Mayo in Hermitage! My only complaint is the booths are uncomfortable and the bathroom is pretty lacking. Luckily I've only had to use it maybe twice in the last 6 years! The waiters are always friendly, fast, and accomodating. Can get pretty busy at times, but never had to wait more than 10 minutes, and that is rare. Try it! You won't be sorry!!

I get why this place has 3 stats overall - it's not the shiny new grocery stores that are popping up all over. But hear me out, they have the basics, they have a meat counter, they have excellent selection especially for the size, the size makes for quick trips, but the gem is the staff. The staff is super friendly. They are really really great. Would I recommend this location for a refresh of the store, sure but I find it convenient. 

Groceries: 4/5
Staff: 5/5
Place: 3/5 - it's old and needs an investment

I'm a fan of this teeny-tiny Kroger because I love being able to walk to the grocery store with my little reusable bags. Okay, this Kroger does not have the greatest selection, but they do have staples and some pretty nice high-end items, cheeses included. The tuna steaks I purchased are beautiful, and at a really good price.

The wine selection is awesome for such a small space!

I really wish they carried Athenos Greek yogurt, because they carry all kinds of Athenos products. I also really wish the cashiers were nicer. Some just act like it's a huge hassle to check you out and scan your coupons.

Get stoked that there's a grocery store so close to your house!

Did you know there's a Kroger tucked away off the main drag in Broad Ripple? Me neither! It's an old school Kroger that feels like it's stuck in the 1980s, but it gets the job done if you're looking for something basic. The layout is a bit odd, and it feels more like a glorified CVS than an actual grocery store. But, it's convenient if you're cruising through Broad Ripple. Find it back by the new Three Sisters location!

I totally agree with Sarah A.'s review...and bumping it up an extra star.

I love that I live in an area that has so many places that I can walk to without ever venturing out on a busy street like Keystone.  Yes, I own a car!  But what better way to reduce my carbon footprint then by hoofing it to the grocery when I just need a few items...with my own bag(s) of course :-)

I've only lived in the neighborhood for about 4 weeks, so when someone told me we had a Krogers in Broad Ripple, I said:  "Really?  Where?"  I only knew of the one on Keystone.  I finally stumbled upon it the other day when driving down Guilford Avenue to avoid Broad Ripple Avenue during rush hour...or is that more accurately...happy hour...not that I am one to EVER disparage Happy Hour!

So today, during my lunch break (I work from home)...I walked over to Kroger to pick up a few things that couldn't wait until my next Trader Joe's run.  Prices were a little higher than Marsh's, but that is to be expected for the size of the store and area it serves.  While I wouldn't do all of my shopping here, I certainly appreciate its existence.

Small Kroger with most of your needs. Don't expect to find everything you need on your list here. 
For the most part the staff was friendly.
We did some late night shoppin. Online it said the store closed at 11. We got there around 9:45 pm and were greeted with a voice over the loud speaker saying the store would be closing at 10pm. When we were checking out, we told the cashier that online it said the store closed at 11 and her response was "we know, its been like that for forever". 
Now had we gotten all the way there and it been closed I would have been livid. 
As an employee, if you have knowledge of something like that, why not make en effort to get it changed. 
On our car ride back home, I went to google, and suggested an edit for the times. In less than 48 hours, the hours had been updated to the proper time on google.

Compared to other Kroger stores, this one has a more neighborhood feel to it for you to pop in to grab a few items. I have had times where I am unable to get all my groceries or preferred brands at this location but the staff is nice.

This Kroger is an old style before the era of the superstore.  It's smaller, but they make a concerted effort to carry a little bit of everything and to keep the older building nice and orderly.  The staff was so friendly in the meat department and at checkout.  It's a convenient location in the heart of Broad Ripple.  If you are wanting to pick up your basic pantry staples or just immediate needs for dinner tonight, this location does the trick.

Went here for lunch with 2 co workers.  I got a regular beef burger American cheese sautéed mushrooms and lettuce sweet potato tots.  My bill was $19.00.  That is a little steep.  The burger was just okay.  The bread was really dry if that makes sense.  The tots were awful.  They were falling apart and no flavor.  There was 5 people in the whole place at lunch time.  Obviously, there is a reason for that.  I probably won't return.

Charcoal's offers unique meat choices and serves up a very tasty burger.

I normally wait to visit a new establishment for a few weeks to give them time to work out the kinks. I don't think it is fair to the business to review a place in its first few days without cutting them some slack for sow service, or menu shortages. I lucked out on my visit a week or so after they first opened and had a great experience.
