I drive past the intersection of Jackson and Magazine quite frequently and have been curious about what the new building was going to be for several months. I drove by on opening day, but didn't go in because I hadn't heard anything about it. After my first visit, I know I will be back.

I was surprised at the different meat choices. There were several exotic game burgers along with their house bend ground beef. I was feeling adventurous so I decided on the antelope with cheddar. The burger was cooked perfectly. It was juicy and did not taste as odd as I would have expected antelope to taste. I guess I had no clue what to expect, but it was very good. The burger came with a side of homemade chips which were similar in style to plain Zapp's. I think I will upgrade to tots or fries on my next visit.

I was surprised at how friendly and efficient the staff were. I came in early to beat the lunch rush which I would recommend to others. At 11:00 a.m., there was no line and several open seats.

While I did really enjoy the food, I have a couple of slight issues. The first is that it was more expensive than I would have expected. With cheese and sauteed onions my burger, chips and drink ended up around $15. While not super expensive, some friends went another day and had a bill of close to $80 including alcohol. The other slight issue is the seating situation. Most of the seats were either bar style seating or at picnic tables. I am a friendly guy, but I prefer sitting at an actual table separate from those I don't know. Since I came early I was able to snag that table, but if I had waited I don't think I would have been able to.

In summary, I really enjoyed the food and service at Charcoal's. I suspect they will become one of my regular lunch spots.

Maybe this is going to sound mean, but I don't care: The South is not ready for a place like Charcoals. 

Places like this are everywhere in California. If this place was by my house, I would eat there every week. $20 for a burger with chips is not outrageous. I got a bison burger with 2 kinds of cheese, 2 kinds of bacon & basil & that's what it came to. Yeah, it took a little while to come out. That's what happens when food is cooked to order. I did not mind the wait. Our food was delicious. I have absolutely zero complaints. Neither did the rest of our party. I only wish this place was not 1800 miles from my home.

Decided to dip into the Irish Channel. I am a frequent flyer of the Black Pearl. Actually, let me back up, I visited during lunch break and they were out of Turkey meat. You get a pass, because you're new. I decided to give them another shot and I am glad I did. 
Sat at the bar, and here's my dialogue.


Me: Can I  see your drink menu Mr. Bartender? 
Bartender: Sure, what's your flavor?
Me: Gucci
Bartender: I have he perfect drink. It's called Gucci. The drink was named that. 

LOL! My experience didn't quite go like this! Just a little word play.  To sum it all up, the Gucci did not disappoint and I did not spend an arm and leg for it. 

For my main course, I ordered a Gourmet Turkey Burger. Made it real simple, gimmie the Turkey Burger that has already been designed by you  Charcoalians! It was So round, so fully packed! A double entendre. I know!! Love the charcoal taste in my burger. The sweet potato tots were really yumcrazy too. 

Would I go back? Yes indeed!

The massive, rusted shackles binding my wrist and ankles savagely chewed into my flesh like a starved carnivore as I was dragged by the King's guards through the inner cloister of the monastery; my limp, weakened frame incapable of standing upright on its own without the support of the guards' unrelenting grips just above my elbows.  Only minutes prior, I was violently awoken and forcibly removed from my 180 cm x 240 cm prison of crushed stones, moldy crevices and vermin-infested straw which I now called home.  My only company amongst the damp, ever resonating darkness were the bone piles of the cell's previous occupants.  I had recently been accused of heresy and apostasy, as well as obscene rituals and was to be brought immediately before King Philip IV of France and the Church for trial.  While lacking sufficient legal experience, I maintained a strong faith in logical reasoning, which I prayed may be the only weapon I required with which to defend myself before the court.  The great doors of the refectory sailed open before me at the simple wave of the guards' hands and suddenly, I was thrown to the cold, rugged floor at the feet of the King and Pope Clement.

"Ah yes, it thrills me ever so that I've finally got a seat this close to you.  I want to be where I can see the yellow of your eyes", said King Philip.

"I'm not currently in possession of yellow eyes", I replied.  "These charges against me are as much a farce as this trial!"

"Silence, beast!  You'll speak only when you're told!" cried one of the King's guards, drawing my head back by my hair as he lay his worn, blood spattered blade against my throat.

In a two finger motion, the King waved off the aggressive advances of the guard.  "So, Sir Paul of the Warehouse District", began the King.  "Explain to me and this court where you were on the evening of February 15th.  I wish to hear every detail so that we all may bear witness to the errors of your ways."

"Your majesty" I explained, "it's as I've stated before and my story shan't be altered.  On the eve of February 15th, my ship's crew and I witnessed a light like that of a wax candle dancing on the horizon though with a body so small, we could not affirm it to be land.  I called to my First Officer and bid he look that way, which he indeed did and saw it."

"...And you described this most mystifying light to your crew, as well as within your personal log, as resembling the Jewish Menorah?" the King sternly enquired.

"I did, your Excellency...", I replied puzzlingly.

Shrieks and gasps ruptured the silence throughout the magnificent dining hall; four monks gathered near the threshold to the Infirmary nearly lost their composure before the Abbot rushed to their aid.  "Blashphemy!" cried the Arch Bishop.  "'Tis the work of false Gods and malevolent magic, m 'Lord!  Add sorcery to the list of charges against him!"

"Would you be so kind as to allow this man to finish his thought, sir?" asked Pope Clement.  "Please, continue on."

"According to our map, we had sailed upon the seas of Magazine" I began again.  "With small boats and provisions, we set out to investigate the strange light upon the island we dubbed Jackson.  Just off the sandy shore, we came upon a jovial tavern which housed several brightly lit lanterns, which I believe was the source of the inexplicable light which my crew and I witnessed at sea.  As we ventured inside this most cryptic tavern, a female of alluring beauty rushed to our side and offered placement on the establishment's second floor where every variety of beer, mead, godale and other intoxicating beverages flowed like the Rhine river."

"Never have I heard such a tale of villainy and perversion!" shouted the Arch Bishop.  "A tavern of wenches wielding the Devil's arcane witchcraft and yet again, you fell victim!?  Just forty-five moons ago, you were seen in Rochester Castle consorting with women and drinking heavily at the keep's tavern, 'The Complacent Mammary'!  What say you?!"

"The Holy scripture states that he who is without sin may cast the first stone" I replied.  "While I do not deny those charges, I believe one must know evil before he can condemn it.  Further, this new establishment my crew and I discovered was not a tavern but rather typical of an Inn that goes by the name of 'Charcoal'.  The Inn's butcher prepares potent meats for seafaring and battle weary men in the form of what they call "burgers".  These "burgers" are produced of only the finest quality meats, such as beef, venison, kobe, elk, turkey, bison, and of course, antelope.  These meat patties are then topped with the local monastery's freshest vegetables, cheeses and condiments; all of which are situated beneath a crisp, buttery bread bun of your choice.  If this court deems me guilty and my existence extinguished, with my last words I say this: I am not wicked to love such flavors as the Gorgonzola Piccante or the Aged Goat.  Only God knows who is wrong and who has sinned!"

Place was great! Had the buffalo burger, and it was amazing. The meat melts in your mouth. Would definitely eat it again. The only thing is, why is it SO EXPENSIVE?!? If it was just $3 or $4 dollar less would have definitely gave it a 5 star, but it was $20 overall with tax. Staff was friendly and good.

This place is ok. If I am hungry and next door I would go in, but I wouldnt make an effort to go and I certainly wouldnt take anyone from out of town there.

The burgers come from all different kinds of animals but you cant really tell the difference. 

I will give them props for their fried pickles. Delish!
Tried the chocolate shake...it was great.  Burgers & fries were equally delish.  Charcoals is two for two.

I had higher expectations for Charcoal. I'd heard good things and was excited to try it out. While I was tempted to sample something on the more unique side (i.e. elk burger), I really just wanted a classic American beef cheeseburger. Seemed like a good place to start.

The waiter asked if I'd like it done medium, which is pretty much what I always get. The burger came out well done -- there was not a hint of pink anywhere in there. I liked the bun and the toppings, though I could have gone for a few more pickles on there. The standard fries that I got were good too.

My girlfriend got the salmon burger. She was not impressed in any way. She also had the sweet potato tator tots, which she said tasted like they had been frozen. She said she wouldn't mind if we didn't return. I wouldn't mind if we did, but there are other burger places in town that I prefer -- namely Five Guys (still my fave) and Cowbell.

Although SO many options, this place is just OK. Where to start....
bison, 
venison, 
kobe, 
shrimp, 
salmon, 
turkey, 
veggie, 
elk and so on. 
These are some, that's right, some of the burger options. This was the most convenient/casual place to dine in the area before our tour started. We didn't want anything sweet so district donuts was out (sadly, because they looked amazing). The art on the walls was unique, bright- bold colors and very inviting. We approached the counter and the woman at the register gave us the run-down of how the restaurant worked: casual dining at the counter downstairs or sit down/wait staff service upstairs with balcony seating. Since we were in a slight rush, we sat downstairs at the counter.

After an overview of the menu, we opted to build our own burger and oddly enough felt fancy to go for the ordinary house beef burger (see what I did there?). We generally like our beef cooked medium, but it came out borderline done. A hint of juiciness lingered, which made it palatable. Toppings: lettuce, ketchup, mayo, creole mustard, pepper jack cheese, jalapenos on a Hawaiian sweet bun topped with an order of Slap Ya Mama fries to share. It worked out nicely to share the entire meal because we wanted to save room for a larger meal later in the evening. We washed everything down with 2 for 1 ritas to celebrate Cinco De Mayo. 

Overall, the service was good; the ambience was cool, but I can't say this is a restaurant I'd keep on my bookmarked or favorites list. The seasoning on the fries were pretty good and the burger was pretty good, but all in all nothing to write home to mom about.

I really should have payed more attention to the bad reviews on this place because my experience was just as poor as everyone else. I ordered the bison burger and proceeded to get nickel and dimed to death on toppings. Then I chose fries rather than the free chips that I didn't know were free due to the small print. My order took 45 minutes before it was ready. My friend complained and he was given a free dose of grease via the chips that were nothing to write home about. They are of a potato medley though the only ones out the medley that are decent were the sweet potato chips. When I finally got my burger it was good though you couldn't tell it was bison. I had my suspicion as to if it was actually bison due to the light color of the meat when bison has a much darker color. I have eaten many a bison burger from Ted's Montana Grill and you can tell when you get bison over beef there. The meat also didn't have that little hint on tang that bison normally has. The so called slap ya mamma fries were tasteless at its name, I had to dip them into a hot sauced mixed ketchup to provide any spice. Overall the bad reviews are true and its best to just stay away from this place. The only good thing that has changed since the early reviews is that at least for me and from what I saw the patty is much bigger than some I've seen posted on here. If your in the area go to the District or Stein's across the street. UPDATE: "WHERE IS MY APOLOGY?"

I would like to start off my review with a little lesson on how a business works. When a new place opens it needs a minute to find it's groove. You can't go into a place on the first day and expect everything to be flowing like clock work. There are going to be hiccups. To go into a place on the day it opens and then rate it two stars when everything doesn't go perfectly is a little unfair in my opinion. Yes, they are going to run out of things. Yes, they are going to be a little slow. If the place has been open less than a month, please go in prepared for that.  Just putting that out there.

Today I had the delight of trying the new burger place in town: Charcoal's. As soon as I heard about the unique menu, I was in. I couldn't wait to try it out. Among some of the items besides the basic beef are antelope, elk, bison, salmon, venison and veggie.

Being the adventurous spirit I am, I decided to try the antelope burger. I got it topped with cheese, lettuce, tomato, ketchup and mayo on the brioche bun. You can get all kinds of fancy ingredients on it like bacon and avocado and grilled onions, but I decided to keep it simple.

The burger itself was so good. It didn't taste crazy or anything like that. It had a bit of a "gamey" taste, but nothing overwhelming. It was a really thick, juicy patty and it was cooked to perfection. The bun was soft and flavorful and really good. I got a side of sweet potato tater tots. I had never had them before, and they were obviously house made and delicious. They were almost like small sweet potato hash browns. They were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. All in all, really good.

Although a little expensive, I would definitely check out Charcoal's again when I am in the mood for a special burger treat.

We ate here twice while in town a few weeks back. The house we were staying in was just down the street, so when hunger hit and the lines were too long at the deli across the way, we found ourselves here. 

The restaurant is split into two zones. The first floor, which is a more casual counter service and the second floor, a table service kind of area. We ate at both over the two visits. 

One rub I heard from local friends and felt myself, is the buildout of the space. The materials used give a polished almost chain produced feel and doesn't lend much character to the space, which just about every other eatery in the area has tons of. It almost subconsciously sets you up with a feeling of unease while coming in for a bite because you're so used to walking into an old worn out building with weathered floors and warm woods, instead finding stainless steel and polished concrete. They do make a good attempt of incorporating NOLA into their decor though by having dozens of signs and works from local artist Simon Hardeveld strewn about the space. 

We had breakfast downstairs in the counter service area and it was great. I ordered a simple two eggs, bacon toast and other staples style plate and everything came out quick and good. A plus of the downstairs seating is much of it sits you looking out to the street for great people watching. Lunch, another visit, was upstairs in the table service seating. Their main attraction is the wide range of burgers on their menu. They offer multiple meats beyond beef, including wild game and plenty of topping options to make your burger your own. The regular beef burger I ordered was good enough, but for a place that focuses on burgers burgers burgers, I wasn't blown away. 

Service upstairs was great. Our server was very friendly, chatted us up and made sure our food came out as quickly as possible. 

All in all, I liked it better for breakfast downstairs than the table service burger house upstairs. It's worth a visit if you're looking for something easy, especially if you're an exotic burger hunter.

My friend and I work in the Earth City business park and we go to this Dierbergs location at least twice a month for lunch. I'm not sure if all Dierbergs have a dine-in area, but they make great lunch spots for eating all of the awesome home cooked food you can get at their deli and sushi bars!

We like it because Dierbergs deli has a great selection of real food that you can get small portions of and either have them heat it up or you can take it to the little lunch area and heat it up yourself. Most of the time we get either sushi or the baked chicken dinner which for 6 bucks gets you a chicken breast and leg, plus two sides and a dinner roll! Today we opted out of the sushi and went for the chicken as you can see by my before and after pics. Sometimes we get yummy desserts from the deli too.

Another reason we really like to eat in the store is because it seems like a place that older people, blue collar workers and stay at home mom's like to also have their lunch. Its nice to get out of the office cafeteria and be around something other than your working class lunch crowd at all of the traditional lunch hour spots. It's more like sitting down at a dinner table and taking it easy over some good home cooking.

One time we'll always remember is when a cute little old man started talking to us as we were getting ready to leave, asking us where we worked and so forth. We told him we worked at a health and medical sciences book publisher and he asked me, oh so you're not a nurse then? I told him no, he looked sad for a second and said, Oh I was hoping that you'd check me out and see if i'm healthy, then with a wink and a chuckle, he sent us on our way.

Great store. I come here for all of my shopping needs...or at least 95% of them anyway. Sometimes there is the occasional item I want from TJ's or WF that I just cannot find at Dierberg's. But that's usually pretty rare. I like this store because all of the workers here are really friendly and will go out of their way to help me find something. Sometimes they will even walk me to the aisle where the item is located to make sure that I find it. The fish and meat here is always really fresh. The store is clean. It can be expensive but I'm willing to pay a bit more so long as I don't have to go to the grungy Schnucks near Lindenwood, lol.

Stopped into this Dierberg's to pick up a few things with my friend while his Tesla was at the supercharger a few doors down. We wandered through and found everything we needed. I think we'll be back plenty due to the proximity to the Tesla supercharger.

The only real complaint with this store is it out of way and not laid out like the one closer to me.

However, this store seems to have a smaller yet better stocked "Markdown" refrigerator selection.  "Day Old" refrigerator specials are a excellent value.

This store has a better selection and more consistent of a selection than on 79.

$5 sushi roll Tuesday is only good when they offer a selection.
Staff is always friendly and helpful. The store is clean as a whistle. It's a Dierberg's and they have worked hard for their reputation. Not problems here.

I appreciate that there's a haunted attraction in my current hometown, but I'm a bit disappointed in it. The hayride usually has a huge line (last year we waited well over an hour), and the hayride itself is quite lackluster. While it is unique in that your legs dangle off the sides of the truck bed, the ride itself isn't scary, and isn't unique in its shows. (The clown one, for instance, was interesting but could have been a lot better, and a lot scarier!)

In my opinion, not worth the money. If you're in the area maybe check it out, but don't expect to be blown away.

love that this is only 10 minutes from my house.  We try to go on a Sunday right before / after sunset, to avoid the long lines. They do offer a fast pass for an additional cost  ($15 I believe) but it's not really worth it, unless you are going right before Halloween. They also offer discount coupons locally or online.  Parking is usually $5.00. 

They offer a few attractions with your combo ticket, which is worth it. The hayride could be a little longer, but the scenes and actors are amazing. They have a few haunted houses/ walk thru's even a "Forrest" it's always a great time. 

I love that they offer snacks and drinks for sale, so you can sit and enjoy the live music and huge bonfire. They even offer a photo with a zombie and Valley of Fear as a backdrop. I usually think it's too much for one photo but we had a decent size group and I'm happy we got it!

No matter how old I am I will always visit numerous haunted houses every year. This one is definitely up there in terms of my haunted house ranking! And, better yet, it all goes to a great cause. 
My one gripe is how expensive it is. To do all four attractions is almost $50 a person. Probably too expensive for most people with kids. 
However the attractions are all really good. I love a good hayride and this one was probably the best. They also have an attraction that involves paintball which is pretty cool. But don't get too excited and use all your paintballs at once like I did! They only give you a handful. 
The scarytales attraction was my second favorite...basically a walk through in the forest, which was a welcome change from the other claustrophobia inducing attractions here and elsewhere. 
Pro tips: be prepared for what basically amounts to a hike if you do all the attractions, and bring money for the s'mores and cider!

I'm not sure why this place gets so many bad reviews. Parking stinks! It's always muddy and wet so wear old shoes. I can almost guarantee you'll be parking on grass. The lines just to get in can be long so it's best to go on a Thursday or Sunday. They do have fire pits and usually have live music. They also have a concession area for cider and little snacks. 

The prices can be a bit high but it's a seasonal attraction so for me it's to be expected. I'm not a huge fan of the fast pass. For an added $15 you get bumped to the front of the line, if you don't get it, expect to have a longer wait. The attractions themselves are all ok. I wouldn't go there with huge expeditions. It's just a good time. The hayride is always overcrowded and really not worth the wait. Like i said it's a good night out though. We go once a year and will go back next season.

Valley OF Fear & The Original Haunted Hayride is Here!!! Promising to frighten anyone who can not separate fantasy from reality! ( that's how I get through it anyway, I'm a big girl now and no whoosie! ) Plan on any little ones to crawl between your sheets for nights! 

This is the original Buck's County Haunted Hayride and " America's Most Horrifying Woods.." Price of admission is divided into 3 different packages. For $44.00 you can do all 3. Children are less and depends upon age. 

1. Riding on a Hay padded wagon and through deep woods, they startle you by jumping out in their horrific garbs. See spooks and gargoyles, monsters and things that go bump in the night! 

2. Miles Manor is too cool to miss! It's a very old run down, spooky and Haunted House.. BOO! ;+} Sorry, I couldn't help myself! LMAO 

3. Valley of Fear is the walk through the Dark Deep Woods.. Am I scaring you? Just hope there is a Full Moon to guide you along the way! You'll hug everyone in sight ;+} 

The Valley OF Fear & The Original Haunted Hayride proceeds all go to the Phoenix Sport Club. If you don't want to tag along, you can enjoy a Brew and the Games on 12 Ft. screens in Pumpkinhead's Picnic Grove. Call or go on line to reserve your tickets. 

Parking for the Haunted happenings is $5.00 and proceeds go to their Youth Programs. The Phoenix Sport Club is nice. Wedding receptions are held there. They have an Olympic sized outdoor pool. Coupons are available for 3 for 2, by going on line and for certain times. 

Expensive and scary! How much will you pay to SCREAM!!! I love goosebumps!

Fun hayride, woods walk and zombie maze... definitely more fun than scary or creepy.  Seems great for kids or those who scare easily.  Then again, I've never met a haunted house or hayride that actually scares me.  I thought the hayride was a little short and lacking overall, but the zombie maze and Scary Tales walk were worth it.  They had some cool characters and costumes, and it's fun interacting with the people who come out at you.  (I couldn't stop laughing after I accidentally chest bumped Hansel and complimented his lederhosen by saying "nice pants'".)

Saturday night the lines were fairly long - I'd suggest getting there early and doing the hayride first since it has the longest wait.  And paying with credit card will save you a few minutes in the ticket line.  We did the hayride first a little after 8pm and had to wait about 30-40 min, then waited ~20 min for zombie maze, then no wait for Scary Tales.  Not too bad.

Definitely recommended for families or scaredy-cats!

I've come here every year for a bunch of years for the hayride.  My girls and a bunch of us form the studio.  Thank goodness the kids have graduated to at least doing the walkthrough the last two years.  The hayride is cute, fun, they switch it up but not too much and I'm kind of over the hay in my boots.  I will say this year despite the it taking forever to get on, it was a lot of fun.  I feel like we have had the same Hayride Car #6 for the last three years a heavyset lady runs it, and she runs a tight ship no cell phones, camera, flash and no touching! Let me back up a bit, why you might ask did it take so long? Well one might think because it's close to Halloween and it was crowded.. but that's not actually the case, we kind of beat the crowd. but two things changed this years. 1. They have the hayride more interactive so they load less people onto each car.  and 2. They started with "fast passes" for an extra $15 you can piss everyone else off and cut the line. At Disney I get it, at Six Flags I get it, but here??? No freaking way.. AND the other places have a system and /or a limit here nope, nothing just grab all of you friends and lets skip, it was ridiculous.  We encountered the same problem at the walkthrough we would be close and didn't matter in come heards of fast passers.  smh anyway once we finally go to walkthrough it was a lot of fun, it had twists and turns and spooks.. Good frightful fun! It's a good time.

I L-O-V-E Anthropologie and I am VERY excited there is going to be one at San Diego's Fashion Valley Mall.  I would give this place 5 stars if it wasn't so darned expensive.  

I love that you can pick up shoes, jewelry, a kickass dress, and kitchen towels while shopping here.  Right now I literally have 3 things in my online shopping cart totaling of $550.  I need to find a better job to support my habit.....or get a part time job here.

This a cool store ... and as I found out afterwards, but really it was apparent, it was a women's clothing store.   It really has much more than that ... cool dishes, unique candles and book and other misc stuff.  I can't really comment on the "women" part of this store but I was drawn in by the decor and the life size paper mache horse by the register.   I just happened to be in the Galleria to kill some time and thought why not, plus I picked a cookbook on natural food since I am trying to fit more of it into my eating.   Worth a walk through ... check was a bit slow but that could have just been the transactions in front of me.

When it's time to get some life-prolonging drugs, I've always gotten professional help in their pharmacy. Alex takes the time to get it done right if there are issues with insurance, prescriptions, or whatever. The pharmacists themselves have also been helpful answering any questions I might have.

My only issue is that it can be tricky to get in the parking lot unless you are coming from the correct directions (westbound on Tampa Road or northbound on Forest Lakes). Otherwise, you have to make a U-turn or sneak in the back way via Walmart.

Thanks CVS!

Fantastic Minute Clinic

I am a fan of all Minute Clinics. My husband doesn't understand why I don't have a primary care doctor, but I tried once and the three I called weren't taking new patients! I was experiencing flu like symptoms so my OBGYN told me to go get swabbed for the flu. Luckily while looking online to see the closest minute clinic I noticed I could also put myself in line remote. DO THIS. There was a forty-minute wait time, but when I got there I waited ten minutes! I'm assuming both myself and the man in front of my put ourselves on remote waiting whereas the woman sitting there did not. Both of us came around the same time so I saw our names on the board go from not arrived to present. He was taken immediately and I just had to wait for him to be done. The woman who was sitting there who was marked present the whole time had to wait for both of us. Don't be that woman, be like us instead and take advantage of remote wait.

The nurse practitioner did all the normal vital sign checking and after swabbing me determined that I did indeed have the flu. She asked if I had difficulty reaching my OBGYN earlier in the day since I'd have to call back to let them know the diagnosis and when I said yes, she actually picked up the phone to call them for me! (Turns out the office was closed for lunch, of course they were). She had my prescription filled right at the pharmacy so I wouldn't have to go anywhere else. She seemed pretty worried about my wellbeing because she kept asking if I was ok to drive. (I must have looked really bad). In the end she sent me to the ER because she was worried about my high temp and high heartbeat (I was 16 months pregnant at the time). She called ahead to the ER so they would expect me. 

I'm actually really glad she was so worried about me driving because it scared me enough to call my husband to pick me up. In the end she was right, I shouldn't have been driving. 

Terrible circumstances, but great service. I'll definitely keep coming back to this minute clinic. I just hope I don't have to again.

This review is about the Minute Clinic inside this CVS. 

2nd visit and wondering why I ever used to go to my PCP or urgent care for non-critical medical needs (flu, sinus infection, stye. etc.). I've seen the same nurse practitioner both visits and she is super friendly and very thorough (better than most MD's I've seen!) In and out very quickly and short waits both visits. Love that you can see the wait time for your appointment on a screen vs. sitting in a waiting room with no updates. Kiosk registration can be a bit cumbersome and not the most comfortable or private waiting area - the convenience, quality, and speedy service greatly outweigh these minor issues.

Drugs, alcohol, and stuffed animals. Could you possibly find a better combination? I'm referring to you, not me. 

Personally, I go here for Red Bull or the ATM machine. I know someone will say those two things are worse for you than drugs or alcohol, but perception is everything.

They have a Minute Clinic here, but I have never used it, so I don't know what it means. I would assume it means you only have one minute to explain your condition and after that you're charged $1/minute to explain your situation. If I'm right, I'm guessing they do this to keep the line moving.

Otherwise, a clean and convenient location with employees that try to secretly talk about their personal lives (and fail miserably). 

Overall, definitely recommended. I'm more of a Walgreens person, but this CVS has won me over.

I'd never been to a Buffalo Wild Wings before but my nephew convinced me for his Birthday. Glad I checked it out because now I'm fascinated at how successful this chain has been and how mediocre it is. 

Service is great and kids love it, but it's disappointing wings all around.

Uhh! This place is pretty good like most BWW and etc. I have to say that there customer service is a little below average!!! Well that's kind of alright for me, but I have to say that there food is good. I like it like other BWW I been to. 

One thing I love about BWW is there wing challenge! Me and my friends will do it together once a while for fun. Not to complain much but I will raise a star in this BWW if the service would pay more attention to my table!

I found a diner in Salem County, the "Talk of the Towne Diner."  When I stopped around lunchtime on a Saturday, it wasn't too crowded, and I was quickly seated.  

Atmosphere: 
The Talk of the Towne looks like many South Jersey Diners with a cobblestone exterior and multiple rooms. Inside there are plenty of booths, tables, and a full-length bar.

There was also a full salad bar as well as a "hot foods breakfast bar" which looked like it might be for a catering event or party.
Coffee: 
The Talk of the Towne Diner served the local Lacas coffee which is one of my favorite coffees.  The waitress brought plenty of refills, and I had no complaints.  It was one of the better coffees I have had in a while.

Food:
The Talke of the Town has everything a diner usually has.  There are plenty of breakfast options, as well as a full salad bar, lunch, and dinner options.  There aren't too many unique options at the Talk of the Towne Diner, but there also isn't anything it's missing either.

I opted for one of their skillets which came with eggs, potatoes, sausage, and vegetables.  When the skillet came out, it was sizzling and hot, it actually reminded me of something I would get a Mexican restaurant.

I also decided to get a cinnamon bun which was great.

The Talk of the Towne was definitely one of the most surprising diners, food wise.  It was much better than I anticipated and I was very pleased.

Service: 
The waitress was extremely friendly, and the food came out within 15 minutes.  To be honest, I could not have asked for a more pleasant experience.

Overall thoughts/would I come back:
I liked the Talk of the Towne Diner and would go back again.  It's a great stop if you are near the Delaware Memorial Bridge and need a quick bite to eat or break from the roads.

I love this place. Best sushi in Tampa. The staff is always friendly and dies a great job. I've never had a bad experience here. You can sit at the bar and watch them create your meal or a table. They have free WiFi so you can make it a working meal. 
They do deliver which is another bonus.  I've had them deliver several times and the online system is a little clunky and one time we had a rude experience when the driver couldn't figure out how our condo gate worked.

I wish I could rate this place higher:

- watermelon drink: only $1.35, freshly blended with a bit of ice. Perfect!

- edamame salad: fresh ingredients, but next to no seasoning which made it taste blend. Server lady asked how it was and was very receptive to the feedback, but the other person said to be the manager was not. Disappointing.

- purple cloud: interesting combo of salmon and chicken tempura. Loved red and green onions. Perfect!

- fire tornado: the topping was way too saucy and the whole thing ended up swimming in the sauce. It was out of balance and too rich. Again, server lady was appreciative of feedback but the manager was not, which is a shame. 

They are a new local business and we appreciated the clean, modern decor, but I'm not sure if I'd readily want to go back. I hope they improve and do well.

3.5 stars, rounding up.  

This was our second attempt at Kelp.  First attempt was slightly after 9PM on a Friday or Saturday to find they closed at 9.  Seriously, a restaurant that closes at 9 on a weekend is weak.  I know this is Florida, but not everyone is into the early bird special.  And this play is trying to be hip, kind of new-wave sushi, yet they close basically at sunset?  Weird.

Second time around was better.  First thing you notice about Kelp is how small it is.  I think there are 6-10 tables, and the place gets busy.  There were one or two tables when we arrived, but it filled up.  They also did a tremendous amount of to-go orders.  Point being, if you want a table, it might be a crap shoot.  

We ordered 3 rolls and my girlfriend got crab rangoons.  Can't tell you about the rangoons, but the rolls were very good.  Like I said, a lot of them are far from your tradition sushi rolls - even in the specialty roll concept, they were a bit far out.  For example, we got the Desert Oasis roll, which has mango and a thai chili sauce.  Sounds strange, right?  I thought I wouldn't like it, but it was actually my favorite.  We also got a Underwater Lake roll, which has boiled shrimp, cucumber, avocado and krab salad - also very good, but again, not very traditional.  Finally, we got a Salt Cove roll, which was spicy shrimp, smoked salmon with jalapeno.  This one I didn't care for, and I've had sushi with jalapeno before and really liked it, but in my opinion, the flavors didn't really go well together here.

So really, I'm deducting a bit for that last roll, but the others were very good.  And to Kelp's credit, they go light on the rice, heavy on the fish.  Drawbacks to Kelp, besides the size, are the options and prices.  They don't have a very extensive menu - 23 rolls (I think) and some appetizers.  Seems like a lot, but that's maybe 1/2 a sushi menu at other places.  Additionally, they are mostly specialty rolls.  They do not have too many of your regular run-of-the-mill rolls.  Finally, price wise, most of the rolls are over $10.  So if you're looking for your regular $6-$8 sushi rolls, this isn't for you.  But if you want to try something different, and really enjoy it, I think you should give Kelp a try

Five stars for their Sushi Burritos which have changed my life forever. In the past 48 hours I have gone to Kelp TWICE because I have their sushi burrito on my mind! I have been wanting to try a sushi burrito for months, but couldn't find a Tampa spot with it on their menu until I stumbled in to Kelp for some sushi on Saturday and BAM there it was on their newly updated menu. 

In the past, I would have given Kelp three stars for their sushi because it's just okay or maybe even good, but it's not great. The same thing goes for the miso soup, ginger salad, seaweed salad and fried ice cream. Those items are just average. 

I'm not sure what changes for the sushi burrito, but I've now become obsessed! You pick two fish options, four veggies or tempura flakes and two sauces. It's all wrapped up into a nice sized roll of heaven and then cut in half. It's still served with wasabi, ginger and soy sauce. I ordered spicy tuna, tempura shrimp, avocado, tempura flakes, jalapenos, cucumber, & spicy mayo. This combination is fresh and delicious. The sushi burrito is priced at $11.95, which I think is a fair price for the portion. I ordered the burrito for lunch and could barely finish it.

I will be back for many, many more sushi burritos!

Kelp sushi joint is located off bay to bay in South Tampa in a plaza next to Starbucks. Kelp Sushi Joint is located in a tiny restaurant. Unlike most other sushi bars where the bar seating faces the raw seafood display case, you get a side angle view of the sushi chefs preparing sushi as well as the chefs preparing other dishes in the back. 

Kelp sushi joint has some great $3 appetizers deals including the crab rangoon, edamame, ginger salad gyoza, miso soup, and seaweed salad.  In addition, Kelp sushi joint also has a great all day $12.95 special for any 2 classic sushi rolls and 1 starter! 

For the appetizer we ended up getting the crab rangoon and it was quite flavorful and not too dry as many tend to be 10/10. For the main course, we ended up getting the  Rose Cave Deluxe Sushi Roll which consists of  Tuna, shrimp tempura, avocado, scallions, eel sauce, spicy mayo 9/10, the Florida Sushi Roll which consists of Tuna, salmon, avocado, cream cheese, and the Mexican which consists of Shrimp tempura, avocado 9/10. 

Kelp also offers Sushi burritos and bowls, which come made to order with your choice of 2 proteins, 4 vegetables, and 2 sauces including spicy mayo, jalapeno mayo, cilantro citrus aioli, teriyaki sauce, and eel sauce. Bowl options include salmon teriyaki, beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, tofu teriyaki, chicken donburi, beef donburi, salmon Poke, himachi Poke, Tuna Poke, sashimi, and nigiri. Kelp does not have a liquor license and only serves beer and sake, no mixed drinks. 

I look forward to coming back to try more appetizers, a poke bowl, more sushi rolls, or a burrito roll!

NOTE: THIS IS REALLY A 4.5 STAR REVIEW!!!!!

The reason I am docking half a star for Kelp Sushi Joint is because they haven't mastered the sticky rice thing yet and the rolls fall apart when you pick them up. Or at least that is what happened to us when we stopped in the other day.

Otherwise, this is definitely the freshest most imaginative sushi I've had so far in Tampa Bay. This is the kind of sushi place you'd find in Chicago or Miami or Philly. Awesome variety of rolls, wonderful ambiance/decor, excellent service. I expect this place to get very popular very fast. 

NOTE: THIS PLACE SEEEMS TO FOCUS MORE ON COOKED ROLLS.

The only negatives I see that could affect its success is the location, which you can't really see unless you look very hard. It's not right on Bay to Bay, it's deep in the crevices of a little strip mall on Bay to Bay. Also, the place is very small and has only 4 or 5 tables inside. Lots of outdoor seating, if you are into that. Me, I prefer A/C and no bugs. That could present a challenge as I can easily imagine that once this place gets more popular, inside tables will be scarce. They should have made the kitchen smaller and the dining space larger.

Yummy rolls you will be craving all the time.

Very prominent sushi place for the purpose of small night snack. Unfortunately during pandemic, they still don't allow dine in. I would definitely like to do that. I like this sushi place because the restaurant is good for late night snack with sake or beer. 

The food is affordable and the takeout is busy. The walk in order take about 15 minutes to prepare. We wait at the car and they deliver to your car. I got the goyoza, spicy tuna, and unagi eel. The roll at medium size. The spicy tuna with good ahi. The flavors good. The goyoza also crispy. Great snack for the night. The unagi has enough eel sauce to sweet it up. 

Overall my experience for the take is great. I will like to visit them at night when they start the dine in again.

I felt like doing some food exploring today so I "dragged" a friend with me to Kelp for lunch. We had never been there before but had heard good things. And if you read my reviews you know that I love to try new places. 

We had no problems finding it. It is in a plaza on Bay to Bay. It is the same plaza that Feet First (running store), Pilot Bank, Massage Studio, Starbucks, Soleil Tanning, and Taco Fusion are all in. 

When we arrived we were able to park right up front. They have some spots reserved just for Kelp customers. We were also pretty happy to see the outdoor seating because it was a gorgeous day out. A couple actually had their puppy with them at their table outside :) Note that there is also indoor seating. It's a small place and I'm not sure how busy they get but between the indoor and outdoor seating, you should be good.

Their lunch options are great. For $12 you get 2 full rolls, a miso soup and a ginger salad. I went with that option. My friend got 2 rolls (see my pictures) and she really enjoyed them both. And their lunch, all the way until 4pm!

Service was very nice. Everyone was very friendly. They were attentive and the service was nice and fast.

Basically, I'll be back for more :)

We got takeout from here and placed an online order. It was easy to make the order, but no where to specify instructions or allergens. We had a little trouble finding the restaurant. its kind of nestled in the back of a small plaza. its a cute space with an outdoor area. We were able to pop in and pick up the food pretty much contactless. As for the food the beef Dan burri was great and would recommend it. The seaweed salad and ginger salad were a hard pass for me. The seaweed salad had a strange taste and the dressing for the ginger salad was kind of odd. It did not have a strong flavor, it didn't coat the lettuce at all. We ordered 2 sashimi platters, online it says 5 items come in it, however there was way more than 5 types of fish/seafood in ours. Some of the items were unidentifiable and the Krab (imitation crab) usually contains gluten so it would have been nice to be able to add a note to omit that item. Anyway, both my husband and I got sick after eating that food and we weren't sure if it was the sashimi platter or the seaweed salad. asomething just was "fishy" and we had what I would describe as food poisoning. We probably won't return because of this and the fact that there are so many sushi joints in Tampa, ones with really fresh fish. I am really only giving them 3 stars because the beef Dan burri with the fried egg was great.

I've been once and was pretty disappointed with the sushi... It just wasn't that great, especially for the price.  The flavors were a little off... I'm not sure exactly how to describe it.  The place was completely empty. I only went because I had a coupon and prob won't be back.

After being stuck in traffic for five hours, the last thing I wanted to do was drive to get dinner. Consequently I succumbed and did something out of character. I got on UberEats and started to search for places that could deliver to the hotel I was staying at.

Because of the fact that I was more exhausted than hungry, but I knew I had to eat, I ended up ordering what I consider light - SUSHI! To be specific, I ordered a Mexican roll and a ginger salad. You know, pretty standard fare for this type of place.

My food arrived pretty quickly. No complaints on that. Presentation was fine. I just wish they hadn't been so stingy with sauces and napkins. At any rate, had the ginger salad and found the sauce strong. Same issue with the wasabi. There's an expression that says "se le paso la mano," which figuratively means they went overboard (literally means "they passed the hand") and that's exactly how I felt about the flavor of the sauces there.

I'm not sure if maybe I ordered the wrong thing or what, but know I ate it, got ready for bed, and slept like a baby. Then, I completely forgot about this meal until now. It simply was unmemorable.

This place is located in a busy shopping plaza with a Starbucks but the parking lot is pretty large. The restaurant itself is not too large so come early. They some happy hour food and drink specials. Overall the sushi here is average to slightly above average for its price. I think people come here for the convenience more than anything. Would not go out my way to come back here.
Update - kelp has updated their menu a lot over the past year. I gave It another try and it is delicious! Love their sushi burrito, volcano roll and ramen options!

I finally got around to checking out this place again and boy am I glad I did! I was starving and exhausted after work and stopped in to have some sushi on my way home from work. I like how they open before five. I sat at the bar and was quickly and warmly greeted. I ordered a specialty sushi roll in the server informed me that a second one would only be three dollars. Both the rolls I had were absolutely delicious and I finished my entire plate. I'll be back.

Sushi was Not worth the price!! Few problems with this place during this visit:

1) overpriced everything
2) our rolls came out and looked like trash. I could have rolled the sushi better ..scratch that a 5 year old would have done better or cared more about what the sushi looked like
3) my spicy tuna cucumber roll had pieces of bacon in it, which was not listed on the menu ingredients. Horrible flavors together.. I love bacon but not with my spicy tuna and I can't imagine someone who can't eat meat would react.
4) my earth roll... Looks good on the menu and was the only roll that looked any thing like a specialty roll - tasted like trash. I love my rolls with volcano toppings and usually eat all the toppings... This time I left them on the plate. And not to mention $16 for that crap.

Not coming back.. If you want good sushi do yourself and wallet a favor and go to Soho or Zen sushi

I ordered takeout from their website and I'm so glad I did! I live about a mile from KELP and haven't tried it yet, but I'll definitely go back. Their website was easy to use and my food was ready when I got there, which is exactly when they said it would be ready. I took advantage of the 2 roll deal, which I strongly recommend if you plan on getting multiple fresh rolls and a starter. For $12.95 I chose the ginger salad, salmon avocado roll, and spicy tuna roll. I opted for brown rice on both rolls. The fish tasted fresh and all the veggies were perfect. I was feeling particularly fat today so I also ordered the veggie roll and chicken teriyaki bowl. Veggie roll was so good and the veggies were delightfully crispy. The teriyaki bowl was also very good and I loved all the veggies included in it. I ate so much and still have so much leftover!

Not bad sushi, especially since you can use ubereats for fast delivery in South Tampa. My order arrived in 20 minutes!

I tried the sushi burrito with salmon and hamachi. I didn't love the hamachi, should have stuck to salmon alone. The whole thing was difficult to eat without making a mess. I think I'd stick to a sushi bowl or poke bowl in the future. I also had a Mexican roll. It was well rolled and tasty.

Kelp Sushi Joint is a nice choice for casual sushi if you are in Palma Ceia. They have a small sushi counter as well as 2 or 4-top tables to choose from. They also have outside seating which is rather unique for a sushi restaurant. 

They have a great lunch special. $12 will get you 2 "classic rolls", miso soup and a ginger salad. There are about a dozen classic rolls to choose from. I went with spicy salmon and a Florida roll (tuna, salmon and avocado). The rolls were very tasty. The rice was cooked nicely, not too mushy which can really ruin your roll. I loved the spice in the salmon roll as I find many "spicy" rolls are actually lacking. This roll had a very pleasant kick! The miso was average but the ginger salad was above average. The dressing was very fresh. I actually took home leftovers from my lunch special! This is a great deal!

I also had the $4 sangria which was very good. It had fresh fruit and wasn't too sweet. 

The service was fast and friendly. My husband and I will definitely be back to satisfy our sushi cravings especially during the lunch hours.

I finally tried KELP sushi. This place has been on my hit list for quite a while now. I didn't feel like dining in, so I took advantage of their delivery service. It took about 49 minutes to arrive (I ordered 2 rolls on a Sunday evening). The delivery man was very nice, I believe his name was Patrick.  He thanked me for my service as well as for choosing Kelp sushi. I think highly of companies that acknowledge their costumers. *insert clap emoji here*. There was one slight mistake but after calling back to let them know the lemonade was not included, the manager told me they'd send me my drink and apologized. I'm obsessed with sushi and could easily eat it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. There were ten pieces in each roll, each a decent size. I will say the spicy tuna roll had a unique, smoky flavor to it. If you like smoky flavor, try it. It wasn't my favorite spicy tuna roll, to be honest. But overall, my taste buds were satisfied. I look forward to trying other rolls in the future.  Enjoy! Xo

Kelp Sushi Joint was ok, but there are better sushi options in Tampa.

We were lured here because the restaurant offers BYOB (bring your own bottle) and they do not charge a corkage fee. Wine glasses and cork screws are provided by Kelp.

While I enjoyed the modern décor and appreciated the purse hooks underneath the tables for the ladies I just wasn't a fan of the menu. Most of the rolls were pretty simple (California, Spicy Tuna, Mexican). If I was a timid eater trying out sushi for the first time these rolls may have appealed to me, but in my opinion the rolls were boring. The rolls that were more intricate contained cooked fish, imitation "krab" or fried chicken. None of these ingredients appeal to me.

The sashimi and nigiri options are almost non-existent which raises a huge red flag. My husband could not believe there were no sashimi platters on the menu. When he asked the waitress if the chef could prepare one for us they agreed, but the platter he created only contained tuna, salmon, and rainbow trout. Not much of a variety!

While everything tasted fine, nothing "wowed" us. We will probably not return, but this is a good spot for people that like very simple or cooked sushi rolls.

So I feel slightly awkward saying that KELP has it going on - but it's true!

We opted for a Monday night sushi dinner because the usual COVID rotation needed a change up. My preferred food delivery service was clutch and made our selections a reality in about an hour. 

We noshed two specialty rolls and a smattering of 'classic' rolls. Everything was well portioned, well crafted and very high quality. The rice was perfectly cooked and each bite was downright umami!

Tempura shrimp? Crispy (not soggy). Tuna? Great texture. Avocado? Ripe and flavorful. The colors and textures were all very complimentary and we know we got a great value for the money.

KELP calls itself a sushi joint but that does not do it justice.

This small, tasteful dining spot has class and sass. The decor is subdued yet has a touch of swank and swagger to it.

Seating is limited but the outside area is really inviting when the weather cooperates.

But what really matters is that how the sushi rolls. Glad to say that the philosophy of make it fresh, find it locally, when possible, and let what's in season be part of the seasoning and flavor is part of what makes the already enjoyable sushi even more enjoyable.

There's even a premise and a promise of using sustainable seafood which is a stand to be celebrated. As Platinum members of the Florida Aquarium's Seafood Now program, KELP helps support responsibly harvested fish.

This sushi stand-out is a bit hard to find within a busy retail center that constantly has cars circling and searching for a place to park.

But find it, try it and you are sure to truly enjoy it.

To-Go order: quick and on time.

Crab Rangoon - $3 - solid price with a pretty solid backup. It's not all breading and the blend mix in doesn't taste like all cream cheese. So 4 crab Rangoon's for $3 that are pretty decent (especially in the little orange sauce they are always served with) - I'd call it a win.
I am trying to find the sushi roll that I ordered but I cannot for the life of me find the name. It was good and hit the spot for my sushi craving.
I'd give them another try.

On a whim, I decided to stop by for a quick lunch bite and felt like being by the water. I came in on the Fish Market side to check out the fish for sale and eyeballed the fresh Cobia immediately. If you've never tasted it, buy some, put it on the grill and sample a lil' true heaven from the sea! SO, I just grabbed a bowl of their corn/shrimp chowder and a beer for a sampling of things to come in the future. Love the creamy consistency and just enough spice to wake up the taste buds without overkill. It was more than satisfying and I will have to return to sample more of the menu in the future. To be continued...

Olde bay Cafe I'm sorry to say though service seemed okay, the food was lacking in so many ways. My Asian Noodle Tuna Salad was $12 and it wasn't worth $12. I know Ahi Tuna is expensive fish and probably cost $12 but the presentation was sad and I think I felt a little sick after eating it. They charged $5 for a jumbo hotdog which wasn't anything special beyond being a jumbo hotdog.  My husband had a cuban pull pork sandwich which was dry and not at all good. I was disappointed all around with this place and I won't be returning to this place although I think they won't miss me,  anyways they do get a lot of customers anyways.

Not a big place- but the food was delicious! So fresh! And the service was outstanding- the mosquitos seemed to be out in full force the night we went, and our waitress brought us some bug spray. 

The next morning we stopped by the fish market to take some seafood home, but we thought the takeout seemed a little expensive.

Yes, it is a fish market. Surprise Surprise. They just opened a waterfront outdoor bar/restaurant called Olde Bay Cafe. You can have a drink and a sandwich, then walk through the door to buy some fresh caught fish to go. 

I don't recall any place like this in downtown Dunedine though. It is a bit Funky! It is more like a fisherman's joint. A character! Actually, I think it is a great idea to have a place like this to rest your feet especially for gents who are tired of waiting their ladies shopping at local antique stores. They will have fun sitting on the deck and chat with fishermen. 

There aren't a lot of customers though since it just opened in late March. The bar serves typical Florida snacks, fish sandwiches and wraps. I tried their fish spread. Fresh ingredients make the difference! 

Price is bit high though, but a place in downtown Dunedin where you can sit on the waterfront deck, watch fish jumping, and if you are lucky, you may spot a dolphin swim by, not mention the friendly host as funky as the bar itself who will carry a great conversation with you about where the great spots to fish. 

Add all these factors in, the higher price is justified. So guys, give it a try and don't worry about our ladies. We go shopping till we drop.

Four stars based on the awesome location. The food was sort of bland but I only ordered scallops and honestly was only there for the great view anyway!

Dunedin Fish Market and the Olde Bay Cafe is located near the Dunedin Marina where a lot of people dock their boats. It's got a perfect view of the water and an AMAZING view of the sunset. It really can't be beat in this respect. 

You can grab a seat on the bar area which overlooks the water if you want to enjoy the day and partake in a great view of Tampa Bay. The place is pretty busy, presumably based on its location, but the menu has quite a few offerings in terms of fresh seafood and bar bites.

I ordered scallops and a side of vegetables. I received four scallops for $12, which is SUPER pricy in my opinion. The scallops were just okay. I think they had the shells still on them? They were sort of crunchy and weird. The vegetables were pretty good, but nothing special. They were just steamed. 

I saw several people with peel-n-eat shrimp that looked fabulous and wish I would have gotten that, but alas! I did not. The crab cakes looked awesome too. So...honestly, I'd give this place 2.5 stars for the food itself. It was pretty mediocre.

The service was friendly and pretty quick though, which was nice since I was by myself. 

I'd come back to see the sunset and to try out other menu items if I was in the area, but probably wouldn't actively seek to go to this place to eat again.

I like seafood fresh off the boat no matter what the price, so was excited to bike over to this place on a weekday to check it out. The sunny water view was amazing and the beer was cold. It was very busy for a weekday so I slathered on some sunscreen and we waited for a table Then I ordered my first stone crab of the season. Delicious! Served either hot with drawn butter, or cold with a mustard sauce, I went with the drawn butter. I was soo stuffed but managed to finish the smaller serving. Great view, nice location off the path, fresh seafood and a killer beer selection, how could I not come back here?

Really great little place with amazing views!! they are right on a dock and you see the water, the boats and the sunset! It is a small place but worth the wait. we tried the catch of the day tacos, which were simple but really fresh. And the fresh corvina with asian noodles and avocado. My corvina seemed a bit undercooked and I got a fresh new plate to replace it. Great service! they also have a nice beer selection of local craft brews for $5!!

Wow. Just had some awesome blue crabs at Dunedin fish cafe and let me tell you this place rocks. It's quite affordable with great food to boot. It's right on the water with a picture perfect view. I was waited on by Carly who was phenomenal also. Always checking on me making making my experience a memorable one. 5 stars all the way
This a great place for fresh seafood and great water views. You can get things to go or eat in. All the food is fresh and tasty. The views of the marina are very nice and relaxing.

As always I like my girl to go with me so we can get 2-3 items incase the place is having a bad day for one particular item. However this place went 0-3 on all three dishes. 
The positives. The location and the view. Not the best view from a Dunedin eatery but very good nonetheless. They have several tables to sit at and quite a few seats on the inside railing with counters. The two waitresses were excellent today. Never had to wait for a thing. They were on point. If one of us was out of water and the other waitress saw that she would immediately bring a new cup. They are perhaps the best waitress team of all time also the reason to add a star. Other positives are the extensive beer offerings and the prices of 4-5 for each one. 
The food I most likely would not go back for:
A special of Parmesan crab and shrimp dip was available. It was like warm. It did not taste very appealing and there were textures of coagulation like it was microwaved and cooked in certain areas. There was a decent amount of crab but only one piece of shrimp that we found. 
The cod tacos were also not very good. The fish tasted fresh and cooked properly. However the slaw was undressed raw cabbage and at the bottom of the taco was a large amount of straight lime juice. And not the sweet kind. Some type of cream would have brought this from a 2-4. 
Finally the 14 dollar blackened scallop wrap. Not edible in any way. There was no texture or carmelization on the scallops. The blackening was just a spicy mixture that mixed with some liquid and just poured out of the wrap. We took most of this home and hopefully I can try and save the scallops and get some of the 14 bucks worth. There is nothing worse than blackening season that was not cooked and BLACKENED. Blackened means to blacken the seasonings to char them if you will. It does not mean to just have a spicy seasoning on it. That is called seasoned. 
I would probably go back to enjoy the view a beer and the great service but the food is off limits for us.

In a small city with so many good places to eat you need to really stand out from the rest and Olde Bay does.  We had a beautiful day and sat out on the porch.  We ordered the Grouper platter with potato salad and slaw.  The grouper was fixed just right and was delicious.  Can't wait to go back.

On a sun-shiney Florida day, there is no place better to have happy hour than on the water! Olde Bay Cafe was the perfect spot to have a beer and some appetizers with my parents on my first day in FL!

The restaurant is literally in the Dunedin harbor.  The main area for seating is out on the deck, which is great on a beautiful day!  We had an awesome view of the boats on the harbor for the sunset.

We chose local beers- I loved the one my mom picked, a beach blonde ale by three sisters.  Dad got a Belgian brew and I chose a darker seasonal ale, with some great spices! I loved their local beer selection and specials, it paired well with the seafood appetizers we ordered!

The menu looked great and they had mostly fresh catch options.  We chose the fish spread (the waiter said it was local smoked mullet) and the ceviche (which was made with local scallops).

Both came in a small basket with packaged ritz crackers.  The smoked mullet dip was AMAZING.  It was fresh and flavorful and not too "fishy"! The ceviche was also an excellent choice.  The scallops were small but fresh and delicious and mixed with some vegetables like celery and tomatoes. I would recommend both as appetizers!

Even though the plastic almost flew into the harbor several times, the ritz crackers were actually a good pairing.  The buttery flaky taste actually complimented the dips perfectly!

Perfect happy hour spot in Dunedin!

I love this newly renovated coffee shop! The seating is more comfortable with booth seating and free wifi.  There's no longer a bagel place in the same location but with the variety of snacks here, you can find something to munch on along with your drink.

Even though we sat near the counter where there was a steady stream of customers, I didn't find it was too noisy.  It seems to be a popular place for Mac users to come for a few hours and do their 'work'.  There is parking in the front but also out back where they keep the door open.  

The staff are efficient and sometimes a little slow with getting the drinks made no major concerns.  It will become one of my regular coffee shops to meet friends and colleagues.

Great value for tasty food!  Sesame chicken, fried rice, two crab rangoons, and a soda for less than $7.  I didn't think it seemed dirty, but it wasn't spotless either.  Not a place to go if ambiance is at all important.  There was quite the hustle and bustle behind the counter the entire time we were eating lunch there.  My food was pretty good, but the boss' was way over-sauced such that he ended up with a pool of goo at the bottom after having eaten his fill.  

Not an all-the-time kind of place, but it will definitely get added to the lunch rotation.

I've decided it's time to bump them up a notch.  Why?  A few reasons...

1. They are always hellaciously busy and that means the food is always fresh.  Always!
2. Their food is consistently better than any other similar place I've tried in the STL area.
3. I really respect the amount of business they do.  Yes, that's also my #1 reason but the fact is that if you go in for lunch and spend maybe 30-minutes in the place you'll probably see them push out 50+ meals in that time with an unknown number going out for delivery as well.  That's just pretty damn impressive for a little Chinese place.

They are what they are...but I respect that a little more after trying other similar places.  They really are at the top of their segment.

I don't understand why I didn't use you earlier. You are lessening our carbon footprint, cheaper than the other food delivery services, and my Sushi came cold with a modified way of tracking my order. They will notify you when your order is received by the restaurant, when it is ready, when your pedaler is there for pick up, and when it is in route. I wish it was more accurate like Uber, but it gets the job done. 

Honestly, if you live in the Loop, CWE, Midtown, Downtown, and even Clayton. Use Food Pedalers to delivery your food on bikes. I honestly don't know how they would do it with very very large orders, but they have group catering online. 

The only thing I would note is they have some great restaurants in their porfolio, but not everything yet. 

Loop:
United Provisions, Pi, Three Kings, Rannoush and some others that don't deliver

Clayton is on break for the summer. This seems weird to me, but I'm sure it's because they are working on increasing their market share.

Things to be wary of: The app sometimes is a little off. I tried to pre-order even in a close window and it often boots me out. In addition, the menu online is not the same menu for the same restaurants often. It's more limited.

Anyways - glad to have this local service around for around $3.99 a delivery and you can tip your pedaler if you want online.
The selection is so sparse, I'd swear this place has an echo. The deals are still good, though.
